column2:
Collision of Worlds
Declaration of War
Part 2
By Michael DeBuse

Chapter 1 
“The Arkhon’s Gift” 
Sammy
Sammy’s head throbbed with a painful and nauseating pulse.
She had little experience with hangovers.
Once in the past, a former boyfriend shared with her his home-brewed mead.
He brewed it using baker’s yeast instead of brewer’s yeast which, according to him, made gauging the alcohol content difficult, and from time to time the resulting brew was rather potent.

This particular batch was much stronger than normal, and despite knowing this and that Sammy had never tried alcohol before--she was only 18 at the time--he let her drink multiple glasses without revealing this important little detail.
She had no memory of what transpired afterwards, but the next morning she awoke naked on his couch with an aching hip and feeling like he had beaten her head in with a baseball bat.

The pain wracking her head now was not a hangover, or at least she was sure it wasn’t because she had no memory of drinking, but the ache was not dissimilar and made all the more miserable by reminding her of that horrendous mistake of a boyfriend.
Like that terrible evening over two years ago, Sammy couldn’t remember well why she had her current headache.
Her most recent memories were of crying in some trench in the forest.
The Sprite Arkhon appeared, she argued with him, and then she blacked out, but she had difficulty remembering why they argued.
She tried piecing together the fragmented scenes in her mind.
He wanted to reward her for completing her challenge to find help for Justin.
She refused because Justin was taken away by the Tolmyur soldiers.
She couldn’t save him.
That much she remembered clearly, and it made her heart ache.
But the Arkhon still saw fit to reward her.
Why?
In her memories clouded by the incessant pain, she recalled that it was because she did something the Arkhon did not expect.
No, it wasn’t something she did.
It was something that would happen because of something she did.
Sammy opened her weary eyes and sat up abruptly.
“Kree!” Coby startled and flapped his wings lightly.
Sammy quickly grabbed his beak to prevent him from making that earsplitting noise again.
“I’m fine,” Sammy said, releasing Coby’s beak and lightly scratching the feathers on the side of his head.
“Just… don’t do that again.
My head hurts.” She now felt even sorrier for Justin who had to endure such pain every few months for the majority of his life.

She often brushed his headaches off lightly because Justin always tried to act like they were mild, but if they were as severe as hers was now, or even worse, she realized how ignorantly callous she had been to him regarding his condition for the entire year they were dating.
Then again, she had her own monthly pains to deal with that Justin could never experience, but if she had to choose between regular cramps or headaches, she’d pass on the headaches.
She was used to her periods, and fortunately, they were never all that severe.
“Where’s Ceil,” Sammy mumbled.
Coby gave a silent trill and clapped his beak lightly to not aggravate Sammy’s headache.
“She’s not here?” Sammy moaned as if those words were not hers.
She looked around at the unfamiliar hut.
Faint specks of light shimmered through the walls and thatch ceiling.
The walls of the hut grew like saplings from the ground with their branches weaving them together.
The weave was tight but not perfect, so Sammy could see the shadows of people walking about outside.
This was the same type of hut she had seen in the central Melian village, so her most reasonable guess was that she hadn’t left.
At least Chloe and Ceil didn’t carry me off again when I was out, Sammy thought, remembering the acute pain in her shoulders after hanging by her arms for hours in a world with such strong gravity.
The thundering of Sammy’s head continued.
If what she felt now was anything similar to a hangover, perhaps eating something would help.
The thought of food made her empty stomach cramp.
She had not felt this hungry since the day before Ceil found her atop the plateaus of Fiorrae.
Coby heard the growl of her stomach and hopped over to a bark platter beside her bed.
On it sat a variety of dried meat and herbs with what looked like small white berries that had a teardrop shape.
She was surprised that Coby had not eaten all the meat while she slept.
Then again, she did not doubt that he had helped himself to some of it.
After all, she had no way of knowing how much had originally been provided on the platter.
Sammy tossed one of the white berries into her mouth and immediately spat it out after biting into it.
It was sweet beyond sweet and increased the aching of her head particularly around her temples.
Her body shivered from the sheer amount of sugar in the fruit, almost as if the very essence of sweetness had been refined to its purest form.
She immediately grabbed one of the more bitter herbs, one she recognized from scavenging with Ceil, and chewed on it to rid her mouth of the pungent sweetness.
She then grabbed a strip of the meat to balance out the ruthless assault on her tastebuds.
The moment she brought it to her mouth, Coby hopped about with a longing in his eyes, begging for handouts.
Perhaps he didn’t touch any of it.
If Coby had been waiting patiently for Sammy to wake in order to ask her for some of her meal, she felt bad denying him.
Of course, she also realized that he could be putting on an act and just wanted more, but she had no way of knowing for sure.
He was staying by her bedside for whatever reason and expressed concern when she woke, so she could at least give him at little.
While she held out a strip of dried meat for Coby, she caught hold upon a peculiar part of her reasoning.
Coby expressed concern?
Did he really?
Her question did not come from a doubt that Coby would be concerned about her.
He had expressed concern through his actions when she was so exhausted that she was on the verge of collapse and eventually did collapse, but this was different.
His high pitched cry was not unlike the many she heard before, but within it she felt a genuine concern about her health, almost as if that concern was spoken in words.
She handed another strip to Coby before taking a second strip for herself.
Her head ached too much to think deeply about what was likely something she imagined up in her exhaustion.
She wanted so desperately to lie back down on her lush moss bed and sleep off the headache, but she had to warn the hamadryad.
If what the Arkhon predicted was correct, the dryads were going to join the war, split on opposing sides.
The sooner she could prevent any war preparations, the better.
Sammy gazed around the hut.
There was no exit.
The tight weave of saplings surrounded her on all sides almost as if this was a prison.
Or perhaps it was a prison.
After all, they did attack the village, and during the negotiations between Ceil and the soldiers, most of the dryads stood on the Tolmyur commander’s side.
Sammy could not shake the worry creeping up her spine.
She stood and nearly fell from her weak legs, but a rush of wind from Coby kept her upright.
She walked slowly to one of the small gaps in the wall while holding the side of her head in an attempt to suppress the ache.
Her clothes stuck to her uncomfortably due to how much she had sweat while sleeping, but she could wash later.

The gap provided little visibility of the outside village, but at least it was a dryad village, both adding to her confidence that they had not left the village and adding to her worry that something might have happened to Chloe, Ceil, and Lemi.
Their provisions were not in the hut, so this hut or prison was meant solely for her and Coby.
Coby could escape whenever he wanted with his wind magic, but instead he stayed by Sammy’s side.
She tore the piece of meat protruding from her mouth in two and passed the larger part to Coby.
Sammy moved along the wall to another larger gap.
From there she could see the back of the large tree in the center of the village, now looking more like a cedar than whatever that stout tree had been before, confirming her location.
The roots of the Hamadryad circled the trunk of the tree from the front and snaked their way through the nearby huts.
The few dryads she could see took extra caution to avoid stepping on any of the roots.
The huts the roots touched looked dried and dead and were in various states of deconstruction and removal.
Sammy felt terrible that because of her demand that the hamadryad root here, so many lost their homes.
If anything, she deserved to be in prison.
If she convinced someone to destroy a bunch of houses on Earth, she would be culpable if not just as guilty as the one who destroyed them.
Near the tree, a young dryad appeared who did not mind stepping on and climbing over the roots.
She was an Anthousai, her hair covered in so many tiny white flowers that it glistened like powder snow in the sunlight.
Sammy wanted to call out to Lemi but hesitated.
Lemi was not imprisoned.
Either some deal had been made or they forgave the girl, being only a child.
Still, she was Sammy’s only hope for an explanation about what happened after she blacked out.
“Lemi!”
The young dryad turned her head towards Sammy so fast that Sammy could almost feel the pain in her neck that such a quick jolt would cause.
Lemi then ran off.
Sammy half expected the reaction.
If Sammy was a criminal, avoiding her was the best choice.
She walked back to the center of the hut and sat down on her moss bed.
It was damp like her clothes from her sweat, now cold and uncomfortable to lie on.
Sleep would not be possible much to her dismay, so she decided to finish her herbs, avoiding the white berries.
While eating, Sammy noticed the hut growing darker.
She assumed a cloud was passing over, but light still filtered through the sparse holes in the thatch roof.
Only the light from the walls was blocked.
The passing shadows stopped moving and continually grew in number.
Sammy could hear them whispering among themselves.
“She’s awake.”
“What are you doing?
We are supposed to leave her be.”
“Mom, I want to see her.”
Sammy felt like a caged animal in a zoo.
Coby noticed her discontent and trotted up to the shadows.
He flapped his wings with an annoyed trill.
The hut shook lightly in the strong wind, and the dryads on the other side of that wall yelped in surprise.
They kept their distance after that.
Again, Sammy noticed the meaning of Coby’s trill.
Unlike spoken words, she only caught the succinct emotion or intent conveyed by the call, but she understood it perfectly.
The whispers too.
The dryads were not speaking English, but she understood what they said.
Sammy had little experience in foreign languages, only learning French in school, and she was never fluent.

She had to think hard about the meaning of any French she heard, but her instructor always told her that when learning languages, there is a point when the language “clicks,” when you no longer needed to process it in your mind because you naturally understand the meaning.
That level of competency was the strange sensation Sammy felt.
She recalled the negotiations between Ceil and the officer of the enemy soldiers.
“If you can promise me that you will return my companion in full health, I accept.
I will meet you in battle in Vallen.”
She understood the agreement.
She hadn’t then, but she did now as clearly as if they were speaking English, and it terrified her.
“Clear the way!”
Relief washed over Sammy when she heard Ceil’s voice.
The shadows parted, and the sapling wall split open to allow Ceil and Lemi through.
Ceil closed the wall behind her so that no one else could enter.
“What’s going on?
What happened after I passed out?
Am I a prisoner?”
Sammy rattled off the questions weighing on her mind, but her quick and breathless speech caused her head to ache worse.
She held her head and sat back down on her damp bed.
Ceil looked around at the doorless walls with an understanding grimace.
“I can see why you would think you are prisoner.
Sorry to worry you.
The truth is the opposite.
There is no entryway to remind the villagers to leave you alone.
The Sprite Arkhon ordered me to prevent any dryads from touching you while you slept.
It was easy at first, but…” Ceil gave an exasperated sigh, “…things grew complicated.”
“What do you mean?”
“Part of this is my fault.
Remember when I apologized to you after the soldiers left?
I bowed myself in front of you.
I was not thinking about how that would look to the entire village watching us.
That was a sign to them that you are of higher standing than I, the Empress of the Amelian Empire.
The next day, the hamadryad let slip that you obtained the Sprite Arkhon’s favor and were the one who ordered her to take root in this village.
That was also a sign to everyone that you are of higher standing than even their hamadryad.”
Sammy was speechless, and for a moment, she forgot about her headache.
“I think that was a calculated move by the hamadryad after she felt the reaction the Melians had to my mistake.

Most the village was opposed to the hamadryad, but now that they think that you, with more authority than any of us, ordered her to root here in the village, they became more understanding, and the village is slowly starting to unify under her.”
“And now I am a celebrity,” Sammy whispered under her breath, her voice weary with a new kind of exhaustion.
“What did the Sprite Arkhon do to you that was so important he forbade anyone with life magic from touching you?” Ceil asked.
Sammy scanned the walls of the hut.
She could still hear and understand the whispers and curious conversations of the villagers.
“The Arkhon’s gift…” Sammy faced Lemi.
“Can you say something in Melian?”
Lemi’s eyes grew wide and her smile wider.
She dropped to her knees and grabbed Sammy’s hands in excitement.
“You speak Melian?
Since when?!”
“Am I really speaking Melian,” Sammy asked Ceil.
“You are speaking Fiorran now, or I guess it is the language of your world, but when you talked to Lemi, you spoke Melian.
I could not understand you.”
I really did speak Melian?
Sammy tried to recall the words she spoke when addressing Lemi, and the memory that came was not in English.
It was another language, but like listening to the babble outside the hut, she understood the meaning of her words without needing to parse them.
Somehow, she spoke a language she had never learned as if it was only natural for her to do so.
The revelation was terrifying but exciting all the same.
The Arkhon had asked her what she regretted most.
Aside from Justin’s health and capture, her greatest regret since arriving in Melia was her inability to understand anyone but Ceil and Chloe.
She could only sit and wait while Ceil spoke with the hamadryad and then needed Ceil to translate for her when the hamadryad wanted to hear from her.
Again, she could only stand and wait during the negotiation between the soldiers and Ceil.
If this was the Arkhon’s gift, it was too good to be true.
Something like this should be impossible, but how else could she explain her newfound language skills?
Sammy thought about the sparse Elven that Eydis taught her.
“Ceil, what language am I speaking now?”
“That is Elven, specifically the High Elf dialect of the capital,” Ceil replied in a state of shock.
“It is a little different from the Filinceil dialect of my childhood home.
Is this what the Sprite Arkhon did to you?
Why?”
Sammy felt uneasy about explaining her bet with the Arkhon.
She still felt that she had not accomplished anything and only made the situation worse.
“That’s right!”
Sammy’s outburst caused her head to pound, and she reeled from the pain.
“Are you hurt?
Should I heal you?” Lemi gripped Sammy’s hand with genuine concern.
Sammy shook her head.
“I’m fine.
I need to speak to the hamadryad.
It’s urgent.”
Lemi’s face lit up from again hearing Sammy speak Melian.
“Of course!
I will take you immediately.”
She pulled Sammy to her feet and led her to the wall of the hut facing the center of the village.
“Where are you going?” Ceil asked.
Sammy realized that because she spoke to Lemi, she spoke Melian, a language Ceil did not know.
Language barriers were troublesome.
Even with the Arkhon’s gift, she could only speak one language at a time.
The words she spoke were not universal.
“I need to see the hamadryad.
The Arkhon gave me a warning about the war,” Sammy explained.
Ceil understood the urgency and followed Sammy and Lemi out the opening Lemi made in the wall.
Immediately Sammy was accosted by the villagers greeting her and trying to present her with gifts of herbs and wreaths of winter flowers.
“Sorry, but I don’t have time.
This is urgent.
Please move,” Sammy ordered.
The villagers reluctantly cleared a path.
Lemi continued pulling Sammy along, each step causing Sammy’s head to throb.
“What about Chloe?
Is she alright?”
In Sammy’s most recent memories, Chloe was near death from fighting against the Tolmyur soldiers.
She had not arrived at the hut with Lemi and Ceil, so she was worried.
“Chloe is fine,” Ceil replied.
“She is resting in Jenae’s care.
We’ll take you to her after you speak with the hamadryad.”
Sammy exhaled her relief.
Her legs were still weak, so Ceil and Lemi helped her over the thick roots surrounding the stout tree in the center of the village.
They led her inside the hollow that was once the abode of the village matriarch.
There Sammy saw for the first time a true hamadryad.
The formerly terrifying woman with dark sunken eyes and cracks of orange covering her bark-like grey skin had grown to become a beautiful woman in her prime.
Her skin remained its dark, grey-brown hue, but a hint of orange gave it color.
Her arms were fused with the trunk of the cedar above her head as was her back and a single leg below her.
The leg that was missing below the knee in Sammy’s memory was in the process of regrowth and was only just beginning to fuse with the trunk.
“I am honored by your visit, child.
What need have you of me?”
The Hamadryad’s voice was soft and melodious, far different from the course, grating noise Sammy remembered, but the formal manner of speech made her uncomfortable.
She assumed that the hamadryad was only supporting the lie the villagers ignorantly fabricated, treating Sammy as if she was higher in status.
Sammy was about to speak, but then stopped.
If she spoke without thinking, she might speak in Melian or whatever language this cedar dryad used in her homeland.
Thinking on the Elven taught her by Eydis, she spoke her worries.
“The Arkhon warned me that the dryads will be pulled into the war on both sides because I convinced you to plant yourself here.”
The hamadryad’s peaceful expression grew stern.
Before she could speak, Ceil grabbed Sammy’s shoulder and turned her to face her.
“Is this true?
Did the Sprite Arkhon truly say that?” Ceil asked.
“Yes.” Sammy wanted to deny it, but because she was at fault, informing everyone was her responsibility.
“Then, what was the reason for my agreement with the Tolmyur commander?
We were to fight in Vallen, in an existing battle, to spare the dryads.
I do not want more people to die.”
Sammy’s heart sank, and her guilt made her nauseous, more so than her headache.
Ceil paced a tight circle between the roots in thought.
“We already know that the dryads are now split because less than half of them recognize the hamadryad…
Of those under your influence, what are their opinions on the war?” she asked the hamadryad.
The hamadryad grew as still as a wood carving.
While waiting for an answer, Sammy sat into the bend of one of the thicker roots and leaned back to rest her throbbing head.
“Want me to check what’s wrong,” Lemi asked with her hands clasped in front of her chest.
“Yah, please,” Sammy replied.
Lemi knelt down and placed her hand on Sammy’s forehead.
A warm pulse ran through her body.
“Your nerves are strained.
Muscles in your head are inflamed and contracting.”
“I know that.
That’s what a headache is,” Sammy said, letting her frustration slip.
“Did you find a reason?”
Lemi shrunk back, so Sammy took a long and slow breath and grabbed Lemi’s arm gently.
“Sorry.
I didn’t mean to sound angry.
If you don’t know, that’s fine.
It will probably pass with time.”
Lemi shook her head.
“I don’t know if it’s the cause, but your mind is very active.
I don’t know mind magic, so I cannot say more than that.”
“Let me see.”
Ceil placed her hand on Sammy’s forehead.
A sensation followed that Sammy had never felt before.
It was as if Ceil reached inside her and stopped before touching the very core of what Sammy was.
Her hand hovered there as Ceil’s face grew more and more worried.
Then she touched.
Sammy’s hearing and vision distorted as if submerged under agitated water.
Her body grew numb but the ache in her head grew to a skull-splitting pain.
She cried out, or at least she felt as if she did because her ears could not hear it.
The distorted shapes of Ceil and Lemi panicked.
They each grabbed one of Sammy’s arms and placed her hands on the large roots.
A flow of warmth ran from Sammy’s right hand, through her body and mind, and out her left hand.
The aching of her head ebbed to a dull throb no less intense than it had been when she woke but was made far more tolerable after the sudden acute pain.
Her vision cleared and her hearing returned.
She could hear sobbing, and only once feeling returned to her body did she realize the one sobbing was her.
The taste of iron filled her mouth from the blood that ran down her lip from her nose.
“Sammy!
Are you alright?!”
Ceil asked in panic.
“I am sorry.
I only touched your mind like I did before. I…”
“Child.”
The Hamadryad’s voice silenced Ceil.
Unlike the melodious tone of her earlier greeting, her voice now held the authority of one who rules the dryads.
“Who did this to you?”
Sammy could only mouth a single word reply.
“…Arkhon…?”
She was unsure, but her strange headache happened after her argument with the Arkhon and the unknown space of time she was unconscious.
If it was a tension headache from stress or from sleeping in bad posture, Sammy expected Lemi would have said so and probably could have alleviated it.
“I assumed as much.
This level of life magic is beyond what I am capable.
There is one dryad, an ancient kissiae, who could potentially manipulate the mind to this extent, but this magic may even be beyond her.
I feel I know the answer, but what was it that the Sprite Arkhon did to you?”
Sammy swallowed the blood that pooled in her mouth.
The bleeding from her nose ceased, so she wiped her lip with the side of her hand.
“Language,” she replied after a few deep breaths.
“Speak and understand… languages.”
“Far more benign that I thought,” the hamadryad replied with a hint of relief.
“I assume your pain is caused by your mind being unaccustomed to the mental strain of the level of knowledge you now possess.
Your mind is agitated and unstable.
Until you grow accustomed to your new abilities, I would refrain from allowing others of weak life magic from interfering with your mind.”
Ceil bowed her head apologetically.
“Sorry. The Sprite Arkhon warned me not to let anyone with weak life magic touch you, and I went and did it anyway.”
“No, I am the one who asked you and Lemi to find what was wrong.”
Sammy returned her attention to the hamadryad.
“More importantly, about Ceil’s question.
What do the dryads think of the war?”
“I cannot speak for those I do not influence.
Those outside of Melia who have accepted me as their Grandmatriarch hold a neutral opinion of the war.
If I push for or against their involvement, their stance will shift as well.
Melia is more troubled.
There are two opposing waves spreading throughout the villages.
One wave of messengers preaches continued submission to the stronger forces of Tolmyur and a warning to be wary of the widow of Emperor Yuro.
If ordered by the enemy, I feel they will join with Tolmyur.
The second wave preaches support for the surviving member of the royal family who has entered their lands raising a rally cry to take back their empire from the Tolmyur invasion.
They may join the war against Tolmyur with or without my direction.
Fear and hope are equally potent motivators.”
“I did no such thing,” Ceil protested in pure exasperation.
“Where did these rumors start? Here?”
“I cannot say, but the origins are not from this village,” The hamadryad replied.
Ceil looked at Lemi who immediately grew nervous.
“Your village… All the dryads that were missing when we returned.
You sent the messengers.”
“We didn’t know where you would go when you left or that you’d return to our village.
We didn’t want other villages to betray you like you thought ours did.
We only said that you are fighting for us.
The message must have changed as it traveled.”
“You only made things worse!”
Lemi cowered behind Sammy, and Sammy winced from the throbbing caused by Ceil’s shout.
“Lemi didn’t do anything, and shouting at her is not going to stop this,” Sammy rebuked before returning to the main topic.
“How many of those who believe that message are under your influence?
How many accept you as their Grandmatriarch?”
“The majority, but not all,” the hamadryad replied.
Ceil pleaded with the hamadryad with her hands on the hamadryad’s knees.
“No matter what happens, you must not join the war.
Use your influence to stop the dryads or hold them back.”
“A hamadryad’s influence is far from absolute.
I cannot rob them of their free will.”
“Promise me!”
Ceil bowed as low as she could with her hands clasped on the Hamadryad’s knees.
“I do not want them to die because of me.”
“I will do what I can.”
“That’s all we can ask,” Sammy replied with her hand on Ceil’s shoulder.
“Thank you.”

Chapter 2
“Preparations for Departure”
Sammy
“I suppose I’m going to have to face the crowd now,” Sammy moaned.
“Sorry,” Ceil answered with a light grimace.
Chloe’s hut sat next to Sammy’s “prison.”
Before they left the hollow, Lemi warned them that the crowd had not dispersed.
The villagers were forbidden from interacting with Sammy while she slept, but now that she was awake, there was little reason to stop them.
Of course, the villagers realized this as well.
They waited with gifts and questions about Sammy’s origins and how she obtained such authority that even their Grandmatriarch and Empress bent to her will.
Sammy was at least grateful that they had the self-restraint to not interrupt her meeting with the Hamadryad.

Then again, interrupting an urgent meeting between what they believed to be the three of the highest authorities in all the dryad forests of Dhuillir, possibly all the Amelian Empire, would be the height of impudence.
Before Sammy could even see Chloe’s hut, she had two wreaths and four necklaces placed around her neck.

Ceil tried to direct the crowd so they could at least make some progress, and Lemi’s job was to collect other gifts which were quickly piling up too high for her to hold, but there was one gift that Lemi did not reach for.
A teal-skinned Dryad with heart-shaped, erose leaves for hair knelt before Sammy and presented four of the same white berries that were provided with Sammy’s meal.
The presentation of gifts ceased as all waited for Sammy to receive the offering.
“What are those berries,” Sammy asked Ceil, worried that she might do something offensive.
“She is an epimeliad, an extremely rare form of dryad,” Ceil replied.
“They are about as rare as my two tails.
They are not a special species of their own.
Any dryad can mother one, and from her appearance, she is not from Melia.”
“Instead of bearing children, they bear fruit,” Lemi added, struggling under the awkward load of gifts.
“They often travel, planting their fruit to diversify the forests.
To be given their fruit is the same as a mother giving you her daughter.”
“I can’t accept it,” Sammy whispered in English to Ceil, trying to hide her panic from the dryads watching in anticipation.
“I’m not special enough to deserve this.”
She remembered the pungently sweet berry she spat out.
If this Epimeliad knew she spat it out, how grave of an insult would that be?
“Take them,” Lemi suggested after she, too, grew nervous from Sammy’s inaction.
“Only the one given the fruit can receive it.
If you do not want to eat them, plant them.”
“It is as the anthousai says,” the epimeliad said with her face bowed and her cupped hands extended.
“I am aware that you may not understand our customs, but please accept my offering.”
Sammy extended her shaking hand and received the four berries, taking extra caution not to crush them.
“Feel free to continue using my hut as a sanctuary from the crowds until you and your companions are ready to depart for Vallen.”
“Thank you.
I will treasure them,” Sammy answered, realizing immediately afterwards that her words were another new language similar in structure to Melian yet sounding very different.
The epimeliad stood, and even though her face was that of a healthy middle-aged woman, her smile was reminiscent of a giddy teenager who just received an autograph from her celebrity crush.
If she could bring such joy to the villagers, Sammy felt that she would not mind continuing the façade until she left the village.
The moment the epimeliad stepped back, the informal procession continued, and soon Lemi had to run to the epimeliad’s hut to drop off the gifts so that she could receive more.
The toothy grin on Lemi’s face and the spring in her step as she returned showed that she was thoroughly enjoying every second.
She nearly had a second full load of offerings by the time they reached Chloe’s hut.
Jenae greeted them from the entryway with Coby ruffling his feathers right beside her.
With them guarding the door, none of the dryads dared approach too near.
Chloe sat up on her lush moss bed and smiled sweetly at Sammy.
Sammy couldn’t hold in her rising emotions.
She dove to Chloe’s bedside and embraced her dear friend who nearly died.
“I’m so happy you’re okay,” Sammy whispered with a light crack in her voice.
Her free-flowing tears wet Chloe’s shoulder.
Chloe chuckled lightly and wrapped her arms around Sammy.
“Glad you’re awake.
You slept for three days.”
“Three days?”
Sammy looked back at Ceil in disbelieve, almost hoping that Ceil would refute what Chloe said.
Three days on Whinhlem was about six on Earth.
That would explain how weak she felt and her terrible hunger after waking.
If she did not know the true cause, she would have attributed her current headache to oversleep and malnutrition.
“How is your recovery coming?”
“I would be completely healed now if they used life magic, but they only took care of the life-threatening things.”
Chloe showed the scar in her arm from the arrow, and there was likely a similar scar on her back.
“I asked them to heal her completely, but the village shaman said this way was better,” Ceil replied.
“Tyree said something similar in your village.”
“Said what?”
Lemi was rummaging through the gifts in the second load she carried inside Chloe’s hut instead of dropping them off like the first.
“Do all Melians believe that natural healing is better than life magic?” Ceil asked.
“Oh! Yes.”
Lemi set down what looked like a carved bone necklace in her lap.
“Dryads view life magic differently than High Elves.
We use it in emergencies, but we feel that your body grows stronger by not relying on it.”
“I thought life magic only sped up natural healing, so there should not be any difference,” Ceil countered.
“Well… You might be right about the injury but…”
Ceil’s single response was logical enough from Sammy’s understanding of life magic to push Lemi into a corner, and Sammy felt a bit bad for her, especially because Lemi struggled to refute it.
Lemi was a dryad, but she was still only a shaman’s apprentice.
She probably didn’t know all the reasons behind why dryad medicinal practice was this way, but Sammy could think of a few reasons from her own education.
“Maybe there is no difference with the injury, but there is probably a large difference with how the body copes with the injury or illness.
The body develops a resistance to diseases and infections that allow it to fight them better when it encounters them again.
If you shortcut the healing process, there is little time for the body to build those defenses.
Same with injuries.
When a part of your body is inhibited, other parts compensate for the burden and can become stronger.
At least, that’s how it is with humans.”
“Yes! That’s why!
Thank you, Sammy.
I did not know how to explain it.”
So, she did know, Sammy thought with a faint smile.
Dryads probably knew more about the body than her professors and textbooks did because of their strength in life magic.
“But, I am fine with healing you whenever you want it,” Lemi added.
Content with Sammy’s explanation, Lemi returned to searching through the gifts.
Her eyes lit up when she removed what looked like a sarong with a zig-zagging, green and brown, ikat herringbone weave.
The fringes were tasseled with tiny, glossy wood beads that clacked lightly together with every small movement of the fabric.
Sammy’s eyes were glued to the fine craftsmanship.
It was gorgeous.
Lemi immediately removed the makeshift skirt she had fashioned from her cloak and then tied the sarong around her waist.
She hopped and spun lightly as the wooden beads sung to every motion.
Lemi was positively giddy, and Sammy, Chloe, and Ceil watched the exotic maiden with blushing faces.
Like the beautiful white bind that Chloe had used in place of a bra, Sammy desperately wanted this sarong as well.
It was given to her, but she felt guilty asking for it after seeing how well it looked on Lemi and how happy Lemi was to wear it.
Sammy suppressed her desires and continued watching the prancing girl.
“She’s adorable,” Chloe whispered with a smile.
“I am most pleased that it is to your liking.
That dava was woven by my wife.”
It was then that Sammy noticed two other occupants on the far side of the hut, the two elves who protected Chloe from the soldiers.
They had antler-like horns protruding from near their temples and circling the sides of their head like crowns.
Their ears were different than Ceil’s, short and sharply rising to a point.
Their legs appeared like human or elf legs but with a digitigrade bone structure.
The elder of the two Elves noticed Sammy’s gaze and bowed his head.
“Lady Sammy, it brings me great joy to see you up and in good health.
I express my utmost gratitude for your company’s aid in treating my son.”
The man’s son echoed his father’s gratitude.
The son, appearing about thirty years old or a little younger if he were human, sat on a moss bed similar to Chloe’s.

He was shirtless with a woven grass blanket draped over his lap and legs, and the heavy scarring from the intense burns he received for covering Chloe while she was overheating made Sammy wince instinctively.
“How is your son?” Sammy asked, much to the surprise of the two men and Chloe.
“Benab is well despite appearances, but how is it that you know our language?
Oramare is the smallest Forrest Elf province in Ghalanail.
Sammy sighed.
No foreigner would have a need to learn it.”
She made a mental note to think before speaking, otherwise these exchanges would only repeat over and over again.
She had no idea where Oramare or Ghalanail was.

She did not want to explain to everyone that the Sprite Arkhon messed with her head, so she used the first excuse that came to mind that she hoped would be more believable, letting them fill in the blanks where they will.
“I am good friends with Eydis FeAmel.”
The Forest Elf glanced at Ceil and came to his own conclusion.
“The First Princess, how does she fare?”
“We don’t know,” Sammy replied with a hint of remorse, changing back to the Amel dialect of Elven, and the man nodded in understanding.
“If you wish to continue discussion with your companions in private, we will leave.”
“If I may,” Benab interjected.
“You will be departing soon for Vallen, correct?
With your permission, I wish to accompany you.
You will be traveling through war-stricken lands, and no women should make such a dangerous journey unprotected, especially one of your standing.”

Sammy thought upon her travels with Chloe and Ceil through Fiorrae and Melia, all the times they had been lax in their apparel and manners, the countless times when they had been half or completely naked in the convenience of their company of women with Justin unconscious.
She did not have any plans on continuing the lie about her authority.
What would this man think when he finds out that she was nothing more than an inconsequential figure in this war?
The father noticed Sammy’s unease and rubbed his forehead between his two antlers.
“Please forgive my son’s impertinence.
I have discussed this with him many times over the past two days.
To put his worries at ease, if I am not overstepping my bounds by requesting this of you, Lady Sammy, can you make a combat stance?
Any stance will suffice.”
Unsure what reason the man had for the odd request, Sammy did as he instructed and held a simple striking stance that Eydis had taught her for creating an opening to escape an attacker.
“Notice the alignment of the well points from her ankle to her hip and shoulder to her retracted strike hand?” Debin asked his son.
Sammy grew more uncomfortable as Benab scanned her posture, his eyes slowly widening as if coming to some realization that not even Sammy knew.
“The moment her fist extends, the dar alignment completes.
If she struck your right breast, your ven would seize, and the distortion of your well points could make your heart momentarily fail.
Like the grandmaster fire magician, Lady Chloe, Lady Sammy has received martial training from the royal family.
Your skills are in the hunt and the hunt alone.
You could not provide these women better protection than they can already provide themselves.
You could only become a hindrance and liability.”

“Your son may lack skill, but you are rather knowledgeable for someone from Oramare, if I heard correctly,” Ceil replied, placing her hand on Sammy’s shoulder to signal that she could ease her stance, much to Sammy’s relief.
“I was an archer for the royal guard until nearly thirty years ago, Lady Ceil, just before your late husband, Emperor Yuro, ascended the throne.
The untimely death of my brother called me back to Oramare to support my aging parents.”
“The abilities of your son aside, someone of your experience would be highly beneficial.
Are you familiar with Vallen?”
The Forest Elf bowed his head.
“Forgive me, Your Highness.
My wife is much older than I and frail from age, so I cannot be your guide.
You have done so much for me by treating my son alongside your companion, but I have no service to offer in return.
Please forgive us.”
“We know Vallen,” Benab replied, much against his father’s wishes.
“We lived there until recently.
When the armies of Tolmyur approached our village, we fled for Melia.
I am duty-bound to help.
Lady Chloe and I have stood--”
“Not another word,” Debin reprimanded, gripping Benab’s arm.
He bowed his head to Ceil.
“I am sorry, but we cannot.”
“I understand.”
Ceil knelt in front of them but kept the refined posture of a member of the royal family.
“Is this your only son?”
“Yes.
My wife is too old to bare another, and I am too old to take a second wife of childbearing age.”
After nearly losing his son, Ceil understood why he would not let him join.
“We’ll be fine on our own,” Sammy said, kneeling in front of them and attempting to mimic Ceil’s posture.
“You may still be of use to us, Debin,” Ceil continued.
“You are familiar with Vallen and know the direction of the enemy march.
Can you provide us a map and order of the most likely cities they would target next?”
Sammy searched her memory of the negotiations and realized that a location for their battle was never given.
This would make sense if the commander did not know how far the war in Vallen had progressed, but it made meeting him to return Justin far more difficult.
Sammy could only hold onto the Arkhon’s promise that Justin would be returned to her in good health.
Debin’s countenance lightened.
“I would be most honored.
Come.
Let us leave them to their own discussions while I prepare the map.”
Debin stood and held his arm to his dejected son who grasped his wrist and stood.
The grass-woven blanket covering him fell, revealing his naked, hairless body.
Sammy was startled but tried not to show it.
She half expected this would happen.
People in Melia did not seem to mind nudity, or perhaps it was Whinhlem in general.
Jenae and Coby moved away from the entryway.

Sammy watched the two men leave the hut with their tails, long enough to touch the ground if the tips at the end did not curl upwards, swinging lightly from side to side, and then returned to Chloe’s bedside.
Chloe’s face was turned away and so flushed that the edges of her ears glowed pink.
“After seeing Justin’s so many times, you still get flustered?”
Sammy jested, causing Chloe to blush further until her ears flushed completely pink.
“But the Forest Elf’s did look quite different, didn’t he?
Much thinner,” she added, forcing Chloe to recall the details of her mental image again to make her blush even harder, if that was possible.
“Stop pestering her,” Ceil rebuked.
“What’s wrong with Chloe?
Is she sick?” Lemi asked, now wearing a necklace of red winter flowers and looking very tropical in her dava.
“No, she just can’t handle looking at naked men,” Sammy replied.
“Oh! Is this what arousal is?”
Sammy burst into laughter, and both Chloe and Ceil were left wondering what was said.
She couldn’t even imagine how Chloe would react if she understood Lemi.
After a few seconds, she tried to stifle her laughter enough to formulate a reply and to stop her head from throbbing.
“No, no.
She’s just embarrassed.
Women with no experience with men are like this sometimes.”
“You mean she hasn’t birthed any children yet?
At her age?”
Lemi was quite perplexed.
“I haven’t either,” Sammy replied, “but I do have experience with men.
Many women from our world don’t have children until a bit later in life if at all.”
“I see.
I guess it’s different when you get to choose.”
Content with Sammy’s explanation, Lemi returned to the pile of gifts.
“How long until you recover,” Sammy asked the still-pink Chloe who was taking slow breaths to calm down.
“Until the map is completed,” Ceil answered for her.
“I’ll order the village shaman to heal you the rest of the way.
She should have no reason to complain if we will be departing.”
“What about Lemi?” Chloe asked, finally regaining composure.
“She will not be joining us,” Ceil replied flatly.
“She was only helping us locate the hamadryad.
We cannot risk taking an anthousai with us.”
“Because she might be pregnant?” Chloe guessed.
“That is part of it…” Ceil answered, her voice fading into worried silence.
Sammy knew the true reason.
There was no guarantee of survival, and Ceil wanted to involve as few people as possible.
Only the three of them had ties to the agreement Ceil made with the Tolmyur commander.
“Have you told her yet?” Chloe asked.
Ceil shook her head.
She likely felt that Lemi would protest and did not know how to bring up the conversation.
Sammy understood the risks and felt that remaining in Melia would be best for Lemi.
If the hamadryad upheld her promise, hopefully the Melians would not be pulled into the war.
Sammy took a deep breath.
“Lemi, when you return to your village, feel free to take the dava with you.
It looks good on you.”
“Thanks!” Lemi beamed, but then her joy melted.
She found the meaning hidden in Sammy’s words.
“Is that what you were talking about just now?
You don’t want me to come with you?”
Sammy spoke in Elven so that Ceil could be part of the conversation.
“We feel that it will be too dangerous to take you along.
After all, we are going to war.”
“No! I’m coming with!
I haven’t done anything for you yet.”
Lemi dropped the cloth she was holding with a polished blue stone wrapped in it and knelt in front of Sammy.
“I was supposed to help you convince the hamadryad because I know Ceil is fighting for the dryads, but I didn’t do anything.”
“I am not fighting for anyone,” Ceil argued.
“I just want this war to end.”
“Then let me help you end it!”
Lemi gripped her fists tightly in front of her, begging for Ceil to allow her to stay.
“No, Lemi.”
Sammy placed a gentle hand on her shoulder.
“Is it because I am still young, because I am an Anthousai?
I might not even be pregnant, and once I leave Melia, there will be less hemma, and so it will be harder for me to get pregnant.”
“But you still might be pregnant,” Ceil said.
Lemi’s face grew rigid with conviction.
She stood and held her hand in front of her abdomen, almost touching.
“If I am not pregnant, will you let me stay with you?
If I am, I will go back to my village.”
“You are not supposed to check,” Ceil protested.
“Go back to your village.
I want you to be safe.”
“Ending the war is more important!
I want to help!
Promise me.
If I am not pregnant, you will let me stay.”
“No,” Ceil replied.
“Okay, we promise.”
“Sammy!”
“If we don’t make a deal somewhere, she might end up following us anyway,” Sammy told Ceil in English so that Lemi could not understand and get any ideas that may or may not already be there.
“At least this gives her a chance to stay in Melia on her own terms.”
Ceil grew conflicted but eventually caved to Sammy’s logic.
“Fine.
If you are pregnant, you return home.”
Lemi’s breath grew short, and she hesitated to place her hand on her abdomen.

She was about to break a longstanding dryad custom of not monitoring an Anthousai’s first pregnancy, as well as depriving herself of the anticipation of motherhood unique to dryads caused by unknown conception, something that she was formerly so excited about.
Her hand touched her abdomen, and her breaths grew ragged.
“You do not need to do this,” Ceil urged her.
“Just return to your village.”
Lemi ignored Ceil and squeezed her eyes shut.
In that moment, Sammy knew the girl scanned her body for signs of pregnancy.
Lemi’s breaths grew long and slow, and she opened her eyes with a faint smile.
“I’m not pregnant yet.
I’m going with you.”
Ceil looked over to Jenae, the former matriarch of Lemi’s village, for help in convincing her.
“If this is what the child has decided, I cannot stop her,” Jenae answered.
Ceil was defeated.
Sammy grew uneasy about the decision and how it was made, but part of her was happy to have Lemi continue with them.
The girl’s radiant personality helped improve their morale, standing in direct contrast to Ceil’s pessimism.
“Gather our belongings into the epimeliad’s hut,” Ceil ordered with mild irritation.
“Once the map is finished, we will depart.”
The village shaman was called over to rush Chloe’s recovery, and she finished in about an hour.
During the treatment, Sammy asked Chloe why she never brought up her newfound language abilities.
Chloe’s reply was simple.
“After I heard you speak, I just assumed that was why you were sleeping so long.
Was it the Arkhon?”
Chloe’s intuition surprised Sammy.
Then again, fantastical topics were always Chloe’s forte.

Inside the epimeliad’s hut, Ceil admired the map of Vallen Debin drew on a fine piece of durable tan cloth, planning which of the four remaining major cities in Vallen to travel to and the quickest route to them.
Sammy, Chloe, and Lemi were left to sort through the gifts and the large addition of travel provisions supplied by the village.
“There is no way we can carry all of this,” Sammy complained.
“And the gifts too.
We can’t take most of them with us.”
“We provide what we can.
You take only what you need,” the epimeliad replied, causing an odd sense of déjà vu that Sammy suspected was from something spoken in a memory that she hadn’t understood in the past but could now.
“As for the gifts, they are all meant as an expression of goodwill that one of your greatness would visit our small village.
If you look closely, most are perishable or small enough that they would not hinder your travels.
No one will fault you if you leave their offering behind.”
Lemi was already in the process of sorting out the floral wreaths, necklaces, and crowns from the two piles of gifts.
Clothing, the smallest collection, was placed to the side.
Sammy noticed another light blue dava, and although it was not as extravagant as the one Lemi claimed, she was eager to take it for herself.

Sammy’s bra was wearing down, so she was happy that the village provided her with a green sash, and Chloe tied it for her in the same manner she had learned from Ceil, with the bow folded and pleated into small angel wings on her back.
The final collection of gifts was miscellaneous pieces of jewelry and other small trinkets.
Their make was earthen, either crafted from carved wood or bone, and Sammy did not find any of it appealing.
Excess jewelry would be a burden anyway, so she did not feel bad about leaving them.
“Should we pack similar to when we left Lemi’s village?” Chloe asked.
“Sounds good to me,” Sammy answered.
“We can always scavenge for more food, and Coby can hunt for us as well.”
Coby gave a confident trill and flapped his wings proudly.
“We’ll head to Nalain first,” Ceil announced, rolling up the map.
“It is the closest fairy city, and given the time since Debin and Benab fled, it is also the most likely next target.
There are a lot of smaller villages and another city in the path of the army, so hopefully they will slow them down enough that we can get there first.”
Ceil’s expression darkened.
“The faster we can meet them in battle, the quicker this war will end.”

Chapter 3
“Preparations for War”
“Clear camp with haste,” Lieutenant Kolbur shouted to his men.
“The emperor’s widow is within our grasp.
We must join Captain Byurk in securing her capture before she can slither into another burrow.”
Kolbur repeated the same words each morning to remind his men of the urgency of their mission.
Five days ago, a messenger arrived at the Amelian palace stating that the wife of the late emperor was sighted in the Melia province of Dhuillir.
It came with the news that Captain Byurk would lead a small platoon to capture her while his main force continued to Vallen to transport much needed provisions.
Kolbur’s small army of one hundred swift-footed men was en route to aid Captain Byurk in the wife’s capture.
Dressed in light leather and composed solely of rangers and scouts, his army could move consistently at three times the standard marching pace.
Even so, to reach the far northwestern province of Dhuillir would take another fifteen days.

Within that time, the wife could escape to any of the three Dhuillir provinces bordering Melia, to Fiorrae where they would have no hope of capturing her without Commanding General Jethro’s aid, or even back to Vallen.
He hoped that the dryads would support Captain Byurk in her capture, but seeing the outward hostility of the dryads bordering Amel, he was doubtful.
Their camp consisted of no more than a few small fires and woolen cloaks to ward off the cold night, so closing camp should have been quick.
“Too slow!”
The men were tired from their swift march, which was more of a jog, and the half-rest they were allotted each night was insufficient to fully recover their stamina.
Kolbur was the most tired of the group, but he dared not show it.
Scouts and rangers never rose in rank to become officers, and although he was chosen to lead the march because of his stamina, he lacked the same endurance these men possessed.
“Lieutenant!”
The forward scout Kolbur sent at the start of their march called back from down the trodden dirt road.
Any time a forward scout returned, ill news surely followed.
The scout was not alone.
Another man jogged beside him with his arm slung over the scout’s shoulder.
The man wore no armor, carried no weapon, and his feet were bound in rags stained with blood.
Kolbur ran to his scout.
Their dark eyes showed they had run straight through the night, possibly two nights, without rest.
When he reached them, the scout lowered the man who then fell to his knees, lacking the strength to stand.
“Son, who are you.
Tell me what happened.”
“I bring news from Byurk,” the messenger stated without so much as a breath to recover and without care for the respect of titles and rank.
“I must reach Amel.
I must warn Jethro.”
The messenger lurched forward and coughed a spray of blood.
His excessive exertion lead to hemorrhaging, and there was no way for Kolbur to know how serious the injury was.
“Speak!
What news do you carry?”
“We cannot fight the wife of the emperor as we are.
We will lose.”
Kolbur turned to his men who had finished preparations and now stood in file.
“Change of course!
We return to Amel!”
He selected two of his strongest men to carry the scout and planned a rotation of the burden among his men as they kept a double pace back to the palace.
“Son, in case you do not survive, tell me everything you know.”
Ill news, indeed.

* * *
Seven generals and twelve captains sat along a long redwood table in the grand banquet hall of the Amelian Palace.

The large crystalline windows that showered dancing rainbows on the marbled hall did little to lighten the suffocating aura born by the lone lieutenant and messenger who called the emergency meeting to session.
The messenger was a skilled archer under the command of Captain Byurk, the officer that their Commanding General placed in charge of the Vallen campaign despite Byurk not holding the rank of General.
Captain Byurk had thousands of men under his command to bring provisions to the soldiers in Vallen, and yet somehow he had no scout to send what he claimed was an urgent message.
The messenger nearly died, and had he, the news he bore would have been lost.
“I respect our great Commanding General’s judgement, but his trust in Captain Byurk is ill placed.
He only made him captain due to their hunter mercenary connections and involvement in the Coastal War.
He is not even of Tolmyur.”
“He was but was exiled, the last of the traitorous House Boromek.”
“To leave such a large and vital caravan in the hands of an inexperience lieutenant!
What foolishness!”
“The widow is important, but the lives of tens of thousands of our men are more important.
What will happen if the rations are lost due to the incompetence of the lieutenant he placed in charge?”
“How many of our men would starve or die from their inability to fight at full strength?”
“And to think that Byurk’s messenger would convince the support army we sent to return.
What folly!”
“Perhaps you misjudged Kolbur as well, General Lamek.”

While the generals and many of the captains questioned the competency of Captain Byurk and thus the validity of whatever message they were about to hear, Kolbur fought within himself whether to throw out the notion of authority and demand the messenger be given his time to speak, but his chance for decision passed.
“To question Captain Byurk’s appointment is to question our great Commanding General,” the messenger shouted.
“I would question your own loyalty before you question his.”
The many eyes around the table glared at the messenger in animosity.
Without rank, Kolbur knew the messenger’s words would result in severe punishment and possibly execution after the message was given.
The messenger was prepared to die for the news he bore, and that strength gave Kolbur the courage to speak.
“If I may, leave your judgement of the validity of the message until after you hear it.”
Kolbur found what he learned on the return to Amel difficult to believe, and he did not want to believe it, but one so trusted by the Commanding General would not tell such an egregious lie.
The angry faces around the table grew complacent, and the right to speak was handed to the messenger.
“As you learned from Captain Byurk’s initial message, the widow of the emperor was spotted in Melia in the company of humans who fought on her side.
I was a member of an elite team led by Captain Byurk to capture her.
We quickly learned that she no longer desired to hide and was now in open opposition against us.
Her reason for entering Melia was due to the appearance of a hamadryad.
That hamadryad has taken root in Melia and now supports the wife.”
Whispers rose among the generals and captains.
“You are telling us that now the fairies and dryads have chosen to support the widow?”
“Not quite, Captain Setch.
Although the Hamadryad has taken root, she can only influence those who accept her, but we still estimate that at about a third of Dhuillir.”
The whispers grew to audible conversation.
General Lamek raised his hand to silence the room.
“A third of Dhuillir is about the same in population as all of Vallen.
You are telling us that an army the size of a nation we could only defeat in piecemeal without our Commanding General could organize against us?”
“Yes, but if that was all, I would praise our good fortune,” the messenger said, his face growing sterner.
“What good fortune could such an army be?!”
“Can we hope to fight such an army while our Commanding General remains in the other world?!”
Angry shouts rose from the table, but General Lamek stood to silence them.
He alone caught hold upon the dark omen hidden in the messenger’s words.
“You carry worse tidings than a dryad uprising.
What happened?”
Kolbur’s body shook from a fear he could not explain.
What the messenger was about to say could be the tidings of a war that Tolmyur had no hope of winning.
“The reason we could not capture the wife, and the reason we could not stop the hamadryad from taking root and supporting her…
We have learned that the other world has joined the war in support of the widow of the emperor.”
Kolbur expected the commanders to shout accusations or voice their doubts or ask any number of questions, but all were silent.
A somber air hung over the room.
There was something the Generals and Captains stationed at the palace knew that they withheld from him and other lower-ranked soldiers.
The fear Kolbur felt became a physical weight that sank his heart into his stomach.
Grateful for the silence, the messenger continued his report.
“Of those with the wife, there were humans with incredible power.
A single fire mage could conjure a fireball grander than any fire elemental or multitude of minums.
Its flame clings to all it touches like cold oil and burns with the heat of a refiner’s fire.
Almost our entire elite squad was killed by only one of her attacks.
Even our fire mages could not resist its heat.”
A palpable darkness hung over the room as if a stormcloud had covered the sun and blocked the light from shining through the crystalline window.
The light still shined, and the shattered rainbows still danced, but no one saw them.
“Another man,” the messenger continued, causing shocked faces to rise as if saying, “There’s more?”
“Despite being human, he is a time mage.
Captain Byurk could not harm him, even when the man was terribly injured.
He fears this man could become as powerful or is already as powerful as our Commanding General.”
General Lamek was the only man at the table who managed to keep his composure, being the most veteran of the Generals present.
“Do you have an estimate of their numbers?”
“We do not, but Captain Byurk believes there are only few at present.
He feels this might not be unlike our initial efforts to capture the princess, sending small numbers to assess the situation before a much larger force is brought.
With this belief as an anchor, Captain Byurk has challenged the widow to battle in Vallen.
He worded the challenge such that the dryads would not be involved, but I do not know if the wife will keep such an agreement.”
“Do you have any confidence that the wife will meet him in battle?
Could she not take her dryad forces and those from the other world and attempt to reclaim Amel?”
“Byurk has the time mage in his custody, and from how the negotiations played out, this man is of great importance, enough to force the widow to action.
Captain Byurk is confident that she will meet him in battle to reclaim him.
If she does not, the man’s life is forfeit once the campaign in Vallen ends.
The dryad shaman charged with his care and recovery has agreed to this and will provide the means for Captain Byurk to end his life.”
Silence fell on the room.
General Lamek sat down and crossed his arms pensively on the table.
“Is that the end of your report?”
“Yes, but I can answer questions if you have them.”
General Lamek shook his head.
“If we have questions, we will send it to you in writing.
Lieutenant Kolbur, escort him to the parlor and wait there.
We will be discussing confidential information from here.”
As Kolbur expected, the moment the messenger mentioned humans from the other world, he knew something happened.
They became far too attentive far too quickly.
He desperately wanted to be part of the meeting, but as a lieutenant, it was not his place, no matter how his dread-filled curiosity yearned for it.
He saluted to General Lamek and led the messenger out the large redwood door, closing it behind him.

* * *
“Do you think Captain Byurk’s messenger is credible?” a captain across from General Lamek asked everyone present.
“Given the emergency communication from Commanding General Jethro, it is likely,” Lamek replied, feeling the unease of his own words twitching on the corners of his mustache.
“Then you also feel the two are connected,” General Pelette mumbled from beside Lamek, and those who heard nodded.
It seemed all who were present made the connection.
“First Jethro’s voice appears and tells us the siege of the otherworld city has failed, and now this.”
“In all my time in our Commanding General’s service, I have never heard him so panicked, so afraid,” the only captain who was present during the message replied from the end of the table.
“I cannot help but feel we have disturbed a chimera’s nest.”
“Part of me worries that in his own fear, the messenger may have exaggerated many of the details,” General Pelette accused.
For humans to hold such magical power was not easy to believe.
“And if he wasn’t?” Lamek countered.
“We all know the power of our Commanding General.
Who is to say that more humans with similar strength could not exist?
This becomes more plausible if they are not from Tolmyur or even Whinhlem.”
“But I thought the humans of the other world could not use magic,” one of the captains asked.
“That is what makes this all the less believable,” General Pelette chided.
“General Pelette, you were not present during Captain Fect’s report before the siege on the city in the other world.
The doppelganger learned that those humans are capable of magic.
The princess was personally training the civilians closest to her.
Perhaps magic is not taught to the common folk, so none of the citizens could make use of it.
If soldiers or other special operatives are trained in the art, that would explain why those Captain Byurk encountered, those sent to our world to aid the wife, could use it.
Their incredible skill gives this theory further credibility.”
“What do we do with this knowledge and the plan Captain Byurk has constructed?” the youngest General asked.
“The most dangerous part of disturbing a chimera’s nest is not knowing its strengths or abilities.
If the other world is far stronger than our Commanding General assumed, do we even have the strength to defend against it?”
“Should we return our armies to Amel and prepare for a defense against the wife and her force of dryads,” General Bregon suggested, his deep voice reverberating and echoing through the hall.
Everyone weighed his suggestion in their minds.
As the second most senior of the generals, every suggestion General Bregon made was always taken under careful consideration.
He would not have spoken without having thoroughly scrutinized every pro and con, but something in Lamek’s war instinct told him such a proposal was doomed to fail.
He just couldn’t find why he felt so.
While the generals and captains entertained General Bregon’s drastic idea, Lamek pondered on every word in Captain Byurk’s message.
Lamek found the string that tied the plan together.
Perhaps Jethro was correct in placing such trust in Byurk.
Captain Byurk’s plot was genius.
It was still based on a fair bit of assumption, but having experienced firsthand the power of those supporting the widow, Byurk would know best his probability of success.
Lamek now knew why he had sent a messenger back to Amel with the precise message he bore.
“No, General Bregon,” Lamek interrupted, silencing the discussion.
“Recalling our forces now would seal our destruction at the hands of the combined forces of the dryads, fairies, and the armies of the other world.
The widow knows Jethro cannot help us in this fight.
Because she is receiving help from the other world, she may know better than us what happened to our Commanding General.”
“Are you saying that our Commanding General is lost?” General Pelette asked with a troubled face.
Jethro was the hope of all Tolmyur, and there were none at the table who would want to believe for even a moment that Jethro was killed.
“I cannot say, but Captain Byurk’s plan was made with the knowledge that we would not be able to receive Commanding General Jethro’s aid.
I fully support Captain Byurk’s plan.
Fighting in Vallen gives us our best chance of victory.”
Whispers and conversations grew in the hall but were quickly silenced by the deep voice of General Bregon.
“What reason have you found?”
“It relies heavily on what Captain Byurk saw, but the underlying reason is the number of otherworlders currently on Whinhlem.”
General Bregon’s face grew stiff and then the light of epiphany lit in his eyes.
“I support Captain Byurk’s plan.”
Frustrated conversations erupted once more.

All but the two most senior Generals felt that fortifying their defenses in Amel was the best way to weather the coming storm in the absence of their Commanding General, but neither General Lamek nor General Bregon would back down.
Captain Byurk had provided them not only the best means of survival but also a swift victory over the remnants clinging to the former Amelian Empire.

* * *
Tolmyur’s armies numbered half a million strong.
King Azen relinquished half of their total strength for Jethro’s assault on Amel and to solidify their hold on the fallen capital.
This severely weakened their homeland, but revenge against the elves was a dream every soul in Tolmyur held dear, and no one questioned the risk.
And should the army fall, it could be rebuilt quickly through conscription.
Of the nearly 250 thousand stationed in the Amelian Empire, about half was given by Jethro to Captain Byurk to search Vallen for the fleeing wife and to quell any fairy resistance.

The aggression and tenacity of the fairies led to a flash genocide campaign, costing nearly 50 thousand of Captain Byurk’s men before he was forced to return to Amel to recover from an assassination attempt.

With nearly 80 thousand still fighting in Vallen under the acting captain, Lieutenant Soppet, General Lamek planned to send an additional 60 thousand to aid Captain Byurk in his battle against the wife.
“This won’t be enough,” General Bregon said, looking over the many tents from atop the outer walls of Amel.
Behind him the faint cries of the city drifted through the breeze as the soldiers claimed what little remaining food stores the impoverished former capital held.
Deep down, he wished they could purge the city of elves so that the soldiers could claim it for themselves, but his Commanding General wanted the city to suffer.
A swift death like the fairies’ was too kind a punishment.
Even with their current seizure of food, the city was better than many in Tolmyur.
“Not enough manpower, and not enough food,” General Lamek agreed.
Captain Byurk’s message was a call for reinforcements.
Even though the fairies lost much of their formal army in their failed attempt to reclaim Amel, their numbers were still formidable.
The genocide campaign forced the fairies to turn every able body into a combatant, men, women, and also children.
Even without proper military training, their overwhelming numbers led to many losses.
“Are we making the right choice,” Lamek mumbled, questioning his decision.
“Your judgement was correct,” General Bregon affirmed.
“If what the messenger said is true, if what Captain Byurk has seen is true, then there are currently few otherworlders on Whinhlem.
If we do not strike now, we have no hope.
The weakened Vallen will prove an advantageous battleground.

The proximity of the final fairy cities to Melia and the rate of extermination under Lieutenant Soppet will prevent the widow from rallying the dryads, or at least many of them, the Melians and Itians at most.
She will not have the time.
If she delays in her arrival, the war in Vallen will end and her important companion’s life is forfeit.
If we fell back to Amel, she would have time to rally the fairies and dryads, and there will be ample time for more otherworlders to arrive.
If the soldiers in their armies are as individually powerful as those Captain Byurk encountered, we would lose, and they could strike back against Tolmyur.”
“If we can defeat the widow there, the other world will have less incentive to get involved.
The fairies will be extinguished.
The dryads will lose their benefactor and submit once again to us.
Our claim on Amel and victory over the Amelian Empire will be assured.”
Lamek rested his hands on the crenel and looked down at the gateway below where two soldiers pulled a handcart of grain towards the encampment.
“But that depends heavily on our victory.
Seeing the supplies we have now and the men we can safely send without weakening our hold on Amel, I worry we will still lose.”
“I have been thinking on this, and I feel I have a solution.
I had the chef staff work on it throughout the morning, and it should be finished.
Follow me.”
General Bregon led Lamek back through the main streets of Amel to the palace.
The wide, white-brick roads were active with soldiers breaking into homes to take any non-perishable food they could find and add to their handcarts.
Angry cries and protests of the citizens went unanswered, and those who rose to defend their homes were quickly disposed of and tossed into the street as a message to all who saw.

The handcarts kept a wide breadth from General Bregon and Lamek, and the soldiers who pulled them nodded their heads in respect to their superior officers, being unable to remove their hands from the carts.

Inside the palace, General Bregon led Lamek back to the dining hall and through the servant’s passageways to the kitchen where four distraught spriggans sat on simple stools or on the floor against the far wall.
A viscous, clear liquid with a faint green tint covered their white aprons.
Neither of them lifted their heads to acknowledge the giant and dwarf’s presence.
“Have you finished?” General Bregon asked, his deep voice causing the two women sitting on the stools to cower, but no one answered.
Lamek found the posture of the two men against the wall odd.
He walked over and inspected the bodies, finding them dead.
There was no physical injury, but neither of them had a pulse.
There were no signs of strangulation or visible aftereffects of poison.
He kicked one of them to the ground and stepped on his chest.
Water seeped from the chef’s mouth onto the rough stone floor.
A spriggan chef was bound to have a water affinity.
The two spriggans drowned themselves.
“What order did you give these chefs?” Lamek asked.
General Bregon grabbed the arm of one of the petite women who had an odd silver mark between her brows, possibly a symbol of status or religion that he did not know.
He lifted her to eye level letting her dangle in the air so that she had no choice but to look at him.
“Have you finished,” he repeated, releasing her to the ground.
Tears fell from the woman’s eyes, and she nodded.
“Show me.”
The two spriggans rushed out of the kitchen to the storage room and returned with a plain wooden platter.
Various types of what looked like diced or dried vegetable were arranged on top.
“Is it safe to eat?”
The two chefs nodded slowly.
“Show me.”
Terror grew on the two women’s faces.
Lamek thought at first that their fear was due to adding poison or other ill ingredients to the food prepared for the general, but his intuition told him otherwise.
Why did the two male chefs kill themselves after preparing the dish?
They would not have done so if it was simply poisoned.
General Bregon grabbed one of the chefs by the hair and pushed her face into the platter.
“Eat it!”
The spriggan grabbed a cube of the diced vegetable with her trembling hand and placed it in her mouth.
Tears streamed down her cheeks as she chewed it and swallowed.
The other chef, unable to hold her stomach, vomited on the floor.
General Bregon held the spriggan to prevent her from taking any unnecessary action.
After waiting in tense silence, no ill effects surfaced, but when he released her, she sat down on the floor and placed her hands to her mouth.
Water and mucus shot from her nose from the high-pressure water magic.
She fought to contain her coughs and spasms until she too fell to her side having drowned.
“What vegetable is this?” Lamek asked.
“Why would these chefs kill themselves?”
“It’s dryad,” General Bregon finally replied.
He grabbed a cube of diced dryad and tossed it in his mouth.
His raised eyebrow showed that the flavor may not have been all too unpleasant.
“The quickest way to the final fairy cities is through Dhuillir.
Dryads are plants, just like any other.
We can conscript the dryads still faithful to Tolmyur.
Those who rebel we know have sided with the widow.
We can use them to feed our armies.”
General Bregon grabbed the final chef by the arm and pushed her towards the supply room.
“Bring the rest.”
The chef staggered off and around the corner out of sight.
“Where did you find a dryad,” Lamek asked, tossing a cube into his mouth.
The texture was fibrous, and the flavor was slightly bitter but palatable, better tasting than most army field rations.
He could easily see this being a viable food source.
“As you know, one of the strengths of the dryads is in their ability to move almost unnoticed in nature should they choose to do so.
The gardeners of the palace were replaced by dryads a year ago when some strange disease caused most of the plants on the palace grounds to wilt and blacken.
The high and mighty elves were not strong enough alone to combat the disease, so they summoned dryads.
Most our soldiers did not notice they were living among us.
I did not until recently, as terrifying as that prospect is.
Had the emperor more forethought, he could have trained them as secret guards instead of gardeners.”
“But how did they cook them?
Any fire and dryads ignite like dry kindling.”
“That is what I am here to discover.”
The chef returned dragging a burlap sack.
Lamek could tell immediately that it contained bodies, or parts of bodies, from how the coarse fabric bulged.
General Bregon retrieved the sack from the spriggan and dumped the contents onto the table.
The dismembered limbs and sectioned torsos of two unused dryads spilt onto the table and floor.
The life sap of the dryads left the body parts sticky, and strings of sap bridged between them and the sack as he tossed it aside.
“Explain how to prepare them,” General Bregon ordered.
The chef quivered and grabbed a knife.
She demonstrated how to carve the meat on the limbs from the tough, fibrous cores that made up the skeletal structure.
The torsos were of little use with how little meat was on the typically lithe dryads, so only the arms and legs could be salvaged.
The only feasible way to eat a dryad was raw or boiled, but once boiled a water mage could extract the moisture to preserve it, creating a texture not unlike jerky.
Extracting moisture without boiling hardened the flesh like wood, making it inedible, and no amount of boiling could return it to something palatable.
This was all General Bregon and Lamek needed to know.
Preparation was simple enough to perform on the march, and dried dryad was incredibly light.
“You are a genius,” Lamek complimented with a pat on General Bregon’s leg as they walked out of the kitchen.
“With this, we have a chance.
I wish I could join you in the battle.”
General Bregon grunted.
“I cannot understand the dwarven obsession with the honor of battle.
You oversee Amel in our Commanding General’s absence.
There could be no greater honor.
Do not fret.
I will bring us victory in Vallen.”
Once the Tolmyur commanders walked out of sight, the final chef slit her throat with her knife.

Chapter 4
“The Real Monster”
Byurk
“Byurk, we must stop the march.
He is growing worse.”
Tyree wove nimbly through the trees of the steep slope to the right of the hillside path to reach Captain Byurk who led the march.
The nine soldiers glared at the dryad as she passed.
This was the fourth time that day she had requested the march be stopped.
Byurk grumbled within himself as his hand reached for his blade.
He contemplated how he could kill the dryad to end her incessant pestering on their prisoner’s behalf.
If her life magic could overpower his earth magic, perhaps water magic or rigid steel might work.
He complied with her first request earlier in the morning when they had space to stop, but the path they followed was now more ravine than glen.
His men marched single file through the slick mud, ever conscious of the steep four-meter decline to their left that ended in a rocky stream.
This was no place for a break.
“Then heal him,” Byurk ordered.
“I thought you dryads were proficient with these things.”
Tyree slid down the steep embankment in front of Byurk and walked backwards in front of him following his pace with incredible perception of where she placed each step.
“I thought I did, but the symptoms have resurfaced far stronger than before.
Unless I take time to thoroughly investigate the cause, I fear we may not be able to uphold our end of the agreement.”
Return him in good health…
Byurk regretted his poor wording in his agreement with the widow of the emperor.
A hostage, a prisoner, should never be treated as a priority charge.
If the otherworlder succumbed to illness despite the dryad’s efforts to heal him, Byurk felt a breach of their agreement was justified.
His death would have been out of their control.
It would even be beneficial to their upcoming battle by having one less otherworlder present, especially if this man was equivalent to Jethro in ability.
“We will clear the Mailan Hills and enter Vallen if we continue through the night.
If he survives until then, you can investigate his condition thoroughly.”
Tyree stopped walking, forcing Byurk and the rest of this men to halt.
“He may not last that long without proper treatment.
You ignored my last two requests to stop, and his symptoms are worsening at a much greater pace.”
Byurk’s grip on his blade tightened.
“Then do something about it while we march.
I thought you were one of the best shamans in all of Melia.
Was that a lie?
Or perhaps you are purposely stalling us to provide the widow ample time to prepare for battle.
I thought you despised her manipulation of the Melians as much as I did.”
When Tyree could not answer, he pushed her aside into the embankment and continued the march.
Thick briers grew from the path in front, rising to his height and preventing passage.
Byurk turned to see Tyree digging her hand into the soil of the embankment.
He drew his sword, and his men who were not holding the stretcher followed.
“You overstep your freedoms, dryad!
We are close enough to Vallen that we no longer need you as a guide.
I am not against ending you here and letting fate decide whether that man lives or dies.”
