Tyree retracted her hands and shook off the dirt and mud.
“You lost your fire mages, and this forest is blooming with life.
You had best hope you can remove my head, because little else will kill a dryad quickly.
I am only here to make certain the battle happens and the war ends.
So long as this man survives, Lady Ceil has stake in the agreement and will uphold her side.
You and your men are not important to the agreement.
I am not against killing you all and taking him to Vallen myself.
We are still in Melia.
I can find dryads to assist me in your place.”
Byurk sheathed his sword.
If this was a bluff, it was a convincing bluff.
She had skill in the medical aspects of life magic which meant she could harm just as well as she could heal, and she had both bound him easily and restricted his earth magic in the past.
He did not know her strength in combat, but there was little doubt in his mind that some of his men would die if he ordered the attack, especially with their limited mobility in the narrow terrain.
“Remove the briers.
We will continue the march.
If at any time the path widens and has stable enough footing, we will rest long enough for you to investigate the otherworlder’s illness.
Is this agreeable?”
Tyree dug her hands into the soil, and the briers flattened to the ground, wilted, and buried themselves into the mud.
The agitation of the soil from the briers made the path far slicker, but the dead plants beneath the mud created a mesh that allowed them to cross so long as they stepped flat-footed.
The march continued.
Tyree tried to investigate the otherworlder’s illness, but the narrow path made this difficult.
She could not stand beside the stretcher for long because of the trees and brush along the slope, and she could not reach him from in front or behind the soldiers carrying the stretcher.
Byurk had to wonder why Tyree suggested this ill-fated path that disadvantaged her aid of the otherworlder.

They could have backtracked to the main road the army had widened and followed it to Vallen far more comfortably, and it would have enabled her to treat the otherworlder through the march, even if it took longer.
Then again, she could not have known he would grow ill with a sudden mysterious sickness.
The otherworlder’s health was suspect from the start.
The widow brought him to Melia to find him treatment.
He was sick to a degree that Tyree called him a living corpse.
Even after treatment, he was weak and rarely woke.
Now the ailment plaguing him was growing worse, and one of the self-proclaimed best shamans in Melia did not know the cause.
Byurk wanted so desperately to dump him in the forest and be done.

While Byurk entertained this thought, possibly telling Tyree to find those Melians she claimed she could ask to carry him so that he and his soldiers could rejoin the conflict in Vallen much faster, he heard the light roar of water.
The mud path reached a small, waterfall-fed spring.
It was located down the steep embankment, but there appeared to be weathered stone steps.
Beside the spring sat a barren oval altar covered in moss with enough flat, dry stone for his men to rest.
Byurk groaned within himself.
He could argue that because it was not on the path, they did not need to stop, but he knew Tyree would complain to no end.
“We rest here while Tyree cares for the otherworlder,” he announced.
He descended the steep decline first, widening and hardening the crumbling stone steps as he walked to ensure the safety of his men.
The slightly elevated, circular stone platform the altar sat on was clearly elven in make, or at least embellished by elven hands, but its purpose eluded him.
He felt damaged ven channels through the stone, so perhaps there was some enchantment upon it that was now useless.
It was long abandoned, and any markings that may have been there to reveal its purpose had long eroded away.
The spring looked clear, but before he gave his men permission to drink, he placed his hand in the water and used water magic to assess the purity.
“The water is clean.
Take advantage of this rest, because we will be marching through the night.”
The two soldiers carrying the stretcher set it down atop the altar for convenience.
The poles hung slack on the sides, and the otherworlder’s legs dangled off the end.
Byurk sat by the spring and watched Tyree circle the unconscious man, placing her hand on various parts of his body from his head to his chest, stomach, and groin.
Each time she performed some investigation, she grew more and more confused and soon she began pacing around the altar pensively.
Now that Byurk had the leisure to see him, the otherworlder looked pale and was sweating heavily.
His breaths were shallow as if breathing deep agitated whatever pain tormented him.
He wondered if he could kill him now while Tyree was distracted.
At this point, it may be considered a mercy.
If it was just for the convenience of their march, there would be no point in killing him.
He already allowed the break, and from the look of his men, they were grateful for it.
He would need a better reason.
Tyree’s pacing ceased.
Her pointer finger hung on her lower lip, peeling it outward, as she looked down to the side at the unconscious man.
Her other hand reached for his forehead, and once it touched, she retracted it quickly as if she had placed it too close to a flame.
Tyree immediately dropped to her knees and placed her forehead against his, and after a few seconds, she broke away and scooted back in shock.
“What did you find?” Byurk asked, the stench of foreboding entering his nostrils.
“Have you found the cause of the illness?”
“Yes…” Tyree hesitated.
“There is a rare condition among elves.
I did not think to check for it at first.
It is separate from the physical body, but its effects can be just as deadly as any illness.”
Byurk’s anticipation angered him.
“Speak! What is it?”
“When the body absorbs ven, those with this illness process it wrong, and it becomes toxic.
This man has no more healthy ven in his body.
It is all poison.
He continues to absorb more, but the excess poisonous ven cannot escape.
It is building and killing him.
To my knowledge, there is no cure.
I did not know humans could have it, and this is my first time seeing someone with a case as severe as I see here.”
The stench of foreboding dissipated and was replaced by sweet relief.
This was terrific news.
“If he cannot be cured, kill him and be done.”
“The illness has no cure, but the effects can be mitigated.
However…” Tyree approached the altar and placed her hand on the man’s forehead, immediately retracting it again the moment she touched.
“A very large ven capacity is a common side effect of the illness, but there is no excuse for this.”
Byurk’s anxiety crept over him once again.
“What do you mean?” he asked slowly, tasting each word.
His soldiers were now attentively listening to the discussion.

“To mitigate the effects, all the toxic ven must be expelled, but then clean ven needs to replace it immediately or his health will worsen, and in his weakened state from his prolonged injury and malnutrition, any hesitation could kill him.”
Tyree’s explanation did not explain what there was “no excuse for.”
It sounded like a matter of course.
The otherworlder was weak and needed his ven replaced.
“Use your ven and let us continue our march.”
Tyree shook her head, and as Byurk suspected, there was more.
“I will not be enough.”
Byurk grew confused.
All elfkind were supposed to be far superior to humans in ven capacity.
Many surpassed his fellow minums.
Even if the ven cost of her investigation was exorbitant, he did not doubt any dryad of her age and skill would be able to replenish the average human’s ven many times over with much to spare.
Then again, this was not an average human.
“How large is his capacity,” Byurk asked, fearing the answer.
“Even if we use the ven of all present here, he will not escape the critical levels, and he may still die.
Our only choice is to find a Melian village and use all their ven, and then we might only be close to safety.”
An entire dryad village, and only then just barely safe?
How powerful is this human?
Jethro had an incredible ven capacity, and Byurk suspected that it was much larger than any elf, but he had seen Jethro exhaust his ven on multiple occasions, especially in the Coastal War.
Jethro was human, a talented and gifted human, but human nonetheless.
This otherworlder was a monster.
Byurk stomped his foot into the altar platform, and Tyree barely yanked the otherworlder off the altar before a large spike shot up.
“Men, use any means necessary!
Kill the otherworlder!”
Unlike the forest path, Byurk was in his element at the spring.
There was plenty of stone and water with very little vegetation besides small water plants and moss.
His earth magic was of the school of manipulation, so he needed stone or soil to use it, but he was both a conjurer and manipulator of water, his dominant element.
The spring and damp air were powerful weapons at his disposal.
Of his soldiers, he had one earth mage, one water mage--both conjurers who did not need the spring or stone to fight--and seven swordsmen.
Without vegetation, the dryad could not hope to protect that monster.
In desperation for a weapon, Tyree grabbed the poles of the stretcher that fell to the sides of the altar when the folded leather lost the support of the otherworlder’s weight.
She deflected the first sword thrust at her using the pole in her left hand, but the edge of the blade slid deep into her left arm at the elbow.
The wound would have been debilitating for an elf, ridding them of the use of their arm, but Byurk knew such a wound was trivial to a dryad and would heal quickly.
While Tyree was distracted by the first swordsman and the spikes of ice flying at her from the water mage, Byurk stomped his heel into the stone again.
He could not see the otherworlder on the other side of the altar, but he knew he was there by what he sensed through the altar’s stone platform.
His earth ven traveled and formed the spike that would end him, but the spike was restricted.
There were no plants with strong roots she could use to resist his magic.
The second pole in Tyree’s right hand--she never used it to defend and kept it angled down to where the otherworlder lay.
When Tyree grew roots from the end of the pole in her left hand to snare the swordsman’s wrist and wrench the sword from his grip, Byurk found his answer.
Tyree was in charge of the otherworlder, so she was always with the stretcher when they rested for the night.
Unknown to him, she had nourished the poles as conduits for her life magic.
The wood was full of life.
She remained disadvantaged, but she was not as defenseless as Byurk had originally suspected.
“Push her back towards the stream away from the otherworlder!”
His two mages circled to the embankment so that their magic might force Tyree towards the stream.
The disarmed swordsman broke free of the roots binding his wrist and stepped back so that two others could take his place.
A single branch grown from the left pole snared the handle of the fallen sword and brandished it like a multi-jointed third arm.
The single branch held back one swordsman while she used the pole to defend against the second.
The mages became more cautious with their attacks to prevent friendly fire, but their accuracy was fitting for elite soldiers hand-selected by Byurk.
A stone spike impaled Tyree’s left knee through the gap between one swordsman’s legs.
An ice spike shattered on Tyree’s immobile right arm that held its vice grip on the pole protecting the otherworlder.
Byurk stomped forward and thrust his palms as if pushing a heavy object.
The Altar fractured and toppled over on the otherworlder.
He checked quickly through the stone with the hope that some of the large fragments of stone had crushed him.
There was perhaps a broken arm and leg, but something supported the bulk of the weight of the altar to protect his torso and head, likely more roots.
There was something else Byurk sensed through the stone.
Something long and thin stretched just beneath the altar platform towards the embankment.
“Get away from the embankment!”
Thick briers shot out of the soft soil and ensnared the two mages.
They wrapped tight around their arms, legs, and neck, shredding the light leather armor and flesh.
Two awaiting swordsmen rushed to the mages’ aid, but one of them was quickly ensnared as well.
He needed to separate Tyree from the pole in her right hand.
Byurk channeled his ven through the moisture in the air until it condensed just in front of Tyree.
He conjured an enormous volume of water and expelled it as a geyser facing the stream and rocky cliffside behind her.
The two swordsmen backed away to avoid the high-pressure attack.
Tyree impaled her left pole into the stone to help hold her in place.
Roots gathered and bound her hands to support her grip.
Byurk’s ven was draining quickly due to the sheer volume of water he was conjuring.
He did not doubt that Tyree had more to spare, and despite her struggle against the torrent, the vines continued shredding deep and messy cuts into three of his men at the embankment.
At least Tyree was distracted enough to prevent her from ensnaring those trying to free them.
One brave swordsman dove beneath the geyser and thrust his sword into Tyree’s stomach.
While not fatal to a dryad, it would weaken her as her life sap drained.
The force of the geyser caught him and sent him tumbling over the crumbled altar into the ravine’s stream, but he crawled out alive albeit heavily battered.
Three of Byurk’s men were ensnared and probably mortally wounded.
Another was heavily damaged from Byurk’s own attack.
Byurk could not keep the geyser active for much longer.
With only swordsmen remaining, once his ven ran out, they had no hope of defeating Tyree.
He had learned that the older the dryad, the more powerful she became.
Tyree was not bluffing when she proclaimed she could kill him and all his men.
While keeping focus on the hand channeling ven to fuel the geyser, Byurk ran across the surface of the spring to the waterfall.
He placed his free hand on the stone and channeled most of his remaining ven through the rocky cliff, spring, and waterfall.
The waterfall ceased and the spring began to drain.
The rocky face creaked from pressure, and when Byurk could no longer hold it back, he cut off the geyser.
All the water he built up in the rock face exploded with the aid of earth magic.
The entire cliff face blew out as boulders, large stones, and mud rained upon the crumbled alter.
The heavy earth buried Tyree and the otherworlder.
Byurk ran back across the now shallow spring to the altar platform.
He jumped and pounded his fists into the stone when he landed.
The entire platform sank two feet.
He repeated, shredding the skin on his knuckles.
After a third strike, the platform fell beneath the water table and quickly filled with water.
After the fourth, what once would have been the crumbled alter was now submerged.
Byurk knew little about a dryad’s constitution, but the water-soaked earth would both crush and suffocate the otherworlder.
Byurk’s neck was just above the water, and he lacked the ven to walk across it.
The muddy water stung his bleeding hands.
His body shook, and he could barely climb up to the stony bank of the stream.
Two of his soldiers reached down and grabbed his arms, yanking him up with pure admiration in their eyes.
What they just witnessed was no small feat of magic.
Byurk looked back at his desperate attack.
The entire waterfall and cliff face was no more.
The spring that fed the waterfall trickled through the crumbling stone.
The stream of the ravine that also fed the pool continued filling the large depression Byurk made as it worked its way around the earthen mound.
The soldier who got caught in his geyser was buried along with the dryad and otherworlder, and Byurk’s heart ached for the valiant young life he extinguished.
The three soldiers who were ensnared had been freed, but as he expected, the briers that bound their necks had cut them to the bone.
They were lost.
Nine elite soldiers versus a single elder dryad in favorable conditions for him and his soldiers, and this was the result.
As powerful as that dryad was, a single otherworlder eliminated most of his taskforce in a single attack, not just a few of his men over the course of a fight like with what happened here.
The loss of his men was a necessary sacrifice to kill an otherworlder.
They had no time to mourn the fallen.
Death was a part of war.
“Are you fit to travel?”
Byurk’s five swordsmen stared at him with steeled faces.
“Good.
We leave for Vallen.”

Chapter 5
“The Otherworlder”
Tyree
Tyree’s lips pressed firmly against Justin’s.
Water seeped into the soil and rock quickly with the sudden dropping of the altar platform.
If he did not receive air, he would drown.
The roots of Tyree’s conduit supported the heaviest of the boulders, but the pressure of the ever-thickening mud was unbearable.
Inhaling was difficult, and unless she resisted the crushing pressure on her lungs, the force of her exhale could also harm him.
Dryads breathed what other species exhaled, and other species breathed what dryads exhaled.
This was known to dryads but unknown to most others.
So long as they breathed into each other, they could survive, but this was not a permanent solution.
Without sunlight, Tyree’s breaths would grow weaker, and while dryads could survive long without breathing, humans could not.
She needed to do something before then.
She needed to rescue this man and return him to Ceil.
If not, Ceil could flee the battle and the war would not end.
If the war did not end, the false hamadryad would remain and divide Dhuillir.

Although she tried to rally the village against her, Tyree knew that without fire, the strength of an entire village could not kill a hamadryad if the hamadryad did not desire death, and fire could not be brought unless there were none who were under the hamadryad’s influence that could protect her.
The hamadryad’s promise to die when the war ended was Dhuillir’s only hope, and a swift end depended on this man’s survival.
Still, Justin’s chances were bleak.
Tyree gripped the conduit tight.
Little life remained in the pole, and she did not know the location of the second.
She released it to quickly cover the man.
It had to be close.
She had only used it to defend herself, so its remaining life should be much higher than the one she held.
If she used all the remaining life of the conduit she still grasped, the roots binding the boulders together and supporting their weight would grow brittle.
If the roots broke, they would both be crushed almost instantly.
If she could not find the other pole, her hope for escape was gone.
After waiting as long as she dared for Byurk to depart, Tyree sent a single thin shoot up through the rubble to sprout out the top of the pile and grow a large leaf, a beacon for help.
She then spread out roots from her pole to search the surface of the altar platform for the second staff.
Each root spread and branched into two or three more roots.
The life remaining in the rod grew low, and when the heavy soil shifted from the weakening roots, she stopped.
She could no longer use the rod for fear of collapse.
She did not find the second rod.
The cascading rocks and soil must have knocked it further away.
She had no more options.
The pressure grew into a dull ache, and she knew the human would be in far more pain.
Her breaths became short as claustrophobia set in.
Panic spread through every thought and emotion, and were it not for the heavy pressure assaulting her from every angle, her body would be shivering uncontrollably.
Only the man under her arm and the feeling on her lips kept her mind from breaking.
She kept breathing through the muffled cries she made with every exhale.
Tyree had lived a long life.
She had mothered two wonderful daughters who were the pride of her life.
She knew there was a possibility of death when she agreed to join Ceil’s companion in captivity.
She was prepared for death when she stood against the false hamadryad’s authority to try and convince the villagers.
She was ready for death when she stood against Byurk to protect Justin.
But, she was not prepared to be buried alive, slowly crushed to death.
All dryads had a natural fear of being underground, away from sunlight, and that fear only worsened when it came to being buried.
The weight of the boulders shifted again, adding more pressure.
Tyree’s cry became a scream.
The boulder’s shifted again, and the weight of one crushed her wrist holding the rod.
When they shifted again, she could no longer feel her hand, and her ven no longer flowed to it.
The boulders shifted, and Tyree’s cries ceased.
This was how she would die.
The altar platform tremored beneath her, and the pressure lessened.
After a second tremor and further shifting of the rocks and boulders, the pressure grew bearable.
Gradually, Tyree could move in the thick mud.
Something reached in and touched her back.
Another pair of hands dug into the mud and wrapped around her waist to hoist her up, but Tyree clung to the human beneath her with her arm.
If she separated from him, the mud could enter his lungs.
More hands reached in, found Justin, and hoisted them both out together.
Mud filled Tyree’s eyes when she opened them.
It stung, but there was light.
A hand wiped her face and eyes, and she saw a Melian crouching in front of her.
Justin was draped across another’s knees as a Melian emptied his mouth of mud and water.
Tyree reached across and touched the young girl’s chest and then cheek to assure herself the girl was real.
She wrapped her arm around the girl and drew her in, burying her face into her neck.
Tyree sat against one of the boulders that were cast aside.
Her right hand was gone, having been severed at the wrist.
Her left leg was broken but slowly mending; however, her right leg was crushed from just above her knee down to her foot.
The severity of the damage was unhealable.
She would need to amputate it and let it regrow like her hand, and that would take a season or two.
Justin fared better.
He was breathing.
A little water entered his lungs, most of it from her breath and saliva.
His left leg had a mild fracture.
The worst of the damage was his left arm.
It broke in three places under the weight of the altar.
“What happened here,” the young girl asked.
Although she was young, not yet fifty years old by appearance, she was still the eldest of the four Melians.
The three soldiers Tyree ensnared were lined up beside the embankment, and the final soldier had been unburied and was being dragged by two of the Melians to the embankment next to them.
Without a source of air, he was not as lucky.
“This man is important to the war,” Tyree explained, looking at Justin in the final Melian’s care.
“These soldiers tried to kill him.
I must bring him to Vallen.”
“I have done what I can aside from his arm, but he is not recovering,” the young shaman announced.
Justin was ill with ven poisoning and needed immediate treatment.
After enduring the avalanche, he would be considerably weakened, and the poison could kill him at any time.
“Where is your village?
I need your help.”
Three of the girls were needed to carry Justin due to his weight.
They climbed up the destroyed waterfall to the ridge above and continued through the forest.
Tyree hung her arm around Tae’s shoulder, the eldest girl, striking a mild conversation as they walked.
The girls had heard the avalanche from a distance and came to investigate out of curiosity and boredom.
When they saw the large leaf atop the fresh pile of stone and soil, they knew a dryad lay buried underneath.
The village was rather close, but what surprised Tyree was its size.
The small clearing in the forest surrounded a rocky outcrop with a single small tree growing on top.
The villagers either sat around the tree or against the outcrop weaving grass and leaves together or singing quietly.
There were no elderly or young children.
The youngest girl had many hemma dotting her hair, but some of the petals fell while Tyree watched.
Some of the flowers were wilting, a sign that she had recently given birth, but because there was no child, her daughter may have been stillborn or died as an infant.
The other girls were between twenty to one hundred years of age, and there were only fifteen of them, or probably sixteen.
This was a new village, and villages were usually seeded with twenty young dryads, at least in Melia.
This was terrible news.
Tyree expected that at least fifty dryads would be needed to restore enough of Justin’s ven, but twenty was better than none.
She would need to keep close watch on him to make sure he lived long enough for his ven to naturally replenish.
Tae set Tyree down at the base of the outcrop, and the three who carried Justin laid him down beside her.
The girl nimbly hopped up the outcrop to the eldest appearing Melian and explained the situation.
Tyree rubbed the aching stubs of her leg and wrist while she waited.
The woman, rather young for a matriarch, jumped off the outcrop and rolled on the ground when she landed.
She twitched and shook her ankle lightly, probably having sprained it in the landing, and trotted over to Tyree with a smile.
“I am Preelen, the matriarch of this village.
I heard you need our ven.”
Preelen squatted down and prodded the man’s chest with her finger.
“I do.
This man has ven poisoning, so I must replace it.
His capacity puts all elfkind to shame, and your village may not be enough, but I have no other choice.”
Preelen grabbed the man’s broken arm, skillfully aligned the broken bones, and forcefully locked them together.
The grind of bone on bone was almost audible, and the pain would have been unbearable if he was awake.
She then scooted back and leaned down, pressing her forehead against his.
Immediately she pulled away and fell on her back.
“You weren’t joking!
Is he even human?”
“Sorry, but we do not have time.
He is so weak that if we do not act, the poison could kill him.”
Preelen stood and waved to her small village.
“You heard her!”
None of the other girls jumped off the embankment, choosing instead to climb down.
Those who sat at the base of the embankment walked over, some of them quizzically admiring the dirty man.
“Mind if I do it?” Preelen asked.
“You are not in fair condition yourself.”
“That would be much appreciated,” Tyree said.
“I will try to stabilize him until you can replace his ven, otherwise he might die once his ven is gone.”
“That would be reassuring.
Let’s do this,” Preelen called to her village.
The girl’s gathered behind their matriarch and placed their hands on her back and arms where able.
Preelen leaned down and placed her forehead against the man’s and held his shoulders with her hands in case he writhed.
Tyree dug her hand under his soaked and muddy shirt, cleared away the dirt, and rested her hand on his stomach.
Preelen took a deep breath.
“I’m starting.”
The man tensed up but did not writhe or wake.
His weak pulse grew erratic, and for a moment, his heart stopped.
Tyree jolted it to activity again and regulated it to the best of her ability, but the body quickly grew cold.
His ven was gone, and Tyree could almost taste the sheer volume of stagnant ven permeating the air.
Some of the girls sensed it too and grew uncomfortable, a few of them even shaking.
Toxic ven would normally dissipate quickly into the natural ven present in the air, but his capacity was so massive that it forced away all the natural ven in the vicinity like a puff of thick smoke.
The body relaxed, and if Tyree did not have a keen sense of his vitals, she would have thought him dead.
Soon warmth returned to his body and the matriarch separated from him.
“We were only about a single berry to a basket, but that’s all we could give.” She leaned back and sighed, shivering faintly from ven exhaustion.
“I thought I was going to be sick,” one of the younger girls remarked.
“What was that?”
“I absorbed some of it.”
“Me too.”
A few of the girls winced lightly as they purged the toxic ven from their bodies.
“You should have shut off your regeneration,” Preelen jeered with a smile as she lay back onto the sparsely grassy dirt.
“I didn’t think it would be that much.”
“Thank you,” Tyree said with a bow.
“He’s not out of the shade yet.
We’ll watch him while you rest and take care of yourself.
When my ven returns, I will finish mending his arm.”
“His leg is fractured as well.”
“And that.”
“Thank you.” Tyree bowed again to the young village.

* * *
Tyree sat against the small tree atop the outcrop to bask in as much sun as possible.
It was now setting below the surrounding hills, its low angle allowing the rays of light to avoid the canopy above her and bathe her in its glow.
A large shadow slowly crept towards her from the hills.
Once the sun set, she would need to change from sunbathing to meditation.
She snacked on roots and herb sprigs the village provided to help expedite her recovery.
A lot of nutrients were needed to regrow limbs, but even with plentiful nutrients, the process would take far longer than she had time to wait.
She needed to find a way to take Justin to Vallen, and with only one leg and hand, she could not do it alone.
“Feeling better?”
Preelen hopped up the edge of the outcrop and sat against the tree with her shoulder touching Tyree’s.
“Yes, thanks to you.”
Preelen placed her hand on the ground to grow the grass.
After breaking off a few blades, she began weaving them as she spoke.
“So, who is he and who were those soldiers I assume you killed?
I doubt many dryads would go through such lengths to save just any man.”
Her voice was less jovial than when Tyree arrived.
She was now acting the part of the village matriarch.
She aided Tyree without question, but now she demanded the explanation.
“He is a companion of Lady Ceil, widow of the late Emperor Yuro.
He is a human from another world who has agreed to aid her in this conflict.”
“Another world?
I guess that would explain why he is so different, even for a human.
His ven, body density, and all that.”
Tyree was glad Preelen did not question the most unbelievable part of her explanation.
“Lady Ceil currently travels to Vallen to join the fairies’ last stand against Tolmyur.
She agreed to the battle in exchange for his safe return, but afterwards the commander chose instead to kill him.”
Preelen set down her small, tightly woven bowl.
“And that is why you protected him.
If I understand correctly, with that man here, Lady Ceil has no reason to join a hopeless battle?
Do you know what road she travels?
I can send a few messengers after her.
It would be best that our empress not die so pointlessly.”
Judging by Preelen’s reply, she had not received any messengers from Melians supporting either Byurk or Ceil nor had she been informed of the false Grandmatriarch and that Ceil betrayed Dhuillir.
This was understandable for a new village.
Other villages would not know its location until it sent out its own messengers.
Village locations were never planned beforehand--the dryads who leave to seed a new village travel until they find a suitable location.
They would also not have aligned under the false Grandmatriarch until a messenger reached their village that was under her influence and could convert them.
With this good fortune, Tyree could act without the Hamadryad knowing.
“These humans from another world are powerful, and Lady Ceil hopes to use them to turn the tide of the conflict in Vallen.
I do not believe she would abandon her cause or deny the fairies the aid of these powerful individuals.
She needs this man’s power.
I must bring him to Vallen.”
“He was a prisoner, right?
If he is a strong as you claim, I can see why the soldiers tried to kill him while he was weakened by ven poisoning, but part of your story is still lacking.
As strong as a single individual can be, I find it hard to believe that he could turn the tide of the war.
I doubt our empress would be so foolish as to go to war relying on a single man for victory.
I also doubt she would agree to go to war solely for the return of this man unless he had some other major significance.
A lover perhaps?
Or maybe he is a prominent political or military figure from his world?”
Preelen rolled to her side and straddled Tyree with her arms.
She looked up into Tyree’s eyes with a regal maturity unfitting for her age.
Only now did Tyree realize this woman was like her, far older than her visible age suggested.
Bearing children aged a dryad quickly.
Perhaps she only had a single daughter or was one of the rare few who passed through her years as an anthousai without ever bearing a child until her excessive blossoms naturally wilted and fell.
“I ask again,” Preelen said with her unbroken gaze.
“Who is he?”
Tyree never gave in to intimidation, but the focused stare of the matriarch made her uncomfortable.
She needed this village’s help.
What could she say to convince her?
“Preelen!
He’s awake!” one of the girls called from the base of the outcrop.
“I suppose I can ask him myself.”
Preelen pushed to her feet, and after a short running start, jumped off the outcropping.
Tyree heard a thud from the bottom and a weak moan.
“You should stop doing that,” one of the girls at the bottom sighed.
Tyree used the trunk of the tree to help pull her to her foot.
She hopped to the edge, sat down, and slowly descended.
Preelen squatted in front of Justin while he sat, his weary eyes flitting between the Melians gawking at him.
Perhaps they had never seen a human before; most of them may have never even seen a male.
Tyree joined the gathering and sat on her one leg.
Justin looked at her, recognizing her from the fleeting moments he regained consciousness.

Now that Tyree saw him so attentive, she realized that all this time from the moment Ceil brought him to her village, the reason he never seemed to recover was due to the amount of toxic ven in his body.
Had she learned of his condition earlier, she could have cured him there in the central village or even at her own village.
Perhaps the events of that night would have gone differently or never happened at all, and the hamadryad would have never taken root.
“What is your name?” Preelen asked in Elven.
“Justin Hapfeld,” Justin replied, his eyes shifting, unsure where to look.
Slowly, his face grew flushed.
“Who are you?
Where are you from?” Preelen asked next.
“Sorry.
Not… I not… speak well.”
Preelen turned to Tyree, frustrated.
“Are we even going to be able to communicate like this?
How was he companions with Lady Ceil if he doesn’t speak Elven?”
“Lady Ceil is fluent in his native tongue.
She never spoke to them in Elven.”
“That helps us little…”
Preelen sat cross-legged and folded her arms.
Justin looked around and then behind him.
“Where Sammy?
Where Chloe?”
“And they are?” Preelen asked.
“Humans from his world,” Tyree explained.
“They should be with Ceil on their way to Vallen.”
“Minum…?” Justin asked.
“The minum is gone.
Minum not here,” Tyree assured Justin, hoping he would understand.
“Captain Byurk.
He was the commander who made the agreement with Lady Ceil and then ordered this man’s death,” she explained to Preelen.
Justin grabbed Preelen’s shoulder and pulled her to the side.
A large stone half the size of her head flew by her ear and bounced in the gap between her and the other Melians.
The girls jumped out of the way as it continued bouncing and rolling down the shallow hill.
“Sorry!” One of the younger village girls climbing down the outcrop to join the rest of the village had slipped and dislodged the large stone.
She ran to the group.
“Did it hit anyone?”
“No,” Preelen replied, her eyes as wide as the stone that nearly crushed her head.
Justin’s reaction speed was unnatural.
“That feeling…” She stared at Justin who was wincing in pain from applying pressure to his fractured leg.
The bone was mended, but there was other tissue damage that was left to heal naturally.
“He is a time mage,” Tyree explained.
“Without channel time?” Preelen laughed faintly to herself.
“Now it all makes sense!
Tyree, I believe your story.”
She stood and addressed her village as their matriarch.
“Those of you who are curious about humans or men, take him down to the stream and bathe him.
Everyone else, prepare for departure.”
All but three of the eldest villagers lifted Justin and carried him down the hill amid his confusion and deeply flushed face.
“Does this mean you will help me take him to Vallen?” Tyree asked.
“It certainly does.
We only just arrived here in mid-winter.
That rock that nearly hit me was not the first to break off the outcrop.
That’s why I jump down instead of climb.
I’ve been thinking this is a poor place for a village, especially when we start bearing children.
Too dangerous.
I mean, we could cover the outcrop with vines and roots and such, as many villages do, but this gives us an opportunity to find somewhere better.
If our travels just happen to take us into Vallen in search of a new home, so be it,” Preelen smirked.

Chapter 6
“Nalain”
Sammy
Beyond the rolling, rocky Mailan Hills of northern Melia, the forests grew sparse.
Flatlands covered in forests marbled together with lush, grassy fields stretched almost as far as the horizon.
In the distance, the snowcapped mountains of the Nuanae Range of the wilderlands, the northern border of the Amelian Empire, seemed to grow like a wall out of the verdant expanse.

Southeastern Vallen was densely forested and heavily populated, so many people believed that fairies only lived in forests, but as close kin to the High Elves--once called Grassland Elves long ago--fairies were just as at home on the plains.
Stone ruins of an ancient civilization stood like obelisks across the flatlands, and the largest ruins were repurposed into fairy cities.
As Ceil explained it to Sammy, the location they were headed to first was one such city.
Sammy examined a strange stone structure sinking into the forest floor.
The stone was intricately carved, but the weathering of time had made what she believed was originally a smooth texture quite porous and rough.
Moss and other small-rooted plants clung to the stone using the abrasive surface as a hold.

The most peculiar aspect of the structure was that it appeared to be a pointed archway that had tilted about 30 degrees and sunk ten feet into the ground, but there were no other ruins anywhere in sight that could explain the purpose for the archway.
Her only guess was that the rest of the ruins were buried far deeper underground.
This place was an archeologist’s dream.
“Sammy!
This way!
I found some!”
Lemi waved her hand in wide arcs almost out of sight.
The sun had only just risen, and they were tasked with scavenging herbs for breakfast and possibly hunting game if they saw any.
Lemi’s skill with the bow was impressive, but her constant shouting would have driven any potential game away.
Sammy smiled while shaking her head.
Hopefully Coby had better luck.
“Sammy, it’s amazing!
There’s so much fedaj here!”
Lemi brandished a thick stalk of a white, feathered mushroom when Sammy approached.
Fedaj, literally “first feather” in Elven and named after the soft down of infant birds according to Lemi, was rare in Melia but appeared to be far more common in Vallen.
It was toxic until cooked thoroughly, but Lemi was able to extract the toxins with life magic to make it edible raw.
Raw was preferable, because the fine feathers burnt off in fire or disintegrated when boiled.
When eaten, the feathers melted like cotton candy in the mouth and had a savory, mildly salty flavor.
Sammy sat her pack down and held it open while Lemi quickly uprooted mushroom after mushroom, only leaving two behind.
“We have to make sure it can come back,” Lemi explained for the fourth time that morning.
She sprung to her feet and pranced off further into the forest with the small beads of her dava clacking lightly with each step.
Lemi lived in the forest, so she was skilled at identifying forest herbs.
Whenever they camped in or near a forest, foraging became Lemi’s job, and she always requested that Sammy join her.

Having someone she could speak to in Melian gave her no shortage of joy, and Sammy enjoyed Lemi’s carefree, childlike attitude because it helped distract her from her worries about Justin and the war.
Ceil was raised on the plains before she entered the palace, so she was far more knowledgeable about the edible plants that could be found in the grasslands.
Her scavenging duty came when they camped on the plains.
To balance out Lemi’s constant requests for Sammy, Chloe always joined Ceil at Lemi’s request.
Lemi was quite adamant about the pairings.
Coby on the other hand hunted whenever he craved meat, so their dried meat supply relied almost solely on his whims.
Sammy lifted the sack and swung it over her back.
It was growing full quickly, but they would still eat most if not all their haul, especially Chloe.
The food of Whinhlem had very little substance to it, including meat.
Vegetables and plants were light and airy, and meat was never very dense, but it was quite succulent.
Sammy thought the light and juicy meat of the weasel-like musdel in Fiorrae was unique to that creature, but most game they hunted turned out the same; it shriveled up to nothing if overcooked.
Sammy assumed this was due to all flora and fauna evolving to survive on a planet with such high gravity.
Lemi retrieved the sack from Sammy on their way back to the camp.
She swung it in wide circles as she pranced through the forest.
“Careful.
You are going to crush the fedaj,” Sammy warned, but Lemi paid little mind.
Back at the camp, Chloe was stoking the fire while Ceil inspected Debin’s map.
“The sack’s pretty full,” Chloe exclaimed in excitement.
“Yah, we can actually have a decent breakfast for once,” Sammy replied.
Ceil set the map down and glared at Sammy and Lemi.
The closer they came to Nalain, the worse her temper grew.
“I could hear Lemi’s shouts from here,” she chastised in Elven so that Lemi could understand.
“You do realize that we are in enemy territory.
What would happen if the army found us before we reach a city?”
“We couldn’t see any army or smoke from the hills.
You said it yourself.
They might not have gotten this far yet.” Sammy placed an understanding hand on Lemi’s shoulder.
She did not want the girl growing melancholy, for both their sakes.
“But that still means they could be coming.”
“Coby is in the air.
He would warn us long before any soldiers arrive.”
“That still does not help us if there is a scout hiding in the fore-- Wha!”
An animal dropped from the sky in front of Ceil.
“I said we do not need anything this big!” Ceil shouted to the large blue hawk circling above, completely ignoring her previous chastisement of Lemi for doing the same.
Coby gave a triumphant cry, proud of his catch.
The animal looked like a spotted deer, but its feet had two distinct hoofed toes.
Its ears were long and could hang almost to the ground if it stood, and it had a goatee-like beard, so perhaps it was more of a goat than a deer.
It was similar in size to Ceil, so she understood why Ceil would be mad.
Cleaning and drying all that meat would delay their departure.
“Chloe, you have a job now.”
Ceil pushed the responsibility of gutting and cleaning the kill to Chloe.
Sammy could not use drying magic, so they had to rely on Chloe’s heat.
At least they had plenty of food to make up for the cost of Chloe’s fire ven conversion, and Sammy was happy to have some meat.
Coby ate the scraps of Chloe’s unskilled and sloppy butchering while Lemi prepared the herbs and mushrooms that could be eaten raw.
Sammy cooked the rest.
All the while, Ceil remained glued to the map.
Sammy thought that Ceil would have had it memorized by now, but Ceil continually spent all her free time staring at it, her face growing sullener with each passing day.
Sammy placed her hand on the map to pull Ceil away from whatever burdened her mind.
“It’s ready,” she said in the most reassuring tone she could, although she was unsure of what she was assuring.
Breakfast finished quickly, and Ceil returned to her map.
Sammy aided Chloe with the butchering and drying of the deer-goat that neither Ceil nor Lemi knew the name of.

Sammy had eaten plenty of goat cheese and venison in the past, and the meat of the peculiar mammal was almost a perfect middle ground between the earthy yet sour flavor of goat cheese and the hearty game flavor of venison, so she felt the description was not far off.
Maybe it had nothing to do with goats and was just a sour deer?
She did feel that the sour smell from butchering it would not get off her hands no matter how much she washed them.
“I think it’s a goat,” Chloe decided after Sammy explained her descriptory conundrum while they picked up camp.
“It sure smelled like one.”
They had enough dried meat for a few days now, and Lemi was more than willing to carry the extra weight, but it might not be needed.
They would reach Nalain at midday by Ceil’s estimates.

* * *
Late into the morning, Coby dove down through the canopy in front of Ceil who led the party.
He bellowed a reverberating cry and flapped his wings as if to keep everyone back.
“What did he say?” Ceil asked Sammy, her face seeped in worry.
“He’s warning us,” Sammy answered.
“He did not see any danger but wants us to be careful from here.”
“Can you really understand him that well?
From a single cry?” Chloe asked.
“It’s more of a feeling, but yah.
I can’t get any specific details, though.”
Following Coby’s warning, Lemi took point after handing her sack of provisions to Ceil and her noisy dava to Sammy.
She moved ahead into the forest with impossibly silent steps, bow in hand.
Once again, Sammy was glad Lemi came with them, and no doubt Ceil was grateful too.
Once Sammy saw the light at the border of the forest, Lemi returned with ill news.
“The armies were here.”
Everyone picked up pace and ran out of the forest to the edge of the field, or what was once a field.
It was trampled flat by an unknown number of boots.
The grass lay torn and wilting, dried by the winter sun.
“They passed through two, maybe three days ago,” Lemi guessed after touching the trodden grass, assessing the level of recovery of the broken blades.
“But we never saw any sign of them.
An army can’t move that fast, can it?” Sammy asked.
“We came from the southeast.
They must have marched from the northeast.
There is a small village there called Henem a little less than a day’s walk away.”
Ceil gripped the rolled map in her hand with white knuckles.
As Sammy suspected, Ceil had the map memorized.
“They are not just targeting the major cities.
This is genocide.”
Ceil ran through the trampled field, and only once Sammy looked in the direction Ceil headed did she see the destination.
An ancient stone tower stood like a beacon above the forest canopy.
It was the marker of Nalain, a city built upon ancient ruins.
No smoke rose into the sky, so Sammy prayed that the city was safe, but if the armies had already passed through, she knew it was a fool’s hope.
She chased after Ceil with Coby flying further ahead.
Instead of traveling through the forest, Ceil circled the forest line.
They found the first body only a few minutes later, a Tolmyur soldier in thin plate mail with his face crushed in by a pointed but blunt object.
The closer they approached the city, the more bodies they found, all Tolmyur soldiers.
The sight of death attacked Sammy’s memories.
Visions of the hospital flashed in her mind and with them, a resurgence of the dread she felt.
Her chest burned, and tears filled her eyes, but she couldn’t fall too far behind, so she kept moving.
Ceil stopped when the field bent around the forest towards the tower.
Lemi stood with her, and Chloe was the next to catch up.
Sammy nearly tripped over a body but pushed through the exhaustion, part physical but mostly mental.
What she saw in the distance dropped her to her knees, and the welling tears fell.
It was a ruin of ruins.
The devastation of battle spread before them in the open field before the ruins of Nalain.
Broken weapons rose like graves from the ground, marking the many bodies of both humans and fairies alike.

The ancient walls of Nalain stood as a powerful defense, and the fairies placed their hope in that defense to turn back the tide of genocide, but that hope was ruthlessly destroyed one by one with each fairy body Sammy passed on their silent march to the crumbling walls.
They looked to her as small elves, almost like children, and each one made Sammy’s heart ache to bursting.
As they approached the walls, the number of Tolmyur bodies decreased, and the number of fairies and elves increased until not a single Tolmyur soldier could be found.
This was the moment the Tolmyur army’s numbers overwhelmed them.
Coby perched on the wall like a sentinel, and his mourning cry warned Sammy not to enter the city.
She stopped before the broken and crumbling defense and watched Ceil and Lemi climb the bloodstained rubble with pained faces.
She could not call them back.
Her voice would not sound.
There was no danger in Coby’s warning, but there was something he did not wish her to see.
Chloe grasped Sammy’s hand gently, almost too hot to touch.
Sammy could not understand how Chloe was not crying.
She only smiled back and pulled Sammy to follow.
This was the war they were entering.
This was the death and destruction they would continue to witness.
Perhaps, this was the devastation they would eventually cause.
Sammy recalled the night at the central Melian village.
She recalled the attack on the university.
Chloe had already killed so many, and the pain of that realization made Sammy’s heart break.
She dropped, and light sobs broke out of her once silent voice.
“You don’t need to come,” Chloe whispered with a loving face full of maturity that Sammy felt she could never achieve.
Sammy could not speak her answer, but she forced herself to stand and take a single step forward.
She placed her hand on the rubble near where another small hand protruded between two large stones.
With Chloe’s help, she jumped up and continued climbing.
Lemi awaited her at the top and extended a trembling hand.
The young girl, looking no older than a tall 13-year-old, was not crying, but the anguish in her face caused Sammy’s tears to flow anew.
Only Ceil’s face was hardened against the devastation.
When Sammy saw the inner-city ruins, she realized now that she should not have brought such a young girl into this.
Such death was not something Lemi should see.
The stone structures were perfectly preserved with no wood in sight.
There was no smoke because there was little to burn.
Large scorch marks showed the rampant use of fire, but stone would never light.
The only fuel for a flame was the countless dead that littered the ground so deep that the weathered stone was sparsely visible.
Their charred bodies gave no path to walk.
Ceil walked across the bodies with no respect for the dead, soldier and civilian alike.
The dead of the city outside the walls were the young and valiant, but those who held against the siege from within were the elderly, women, and children.
Even the children gripped their small knives in death.
Sammy’s heart and mind grew numb as she followed Ceil’s path over the bodies.
She wanted to turn back.
There was no purpose in being here.
The city was lost.
All were dead.
What drove Ceil forward?
She looked up from the death beneath her feet and saw four people standing at the end of the road in the center of a garden square.
The closer they walked, the more Sammy shook with dread.
The four people were women.
And, they were not standing.
Ceil ran to them and stopped at the border of the garden.
Each girl was a High Elf similar to Ceil in age.
They were impaled between their legs up through their mouths on wooden stakes.
In the center between them on the soil died brown in their blood sat a large stone from the outer wall, and atop it lay the four severed tails of the impaled women.
This was a message for Ceil as if they knew she would come.
Without a word or a crack in her stone expression, Ceil turned and walked away.
“We can’t leave them like this,” Sammy screamed.
Ceil pounded her red cedar staff onto the stone road.
“They are dead.
What good could we do them now?”
“It’s too cruel…” Sammy cried.
Death permeated the ruined city like a pungent cloud, but the treatment of these women for the sole crime of being similar to Ceil was unbearable.
“What would you have me do?”
Ceil did not turn to face Sammy, and her voice showed no emotion.
“I’ll burry them.”
Sammy walked over to one of the women and grabbed the stake at the base.
Exerting all her strength, the stake came loose and fell to the side.
Chloe and Lemi quickly helped, but Ceil never turned around.
Sammy located a small shield and began digging, but Lemi quickly stopped her.
She placed her hand on a nearby tree, and roots coiled on the ground, loosening the soil.
The loose soil was easily scooped away, and the four High Elves were soon buried.
Sammy reached into her bag and removed a small satchel.
She loosed the string and dumped the four white, tear-shaped berries into her hand.
After poking a hole above each grave, a berry was dropped in and covered.
I’m sorry, Sammy prayed in her heart to the deceased; not just the four women, but to the entire city.
When Ceil heard Sammy approach, she walked forward, and they left the ruins of Nalain.

* * *
That evening, they sat around a low fire in the middle of the densest section of forest they could find.
Sammy prepared dinner using the meat they dried earlier that morning, but the thought of eating meat after seeing so much carnage made Sammy ill.
“Nalain was one of the cities where the fairies planned to send me for my protection,” Ceil said, breaking her silence from the time they left the ruins.
She held the map in one hand and a charred twig in the other.
“There is another city like Nalain but much larger, Revlan.
It was brought up in the discussion back then but was rejected because of its size.
They wanted to keep lives lost to a minimum if… if Tolmyur should ever attack it in search of me.
It is further west of here.
That is our next destination,” Ceil announced as she tossed the twig into the small embers.
“If the army was in Nalain three days ago, we should reach Revlan long before they do.”
From the corner of Sammy’s eye, she saw a tear fall onto the map.
She immediately dropped the bag of provisions and grabbed Ceil’s shoulder, wrapping her arms around her.
Ceil dropped the map and buried her face into Sammy’s chest, crying silently.
The map on the ground showed eleven black X’s starting from Nalain moving east across every city, town, and village in northwestern Vallen.
A single city to the west was circled, and between it and Nalain, one city and three villages were slashed with a single black stroke: locations they would abandon.
Revlan was the westernmost city, and the map showed nothing beyond it.

Chapter 7
“The Dryads’ Secret Weapon”
Kolbur
The conscription of the dryads progressed relatively smoothly.

The road to northwestern Vallen only traveled through the western provinces of Dhuillir, so in order to better bolster their army, General Bregon periodically set up camp for two to five days so that conscription forces could be broken off and sent into neighboring provinces to conscript any able-bodied dryads.
Their ultimatum was simple: “Join us in eradicating the invaders from another world or become food for our forces.”
Hostilities often arose at first, but after the slaughter of a few villages, the rest were quick to comply.
The initial conflict in each province was even welcomed, because it meant an increase in provisions.
General Bregon’s army had over doubled in size, and their reserves of food had tripled.
At their current rate, Lieutenant Kolbur felt that they would be prepared for a prolonged siege if needed by the time they reached Vallen.
Kolbur’s optimism came from the success of his first conscription mission into the Simydia province.
He and his 400 men had just returned with 2000 pale-green, almost white dryads and another 150 dryads worth of dried food.

The other four groups sent to Simydia saw similar results, but from the discussion happening in front of him as he approached General Bregon to report during the closure of their fourth conscription camp, it seemed not every conscription force was successful.
“Is this the first rebellion?”
“There was always some resistance, but the Fendamai are openly hostile.”
“Did Captain Kremyur truly lose?
He had over a thousand strong under his command.”
Another winded and sweating scout arrived, silencing the discussion.
“Lieutenant Passel and his army were eradicated.
The Dafnai knew he was coming and ambushed them.”
Lieutenant Passel only had a small platoon of 200, but including the thousand under Kremyur, these were terrible losses, and the true battle in Vallen had yet to begin.
General Bregon noticed Kolbur and called him forward.
“Your report?”
Kolbur cleared his throat and hoped that his success could uplift the morale of the other Lieutenants and Captains present.
“Success in Simydia.
We estimate an additional 7000 dryads from the five platoons, including 400 dryads for food.”
Simydia was the greatest success of the provinces so far, but General Bregon’s expression did not change.
“What of Captain Hekket?
Should he not be the one reporting?”
“Captain Hekket is the sole loss in Simydia.
He fell due to his own hubris in the initial hostilities,” Kolbur explained honestly.
“I am the next senior commander.”
The truth was that Simydia would have submitted without a fight and was willing to aid the war effort.
That insufferable minum captain chose instead to make an example of the first village, killing the young who were unable to be conscripted.
The village retaliated.

Hekket was killed immediately with life magic, and the village was promptly eliminated with the fire mages on hand, but word spread that the soldiers could not be trusted, and only after the annihilation of three more villages did the Simydians submit once more.
Conscripting 7000 was an incredible success, but Kolbur firmly believed that they could have doubled that number if they kept amiable relations with Simydia.
“So Simydia is the last,” General Bregon mumbled.
“Last?” one of the captains asked.
“From here on, we are entering provinces under the control of the hamadryad.
Conscription will end.
We must treat every dryad we see as a potential enemy to prevent further losses until we reach Vallen.”
The captains and lieutenants dispersed, but Kolbur remained.
“Sir, if I may,” Kolbur began.
“Speak.”
“I would like to take a larger detour than the neighboring provinces.
There is a species of dryad that is believed to be far more powerful than others.
They are few in number, but they may be vital in giving us an advantage in this battle, especially with the strength of these otherworlders.”
“You speak of the kissiae.
They are under our Commanding General’s protection and cannot be summoned.”
“Pardon my disrespect, but if we lose this battle, we will lose Amel, correct?
Should we not make use of every weapon at our disposal?
If the kissiae are under Commanding General Jethro’s command, they should be easy to convince without the use of violence.
If they are as powerful as the rumors say, none might be lost.”
General Bregon glared down at Kolbur, causing sweat to bead on Kolbur’s brow.
He knew what he was asking of General Bregon, blatant insubordination.
“You said you were the senior-most lieutenant under Captain Hekket, correct?”
“Yes, sir.”
“I promote you to captain, and with that promotion, there is classified information you must know.”
General Bregon knelt down and hushed his reverberating voice to speak level with Kolbur.
“The campaign in the other world has failed, and we do not know the status of our Commanding General other than that he is in trouble.
We must act without him, and with that knowledge, I give you permission to conscript the kissiae.”
“Thank you, sir.”
Kolbur’s chest thundered with a painful combination of fear and gratitude.
The ill news was terrifying, but he felt strongly in his heart that the kissiae could tip the scale of this war in their favor.
“How many men do you require?”
“Not many.
I am not visiting their lands in hostility, nor do I want to give that impression.
Twenty fire mages for protection through the dryad provinces, ten archers, ten swordsmen, and two scouts.
One for forward and the second for observation to report back should something happen to us.”
“Granted.”

* * *
The Dhuillir wetlands of Elos lied beyond Simydia and its eastward neighbor, Velanidia.
Kolbur avoided villages in Simydia when possible--he did not want to antagonize them further--but once they reached Velanidia, he would require a guide.
Elos was small and not a true province of Dhuillir.
Without direction, they could wander beyond Velanidia without ever locating it.
However, securing a guide was not without its own dangers.
Kolbur did not know the extent of the hamadryad’s influence.
If the Velanids were hostile, he would have no choice but to follow the eastern border in hope of locating the wetlands.
Even then he was only following rumors, and Elos may not even be near Velanidia.
Velanidia was unlike any of the Dhuillir provinces Kolbur had seen, and he felt it difficult to call it a forest.
Rolling green fields spread before him like a verdant blanket laid out but not pulled taught.
Massive ancient oaks towered hundreds of feet into the sky with wide branches that could shade a small village.

No other trees grew beneath them, and they were spread enough apart that their leaves did not touch those of another oak, or perhaps the branches could have touched but they grew with respect to the growth of their neighbors.
The forest grew as if the canopy was the ceiling and the trunks the large pillars to a grand natural hall.
The shaded fields devoid of any flora larger than small shrubbery gave a near perfect view of multiple Velanid villages.
Likewise, standing on the border between Velanidia and Simydia, Kolbur and his small platoon were in full view of each nearby village.
As he led his men forward onto the fields, three of the nearest villages gathered and approached.
If the Velanids were hostile, there was nowhere they could hide, and they would have no choice but to flee and go around.
Any violence would alert all of Velanidia, making passage impossible for his small party.
“Do not draw your weapons, but be prepared to defend at the quickest sign of aggression,” Kolbur ordered.
The approaching dryads numbered about two hundred by Kolbur’s estimate.
At one hundred yards distant, Kolbur halted his march, and the Velanids did likewise.
Three representatives, one from each village, walked forward, and Kolbur alone advanced to meet them.
“I request passage through Velanidia and guidance to Elos.”
“A request and not a demand?” asked the eldest of the village representatives.
Her deep brown skin was cracked and brittle.
Splinters fell with every movement of her shaking feet.
Her head was bald and void of the small, pointed, almost sharp oaken leaves of the Velanids.
“I have come seeking the aid of the Kissiae in these dire times.
We have received word that invaders from another world have arrived in Dhuillir and Vallen.
They are powerful beyond reason, and without the strength to face them, we will not survive.”
Hushed conversations rose among the Velanids.
The eldest matriarch closed her eyes and spoke as if for all the villages.
“The Venalids are not whom you must convince.
We can direct you to the sanctuary, but we cannot enter with you.
If what you say is true, they will know.”
“We are grateful for your understanding.
The otherworlders have already attacked a village in Melia and have shown they are not an ally to the dryads.
Upon our return, I also request that any able Velanids join us on our march to battle.”
“Attacking a dryad village makes these otherworlders no different than you humans.
We know of your actions as you travel through Dhuillir.
If you return from Elos with the kissiaes’ favor, perhaps we may reconsider,” the matriarch replied, turning her back and pointing to a much younger Velanid from her village.
The woman sprinted for Kolbur, almost making him draw his blade by reflex, and then bowed deeply, her sharp hair sliding down and scraping at her shoulders and arms.
“I will guide you to Elos.”
Velanidia was one of the smaller provinces in Dhuillir.
Instead of remote villages, the Velanids interacted almost as one united society under the canopy of the giant oaks.
Entire large gatherings--what one would expect to be a village in any other province--moved out of the way as Kolbur’s forces passed.
Their animosity towards Tolmyur was palpable, but he was grateful that it was not severe enough to lead to confrontation.
The Velanids solely wanted nothing to do with them.
Kolbur’s forces reached the eastern border as the sun set below the canopy.
Unlike the other provinces where a single species of tree dominated the flora of the region, the expansive forest before them contained many different species.
It did not appear to be wetlands or even a dryad-cultivated province of Dhuillir.
“Is this Elos?” Kolbur asked, doubting his guide.
“Elos is further within.
If you keep your current course and do not deviate, you will find it.”
“Then we will camp here and continue in the morning,” Kolbur called to his men.
“Camping is not permitted,” the guide warned.
“You are not welcome in our lands.
You requested passage through Velanidia, so pass you shall.
Make your request for shelter in Elos.
If we see you camp near our borders, expect retribution.
Your small band of soldiers cannot hope to defend against all of Velanidia.” The guide glared with rigid ire, and she bowed in false hospitality.
Seeing such blatant defiance, some of the soldiers drew their weapons, and the mages brandished their flames.
Kolbur raised his hand to quell his soldiers’ tempers.
“You have complied with our request, so we will continue on.
I do not wish to see such majestic trees burn,” he replied, half in warning to the guide who was nothing more than a messenger for the heart of Velanidia.
He wanted to teach the dryad her place, but his numbers were few, and they would have to pass through Velanidia once again if they wanted to return to the conscription camp in a timely manner.
General Bregon was holding the camp’s departure for this mission.
He only had six days to return, and three had already been spent.
He turned his back to Velanidia and walked into the lush and diverse forest.

* * *
The Velanid’s warning weighed on Kolbur’s mind.
How near to the border could they camp without the threatened retribution falling upon them?
He did not know, so he made his soldiers march.
The sunset had faded to darkness, and the dense forest let no light from the celestial bodies in the clear night sky pass through the canopy.
If not for the fire mages, he and his soldiers would be unable to see their hand before their own faces.
The underbrush was dense, entangled, and slowed their passage.
There were no paths or game trails, almost as if the forest itself was a barrier protecting what lied within.
“The men are tired,” Kolbur’s lieutenant reported.
He was a robust young swordsman who, like Kolbur, had only just received his promotion.
“We should clear the brush and set up camp.”
“No. I have no basis for this belief, but I feel that this dense forest is still what the Velanids call the border.”
“Are you saying that we are still in Velanidia?”
“Elos is not a province but a location within Dhuillir.
It would be wise to suspect as much.”
“Sir, there is water ahead,” the forward scout announced.
Due to the dense underbrush, he was unable to scout too far ahead, only staying within visibility of the light of the mages’ flames.
Kolbur could hear the faint splash of each of the scout’s steps, and soon the chill of moisture surrounded his feet.
The ground grew soft, but the underbrush did not thin.
Walking from here on would grow even more difficult.
The choice was his whether to turn back and clear ground to make camp or to press forward into what were likely the desired wetlands.
“We move forward,” he ordered.
The groundwater did not grow deep, only to the height of his ankles, but it covered the entirety of the forest floor and soaked into his boots with every step.
The soft, muddy ground clung to his feet.
Trudging through mud after a full day’s march was more than his endurance could handle.
The mages lacked the endurance of the swordsmen and archers, particularly the minums, but they followed without complaint.
There was nowhere to set up camp unless they wanted to sleep on the water.
He began to question his decision to continue the march.
Even if dangerous, camping on dry ground in the dense forest would have been preferable.
Another few hours passed, and Kolbur felt he would break.
The gasps and groans of his men were a dismal chorus in the dark, but they were too deep to turn back for dry ground.
Where were they headed?
What was their destination?
Elos was known as the wetlands of Dhuillir, and the forest they traveled was indeed wet.
It was drowned.
Had he reached Elos?
How could he know?
If this was Elos, where were the Kissiae, and how could he find them?
All at once, the groundcover vanished, and the water level rose to midway up his shins or too his knees in some places.
Next the trees vanished, yet there were no stars, and the moons did not give their light.
They reached a black marsh of perfectly still water that spread out into darkness that not even the flames on his mages’ hands could penetrate.
He continued the slow march deep into the darkness.
A splash sounded in the dark, and a minute later, the ripples reached Kolbur’s legs.
“Gather together.
Form a defensive perimeter.”
He did not know if there was any real danger or if his exhaustion was making him overcautious, but there was something odd about this place.
This marsh was unnatural.
With swordsmen on the perimeter and mages and archers in the center, Kolbur led them deeper into the marsh.
A second splash sounded from the direction they had come and a third from the direction they were headed.
The archers drew their bows.
Something was out there in the eternal darkness, and it wasn’t a kissiae.
The ivy dryads were rumored to thrive in moist climates, but they were not wetland creatures.
They could not live in water.
After a fourth splash so close that Kolbur caught the spray of water but could not see what caused it, he called out in desperation.
“We must speak with the kissiae!”
His heart thundered stronger than the exhaustion of his march, and his fear spread like a disease among his men.
The splash was too large to be a fish, but the water was too shallow for it to be an animal of any large size, especially if it could disappear under the black water.
Kolbur saw the terror of his men’s faces in the fireglow.
He should not have come here at night.
A large splash sounded behind Kolbur where the third had been.
He turned around to see a woman.
Her white silk gown, impossibly pristine in the murky water, was drenched and clung tight to her body, accentuating the curvature of her perfect figure.
Her face, barely visible in the orange light of the flames, held an unnatural and ageless beauty impossible for any elf or human.
When Kolbur noticed the color of her long hair--deep blue in the dark, but when it caught the light of the flames, it shimmered green--he knew what stood before him.
She was a naiad, a water nymph.
“Fire is forbidden in our sanctuary, humans of Tolmyur.”
“It is only for protection against the dryads and to light our path.
We mean no harm.”
One by one, four more naiads stepped into the aura of firelight surrounding his soldiers.
Kolbur’s sword hand shook, but as the leader of his men, he forced his body to retain the most meager sense of composure.
“Is this the kissiae sanctuary?
We are under orders to seek them out and request their aid.”
“The Eleionomai have guarded this sanctuary for millennia.

The emperors of times past have charged us with protecting the kissiae from all who enter, whether they are humankind or elfkind or other, until the kissiae population recovers from the evils wrought against them by the races.
When your leader claimed the empire, he renewed our charge.
Not even his own soldiers will be spared.”
Three more naiads appeared, blocking their escape.
Kolbur heard a faint cry in the dark from far behind them.
Something happened to their observation scout.
He and his soldiers were surrounded, but the enemy’s numbers were few.
“Our discussion is with the kissiae, not their guards.
Let us pass.”
The naiad reached into the water and removed a sword.
It shone grander in the faint light than polished blue-moon silver.
Resfahil, the metal embodiment of the wrath of the gods.
The others did likewise, holding the weapons slack by their side.
None spoke, and Kolbur knew the time for negotiation had passed.
“If they are the guard, the kissiae must be beyond the marsh.
We advance!
Your magic will be nullified if in contact with their swords.
Only fight those who attack you.
Take courage.
Nymphs cannot use magic.”
The first naiad brandished her weapon.
“We have no need of magic.
We are elementals.”
Kolbur heard a splash from behind him and spun around.
His blade caught the resfahil sword thrust at his back, deflecting it to the side.
When the naiad hit the water, she vanished.
“They’re in the water!”
Multiple naiads surfaced with quick strikes piercing the backs and eviscerating the stomachs of his men inside the defensive perimeter.
All attempts to retaliate failed as the naiads disappeared into the shallow black marsh.
“None shall escape this cage.”
“Focus on the forward naiads!
We must reach land!” Kolbur charged the first naiad as two fireballs flew overhead.
They both dissipated with a weak sizzle when the naiad struck them down with her sword.
An arrow flew past his ear, near invisible in the dark, and struck the naiad’s shoulder.
When Kolbur slashed at her stomach, she did not raise her sword.
She dropped into the water, disappearing and leaving only a bloody arrow behind.
“Arrows will wound them!
Protect the archers!
Mages, keep your light!
Swordsmen, watch the water!”
The soldiers moved as quick as was possible in the mud and silt.
The light of their fires grew dim as the mages fell quickly to their invisible enemy within the water, first the minums and then the dwarves whose smaller statures slowed them.
The visibility dropped from twenty yards to ten, then five.
Kolbur had no time to look behind him to see how many of his men had fallen, but the clashes of metal grew fewer as did the death rows of his men.
A naiad dove up from the water in front of Kolbur and caught him through the side with her blade, but his was also forward and plunged through her as he fell with her into the water.
Her body under him vanished like a handful of sand dropped in a flowing stream.
His lieutenant pulled him up by the collar and pushed him forward but was quickly run through by a naiad with a bloodstained stomach.
She would die, but she was only one among many.
Kolbur forged ahead driven by fear and panic, praying that he would reach dry ground where he could contest the naiads as equals.
The splashing from the advance of he and his men masked the sounds of the surfacing naiads, and more fell to their unseen hands.
A shimmer in the water caught the corner of Kolbur’s eye, and he swung his sword in fear.
The moment the naiad surfaced, his blade removed her head from her shoulders, and she fell back into the water, bobbing in the ripples of his flight.
If the arrow did not vanish with the Naiad in the water, neither would their swords.
“Look out for the glint of fahil in the water!
Mages, make your flames brighter!”
The radius of light increased but immediately dimmed as more mages fell, but with them were the cries of the naiads.
The light dimmed further, and soon Kolbur was on its perimeter, unable to see where he fled.
If a naiad struck now, he could not defend.
In desperation, he pushed his exhausted body further and tripped.
His face hit moist earth, and as the dim light approached, he saw watergrass.
He scrambled up the bank and turned behind him, sword forward in his heavy hand.
Only four of his men remained and dashed across the water towards the shore, all human.
Two swordsmen reached him first followed by one mage holding a weak light in hand.
The final mage with bulging eyes full of fear and hope caught a sword through the back from a naiad who surfaced behind him.
He fell forward, only his hand touching the shore.
Kolbur backed away up the bank.
The sole fire mage remained in center with a swordsman on each side.
One by one, the naiads rose from the water.
Two, five, ten, and then more than he cared to count; a whole multitude of them stood before Kolbur and his three remaining men, but they did not step on the shore.
Could they not leave the water?
One naiad walked forward.
She had a light bloodstain on her shoulder from that first arrow.
She did not speak, but each step in the water was an executioner’s bell.
Kolbur backed up, and so did his men.
Her foot reached the shore, and she stepped up brandishing her glimmering blade.
Kolbur’s back hit the thin trunk of a tree, and he felt a faint prickle on his left leg.
His right foot stepped forward followed by his left.
When he raised his sword, Kolbur realized that these actions were not his own.
He drove his own blade into the back of his swordsman, twisted it, and cut outward through the leather armor with strength he did not know he had.
His arm ached from the exertion.
The fire mage fell next before he could register what happened to the swordsman.
The mages fireball fell with him, setting the fallen swordsman alight.
Stop!
Look out!
Kolbur’s voice would not speak his mind, and no matter how he resisted, his body would not listen.
The final swordsman turned his back on the naiad threat before him and viewed Kolbur with an indescribable terror.
He was not looking directly at Kolbur but through or behind him.
He raised his blade to strike Kolbur down, but Kolbur grabbed the swordsman’s wrist with incredible speed.
Kolbur’s blade pierced the man’s stomach as a second sword pierced the swordsman from behind, its bloodied blade glistening in the light of the small fire.
The naiad cast the final swordsman to the side.
Like a marionette whose strings had been cut, Kolbur fell to his back.
Above him stood the naiad guard who had ordered the execution of his small band of soldiers, but she did not strike him down.
Another figure crawled over him and sat on his stomach.
She had smooth green skin and long ivy hair of heart-shaped leaves.
Her age and small stature reminded him of an elderly minum.
It was a kissiae.
She did not speak, but her voice entered his mind.
“Jethro came to us and threatened our destruction if we did not offer a kissiae to his service.
Now you come into Dhuillir and threaten all the dryads with the same.
The kissiae are few.
You cannot have us.”
I had no choice!
Kolbur screamed in his mind, unable to speak.
I know Jethro would have demanded your services again if he was here.
The kissiae closed her eyes, and Kolbur felt a drain on his mind.
When she opened her eyes again, her face grew a worried scowl.
“You seek our aid to combat trespassers from another world, and Jethro has led an invasion into that same world?
Do you not know the severity of the sin you have committed?!”
