The shout reverberated in Kolbur’s head, but instead of the aching of is ears, his mind throbbed with a debilitating pulse.
Sin?
What sin?
“Such a breach of taboo will bring destruction upon us all!”
The elder kissiae gripped her long ivy hair in distress.
“Your knowledge is secondhand.
I cannot trust your estimates of the strength of these trespassers.
If Bydrofe finds word of this, or worse, Gyea, even the kissiae may not survive.”
The kissiae removed herself from Kolbur’s stomach, and he found that he regained control of his body.
In panic, he kicked back until his head hit the tree behind him.

“On my word as acting matriarch of the kissiae, we will help you rid the Amelian Empire of these trespassers, but in repayment, should Jethro ever return to this world, you must execute him and bring me his head.
Do we have an accord?”
Cold sweat dripped from Kolbur’s beard.
Such an agreement was impossible for one of his rank to make.
He was only a new captain representing his general on a mission of his own suggestion.
General Bregon may represent the Commanding General, but such a chain of delegation could never order the execution of that chain’s head.
But, Jethro was in peril in the other world.
No one could know if he would return or if he was even alive.
Even if Jethro returned, he was powerful, and Kolbur firmly believed that no one from this world could match him in order to execute him.
Only the strength of those in the other world who put him in peril could even compare.
“I… I cannot agree to those terms.
Not… not that I do not find them sufficient.
If you could speak with General Bregon, as fourth in command below Commanding General Jethro, he would have the power to uphold your terms.”
The kissiae frowned.
“The weak hearted shirk responsibility.
You were the one who decided to request our aid.
However, I will meet with Bregon.
If you will not uphold the terms, I will hold him and all those under him accountable.”
The naiad genuflected to the kissiae.
“If that is your wish, the Eleionomai will follow you into battle as your protectors.”
Kolbur felt a prickle on his neck and a small hand on his shoulder.
Another kissiae leaned over and looked at him with her deep green eyes almost glowing in the shadow of her face.
Kolbur felt his exhaustion leave him.
The pain in his side from the naiad’s sword vanished, but the ebb did not end there.
The relief of the pain grew to numbness and then an overpowering relaxation.
Kolbur fell asleep, never to wake again.
“We march for Melia,” the matriarch of the kissiae ordered as the fire consuming the swordsman slowly died.

* * *
Emer stood in one of the kitchens of the palace.
Two dryads knelt before him in praise, but he was not the one they worshiped.
The kissiae clinging to his back smiled lovingly back at them.
Their skin showed deep scars in straight lines bisecting their legs, arms, torsos, and necks.
When Keeya found them, their bodies sat shriveled and in pieces on the table.
One dryad still missed an arm and the other missed a leg, but they were alive, pieced together and restored by Keeya’s life magic.
They had no memory of what happened to them, and their minds were addled by the time they spent in death, but they knew their savior because she emanated a presence they could not ignore.
It was a feeling of instinct that she was a greater being than they.
“Arm and leg will regrow.
You better now,” Keeya said with a smile as she dismissed them.
The two dryads hobbled out the door quietly singing Keeya’s praise with their weak voices.
“I have never seen such skill in life magic,” Emer praised almost in chorus with the dryads, having acted as the conduit for Keeya to mend the dismembered bodies.
“I can imagine Jethro going mad if he witnessed it.
I suggest keeping this a secret from him.”
“But Jethro Keeya’s master.”
“If he does not ask about it, you have no reason to tell him anyway, right?”
“…yes.”
“I never imagined we would stumble upon such a scene while you explored the palace.
Could you really have not treated the chefs?”
“Chefs rotting.
Restore life and they die.
Remove rot and restore life, body incomplete and still die.
Remove rot, restore life, and heal body until body can hold life, maybe survive, but take long, long time, and other bodies rot more.”
“I see… That is a shame.
I wonder why they were cooking dryads.”
“Dryads edible, like elves and humans.”
“That is not what I mean.
They were clearly ordered to cook the dryads and killed themselves out of guilt.
I am curious why.”
Keeya had a sudden and dark premonition.
A feeling within her that she had numbed came to life, and she searched for the hearts of her fellow Kissiae.
The sensation was weak, but she felt tension and worry.
She wanted to know why, but Jethro had ordered her not to leave the palace, so she hid away the feeling once more, having it lingering and active in the back of her mind.

Chapter 8
“The Resistance”
Ceil
Ceil kept to the forests as much as possible.
Her greatest fear was that her small party would be discovered while passing the Tolmyur army.
The flatlands were vast, but the army was both large and close enough that as she traveled, she could hear them like a wraith howling in the distance.
She caught up to the army at the first village but kept far enough south that she could only see the smoke that signaled the destruction of more lives.
She hoped most of them fled, but after the massacre at Nalain, she knew that many would be too stubborn to abandon their homes.
If the fairies had one major flaw, it was their pride.
Ceil forwent sleep for three days until she could no longer hear the whispers of death on the wind.
The army halted its march after the first village either to recuperate or because there was greater resistance than Ceil assumed was possible for such a small village.
She could no longer hear the cry of war, but it continued sounding in her mind, fueled by memories of the destruction in the Gallanvale.

The forest sung its lullaby through the wind and wildlife, but a weak and restless sleep was only possible in the arms of both Sammy and Chloe as they held her between them like a loving shield against the evils that chased her.

The warmth reminded Ceil of Eydis and how she would often comfort her with the same loving embrace whenever Ceil was troubled and could not sleep, but worrying about being a wife to a man who did not love her felt so petty compared to being the cause of what may be the largest genocide in history.
Her emotions leaked out a few days ago, so she renewed her conviction.
She was a leader--she was expected to be a leader--so she could never cry.

* * *
“How long until we reach Revlan,” Chloe asked Ceil, who led the group silently with her red cedar staff gripped painfully tight in hand.
“We are close,” Ceil replied without a hint of emotion.
“Which reminds me…” She stopped walking and searched her sack containing the party’s spare clothing.
She removed a white sash she often used to wrap around her waist to cover the pleats of her skirt.
It was stained brown from blood in a few places, having been used to wrap Coby’s arrow wound in the past.
“Chloe should be fine because of her bright orange hair.
No one from Tolmyur has that hair color, so they might think she is an oread, a Mountain Nymph.
You on the other hand,” Chloe handed the sash to Sammy.
“No offense, but you look half human, half dwarf.”
“Dwarf?” Sammy repeated.
“Your hair is brown, and your breasts are large.
Your shoulders and hips are not broad enough, but you are short enough, hence half.
In a region that is ravaged by Tolmyur, some may not hesitate to kill you on sight, even if they see you in the company of an elf and dryad.
Tie your hair in back and wrap that sash around your head to cover your ears.
Hopefully they will think you are some large-breasted half-fairy or something.
Anything is better than being human right now.”
Sammy retrieved the sash and unthreaded the tie from her satchel to bind her hair into a ponytail.
“If you are making me disguise myself now, does that mean we will reach Revlan today?”
“If the distances on the map are accurate, we will reach it by mid-afternoon.”
“What about Coby?”
“I did not think about him…
There should not be any Habha his size in Vallen, but they might mistake him for a threat or possibly shoot him down for food.
He would be safer walking with us.”
“Okay.
COBY!”
Ceil jumped to Sammy and placed her hand over her mouth.
“What are you doing?”
Sammy pried Ceil’s hand away.
“How else am I going to call him?
You are the one who wanted him to stay in the air to warn us of danger.
And the soldiers shouldn’t be anywhere close, right?”
A cobalt-blue shadow broke through the canopy and landed beside Sammy.
She scratched the feathers on his neck lightly as she spoke.
“It might be dangerous for you to fly right now, so you need to walk with us.”
Coby trilled and hopped excitedly, much to Ceil’s surprise.
She would have thought he hated the days when he was forced to follow them on foot due to his injury.
She almost wished she had Sammy’s ability to understand exactly how Coby felt.
The brush rustled beside them, and the first thought in Ceil’s mind was that Sammy’s call had alerted a wayward scout or soldier of their location.
Lemi silently appeared when Ceil was sure she had been scouting ahead.
Her bow was drawn, pointing in the direction of the noise.
A young fairy boy not even a year old and the size of an elf infant looked at Lemi’s drawn bow and fell to his knees.
He wet his worn and bloodstained tunic in fear and began to cry.
Lemi immediately dropped her bow and ran to the young boy with Chloe close behind.
“He’s not hurt,” Lemi announced.
“The blood is not his.”
“Where did you come from?” Sammy asked, kneeling in front of the boy next to Chloe.
The boy stifled his crying enough to manage a brief explanation before crying again.
“Mom told me to run…”
“If he made it this far ahead of the army, he must have been from one of the earlier villages, before Nalain,” Ceil explained.
She turned away from the young boy.
The dried blood on his green tunic reminded her of the young nymph boy back in the Gallanvale.
Her shoulders quivered as she fought to maintain composure.
“Let’s take him with,” Chloe said as she picked him up without care to his soiled clothing.
“If we are close to Revlan, there should be someone who can take care of him.”
Coby bounced around Chloe, chirping lightly.
“No, he’s not food,” Sammy reprimanded.
She removed one of the last strips of the goat-deer from Lemi’s sack and tossed it to Coby before he caused problems.
“We don’t have much of a choice.
We can’t leave him.”
“There are probably many like him,” Ceil said as she walked ahead.
“And taking him to Revlan does not mean he will survive.”
A few hours later, Lemi announced that she found a road.
It was old and weathered, but people were traveling it in large numbers, all in the same direction.
She did not say they were soldiers, so Ceil knew immediately that they were refugees who escaped the destruction of their villages and cities.
Groups of elves and fairies and other elfkind scattered among them bore sullen faces in the shade of the forest canopy overhanging the wide road.
The volume of traffic on the road was far larger than Ceil expected.

The relief that the death toll of the destroyed cities may not have been as large as she expected was overpowered by the knowledge that many cities would have fallen in order to create so many refugees.

None looked at anyone outside their own groups, so none cared that there were two humans now walking among them, or perhaps Ceil’s assumptions were correct, and they thought Chloe was an oread and Sammy was at least something other than human.
The longer they traveled the road, the more congested it became until Ceil saw walls that towered above the forest canopy.
The lower half of the walls, level in height with the trees, had the same ancient structure as the ruins, but they had been fortified and built upon, doubling in height.
None of the city was visible beyond them.
Fairy soldiers stood guard atop the newly fortified gatehouse and wall walk, watching the slow march of the refugees.
The congested procession slowed to a standstill as the refugees were ushered group by group through the gateway.
Ceil grew more nervous with every step, and when she was close enough to see the teeth of the portcullis and the thin vines hanging down from them, her anxiety made her heart throb painfully.
She could easily announce who she was and enter the city quickly ahead of the other refugees, but she had no way of knowing how they would react.
Would they blame her for the destruction of Vallen and the genocide of their people?
If I were them, I would, she thought.
Sammy wrapped her arm around Ceil’s waist and held her close.

Ceil wanted to push her away and drown in the suffering that she knew she had caused, but the crowd was pushing Sammy against her just as much as Sammy was embracing her, so Ceil let Sammy try to comfort her, even though her heart would not be comforted.
She stood neck-deep in the murky depths of her pained heart, and the waves lapped at her face for every cry that reached her ears.
Part of her wanted to drown in the putrid waters and end the agony once and for all.
When their turn arrived at the gate, Ceil fell silent.
Sammy spoke to the fairy guard in her place.
“We found this young boy in the forest.
Is there somewhere in the city where he can be cared for?”
“There is a representative from the orphanage on the other side of the gate,” the guard replied, visibly astonished with Sammy’s linguistic ability.
“What city have you come from?”
“We are not from Vallen, but we have business here.
We came from Melia.”
“Melia?”
Sammy pointed to Lemi, and the guard eyed the Anthousai and Coby who stood on her shoulders like an incredibly large headdress, scattering some of the petals in her moss-like hair.
The other refugees grew restless from the longer-than-normal conversation, desperately wanting to enter the safety of the walls, so the guard quickly gave Sammy permission to pass through.
She held back the long vines hanging from the portcullis to let Chloe and the young boy pass.
Ceil followed next and then Lemi.
Coby hopped off Lemi and waited patiently for Sammy to follow.
Coby bellowed a fearsome cry that echoed through the tunnel.
Ceil looked behind her for the reason.
There Sammy was held against the wall with a thick white cord around her neck.
“Human,” a female voice announced in an alarming shout, and guards appeared on both sides of the tunnel.
No one else questioned Sammy’s appearance, and they were not attacking Chloe.
How did they know?
Ceil realized the reason for the vines.
If they were a conduit for a life mage, anyone who touched them could get scanned.
It was likely meant for quarantine in case someone came to such a populated refugee city with a transmittable disease, but at the same time, it could also check the race of the individual.
Sammy was the only one who touched the vines.
Coby jumped and grabbed the cord on Sammy’s neck with his beak to try and break it, but it held taught.
Sammy’s face grew red then a light shade of purple, and saliva drained from her mouth.
It continued tightening as if something was pulling it from inside the wall.
Something was pulling it.
There was a nymph in the stone, an oread, and the white cord was made from her hair.
When the guards from outside the wall neared, Coby faced them and flapped his wings.

The funnel of wind sent the small fairies flying back into the crowds, and the force of the wind strengthened by the tunnel knocked the refugees down, creating a cascade of bodies in the congested line.
Lemi pulled her bowstring, aiming at the soldiers approaching from the city, but hesitated to fire.
Chloe was unable to help protect anyone with the child in her arms.
“On the name of Ceil, widow of Emperor Yuro Amel, Empress of the Amelian Empire, I demand you release this human!”
Ceil slammed her staff into the wall near Sammy, its clack echoing through the tunnel.
The cord grew slack, and Sammy gasped for breath, falling to her knees.
The soldiers approached, but Ceil held her staff in front of Sammy, acting as her guard.
“Stand down,” she ordered.
The soldiers slowed and then halted.
Lemi ran to Sammy to heal the rope burn and any damage the cord might have caused her neck.
Coby’s wings spanned the width of the tunnel and blocked the soldiers who had recovered and returned from outside the wall.
His single cry of warning was enough to hold them back.
A guard bearing an insignia on his breast, possibly a ranking officer, approached from the city-side entrance of the tunnel.
He stopped short of Ceil and looked up into her eyes.
“I am Salim, captain of the guard.
What connection do you have to Empress Ceil?”
His voice held doubt, but his expression was not accusatory.
No one would be daring, or foolish, enough to use the empress’s name without connection to her.
“I am Ceil.
Should I show you my tails?”
“That will not be necessary.”
Salim ushered a much taller guard forward.
This guard was two heads taller than Ceil, a male High Elf.
The man held out his hand, and when Ceil touched it, she felt a pulse travel through her arm and down to her lower back.
Ceil’s chest pounded hard enough for her head to throb.
She could no longer escape.
However this city viewed her, she would find out now.
The High Elf knelt immediately, pressing his face to the stone.
“Empress.”
The oread walked out of the wall, her flowing white gown catching in the wind of the tunnel.
She looked every bit a human aside from her vibrant orange hair.
She prostrated herself before Ceil.
“I have made a grave error, and I will accept any punishment for harming your companion.”
Salim knelt, and all the soldiers followed.
“We sincerely apologize for our rudeness.
We never expected that you would come here, or that you would have a human in your company.”
Relief washed over Ceil.
She looked over at Sammy who smiled back wearily and without any ire.
“If Sammy died, things would be different.
You were only performing your duties, so I will not punish you.
Although Sammy is human, she and her people are not of Tolmyur and are enemies to Jethro and his armies the same as us.”
“We are eternally grateful for your clemency.”
“Your eternity may come sooner than you think.
I must speak with whoever is in charge of Revlan’s defenses, the marshal, or other city official.”
“The inner sanctum of the temple in the center of the city has been repurposed into the council chamber for the resistance.
All key officials should be there.
We can guide you.”
A female guard approached Chloe.
“We can take the child for you here.
I will make certain he receives the best care.”
Ceil nodded for Chloe to set down the child.
The fairy guard, short enough to be a child herself, grabbed his quivering hand.
“You can treat him no different than any of the other children.
If you could provide better care for any one of the orphans, should you not already be doing so for all of them?”
The guard bowed deeply.
“Yes, Your Highness.
It is as you say.”
“I will lead you to the temple,” the captain of the guard announced.
“Clear the way!”
The soldiers blocking the path to the tunnel exit parted and stood at attention along the walls.
Ceil offered her hand to Sammy.
“Are you alright?”
“I’m fine.
Lemi patched me up.
I’m more startled than anything else now.
How can that woman enter the wall?”
Salim led them towards the exit of the tunnel, and Ceil pulled Sammy to follow.
“Oreads look human but are stone elementals.
Some elementals are able to meld with their environment.
Nymphs are one of the few with this capability.
Golems for example are stone elementals but cannot.”
“Even their clothes?
And that rope?”
“Nymphs are spinners.
They use their own hair to make silk.
The color is only vibrant when it is attached.
When cut, it fades white and frays into many fine fibers.
When a nymph weaves clothing from her own hair, she can treat it as her body.
The cord was the same.
It was made from her hair.”
“So they could easily find out I am not an oread by plucking one of my hairs?” Chloe asked.
“They could.
I did not think of that, but it is not an issue now.
I do not think any of the soldiers will harm you once they are informed, but we should still be careful in the city.
The refugees and citizens may be less… controlled than the soldiers.”
The tunnel opened into a bailey, or perhaps it was too large for a bailey.
The field stretched for a half mile until reaching the inner walls that stood only slightly taller than the perimeter walls.
The air carried a pungent aroma of bodies and refuse.
Small tents were packed as close together as was possible in order to house the innumerable refugees arriving at the city.

The extravagant paved road suggested that this may have once been a beautiful park courtyard outside the city proper but was fashioned into a refugee camp after removing all the trees, shrubbery, and other structures that may have been present.
The outer wall hugged the courtyard and then widened outward with the inner wall, creating the shape of the thin neck of a pear if the city was larger in diameter.
Soldiers clad in light leather administered food and aid to the refugees, directing them where to camp or seek other assistance.
A benefit of the fairy’s small stature was that they could be packed together in small spaces if needed.
Against the perimeter wall, scaffolds had been constructed to fit multiple levels of tents atop one another.
The courtyard appeared filled to bursting, and there were still so many on the road desiring to enter.
“This is terrible,” Chloe whispered barely loud enough for Ceil to hear.
The refugees paid Ceil little attention, only following her and her companions with their eyes if not occupied elsewhere.
Ceil refrained from eye contact, only looking at the inner wall and the domed cylindrical structure even further in the distance that barely showed above it.
The inner wall was not like the ruins.
It was new, clearly constructed by earth mage artisans for defense of the inner city.

The only remains of what could have been the original ruins were the pointed archway leading to steps downward through a tunnel half the length of the perimeter wall’s gatehouse and the towers that rose every hundred yards or so along the inner wall.
To the sides, the space between the inner and perimeter walls was also being used for the refugee camp.
If the space circled the entire city, then perhaps they would have room for them all, unless that too was as filled as the courtyard.
The steps through the inner wall only descended the height of a single-story structure.
What met them on the other side helped Ceil understand why Revlan, the third most populous city in Vallen, was known as the western capital.
It was a grand sunken city of stone spread in a wide oblong circle.
Where they stood was only one of three sunken tiers of the city.
The structures of the first tier just below ground level rose to the height of the inner wall, and those of the second tier rose to the level of the first.
Thin towers at the end of stone bridges overlooked the sunken city from above, connected intermittently to the bases of the towers of the inner wall.
Trees and shrubs grew atop the flat-top structures with their roots, boughs, and vines running down the sides.
The stone of the ruins was in pristine condition as if time had never touched them.
The tiers of the city rose near the center until reaching a curtain wall at ground level.
The structures beyond it were far grander than those on the tiers, and a cylindrical, domed structure sat in the center with wide towers overlooking the city.
That was likely the temple and their destination.
Sammy and Chloe stood frozen with slack jaws atop the steps down to the second tier.
Having only seen Fiorrae, Melia, and a single ruined town a small fraction of this city’s size, Ceil understood their amazement.
Amel and the Amelian palace were grander, but the natural beauty living in harmony with ancient stone was breathtaking even for Ceil.
“All those ruins we saw, did they all have cities underneath them like this?
And that wall in the center of the city looks just like the wall at Nalain.
Does that mean there was a giant city surrounding it underground there as well?”
“I would not be able to answer that,” Ceil replied, waving at them to follow.
“This looks like a dwarven city.
Are there caves here too?” Chloe asked, trotting down the steps to Ceil.
“Dwarves live on mountains, not underground or in caves,” Ceil replied.
“Oh, I guess I shouldn’t expect stories from Earth to apply here.”
“I’m glad there’s a lot of green here,” Lemi exclaimed cheerfully.
The lower tiers of the city were very crowded, but not nearly as dense as the refugee camp.
The upper tiers appeared to be homes with the lowest tiers being craftshops and the mid tiers having many interspersed vendors between the residences.
They did not need to enter the lowest tier of the city, keeping to an elevated walkway that crossed it.
The steps up the tiers to the center of the city were wide.
The structures were grander and the gardens atop them more landscaped.
Guards stood before the gateway of the curtain wall and saluted the captain of the guard as he passed.
Ceil refrained from eye contact and did not mind that they treated her like some inconsequential visitor.
In time, the entire city would know who she was and that she was here, so she wanted to bask in the anonymity while she could.
The first tier of the inner city was the only location in the city that was not crowded.
Extravagant homes for city officials and large manors for nobles lined the inside of the wall.
The large, peaceful gardens and hedged borders gave the illusion that the city was not in the midst of a war that threatened its destruction.
The servants still tended the gardens, and the nobles Ceil passed chatted freely as if the hordes of refugees entering their city to escape slaughter did not concern them.
Their indifference infuriated her.
Millions of fairies had died.
Did these fools think themselves immune?
The apathy of the nobles soured Ceil’s mood as she climbed the steps to the temple grounds.
The captain of the guard led Ceil to the large cylindrical structure.
Pointed arch windows surrounded its three floors, and its polished white dome reflected the sun.
Unlike the rest of the city, this was the only structure without vegetation growing off it.
The main hall contained altars to the four elements and statues of the deities representing the first ancestor of each race of elfkind.
It was not unlike the Temple of the Gods on the palace grounds.
Ceil looked up at the towering, gilded statue of the first High Elf.
He held a sickle at his side and a bundle of grain across his chest.
The inscription at the base of the statue in Amel read “Nelhah-vlensi,” to lead the nations, but this statue bore the inscription “Nelhah-mein-ceil,” to nourish the nations.
“Her Highness, Empress Ceil, has come to speak with the generals,” Salim announced to the four soldiers standing guard in front of a large double door.
Almost forgetting proper form, they scrambled to open the door and bowed their heads as Ceil passed.
A small, circular inner sanctum sat at the end of a long, sun-lit corridor which felt strange considering there were no windows, and the sun holes did not appear to reach outside.
Some strange architecture was at work to transfer the sunlight into the corridor and inner sanctum.
The voices of those seated around the circular table echoed perfectly off the stone, each as clear as if they were standing beside Ceil.
“Now that Nalain has fallen, we must begin preparations for battle.”
“You need not worry, Thorn General.
Your age has made you fearful.
I have turned this city into the greatest fortress in the Empire.”
“A fortress does nothing unless properly defended, Lord Olvor,” replied a young, bearded fairy directly across the table from the corridor.
“We lost five thousand valiant soldiers in Nalain.
That only leaves us ten thousand soldiers against the unknown many of Tolmyur.
We must begin training the citizens of the city and the refugees.
The enemy is already on our doorstep.”
“Leave matters of war to the Thorn General,” Lord Olvor rebuked.
“You should be focusing on the worsening refugee situation.”

“We would still have those five thousand soldiers, and the five thousand innocent civilians would have survived if you listened to me and evacuated Nalain,” the bearded fairy replied, pounding his fist on the table.
Ceil saw a black scar on the bearded fairy’s wrist.
Memories of the Gallanvale flooded her mind.
The decision of what cities she would hide in.
The destruction of Yeai, Ofaeth, and Hor.
The appearance of Jethro’s army.
The slaughter.
And the marshal who sold her to Jethro because her death would save the fairies.
A black wave rose in the abyssal depths of Ceil’s heart, climbing ever higher and threatening to consume her.
The deathly skeletal specter reached around her and embraced her from behind, standing firm and breaking the force of the wave to prevent her from being swept away.
It laughed into her ear, a laugh that escaped Ceil’s lips as a whisper.
Ceil sprinted for the table.
The rigid wood of her red cedar staff cracked, and the tip grew two long, jagged spines.
The marshal only managed to glance at Ceil before she dove onto the table and impaled him in the chest.
Her momentum carried him over his chair, toppling it to the ground, and she pinned him to the wall.
The sanctum was in an uproar.
“What is the meaning of this!?”
“Lady Ceil?”
The voice of Chief Advisor Kiri that Ceil had nearly forgotten fell deaf on her ears.
“Why did you live,” Ceil whispered through her teeth.
“To save what your existence has doomed,” the marshal replied through bloodied gargles.
Ceil gripped her staff tight, the splinters from its cracks cutting into her hands.
All the ven she could give flowed through the staff.
Black splotches grew on the marshal’s skin and quickly grew into seething blisters.
The blood draining from his mouth grew dark and putrid.
His skin sagged until all at once it rotted off his body as his wailing cries echoed through the stone sanctum.
His tissue softened and his flesh melted, seeping through his clothes onto the floor at Ceil’s feet.
No one approached.
Sammy, Chloe, and Lemi watched in horror from the corridor.
An ominous silence filled the room where the cries had grown silent.
Life magic could be used for both help and harm, but none in the room had witnessed true death magic until now.
“Ceil…”
A small hand rested on Ceil’s shoulder.
She turned and saw pure terror in Kiri’s eyes.
Ceil looked at the moist skeleton at the end of the staff and the blackened puddle of gore at her feet.
She dropped the staff and corpse and stepped back, nearly tripping over the toppled chair, until her back hit the table.
“Has the girl gone mad,” one of the fairies cried.
“No,” the eldest fairy in the room replied.
“Ceil would not act in such hatred without a cause.”
His slender face was affixed into stern chastisement of the council member who spoke, the glare accentuating the deep creases of his eyes.
His hairline receded halfway over his head, but his white hair was long and looped many times into a low ponytail with a dark green ribbon.
The robe he wore was faded, but the ample colors and intricate embroidery showed that it had once been quite exquisite in its time.
“What reason could Lady Ceil have to kill the Rose General in such a horrendous manner?!”
“…Rose General…?” Ceil looked across the table at the most recent voice.
“He was the Rose General?
You made him, of all the fairies, the highest welfare authority in Vallen?”
“He singlehandedly evacuated a dozen of the smallest villages before the armies of Tolmyur arrived.
He always kept two steps ahead of them.”
“What crime could he possibly have committed that deserved such punishment,” another fairy shouted.
“Ceil, tell us,” Kiri pleaded.
Ceil looked across all the angry and terrified faces, stopping on the eldest fairy who only smiled lovingly back.
“Do you truly not know?
He was the one who informed Jethro that I was in Vallen.
Because of him, all of Vallen--”
Angry shouts and accusations against the legitimacy of Ceil’s claim assaulted her from all around the table.
Ceil could not stop herself from shaking.
Sammy ran around the table and held Ceil to shield her from the voices raised against her.
“Is that a human?” Lord Olvor hollered, standing from his chair.
“She has brought a human into my city?
The Rose General would never betray us!
That girl is a traitor!”
The eldest fairy swung his fist, knocking Lord Olvor beside him unconscious with strength unseemly for one of his years.
“I will not allow anyone here to speak treason against our empress!”
The voices died around the table.
Ceil looked up from Sammy’s shoulder at the fairy, questioning why he alone would take her side.
“If we doubt our empress now, all hope in the future of our empire will fall.
Ceil is not one to make such fabrications,” he asserted.
“Then what of that human?”
“I am not from Tolmyur,” Sammy shouted in the Gallanvale tongue of the fairies.
“Jethro is my enemy as much as he is yours.
Shame on all of you for questioning Ceil’s loyalty.
You have no idea how much this conflict has tormented her or how much she blames herself for it!”
Tears flowed down Sammy’s face enough for both Ceil and her.
“She has even wanted to take her own life out of hope that her death will end your people’s suffering.
And now you throw that loyalty back in her face and accuse her of treason?”
Everyone but the eldest fairy was stunned silent.
“Sammy, that is enough,” Ceil said, clinging to what felt like her only friend in a world that despised her.
“Ceil is the first empress in history with fairy blood,” the eldest fairy announced.
“And you question her commitment to this conflict?
By my right as Thorn General, I should have you all executed.”
No one in the sanctum could speak, and Ceil looked back at the Thorn General in disbelief.
The Thorn General left his chair and walked to Sammy and Ceil.
He grasped Sammy’s hand and bowed, pressing the back of her hand to his forehead.
“Thank you for being there for my granddaughter in her greatest time of trial.”

Chapter 9
“Ceil”
Ceil
The Thorn General dismissed the council.
Only Ceil and her companions, the Thorn General, and Chief Advisor Kiri remained.
Three life mages were called in, one to carry out Lord Olvor for treatment and two to clean the remains of the Rose General in case contact with the body was hazardous.
Lemi would not even approach it and appeared more terrified of it than anyone else had been.
Ceil felt bad for scaring Lemi--she scared herself after realizing what horrid magic she just used, magic she never learned--but she felt justified in what she did.
She may have been the purpose of the genocide, but he was the cause.
“Let us go somewhere more comfortable to speak,” the Thorn General said, leaving the two High Elves to their traumatizing cleanup.
The Thorn General led them off the temple grounds and around to the other side of the noble district to an estate far smaller than most of the others.
The two-story ancient manor had a well-kept yard and garden, but the plants on the structure were allowed to grow freely, giving it a sylvan beauty different than the other manors.
Lemi was pleased with the forested appearance and pranced across the garden to admire the long fern-like fronds draping down one of the windows, her dava clacking lightly all the while.
“Lemi, we are going inside,” Sammy called.
“Let her be.
She can enter whenever she pleases.
Cities of stone are often unnerving for dryads, especially the young ones,” the Thorn General said.
“Coming!
I want to be part of the talking, too.”
Lemi ran, gathered her dava, and hopped the small gate instead of opening it.
She followed Sammy inside while the Thorn General held open the intricately carved floral door.
Although the outside of the structure was stone, the inside was warm and welcoming.
Polished wood panels covered the walls, floors, and ceiling to hide the stone.
Large rugs decorated with nature patterns covered most of the floor.
The furniture was finely crafted, but most was small and meant for the short stature of the fairies.
The ceiling was high enough for a fully grown High Elf to stand comfortably, hinting that the original inhabitants of the ancient city were not small like the fairies.
Even the rooms were lavishly decorated with indoor plants to match the lush green exterior.
“I do not have enough chairs for taller guests, but I do have plentiful cushions to sit on,” the Thorn General said.
He led them to a lounge with a low table in the center and bookshelves lining the walls.
A large portrait of a much younger general in regal armor hung from the wall opposite the outward-facing window.
“Kiri, I have cushions in the storage room upstairs.
Do you mind retrieving them while I prepare food and drink?”
“Gladly.” Kiri disappeared up the tight spiral steps beside the central hallway.
“We cannot impose on you like this,” Sammy said, speaking for Ceil who remained silent since the accusations against her in the inner sanctum.
“Do you not have servants like the other nobles?”
“While most retired persons of status would prefer to spend their time lazing about as others pampered them, such a lifestyle would drive me mad.
As the former Thorn General, I feel I must keep active.
If such a time comes when I can no longer care for myself, I will accept my end peacefully.
I never thought that I would be pulled out of retirement by a war that killed my successor in the first battle.”
“Then even the yard and garden?”
“Gardening is quite cathartic, it turns out,” the Thorn General chuckled.
Sammy grew a lonely smile.
“My mother said the same thing.
We hire groundskeepers to take care of our property, but my mother always had her own personal garden they were not allowed to touch.”
“Your language ability is astonishing, Lady Sammy.
You speak as if you were raised in the Gallanvale.
Might I assume that you have had dealings with the Sprite Arkhon?”
“How did you know?” Sammy asked, wide-eyed.
“That will be part of our discussion.”
Kiri returned carrying six floor cushions, and the Thorn General helped place them around the low table.
They were flat but surprisingly soft and supported weight well without feeling the hard floor underneath.
Coby alone opted to perch on the short settee against the window.
“Sorry, Kiri, but our conversation held me up and I was unable to bring out refreshments.
Could you help me?”
“Can I help too?” Lemi asked.
“Of course.”
The three left the room leaving Ceil alone with Sammy and Chloe beside her at the table.
“Are you okay?” Sammy asked, rubbing Ceil’s shoulder.
Ceil did not answer.

The events in the inner sanctum were what she expected to happen when the fairies learned her identity, that she would be labeled a traitor for bringing this destruction upon Vallen, but she did not expect their ire to come from her execution of one who was just as guilty.
That conflict tormented her.
Was she in the right to kill him?
She did not regret it, but thinking on what the both of them had accomplished since the assassination, perhaps the council was right to be furious.
Ceil had spent every day being cared for by the sprites in Fiorrae while the former marshal was working hard to save lives ahead of the Tolmyur army.
Once she left Fiorrae, it was one mistake after another.

Her identity was discovered, she gave someone important to the war--someone dear to Sammy--into the hands of the enemy, and she pulled Dhuillir into the conflict when they would have otherwise been safe.
“Ceil, look at me,” Chloe said, placing her hand gently on Ceil’s other shoulder.
“Nobody expects you to be perfect or make the right decision all the time.
I don’t know what happened back there or if what you did was right or wrong, but I trust you.”
“Would you trust me… even if you might die because of me?”
Chloe’s brush with death was still fresh on Ceil’s mind, and now they were in a city that the Tolmyur army would inevitably assault, placing them in further danger.
“The Sprite Arkhon said I was important to this war, right?
I think that means I won’t die so easily.
I hope.
But my magic is strong for some reason, so I’m more than happy to use it to help you.
Jethro is evil, and you are trying to help people.
That is good enough reason for me.
You don’t need to be perfect.
Just keep doing what you think is right.”
Chloe’s words lifted a small weight from Ceil’s heart, helping her breathe a little easier, but it did not remove the guilt.
Ceil considered Sammy a dear friend, but she had only viewed Chloe as one of Sammy’s companions, simply an addition to their party.
If Chloe is willing to risk her life following me…
No, she already almost died following my orders…
Ceil remembered her own fearful cry when she saw Chloe injured in her fight against the soldiers in Melia.
I knew, but I never treated Chloe as a friend.
“Sorry,” Ceil said, bowing her head and trying to hold back her tears.
Sammy and Chloe embraced Ceil from both sides.
“Sorry,” Ceil repeated.
“Snacks!” Lemi exclaimed, entering the lounge with a tray in hand.
She looked at the scene and paused.
“Is Ceil alright?”
“I am fine.”
Ceil nudged Sammy and Chloe to return to their cushions.
“Thank you.”
Lemi set down her tray on the table.
It was topped with circular, frilled biscuits, cheese, and fruit.
The Thorn General entered next carrying a platter of carved, salt-cured meat.
Kiri followed right behind him with a tray of brass goblets and a large silver carafe with steam wafting from the top.
She set the tray down and filled everyone’s goblets while Sammy selected some fruit and meat to give Coby to keep him occupied.
“This is more of a meal than a snack,” Chloe said as she picked through the fruit.
“Lemi, one of your petals got in my drink,” Sammy chuckled.
“A petal falling in your glass is a sign of good luck,” Kiri explained.
“Perhaps more so because it is from an anthousai.”
Sammy took a sip from her goblet and blinked quickly a few times.
“Is this wine?”
“It is not strong.
One of the best lessons my superior taught me long ago was that wine loosens the lips and supports the heart when discussing heavy topics,” the Thorn General said.
Ceil took a light sip and felt the comforting warmth flow down her throat.
“Tell me,” she swirled the faint red liquid in her goblet, “are you really my grandfather?”
The Thorn General closed his eyes and nodded.
“I suppose we should start from there.”
He took a swig of his wine and breathed deep.
“My name is Dharin, twin brother of the late Fairy High King Dhurin, and I am your great grandfather.”
“How can that be?
My entire family was High Elves.
We never had any fairies in our lineage.
And if we did, the emperor would have never taken me to wife.
Would that not go against the royal family’s pure heritage?”
“One thing at a time,” Kiri said.
Ceil stared at the Chief Advisor.
“Did you know?
Did you know all the way back then?”
“Both Dharin and King Dhurin are my grandfathers, Dharin from my mother’s side and King Dhurin from my father’s.
I am your first cousin once removed.
The maid that served so bravely as your Namie… Vera was my daughter, your second cousin.

We did not know who of our household your family discussed openly, so she was under my orders to never divulge her name out of fear that you or others might discover your lineage now that you would be wife to Emperor Yuro and involved with High Elf nobility and other racial purists.
You were born in the Gallanvale, not on the plains of Filinceil.
Your family moved to Heivleil shortly after your birth.”
“Your grandfather was not a legitimate child,” Dharin explained.

“I regret to say it was a passing fancy of my youth that I intended to forget, but your great grandmother raised him together with her other High Elf children with such love and devotion that I felt obligated to stay involved.
I am glad that I did.
His son, your father, was tall despite his fairy blood, so the truth of his ancestry remained a family secret.
I only met you once when you were an infant during your naming, right after I retired and Kiri’s husband became Thorn General.”
“Was that not bad?
My parents hid the fact that I was part fairy from the emperor when they sold me to him.”
“Yuro knew about you and your ancestry before your father spread news of your tails among the nobles.

The original plan was for the empire to watch over you in secret, but because of your father’s foolish actions to make quick money during the famine, when he revealed your existence to lesser nobles, Yuro claimed you first so that you could be better protected.”
“That does not make any sense.
Why would the emperor know about me?
I never became important until I was his wife.”
Dharin took another swig of his wine, and Kiri topped off his goblet.
“This is where the discussion grows heavy.
There is only one other High Elf in all the empire who has two tails, and she is very old, a hundred and twelve now if I am correct, or perhaps she has already passed.
The sprites have a powerful foresight.

In their predictions, a High Elf girl would be born with two tails, and her birth was to be the sign of the greatest catastrophe since the destruction of the ancient civilization in whose ruins we now reside.
The empress of the time, Denever, prepared to defend the Amelian Empire from whatever calamity might befall it, but nothing happened.
Many resources were wasted, and the fear created undue civil unrest.
She and the next two Emperors lost faith in the foresight of the sprites, so the fairy kings inherited the mantle of the sprites’ prophesies.
The sprites only communicate with one who will listen, and they always communicate with someone.
“My father was the Fairy High King at the time, so I knew Yuro from when he was a child.
The Sprite Arkhon was always in conversation with my family, so I was able to convince Yuro to trust the sprites as his ancestors once had.
It was fortuitous that the sign not only reappeared during the reign of an emperor who would believe in it, but it appeared as one of my descendants.”
“If he knew this was going to happen, why did he not stop it?” Sammy asked.
“That is because it has not started yet, Lady Sammy.
As terrible as this war is, it is only the precursor of far worse events to come.

In gratitude to Yuro for restoring faith in the sprites, the sprites informed him of his fate, that he would not live to see the fulfillment of their prophesy, so he chose instead to raise his heir with as much knowledge as he could so that she would be able to prepare the empire against the coming storm.”
“My birth was just the sign?
Then why did I need to be protected?
And if I only needed to be protected, why did he make me his wife?”
Ceil’s eyes darkened as she peered into the dark red of her goblet.
“I mean… I would have accepted it if he had showed me affection, if he had tried to get to know me… if he truly wanted to love me…”
“I do not doubt that Yuro had no love for you, as sad as it may sound.
He was fundamentally a traditionalist who believed strongly in the pure bloodline of the royal family.
He never could have imagined that you would become the empress.
I do not know the full reason for his decision, but my guess is that your role in this tale was not limited to the sign of your birth.
You may be vital in ending the calamity or leading the people through it.
We do not know.
All we knew was to protect you until your time, an order given us directly by the Sprite Arkhon.
What better protection could there be for you than as a wife to the Emperor of the Amelian Empire?”
“So I was to be doomed to a life without love…”
Ceil fell silent and looked at the goblet in her hands.
The wine was growing cold, so Chloe retrieved it to warm it for her.
“Do you know why your mother named you Ceil?” Dharin asked after handing his goblet to Chloe to request the same service.
Soon everyone was passing their goblets to Chloe.
“She wanted me to live my life as a modest farm girl.”
Dharin shook his head.
“Ceil is one of the oldest roots in the High Elf language.
Yes, it means grain, but it also can be interpreted as life.
Are you aware of the ancient name of the High Elves?”
“Grassland Elves.”

“Those monikers were adopted shortly before the creation of the Amelian Empire as a means of unifying the races under a single name, only distinguishing them by their location, hence Forest Elf for spriggans, Mountain Elf for trolls, or Sea Elf for sirens.
The Grassland Elves are the only true elves, and they had another name, the Celadrian, or ‘Ceil-adri-han’.”
“Givers of grain?”
“Providers of life,” Sammy replied.
Dharin smiled warmly at Sammy.
“It appears your gift of translation has revealed to us the proper meaning.
They may have received their name from their agricultural prowess or due to their natural affinity to life magic that made them renowned as healers.
In either case, your name is the origin of the High Elves.
Your mother named you Ceil with the blessing that you would become a shining beacon to provide hope to the High Elves, and by extension the whole empire, in the coming trials.
Your father protested the name at first, but he lacked the same heart for poetry as your mother.
He only saw it as an ear of grain in the literal sense.”
The conversation fell silent, either to give Ceil time to process what was said or because no more needed to be discussed on the topic.
Ceil vaguely remembered Kiri saying something similar to her long ago, that what the empire needed most was a beacon.
She did not know how to respond or if she even should.
Again she felt as if the wrong person was sitting here.
Emperor Yuro raised Eydis to lead the people, not her.
Ceil was only raised with the most basic knowledge of politics and rule, because her caretakers believed Ceil’s duty was in the bed of the emperor, not standing before the people.
“I…” Before Ceil could voice her apprehensions, Lemi’s head fell forward into the table, sitting motionless with sleepy breaths.
“It seems the wine was a bit much for her,” Kiri said, moving to lay her on the floor with her cushion as a pillow.
“I was wondering if wine was okay for someone as young as her to drink,” Sammy mused.
“Nonsense.
Wine of this potency would be safe for even children.
Dryads only lack the means to process alcohol,” Dharin explained.
“Are you sure?
I started feeling it after only half a glass,” Sammy said.
“A dryad stomach, eh?
You do look a bit red in the face.
The young miss here seems to be fine, though.”
“Of course Chloe would,” Sammy sighed.
“Chloe, is the wine strong to you?
You’ve never drank before, right?”
Chloe was visibly surprised by the question, unable to follow the conversation.
“I don’t really know.
I think my body is just burning off the alcohol.”
“I should have guessed,” Sammy said, exasperated.
“Is this what you’ve been talking about?
I thought the conversation would have been more serious.”
“No.
I’ll explain everything to you afterwards.
Maybe I can convince the Arkhon to make you understand languages too next time I see him.
The lingering headache for a few days is definitely worth it.”
“My guess is that Lady Chloe has a fire belly,” Dharin replied.
“Am I correct?”
“That’s more or less what she said.
At least I’m not as bad as Lemi,” Sammy smiled.
“Young Lemi’s not drunk in the same sense as we would be.
Alcohol only numbs dryads and makes them sleepy.
If you want to inebriate a dryad, offer them sugar.
The sweeter the better,” Dharin said with a wide smile.
“Does that mean that those berries the epimeliad gave me were like the highest-grade alcohol to them?!”
“You were presented fruit by an epimeliad?
You are special,” Dharin said.
“If you are to be one of such renown, you should try to build your alcohol tolerance.
Those in power will think less of you if you pass out after only a goblet or two.”
“Maybe.
Eydis never seemed to get drunk, so that makes sense.”
“As I suspected.
You are acquainted with the missing princess.
I am most interested in hearing about your story and how you got involved in all this.”
“We were more than acquainted.
She was my best friend.”
Sammy explained her history with Eydis and Jethro’s attack on Gullivan.
Her story felt practiced like she was reading from a script because of how often she had given it.
She included how she arrived with Chloe and Justin in Fiorrae and the events in Melia.
Because Dharin knew of the sprites’ prophesies, she included that Chloe and Justin were also important to the war according to them.
Ceil tensed when Sammy explained the deal made with the Tolmyur commander that brought them to Vallen.
She was terrified to see how Dharin or Kiri would react to hearing that she did not return to fight with them, only to seek Justin’s return.
She felt worse now that she came with such a goal, and the first thing she did in front of the leaders of the resistance was kill someone working to protect the people.
Ceil buried her face in her arms on the table, lacking the courage to look Dharin and Kiri in the eyes.
“Ceil, once you regain your companion, I feel it best that you flee the city,” Dharin said.
Ceil’s head shot up from her arms.
She looked at the loving gaze of her great grandfather with bewilderment.
She was fully prepared to fight in this battle and lose her life if that was her fate.
“If what Lady Sammy says is true, the enemy will be at our gates when Sir Justin is returned.
If he and Lady Chloe are also vital to the approaching conflict, we cannot have them or you die in some inconsequential battle.”
“You do not know if this battle is inconsequential,” Ceil shouted, rising to her knees.
“I am tired of running.”
“No, Ceil.
You are tired of living.”
Ceil sat back into her cushion.
Dharin’s words stole her breath and stopped her heart.
His words rang true, painfully true, and she could not deny them no matter how much she wanted to.
“But, you cannot throw your life away.

I will not lie to you and say the future will be bright or that things will miraculously get better, but what I can tell you is what I have witnessed, that you have friends who love you dearly and who will support you through your darkest moments.”
Sammy reached her arm around Ceil and pulled her close, resting her head against hers.
“I will not force you to leave,” Dharin continued.
“The decision is yours.
We may yet survive this battle.
Tolmyur’s campaign has been long, and their soldiers are tired.
Their progress has slowed much in the past days, and they lost many in Nalain.
We lack in soldiers but not in numbers.
As much of a fool as Lord Olvor is, he has done well in fortifying his city.
You have until Sir Justin arrives to make your decision, because afterwards, battle will be upon us.”
“I will think about it,” Ceil said begrudgingly, “but… thank you for telling me all this.
I just wish someone would have told me a long time ago.”
Dharin drained his goblet and set it on the table, refusing Kiri’s offer to refill it by placing his hand over the top.
“I have enough rooms upstairs for you all to stay.
Please treat this old ruin as your home until the time comes when you leave or we do battle.”
“I will call for bed mats,” Kiri said as she headed for the door.
“I am sure you would prefer to have some your size.”

Chapter 10
“The Largest Regret”
Sammy
Dharin’s manor had seven rooms on the long hallway of the second floor.
The largest room at the back end of the hall belonged to the master of the house.
The others were all similar in size, about 200 square feet.
Kiri was using the room to the left of Dharin’s, and the room to the right was for storage.
The remaining four were decorated and stocked with basic furniture, but none of them had beds.
The bed mats in the storage were only long enough for fairies, but Kiri arrived shortly after dinner was finished with nearly a dozen fairies in toe carrying larger bed mats.
Lemi was laid on one in her own room to sleep off the alcohol, and almost the moment Chloe laid on hers to test it out, she was fast asleep as well.
Sammy claimed the room at the front end of the hall across from Lemi’s with a wide window looking out over the garden.
It provided its own fireplace to keep it warm, but Sammy still felt it rather cold, not because the walls and floor were stone but because Ceil decided that everyone would have their own room.
Ceil was in slightly better spirits after the long discussion, having gained a better understanding of her past, but she was still troubled.
Her desire for some solitude led to the decision.
Sammy had almost forgotten what it was like to not have someone in her arms or next to her while she slept, so she was not looking forward to the arrangement.
Coby would be there, but he only sat near her head.
She could hold him while she slept, but he wouldn’t be able to sleep like that.
Sammy thanked the fairies who laid out her bed mat.
When she sat down on it, she immediately understood why Chloe fell asleep so quickly.
The mat was the same material as the small cushions they sat on during dinner but about three times as thick.

Feeling it at this thickness, it was almost the same as contour foam, perhaps even better because no matter how much weight she tried to apply in the heavy gravity, she could not feel the hard floor beneath.
Perhaps they were so comfortable because of the high gravity, and on Earth they would be too firm.
The mat was dangerous.
After sleeping on moss and other groundcover for so long, the bed was heaven.
Sammy was excited that for once she might wake up without a bruise on her back, arms, or legs from prolonged contact with the ground in high gravity over the long nights.
The sun was only just setting, painting the overcast sky in red and purple.
Chloe had this incomprehensible ability to sleep as long as she wanted, but Sammy knew that if she went to bed now, she would wake up in the early morning alone and with nothing to do.
There were no herbs to gather or campfire embers to rekindle and play with.
She could not walk out into the city for fear of someone seeing her without the knowledge that she was with Ceil and attacking her.
Her eyelids were heavy, her head was light, and her body was warm from the alcohol, so it yearned to sleep, but Sammy could not let it.
She walked out of her room with uneven steps to the balcony at the front end of the hall.
The stone balustrade was covered with a thick, felt-like moss with a few drooping ferns interspersed along it.
A wooden bench sat along the base of the balustrade, perhaps for the fairies to stand on and look out over the garden.
Sammy giggled imagining frustrated fairies wanting to see into their yard, but the coping sat at eye level blocking their view.
She knelt on the bench and leaned into the balustrade, resting her chin on her folded arms.
“Damn, I’m drunk, aren’t I…
But, if I can say I’m drunk, does that mean I’m not that drunk?”
Sammy spotted a fairy noble in the distance walking along the wide cobblestone road outside the property.
“Hey!
Am I drunk!?”
“Yes, you are,” Ceil replied, pushing Sammy’s head back down onto her arms.
She then draped a blanket over Sammy’s shoulders.
“You really do have a dryad stomach.
It is not healthy to be out in the cold after you drink.”
Ceil sat down on the bench.
She leaned her head back over the coping and patted Sammy on the back.
Sammy turned on her knees and sat down onto the bench, pulling the blanket around her.
“If I get sick, Lemi will cure me.
And I’ll have you know, alcohol tolerance is determined by your body size and your genetics and your alcohol dehydrogenases in your liver.”
“I do not know what that means.”
“Your stomach has nothing to do with it.
That’s what it means.
Except Chloe.
She’s a fire breathing dragon or something.”
“Is she really?” Ceil’s eyes grew wide.
“No, but she could probably breathe fire if she wanted.”
Ceil breathed a sigh of relief.
“I would have no way of knowing if there were people on your world who could turn into dragons.
That would at least explain Chloe’s power.
What is your world like?”
Sammy pulled the blanket tight around her.
“It’s busy and boring and mean.
Everyone is selfish and only thinks about themselves.
You have to work so hard to survive, but the only people who can live rich, carefree lives are those born into it.
I would know!
I was one of them.”
“Were you royalty?
Is that why Eydis was with you?”
“Maybe as close to royalty as you can get in my country.
My dad owns this huge trade company, so we have more money than we know what to do with.
We don’t have kings or queens or empresses or anything like that.
And I told you many times.
Eydis lived with Justin, and I met her because I knew him.”
“Was Justin royalty?”
Sammy laughed.
“Nope.
He is a poor nobody.
I’m sure his net worth is twenty thousand or more in debt!”
Ceil’s eyes grew wider than they had when she thought Chloe could actually become a dragon.
“What?!
He’s not royalty or an important political or military figure?
Then why was the Tolmyur commander afraid of him?!
Why is he important to the war?
Why are we going through all this?”
“I’m here because I want him back!
Not because he is important to whatever the hell is going to happen.”
Tears fell from Sammy’s eyes.
“Sorry,” Ceil backpedaled.
“I did not mean it like that.
I just would have thought that… because you said he was Eydis’s lover, he would be royalty or nobility.”
Sammy wiped her tears and looked longingly at the floor of the balcony.
“He is rich in ways you can’t buy with money.
Doesn’t change that he’s a dumbass, though.”
“If your family was so wealthy and he poor, how did you know him?
Why is he everything to you?”
“Why are you asking such sobering questions?”
“You do not look sober,” Ceil said with a flat stare.
“Shut up!
I’ve had a lot of shitty relationships, okay?
Justin’s too, but he was different.
I had just gotten out of an abusive situation, but I didn’t realize it was abusive until the end.
He never attacked me or yelled at me, but he always made me feel guilty for wanting anything.
He would ask my opinions but would guilt-trip me if it was anything different than what he wanted.
We always ate what he wanted, went where he wanted, had sex when he wanted.

It got so bad that I felt like I didn’t have a right to have an opinion when it came to us, and I bought into it because I had so much growing up and others had so little, so I had no right to complain.
“When the bastard began telling me that I couldn’t go out with my friends, it was actually Chloe who got mad at me and told me that this was abuse.
I confronted him about it, and he began shouting at me saying that I only wanted everything to be my way, so I decked the fucker and left him.
It was only then that I realized how bad off I was.
I felt like shit, evil, like I had wronged him and that all this was my fault.
I couldn’t eat.
I skipped work, skipped my university classes.
I didn’t sleep.”
“And this was Justin?” Ceil looked at Sammy like she was prepared to melt Justin as she had the Rose General.
“What?
God, no!
I met Justin two days later.”
“Then what was that whole explanation for?”
“Perspective!”
“Your face is too close…”
Ceil sat Sammy back on the bench and urged her to continue.
“I was tired of Chloe asking if I was okay, so I avoided going back to my dorm as much as possible.
There is this tiny foyer outside the upper balcony of a seldom used lecture hall in the oldest building on campus.
No one goes there.
Nobody.
You wouldn’t even know about it unless you had a class in that room large enough to use the upper balcony, and I only ever heard of that happening once, and I was in that class!”
Ceil sighed.
“I understand.
What about this foyer?”
“I went there to be alone, but someone was there!
Guess who it was.”
“Justin?”
“Yes!
I didn’t want to go and find somewhere else to sit alone, so I sat down on the far end of the sofa from him.
Do you know the first thing he said to me?”
“How could I possibly know that?” Ceil sighed.
“He said, ‘You look terrible.’
Can you believe that?
Even if it was true, you should never say that to a girl!
I’ll have you know he looked pretty damned depressed himself.”
“Why was that?”
“I don’t know.
The moment I sat down, everything became about me.
He wouldn’t shut up asking what was wrong or if he could help.
I went there to be alone because Chloe kept on trying to give me advice.
I wasn’t about to ask some stranger for any.
When he asked if there was anything I wanted, I just said the first thing that came to mind.
Chocolate.”
“What is chocolate?”
“Is this translation thing working?”
Sammy poked her head.
“Maybe if I try in Elven.”
“You have been speaking Elven this whole time.
I do not think it can translate something that there is no equivalent for.”
“Whatever.
It’s a sweet.
Candy.
You have those at least, right?
Please tell me you know what candy is.”
“I understand that much,” Ceil sighed again, exasperated.
“Anyway, I asked for chocolate.
He grabs his backpack and removes an unopened variety pack with Hershey’s and Snickers and Milky Ways and whatnot and goes and sets the entire bag in my lap.
Who does that?
And why the hell was he carrying it anyway?
I mean, he was a little chubby back then, so maybe this was normal for him, but I never saw him randomly carrying around chocolate after that.
He wrote his name and number on a piece of paper and handed it to me and said that I could talk with him whenever I needed and then left.
Just like that.
“No matter how horrible I felt before, I forgot all of it.
I was confused!
It didn’t make any sense!
I just sat there staring at the hallway like an idiot.
So you know what I did?
I called him that evening to say I wanted to meet him the next day at his place to talk about what happened.
I returned to my dorm, took a shower, ate, and made sure I was all prettied up to meet him.”
“You wanted to appeal to him just because of confections?”
“Fuck no!” Sammy shouted, leaning her face into Ceil’s and forcing Ceil to lean back.
Ceil pushed Sammy lightly back so she could sit upright.
“You are rather vulgar when you are drunk.”
“I’m surprised profanity translates,” Sammy laughed with little care.
“Every language has foul words and expressions.
It seems yours focuses heavily on feces and intercourse.
It sounds bizarre in Elven, so do not use them in normal conversation.”
Sammy grabbed Ceil’s hand and stared at her with eager eyes.
“Teach me elven profanity!”
“No,” Ceil replied with a blank stare.
“Knowing you, you would get yourself into trouble.
Continue your story.
You beautified yourself before going to meet him.”
“Yah!” Sammy returned to her explanation as if the conversation about profanity never happened.
“After what I went through, I was tired of relationships.
I was expecting Justin to try and seduce me or ask me out or something because I was depressed or say something like ‘I will treat you better’ or some shit like that.
I made myself as pretty as possible to make it easier for him to do that or make him want to do that, and I was ready to punch him as hard as I could if he did.”
“Did he?”
“No!
He acted like I was the same depressed slob I was the day before!
Do you know how insulting it feels to go out of your way to look good and have someone not even acknowledge it?”
“I am confused.
Did you want him to try and seduce you or did you not want him to?”
“I don’t know.
I was so used to good looking, confident guys with a fetish for short girls that I didn’t even know what to do at that point.
I pulled out the bag of chocolates, broke it open, and told him what happened like I said I would over the phone.”
Sammy’s expression softened to the warm longing of a woman in love, and her face flushed redder than the alcohol.
Her rapid speech slowed as if she was reminiscing at every syllable.
“We talked the entire evening.
He got angry together with me and sad with me, and not once did he try to spin the discussion to his favor to get something out of me.
To him, I was a troubled girl in pain that he wanted to help solely for the purpose of helping me.
I was crying by the end and all he did was hold me.
I was so vulnerable in front of him and probably would not have resisted if he tried to force himself on me, but he didn’t.
He just held me.
That’s all.
I fell so hard for him right there, harder than I had fallen for anyone.
Or maybe, this was the first time I had ever actually fallen in love.”
Sammy wiped a tear from her cheek and chuckled wryly.
“Saying it like that makes me sound like an easy girl, falling in love after a bit of chocolate and kindness.”
“Did you suspect that he was being kind just to make you love him?”
Sammy slowly shook her head.
“I kept in contact with him and tried my best to be as close to him as I could, but he never showed any interest in a relationship.
He never made a move, so one day I asked him instead, but he turned me down immediately.
Can you believe that,” Sammy asked with a self-depreciating smile.
“I couldn’t.
That had never happened to me before.
I asked if he was already with someone, but he wasn’t.
I asked if he liked me, and he said he did.
I asked if he found me attractive, and he said he did.
But no matter how much I tried to pry the reason out of him, he wouldn’t tell me.”
“So you two were never in a relationship?
An unrequited love?”
Sammy flashed a confident grin.
“No, I pestered him about it for a month until he caved in.
Once Justin gave the okay, he was all in.
Being with Justin was the happiest I had ever been.
He went out of his way to make sure I was loved and cared for.
He still had his own life and responsibilities, but he made an effort to spend all his free time with me.
He listened to my opinions and desires, and when we disagreed, he was willing to compromise.
We argued from time to time, but that’s normal.
The only thing our relationship lacked was sex, but I was okay with that.
At first.
I mean, I want it as much as any guy would, and I really wanted it from him.”
“I would rather not hear about your bed stories.”
“Don’t worry… Because there are none!
Not one.
Ever!
Every attempt at trying to get intimate he brushed off.
Eventually I was upfront about it instead of trying to entice him into sex and he refused me flatly.
I even convinced Sean to leave so that we could be alone, but still nothing would ever happen.
I asked if he was celibate, and that was not the reason.
I asked if he was just abstaining until marriage, and that wasn’t it.
I asked if he was self-conscious about his penis size, but that wasn’t it.
I asked him if he was asexual, but nope.
I even asked if he was actually gay and was just with me because I loved him, but that wasn’t it either.

“He never told me why, so I thought it would be like the month I pestered him about a relationship, but the more I pushed, the harder he resisted until one night I got too forceful and he got mad and left.
I was left sitting naked on his couch wondering what was wrong.
When he returned, I apologized and didn’t bring it up again.
I went back to trying to simply be intimate in the hope that he would eventually change his mind, but I felt that a rift formed between us.
He became troubled about something and wouldn’t tell me what was wrong.
He started working more, so we spent less time together.
I felt that I had done something terribly wrong, and when I asked, he said I didn’t.
“I began questioning what was wrong with me and why he no longer trusted me.
I can be abrasive and unintentionally mean sometimes, so maybe it was too much for him.
Maybe he didn’t think I was attractive.
Maybe he didn’t like short girls.
Maybe he didn’t actually like me but was too nice to say it because he knew I loved him.
I started doubting myself and picking myself apart piece by piece.
I wasn’t happy anymore, but I couldn’t tell him that.
The rift between us was filling with everything we wouldn’t say to each other.
“He was still doing his best for me and treated me well, even better than before, which made me feel worse, like his kindness was pity.

I started doubting I had any self-worth, and that was when I realized I was beginning to feel the same as I did in my last relationship, but this time I knew it was my fault because it all started when I tried to sleep with him.”
Sammy leaned back against the balustrade and groaned.
“God, I could use another drink.
I’m starting to understand why people drink when they’re depressed.
Talking about this sobered me up real quick.”
Ceil remained quiet to give Sammy time to collect her thoughts, because her story was clearly not finished.
Sammy leaned over and rested her head on Ceil’s shoulder.
“I broke up with him, and it killed me because I saw how much it hurt him, but I couldn’t stand being unhappy anymore.
He never blamed me or questioned my decision, almost accepting it too readily like he knew it was going to happen.
He quit his jobs and became reclusive for a while, but I couldn’t let that get to me.
I forced myself to hate him, to focus on every fault he had to justify my decision.
I treated him terribly every time I saw him…”
Sammy began to cry from the pain of her guilt.
It gripped her heart until her body physically ached.
She clung to Ceil’s bind and pressed her face into her chest.
Ceil wrapped her arm around Sammy’s back and stroked her head, unsure how else to comfort her.
“Even after all of that… even after I treated Justin worse than shit… he didn’t stop caring about me.
He took a bullet for me.
He saved my life.
I want him back.
I want to undo everything.
Tell me,” Sammy looked up into Ceil’s distressed eyes.
“Is there something wrong with me?
Is there something that you think Justin would hate?”
“I feel that any man would be lucky to call you his woman.
Justin is at fault, not you.”
“But Justin did nothing wrong.”
“You still think that after everything you told me?
You truly love him, and that love has blinded you, but…” Ceil rested her cheek on top of Sammy’s head, “Everyone has the right to be blindly in love.
Justin is not perfect, but he does not seem like a bad male.
When you see him, make him tell you the truth and stop hiding things from you.”
“Okay…”
Ceil lifted Sammy off her and looked her in the eyes.
“I also have to apologize.
I chose this time to talk to you because I felt that you would be more honest when drunk.
I wanted to see how you felt about Justin before making my decision.”
“About staying for the battle?”
“About you staying for the battle.
I have already made up my mind.
I will not run.
However, when Justin arrives, I want you to take him, Chloe, and Lemi and escape the city before the fighting starts.”
“What? No!”
“Have you even been listening to yourself?
If you truly love Justin, how would you feel if he died in battle?
If he cared for you enough to take an attack for you that nearly killed him, how would he feel if you died in battle?”
“That’s not fair!”
“Of course it is not fair!
Nothing about war is fair.
Lemi is an anthousai.
She should not even be a part of this.
You, Justin, and Chloe are from another world.
You should not be a part of our war.
Chloe is right.
If I am so important in what is to come, then I will survive this fight whether the city is saved or lost.
I should not die so easily.
But you, you are not important according to the sprites.
You could die in this battle like any other soldier or civilian.
Do not so easily throw away the life that Justin tried to save.”
Sammy’s mouth hung in shock.
She could not form a rebuttal, but she could not accept Ceil’s words either.
“I’ll show you too.
I will prove that I am important!”
“Then do it by surviving, and the best way to survive is for you to flee.
I have made my decision to stay, so I will offer you the same conditions Dharin offered me.
You have until Justin arrives to choose, but I want you to take that time to give serious thought into your future with Justin in this world.”
“Lady Ceil!”
Kiri appeared from the spiral staircase in the center of the hall and ran towards the balcony.
“There is a group of dryads held up at the gatehouse demanding to see you.
The refugees are in an uproar.
The dryads are protecting a human.”
“Is it the minum commander?
Have you spotted their army?
It is far too soon for them to arrive.”
Ceil stood in panic.
“No, it is a general human.
They said his name is Justin and that you would know him.”
Sammy sprinted to the stairs and nearly tumbled down them.
She raced with unbalanced steps out the door.
“Sammy! Wait!”
Ceil called from the balcony, but Sammy could not hear her over the pounding of her own heart.
She sprinted over the cobblestone steps in the ever-darkening twilight.
Twice she fell before even reaching the gate of the curtain wall.
Her mind felt clear, but the effects of the wine still had a strong hold on her body.
She ran past the guards and down the steps to the lower tiers of the city.
Cries rang out from the citizens who spotted a human in their city.
They fled and hid in panic or called for the guards.
Sammy reached the bridge crossing the lowest tier.

Her mental map was foggy, and she did not know if this was the same bridge she had crossed before, but so long as she crossed and climbed the tiers to the inner wall, she should reach the steps to the courtyard and make it to the gatehouse.
She did not care about the fear of the people or the guards quickly rallying to capture her.
Justin alone occupied her mind and fueled her adrenaline.
“Capture her!
Signal the wall!
Block the gate!”
An orange flare rose into the sky when Sammy reached the second tier.
She could hear boots behind her, but that only fueled her adrenaline.
She rose to the first tier and saw five guards blocking the steps up through the inner wall passage to the courtyard and refugee camp.
She had no plan, but her feet would not stop.
If they did, she felt she would collapse from exhaustion.
“Let Lady Sammy pass!”
A single fairy soared through the air on transparent feathered wings with his long white ponytail fluttering behind him.
“Let her pass!” he called again.
The soldiers parted, and Sammy ran up the steps.
Dharin flew over the wall and called for the path through the refugee camp to clear.
He landed beside Sammy and followed her through the gatehouse.
The angry shouts of the refugees outside the wall echoed through the tunnel.
A ring of Melians stood their ground against the throng with staves in hand blocking the guards.
“Justin!” Sammy’s hoarse voice left the tunnel but was drowned in the cacophony of noise.
The Melians saw her approach and brandished their staves.
“Let me through!” Sammy screamed in Melian as she approached.
“Justin!”
“Sammy!”
The healthy voice that called back was Justin’s.
Tears streamed from Sammy’s eyes, and she felt her heart would burst.
The Melians heard Justin call back and parted to let Sammy pass.
She stopped just outside the ring.
Her hoarse and wheezing gasps tore her lungs and throat, but there stood Justin.
He was shirtless and wearing nothing but a coarse green skirt that only revealed his ankles and feet.
His ribs were visible, and his stomach was slightly sunken.
His blond hair was disheveled, and his chin was covered in meager, uneven scruff.

Seeing him standing, he felt to Sammy like a completely different person than the one she helped carry all over Fiorrae and Melia, but the sunburst mark of the bullet wound on his abdomen was the proof of his identity.
Sammy’s hand balled into a fist.
With a deep and painful breath, she charged him and swung the strongest haymaker she could, but he didn’t dodge it.
She caught herself and tried to pull her arm back before it struck his face.
