Her drunken feet tripped over themselves, and she collided into him, knocking them both to the ground.
“I said…” Sammy began with tears pouring from her eyes.
“I promised I would punch you once you were better.
Why didn’t you dodge it?”
Justin looked with gentle eyes back at Sammy who knelt on top of him.
Ignoring the red mark on his cheek, he reached up and wiped the tears from Sammy’s.
“With how tired you looked, I didn’t think it would hurt, but you do hit pretty hard.
Sorry for worrying you.”
Justin sat up and held Sammy as she cried into his chest until Ceil and Kiri arrived.

Interlude
“Earth’s Oracle”
Miriam
Sparse white clouds dotted the clear blue expanse.
The air was warm but not too hot.
Beautiful late-summer days like this were perfect for sitting among nature taking in the sights and smells, reflecting on Earth and its beauty, and thinking deeply about one’s place in it.
Nature had a rejuvenating power within it that so few understood, but every individual was connected with that power.
It flowed into them as thoughtlessly and easily as an unconscious breath, and it provided life and health to their minds and bodies.
Even if someone had never heard of or believed in this natural energy, the belief in a “nature recharge” where one can feel reenergized by spending time in the outdoors was not uncommon.
When Justin first taught Eydis the English word for this energy, he used mana.

The term originated in Polynesian and other Pacific Islander religions and was a sacred power earned by or inherent in locations and people, providing them with power and authority and enabling the use of supernatural feats.
Although there were parallels in its definition, the freely abundant nature of the energy was not fully expressed in traditional mana.

The Chinese qi was closer in its claim to be a life force present in every living individual whether plant or animal, but it often lacked the belief in the manifestation of supernatural power that mana professed.

Almost every culture in the world had some belief in the mind, spirit, nature, or faith that could attribute in part to this ever-present natural force, but none understood its true and complete nature.
Elves had a term for it: ven.
By literal definition, it meant “flow.”
Although Miriam did not understand the history or reason for why it was given this name, she felt a detachment with the energy when referring to it by any of the cultural terminology of Earth.
Her grandmother simply referred to it as nature and the elements, and although her grandmother could recognize the energy and had a strong personal connection with it, she could not use it.
Miriam could manipulate the energy because of Eydis’s instruction, and she felt it strongest when she understood it as ven and nothing else, but she lacked the personal connection.
Ever since the disaster at Gullivan, Miriam questioned her connection to this natural energy that she knew was the source of her grandmother’s predictions.
After learning to feel and control her ven, she began hearing faint voices, but they were rare, brief, and none could be considered a prophecy.
They were only simple and vague directions.
An underlying feeling of guilt burdened her heart.

She felt that if she had a better connection, she could have predicted the attack or perhaps could have known the best course of action to take, and maybe--just maybe--Sammy, Chloe, and Justin would still be alive.
She spent every free day meditating, but this proved difficult in the city.
Both Eydis and Symra said that ven was present even in cities, but Miriam could not feel it.
It was there, because the ven in her body replenished while she slept in her apartment or worked with Eydis and Sean at the Pentagon, but it was elusive.

Ambient ven was easiest to feel in nature, but living in such a dense city, nature was difficult to find, especially where it was peaceful enough to meditate uninterrupted by the noise of Washington D.C. tourists and workers.
The hectic summer influx made this even more difficult.
Thankfully there was a memorial park within walking distance from the Pentagon, the Lyndon Baines Johnson Memorial Grove.
It was less visited than the more famous capital landmarks or memorials and was partially forested, making it ideal.
Miriam knelt beneath a dogwood with her eyes closed and hands clasped lightly in her lap.
She zoned out her sense of sound and focused on the smells of nature and the gentle warm breeze.

At first, all she saw was darkness or the faint glow of the sun as it scattered through the trees and hit her closed eyelids, but soon she could recognize the presence of the ground around her and the trees beside her.
The plants did not have a definitive shape, but there was an essence with an undefinable color that could only be viewed with the mind’s eye.
The energy of the trees and grass had a pulse that reverberated through the air and resonated with the pulse of other lives.
Even the ground had shape and form in the darkness, and the energy was firm.
It tremored with the movement of people and vehicles, and Miriam could feel where they were as if their footsteps were the heartbeat of the soil.
If she focused, she could almost count the number of visitors who walked the forested paths.

Miriam found the most strength in the energy of the earth, attributed by her affinity to it, but even though the energy resided in the earth, it was no different than that of the plants or the energy of the wind that flowed like particles of dust in the breeze.
It was all the same ven and part of the same connected flow.
Or so she thought.
Miriam felt a dense gathering of the particles that flowed with the breeze around her.
They were not so much particles of energy but a cloud; or perhaps if the ven she normally felt while meditating was vapor, this strange ven was water, condensed into a completely different form.
It circled her once, then twice, and stopped in front of her at eye level.
It took almost a human shape and waved what may have been an arm.
She opened her eyes and shrieked.
A translucent teal woman hovered naked in the air in front of her face.
Her hair flowed freely in the breeze almost as if submerged in a slow-moving current.
She smiled sweetly at Miriam with the proud face of a mother admiring her child.
“You can see me.
You probably could have seen me for a few weeks now, but I was tied up elsewhere with my responsibilities to Kalya.
If you want to meditate, might I suggest moving to the field?
It was designed specifically for the rejuvenation of spirit, and I must admit that they knew what they were doing when they created this park.
You will find meditation much easier there,”
“That voice.
You were the one speaking in my mind.
Are you what my grandmother called the wind?”
The woman smiled wider.
“Mabel was such a dear soul, and she always regretted being unable to instruct you properly, so I must express my gratitude to Eydis FeAmel for fulfilling the role as your teacher.”
“What are you?”
“Mabel spoke true.
I am the north wind.
Her mother and her mother’s mother, all throughout your maternal ancestry, have acted as my oracles.
We always speak to one who listens, and no matter the change in time and culture, your ancestors have always lent us an ear.”
“Then there are more of you?”
“There are four of the wind, fifteen of the earth, two of fire, and seven of water.
We are the elements tasked with maintaining the balance of this world, although I do feel sorry for the two of fire.
They are overworked trying to keep your planet from overheating.
Kalya’s obsession with the rapid advancement of your species does come with some ill side effects.”
Miriam remembered the personification of the elements taught her by her grandmother.
“Are you a Sylph?”
“Theophrastus--or is he better known as Paracelsus?
He did give us that name, but again I feel sorry for fire.
Salamanders have always been viewed as monsters or animals despite looking no different than you or I.”
“Do they each have an oracle they communicate with?”
“No. Only one is given this duty.
I am the speaker, and you are my oracle.
You may refuse the role if you so desire, and I will be forced to find another.”
Miriam shook her head.
Her heart welled with relief that she could not contain.
A tear curved around her wide smile as it ran down her cheek.
She had never felt happier.
“I’ve been trying so hard to follow in my grandmother’s footsteps.
I kept doubting myself.
I didn’t think I was good enough.”
She nodded enthusiastically.
“Yes. Yes, I will be your oracle.
I only wish that I could have been worthy before the attack on Gullivan.”
“Even though your mind was closed off to me and made it hard for me to speak to you, the event happened as it should.”
“Then Sammy, Chloe, and Justin… I couldn’t have done anything for them?”
“Nothing will come from worrying about them now.
There are far more pressing matters.
As my oracle, I must give you a warning.
Eydis FeAmel is following a dark path that will see to her ruin and the loss of many lives.
She must return to how she once was if we are to survive the coming calamity.”
“Before she was captured by the doppelganger?
How am I supposed to do that?
Justin and Sammy were a major part of her life back then.”
“That is for you to discover.
I have already interfered too much in these events.
The more we interfere, the less accurate our predictions become, the more blind to the future we grow, and Kalya would be angry if she knew we were overstepping our responsibilities.”
“Who is Kalya?”
“I apologize, but I cannot answer that question.
I have high hopes for you.
You are the first oracle in a millennium who can use magic.”
The Sylph flitted to Miriam’s forehead and kissed her lightly before vanishing.
Miriam stared blankly in front of her almost wondering if what she saw and heard was a dream.
Her heart bubbled with excitement, and when her adrenaline peaked to bursting, she stood and sprinted back to the Pentagon, bounding with each stride.

Chapter 11
“The Itian Struggle”
The six days were up.
General Bregon ordered the closure of the conscription camp for the second time in grave disappointment.
The food cost for the six days had been equivalent to the food gathered by Captain Kolbur in Simydia.
The amount was small compared to the haul of other conscription forces, but it was a terrible waste nonetheless.
He lost the gamble on the possibility that the Kissiae would join their cause, at least for now.
Traveling to and from the proposed location of Elos should have taken only four days from the camp’s location, especially for a platoon as small as the one Kolbur requested.
If Kolbur fell in battle with hostile dryads, nothing could be done, but there was still the possibility of delay.
With the speed of his small platoon, they would catch up depending on how mobile the kissiae were.
“Move out!” Bregon hollered, and the deafening thunder of boots roared across the forest.
His soldiers kept to the thin road in fifteen men or three handcart spans.
Fire mages lined the edges, spaced out evenly where possible.
The nearly 90 thousand conscripted dryads followed the march on both sides of the road, walking uninhibited through the forest underbrush.

The evenly spaced fire mages were a warning to those who might think of rebelling, and the dryad-pulled handcarts piled high with preserved dryad were a constant reminder of what would happen to them if they rebelled.
This did not relieve the constant fear pricking the back of each soldier’s mind.
The soldiers may have fire, but many felt that the dryads could eliminate their entire army if they collectively rebelled, although at the loss of many of their own.
The hostile Fenda province was next on their path.
The Fendamai already killed a thousand soldiers, so Bregon was prepared for immediate confrontation.
Five-thousand dryads led the march as a shield against ambush.
Another 5000 took up the rear to prevent an ambush from behind.
Dryads were silent killers, but only against other races.
A dryad skilled in life magic would be able to detect the stealthy approach of another dryad.
Bregon preferred to avoid conflict if possible so that they could expedite their march and save all able bodies for the vital battle in Vallen.
He hoped the protective cage of dryads around his four-mile train of soldiers would be a powerful deterrent, and it was, at least through the Fenda province.
The march halted on the border between Fenda and Itia where the dense red maples suddenly changed to lush, drooping willows.
Bregon, who stood at the head of his soldiers, demanded from the protective shield of dryads to know why they had stopped.
A pale-skinned dryad, a Simydian, weaved through the dryad barrier for Bregon.
“General Bregon, forgive us.
A large number of Itians have blocked the road.
They refuse us passage.”
“Define large.”
“Multiple thousand.”
A few thousand would not threaten his army.
He could easily overpower the Itians with his dryads alone.
“Are they armed?”
“No.”
Lack of weapons did not mean they were harmless.
Although elemental magic was impossible for dryads, they still excelled in life magic.
“Push through, but do not attack unless they do, and do not let any through your perimeter.
We will force them to part from the road.”
The Simydian reluctantly returned to the forward perimeter to relay the message.
Bregon waited, and eventually the forward dryads advanced at quarter pace or slower.
He grumbled to himself.
If this was to be the rate going through Itia, his army would take ten days to reach Melia.
Melia was the largest of the Dhuillir provinces, and although it was much wider than it was long, at quarter march, traversing it would take fifteen days.

Perhaps eliminating them would be quicker, but then he might have to fight his way through Itia, potentially costing more time and resources, and their aggression would give reason for the dryads under the hamadryad’s influence to rally against him.
Traveling through hostile territory was a precarious situation, so erring on the side of caution was the best choice.
For now.
Bregon decided to tolerate the quarter march, hoping that once the Itians were diverted to the side, the march would speed up if only a little.

* * *
“We are stalling them as much as possible, but the estimates from the Fendamai were grossly miscalculated.”
“What are their numbers?” the hamadryad asked.
“Twice or more, 120 to 150 thousand.”
The hamadryad’s smooth brow furrowed, creating the first creases in her newly youthful skin.

If Tolmyur was sending 150 thousand, or even if only 120 thousand, once combined with the forces currently in Vallen, Tolmyur’s total army may outnumber all the fairies remaining in Vallen, including untrained civilians and children.
Ceil ordered her to prevent conflict to save the dryads from the war, so she was focusing on stalling the army with minimal aggression, but with such a large army, she could not let them pass.
Such would be a death sentence for Vallen, Ceil, and Ceil’s companions.
“Jenae. Seiva.”
“What do you require,” Jenae asked, standing between the thick roots beside the entrance to the hollow.
She and Seiva, the former village matriarch’s aid, had taken the roll of the hamadryad’s attendants.
“We will make preparations for war.”
Seiva’s eyes grew wide, and Jenae knelt to the ground, bowing deeply.
“I cannot communicate with Melians outside my influence.
Send messengers to seek them out and exile them to the east, out of the path of the approaching army.
I will inform the other villages to do likewise.
We cannot let them join the enemy’s forces.
Expect some resistance, but they fear Tolmyur more than they support them.
They should cooperate.
Also… exile all anthousai and younger with them.”
Seiva was confused about the second order, but Jenae looked up at the hamadryad from her subservient posture with terror in her eyes.
“Then it has come to this?”
“With the exiled, some Melians will survive.
I apologize for using your people to this end.
We will fertilize Melian soil with the bodies of Tolmyur and our kin.
Lady Ceil and her companions must survive.”
The hamadryad relayed the message to all matriarchs of Melia under her influence and received similar shocked responses, but she did not have time to elaborate or justify her order.
As the eldest of the dryads within her influence, her word was absolute to those who followed her, but that did not remove the free will of others.
She felt a slight decrease in the hearts connected to her in Melia, but the number was not enough to hinder the exile.
The Melians would know who of their kin were connected and who were not.
Those who rejected her would survive, so she could not fault them.
Such extreme measures were needed because the army would travel through Melia.
In the other provinces under her influence, her orders were more lenient.
She contacted every matriarch through her connection to them and requested any dryads who were willing and able to travel to Melia with haste and prepare for war.
Dryads could travel far faster than a human army due to their incredible stamina, so she hoped a large number would arrive in time.
Although Melia was the largest territory in Dhuillir, their villages were few and spread far, making their population one of the lowest.

Melia had no hope of stopping the army on their own, and if none answered her call, they would at least reduce the number of soldiers arriving in Vallen at the cost of the lives of the Melians who remained.
It was fortuitous that the Tolmyur commander had swayed many Melians against her.
Indeed, no matter the outcome, some Melians would survive.
“Grandmatriarch, Itia will aid in your struggle, but some of us will not be joining you in Melia.
We will fight them here.”
“You have no hope of defeating them on your own.”
“If we leave, you will not have time to gather the tribes.”
“Those of us closest to Melia will join you there,” replied another Itian matriarch.
“The rest of us along the road will stall as long as possible.
We are stronger in our own lands.”
“May you be blessed with victory.”
“Shouldn’t you be saying something like, ‘May your sacrifice not be in vain?’” spoke a far younger voice, a matriarch of a new village.
“It’s not like those of us holding them back will come out of this alive.”
“Thank you for your sacrifice,” the hamadryad said, rephrasing her previous statement.
Pride welled in the hamadryad’s bosom.
The youth did not fear death, and their courage would be the fiber strengthening the will of the resistance.
In these perilous times, it was the youth who were building the future.
Even Ceil, the young empress, was shouldering the fate of the Amelian Empire.
The hamadryad was unable to communicate with her, but the staff in Ceil’s hands cut from her own branch relayed the message that Ceil was still alive.
However, the powerful malice she recently felt flow through the staff was worrisome.
I pray that you stand tall against the storm’s wind.

* * *
Meera looked into the worried eyes of her thirty-three young sisters.
They were unable to hear the hamadryad’s voice, but they heard Meera’s reply, that they would be sacrifices in this war.
She rubbed the long willow boughs that sprouted from her head and hung down to her ankles.
“That about explains the situation.
The army will be upon us by evening, and our lot has fallen on holding them back.”
“Meera, you should flee.”
“We cannot make you fight.”
Meera shook her head.
“What matriarch leaves her sisters to die in her place?”
“But your daughter!”
Meera placed her hand on her lightly bulging stomach and smiled.
“Are you not all daughters to your mothers?
Whether I am with child or not makes no difference.
How many fairies have lost their children?
How many mothers with child have been slaughtered by Tolmyur in Vallen, in Amel?
I have a purpose here, and my daughter shares with me in that purpose.
I will at least take two soldiers with me.
One for me, and one for her.”
The girls exchanged pained glances in silence, unable to say more.
“But, what can the few of us do?” asked the youngest, a girl just beginning to blossom into an anthousai.
“It’s Tolmyur’s fault that they extended the road through our village.
They have no right to be angry if we remove it.” Meera scratched her head and looked around at her sisters.
“I’m not a shaman, so I cannot be sure, but how many trees can we uproot with the total ven of our village.”
“One acre. Two if we meditate intermittently,” replied the village shaman.
“That few… Hele, you are the fastest.
Other villages should be heading to the road to prepare their own defenses.
Send them here.
Our village will be the battleground.”

* * *
The quarter march sped up to a third march, easing some of Bregon’s worries.
Twice an Itian tried hiding among the branches of the willows but was discovered by the dryad shield and promptly eliminated.
There were never any attacks.
There was never any aggression.
The Itians solely held their ground and pushed back against his advance.
Normally this would be no cause for worry, but Bregon’s military instinct told him something nefarious was at work.
If the Itians were solely against Bregon entering their lands, then his army had long passed that point.
The most reasonable choice then would be to grant passage so they could leave Itia as quickly as possible.
Instead, they kept their resistance.
The only explanation was that they were stalling, but stalling to what end?
The overcast sky dimmed with the sun that had long set over the horizon, casting deep shadows over the willow forest, and the road almost disappeared in the distant dark.
At Bregon’s height, he could just barely see over the barrier of dryads to the Itian resistance, and soon the resistance was swallowed into the dark.
The vanishing road was no illusion.
“Halt the march!” he bellowed, and the thunder of boots ceased in a cascading echo down the four-mile train.
His dryad wall stopped, and the few remaining Itians at the front disappeared into the darkened forest where the road should have been.
This was a trap.
“Where is the road?”
Bregon called to the Simydians at the front, and the same former messenger weaved through the throng to answer, or at least he thought it was the same.
They all looked alike to him.
“Sir, the road is still there, but trees have been transplanted on it.
They are densely packed together in a long wall wider than our advance, including the dryads on the perimeter.
Your soldiers will have difficulty maneuvering through them, and your carts will be unable to pass.”
“Any sign of movement from the Itians?”
“None. They wait behind the tree wall.”
“If they were able to transplant the trees, you should be able to remove them, correct?”
The Simydian nervously plucked a heart-shaped leaf from the long boughs of her hair.
“We could, but I feel there would be no end.
As we clear them, they could be setting more in our path, although we cannot hear such work currently.”
Waiting for the dryads to clear the trees would reduce his march to a standstill.
This was no longer a territorial dispute; it was supply chain obstruction, a form of hostility no different than an organized attack.
Bregon sent the Simydian back to the front to inform the forward dryads to pull away from the tree wall.
He then raised his hand to give the signal to draw weapons.

The dryads surrounding the road were not knowledgeable about Tolmyur hand signals, but once they saw the soldiers preparing for combat, they placed their hands on the trees and fashioned their own bows, spears, and staves.

“One hundred fire mages to the front,” Bregon ordered to one of his captains who then ran back along the road to flag the fire mages forward, totaling nearly half of the fire mages remaining under his command.
As the fire mages gathered, the other soldiers shifted back to make room on the narrow road.
“Ready hailfire,” he ordered quietly.
The one hundred mages raised their hands to the sky facing forward but without any prepared flame.
He then approached one of the forward dryads.
“Are the Itians still there?”
She ran to the front, confirmed, and returned to report.
They were.
Marching through a burnt forest would be faster.
“Fire!”
Thousands of small fireballs shot from the mages’ fingertips in a wide and scattered arch, raining devastation upon the forest.
The tactic was meant to lay waste to villages and draw enemies out of their fortifications.

It was less effective on armored infantry, stone fortifications, and forests where much of the flora was wet and green, but of the sheer number of projectiles some were sure to catch, and any dryads caught in the hailfire would be dealt incurable damage from the flame.
The first volley was followed by a second and then a third without the slightest break between.
The conscripted dryads watched in fear and awe at a form of magic they felt was specifically designed for their ruin.
Many secretly felt that they had made the correct choice in joining Tolmyur instead of opposing them.
A wide grin spread across Bregon’s face as the orange and red glow of flame spread in the dense forest, but his grin quickly faded as an unforeseeable rain fell upon him and his army next.
Bregon thrust his spear into the air and caught a falling body.
The Itian impaled herself half-way down the haft and gripped it tight as her life sap ran onto his gauntlets.
She tried to use life magic through the wood, but there was no life remaining in it to act as a conduit.
Bregon flung the Itian to the side into the forest where the waiting dryads would finish her, taking caution to avoid her long hair.
“Cowls up!
Do not expose your skin!” he ordered.
His men acted with haste to pull the cowls at their necks up over their noses as dozens of Itian’s rained down on them from above.
Their bodies were barely visible in the dark sky, only being lit by the fire spreading through the forest behind them and what little sunlight filtered up from below the horizon.
The Itians collided with the soldiers and the trees with a jarring crunch as their arms and legs broke from impact, but this damage was minimal to a dryad.

They sprung up and clawed at the soldiers with their hands or attacked with their spears, attempting to reach the soldiers’ faces or pry open any gap in their armor where life magic could fatally wound through contact with the skin.
The Itians who landed without injury spun in wild dances using their long hair as whips.
Even the slightest contact with the long and slender leaves on the boughs of their hair caused flesh to rupture.
The unarmored dryads were most susceptible to the caustic dances of the Itians.
Lacking bladed weapons, they could only block the hair with their staves and spears and impale the Itians to the ground.
Those skilled with life magic then ended the Itian’s life, and when one Itian excelled in life magic, two or three dryads were needed to overpower the difference in ability.
The swordsmen on the path scrambled to protect the lightly armored mages from the raining Itians, cutting the long willow boughs and dismembering their arms to remove any ability to attack.
The mages, when able, continued their hailfire into the forest beyond, their innumerable miniature fireballs colliding with the Itians who appeared to fly over the burning forest.

Bregon swung his spear with masterfully practiced motion, knocking the falling Itians aside or cutting through them with his long, broad-leafed spearhead, showering those around him in the thick and bitter sap.
Bregon’s anger built, but he refrained from showing it.
His composure was the composure of his army.
If he faltered, so would they.
The source of his anger was the unfathomable tactic employed by the Itians.
His protective wall of dryads was meaningless against attacks from above.
He expected a rain of dryad arrows, but Itians did not appear to employ such weaponry.
Instead, they used their own bodies, but how?
What sorcery are they employing, Bregon grumbled in his mind as he eviscerated a withered old Itian before she could land on the minum fire mage beside him.
“Earth mages to the front!”

* * *
Meera grabbed a handful of soil and smeared it on the burning cinders that ate deep into her sister’s back and shoulder.

They had transplanted most of the willows starting from her village and continuing down the road to create a seven-acre wide, thick tree wall, but that left the gathering of the thousands of dryads exposed in the open dirt field and susceptible to the countless fireballs raining down on them.

The first few volleys were so thick that few remained uninjured, including her, and those who could not smother their flames curled up on the ground to burn so that their death would not spread to others.
The tree wall was burning, and the thick smoke wafted downwind to them.
Dryads could survive without breathing for long periods of time, but they would weaken, and being night, they were already weaker than they would be under the sunlight.
“You should fall back,” Meera suggested to the young girl, but she shook her head.
“If I am injured, I should be next to go.”
Meera’s heart sank.
The pink blossoms of the girl’s hair were just beginning to bloom full down the long boughs, but many were now singed and blackened from the fire and smoke.
The young anthousai looked up at her with tearful eyes full of determination, and Meera could not deny the girl.
They were the sacrifices so that the dryads could gather against Tolmyur, sacrifices so that their young empress would not be overwhelmed.
Meera lifted the girl and led her through the sparse hailfire to one of the willow trees they kept in the field.
Three shamans knelt with their hands on the trunk.
The willow bent back in an unnatural arc, and six Itians clung to the long boughs, pulling them taught.
The anthousai gripped a handful of boughs with one arm and was handed a spear for her other hand.
Being so young, she was unable to make use of life magic for combat.
Seeing that no others gathered, the shamans snapped the willow forward, flinging the seven Itian’s through the smoke over the burning tree wall and into the unseen army.
The shamans quickly worked to repair the damage to the trunk from the quick snap and  bent it back again for more Itians to gather at the boughs.
There was no way to know through the smoke and fire just how many of the soldiers and dryads had been defeated.
Already half of their thousands of Itians had succumbed to the hailfire and multiple hundred had been thrown over the wall into the enemy.
“Fall back to the second line,” an elderly matriarch of another village called out.
The second tree wall was finished.
This devastation would repeat again, and if possible, a third time.
Meera looked around for the sisters of her small village, five already laid charred on the ground and an unknown more had thrown themselves into the enemy.
She saw no faces that she knew in the fiery chaos.
“Fall back,” the matriarch called again.
A fireball impacted the matriarch’s chest, blooming into flame.

Meera ran towards the matriarch, scooping up a handful of loose soil from the uprooted trees, but before she could reach her, the ground rumbled, and the snapping of wood cried above the crackling of the fire.
Meera turned towards the tree wall to see large mounds of rock and earth upheaving the burning trees and forcing them aside.
Multiple gaps in the wall opened, and all at once, dryads and soldiers flooded in.
The shamans tasked with throwing the Itians over the wall quickly climbed their willows.
Those unable to skillfully use life magic picked up the prepared spears, making room for the shamans on the ground who readied their dances.
The life magic that ate away flesh would affect both friend and foe alike.
Meera picked up a spear in each hand, holding them mid-haft with the back of the haft cradled in her armpits.
The traditions of the Itians were rooted in dance, and that included combat.

Itian spears were shorter than most but would still be unwieldy and inhibit combat for other races when dual wielded; however, for an Itian, they became an extension of an Itian’s body that followed with every graceful movement.

Two staves were used in most traditional dances, but when replaced with spears, they became lethal talons that both extended beyond their hair and could direct their hair where the motions of their head could not.
A Simydian approached with a long spear in hand, and using her forward hand as a support and fulcrum, her back grip thrust the spear forward in many quick jabs.
Meera paid little attention to the few jabs that punctured her chest and shoulders.
She spun her arm, locking the long spear between her shorter spears, and whipped her hair forward to block visibility.
With a step and twist, she wrenched the spear upwards, but the Simydian retracted her spear and thrust it again.
All it hit was hair.
Meera was beside her, and using the Simydian’s spear as a lever, she flipped her over her back and impaled her on her own spear.
Meera grabbed the haft and thrust it into the ground, pinning the Simydian.
That alone was not enough to kill her, but the spear was deep into the soil and would hold her for a while.
Meera had no interest in dryads.
She was after the humans.
She spotted a lone fire mage near the tree wall that stood back throwing lethal flames over the melee.
Quick feet carried her over the loose soil.
She slid beneath the wide fan of an Itian shaman’s boughs and weaved through the preoccupied dryads with graceful motion.
The minum spotted her and threw a fireball which she swatted away with the butt of her spear.
It exploded, but the heat only singed her.
She broke through the flames and bounded in an aerial cartwheel over the minum.
The minum ducked below the following swing of her spear with a fireball ready.
Meera knocked his arm aside with the next twist of her body, sending the explosive flame into the dryads flooding through the wall.
The accompanying spear in her other hand finished the dance with a thrust through his heart, uninhibited by the light leather armor.
“One,” Meera sneered.
A searing pain spread through her lower back to her stomach.
She looked down and saw a broad-leafed spearhead wider than her arm.
She dropped her spear and grabbed the haft protruding from her back and glared at the one who held it.
It was a giant in crude plate armor that only one of his strength could wear in battle.
The giant lifted her on the spear head and swung her forward.
The blade cut out through her side and sent her soaring over the melee into a crumpled heap against the trunk of a willow.
Her lower body tore out at a right angle with the sap and fluids of her stomach muddying the soil.
The dryads pursuing the Itians who fled to the second wall ignored her for dead, but a lone swordsman caught the seething whites of her eyes.
He approached to execute what the giant’s spear failed to kill instantly.
The steel blade reeled back to remove her head, but the boughs of the willow ensnared his arms and eroded his skin.
A lone shaman remained on the branches.
The boughs lifted him by his ankles as a fireball impacted the willow’s canopy, engulfing the shaman in flames.
Before the boughs could release the soldier, Meera thrust her spear through his eye.
“And that one is for my daughter,” she sneered as the loose boughs dropped him to the ground.
Meera leaned her head back against the trunk of the willow and watched the burning leaves and branches fall around her.
Her wound was too severe to heal, and she would burn down with the willow, but a smile spread across her face.
She had accomplished her goal.
“Long live the Amelian Empire.
Long live our young Empress.”

* * *
Bregon looked at the devastation in the dirt field beyond the fourth tree wall.
There were only about two hundred Itians remaining, but like any cornered animal, they were the fiercest of them all.
The long night of combat was over, and the light of the morning sun was creeping over the horizon, although the sun itself had yet to show its face.

He estimated about five to six thousand Itians in total had gathered to hinder his advance through Dhuillir, and due to the bizarre tactics that allowed the Itians to fly over their defenses, tactics that he still could not figure out, nearly two thousand of his own soldiers were slain.
For his overwhelming difference in strength and number, this was a humiliating loss that enraged him.
“We rest until noon,” Bregon ordered.
“Dryads, heal the wounded, gather the bodies for provisions, and retrieve the handcarts abandoned behind the first tree wall.
Once that is done, feel free to sunbathe and recover your strength.”
The number of conscripted dryads that had fallen was unknown, but he expected it to be few.

Without bladed weapons or life magic, one dryad killing another was difficult, often leading to prolonged and brutal confrontations that wore away each combatant until one was left in a mutilated heap.
When life magic was involved, higher skill won out, but numbers could potentially overpower skill, and his 90 thousand dryads clearly outnumbered the six thousand Itians.

The last two walls were handled by the conscripted dryads alone to prevent further losses to his army, and the gruesome battles between melee combatants and the slow power struggles between shamans that drained ven until they too were forced into physical combat caused the battle to last the entire night.
If anything, Bregon was amazed that dryad stamina could last so long in all out combat even without their precious sun giving them strength.
Now that the battle was over, Bregon was as certain as he could be that something awaited his armies before he would leave Dhuillir.
The Itian resistance was a suicide struggle for time.
The danger was that there was only one road, and his handcarts required him to use it.
If it weren’t for that, he could take his army through the forests to the Itian border with Fiorrae and up north along the Melian border to avoid whatever awaited him.
Perhaps that would not be such a terrible idea.
Bregon sat on the trunk of a toppled willow and waved down one of the dryads.
She approached with haste and bowed before him.
“Find me a large number of dryads who are knowledgeable about the sprites.”
He sat and waited as the sun peaked out over the willow canopy.
The dryad returned with a depressingly small number following her, eight in total and all elderly.
He expected as such because only Itia and Melia bordered Fiorrae.
The sprites avoided any conflict with Tolmyur and ignored all demands for surrender.
The few platoons sent to subdue their small numbers were all chased out by the prominent bird of prey in the region, not the sprites themselves.
Never once had an army the size of his approached their borders, so he was unsure how they would react.
The sprites were believed to be elementals that also held magical capabilities; a dangerous combination because their elemental attributes would increase their magic power further.
“Do any of you know why the sprites have stayed neutral in this war?”
The dryads looked to each other as if trying to figure out who knew best to answer.
The eldest dryad with long, grass-like hair and skin the color of a dried reed, an Efkalypiad, stepped forward.
“The Sprites have always avoided involvement with any political affairs, even within the former Amelian Empire.
I assume their desire to stay out of the war is related to that stance.”
“And yet I heard from a messenger from Melia that they had sheltered the widow of the emperor after she fled Vallen.”
The dryads again exchanged glances with each other, but none seemed to have an answer.
“Do you know how they would react to an army of this size marching along their border or potentially crossing through Fiorrae to enter western Vallen?”
“You mean to avoid Melia altogether,” a Simydian asked.
“The battle in Vallen is far more important than the struggles of the hamadryad and her ilk.
If we can avoid a repeat of last night by avoiding Melia, I would prefer to do so.”
Especially if machinations of a far grander scale were being prepared.
The Efkalypiad shook her head.
“I can only speak of rumor, but there is one among the sprites who is known as the Arkhon.
All sprites are immortal, undying, but he is believed to be ageless from times long past, before the Amelian Empire was, before the dryads, possibly older than the ancient civilization.
You would do best not to make an enemy of such a being.”

Bregon glared at the Efkalypiad for insinuating that he and his soldiers were so weak that they could be threatened by a single individual, but there had always been legends of beings with exceptional power who defy reason.

There were the two titans, Bydrofe and Gyea of the wilderlands, the trow witchdoctor who abducted men who fled north out of Tolmyur through the swamplands, the golem colossus in the caverns deep below the Stollmuk range, the hydra used against his own people during the Coastal Wars, and others.
Even Tolmyur had their own, their Commanding General, but Jethro was missing in action in the other world and could not aid his army.
If this Arkhon was one such being, perhaps angering him would be a foolish decision.
“Even if he is no stronger than you or I,” the Efkalypiad continued, “no weapon or magic can injure a sprite.
If your invasion of their lands draws them into battle, your only hope is to flee from them as they kill you one by one.”
“Are you certain these sprites are immortal?”
Bregon looked into the eyes of each dryad in turn, and they all answered in the affirmative without deception or guile.

The sprites lived deep inside Fiorrae, so there was a chance that they would not confront his army for just passing through, but if the Efkalypiad spoke true, bringing their ire could result in the inevitable destruction of his army.
Whatever awaited him in Melia could endanger his army, but he had confidence that he would win against the hamadryad’s plot.
The choice was between the risk of elimination and the guarantee of loss.

When traveling through hostile territory, it was best to err on the side of caution, and elimination was too grave a risk to take, especially when the campaign in Vallen needed every possible soldier he could provide.
Bregon grumbled within himself.
He would take his army through Melia.

Chapter 12
“The Children of Vallen”
Sammy
Sammy’s hand reached over in her sleep and found warmth.
As if drawn by its comfort, she unconsciously shifted closer to it and wrapped her arm around it.
There was an herbal scent lingering in the warmth, not unlike Lemi’s, but it was faint and overpowered by a nostalgic aroma that made a tear fall from her eye.
She squeezed the warmth as her eyes cracked open and saw the slow rise and fall of a bare and nearly hairless chest.
“Justin!” She shot up, and her left hand immediately ran to the sunburst-like scar on his abdomen.
“Good morning,” said a soft voice that caused Sammy’s chest to well up with an emotion that was difficult to describe, a combination of anxiety and elation and confusion and relief.
Justin smiled warmly at her.
“Is this how you are going to wake up every morning?”
“Old habits,” Sammy said, returning his smile as she wiped the tear trail from her cheek before another could trace its path.
She looked longingly at the man who she had cared for and carried for what would have been months on earth while he was too sick to even wake.
He turned to his side and clasped her hand, making her heart beat heavy in her chest.
It was a habit he did not have while they were dating and that he had picked up because of his relationship with Eydis, but Sammy did not mind how it originated.
She enjoyed it all the same.
Justin was shirtless, and the blanket covered only his waist and below.
Sammy was also topless, but Justin was not bothered or flustered by it.
Anyone who saw the scene would have suspected that they slept together, and they did, but only in the literal sense.
Keeping with Ceil’s declaration that the four girls should have their own room, Justin was the odd one out.
The obvious arrangement was for Justin to share Sammy’s.
She could not deny that waking up with him each morning with them both half naked was terribly arousing, but from past experiences, she was far too scared to act on her desires.
Even if Justin was willing to have sex, Sammy would be the one denying him this time.
The reason was that he was still not healthy.
Justin’s stomach and cheeks were rather sunken, and his ribs were clearly visible, but he appeared far better than in her foggy drunken memory of colliding into him at the gatehouse.

Due to Sammy forcing him to eat almost as much as Chloe, which Justin complained about each time because his stomach had shrunken drastically, the meat on his arms now matched the width of the joints in his elbows instead of looking like some old ball-jointed toy.

The best shaman of the entourage of Melians that now resided in the manor’s front garden, the shaman of Lemi’s village, checked up on him twice daily to make certain that there were no issues arising in his rehabilitation and that he would regain his strength and stamina.
The door to the room opened, and Lemi stepped in.
Justin looked away out of respect for the girl, a reaction Sammy always found charming.
Lemi saw them holding hands, and a wide toothy grin spread across her face.
She was the only one who was willing to wake Sammy or Justin or enter the room to greet them first thing in the morning, and seeing them together gave her no shortage of joy.
“Food is almost ready!” Lemi announced with glee before spinning and prancing back to her room to get dressed, leaving the door wide open.
Sammy apologized for Lemi’s childish behavior and lack of modesty at first, but now she could only chuckle lightly to herself.
Justin had spent days traveling with dryads, so he should have grown accustomed to them by now anyway.
At least Lemi wore her dava most of the day.
These events only happened in the morning right after everyone woke.
Sammy removed her blanket, stood, and stretched her back and arms, not that they ached or were tense from the heavenly bed mat.
With mild consideration for Justin, she turned her back to him while she swapped her night skirt for her dava and then wrapped her breasts.
She then helped him up and handed him his skirt.
It was meant for a High Elf, so it was originally quite long for him until Chloe trimmed and hemmed it.
Justin did not mind changing in front of Sammy considering she had taken care of him most of the time while he was injured.
She handed him his simple brown robe, which was meant for a heavy-set Fairy so that it fit him around the shoulders.

When tied about his waist with the skirt extending from below, Sammy thought he looked like a monk, and he probably would have further resembled a monk if he hadn’t requested that Sammy ask Dharin for his shaving knife.
Sammy still chuckled remembering how many times Justin nicked himself trying to use it the first morning, especially remembering how much Lemi giggled while she healed him.

The only person absent during breakfast was Kiri who was always off performing her duties as Chief Advisor and Council Head, arguably the highest current ranking official of the fairies, higher even than Lord Olvar and Thorn General Dharin because Kiri was second in authority only to the late Fairy High King.
The king’s official successors all died in the fall of the Gallanvale.

After the assassinations and during the subsequent campaign in Vallen, there hadn’t been an opportunity to crown a new king, and the only royal descendants that were known to still live were Dharin and Kiri anyway.
And of course, Ceil.
The breakfast Dharin and Lemi prepared was a modest spread of fruit, cheese, and bread with heavily watered-down wine out of consideration for Justin and Sammy.
It became more of a bitter fruit juice than any alcohol.
Even Lemi was able to drink it without much issue, although if she drank too much, she would still take a late morning nap.
“Have you come to a decision yet?” Ceil asked Sammy as breakfast wound down.
“Are you going to ask us this every day?” Sammy replied, slightly exasperated.
She finished her goblet and leaned back into Justin’s chest to relax her full stomach.
“I know I gave you until Justin arrived to make the decision, but we couldn’t have expected him to arrive with Tyree that same day.
Another village fell yesterday, so that only leaves two more locations until they reach Revlan.
You are running out of time.”
Sammy leaned her head back to look up at Justin, but he only looked sorrowfully at Ceil.
She was like a younger sister to Eydis, and she had already decided to stay for the siege.
Justin never voiced his opinion, but Sammy knew that if she asked it of him, Justin would tell Sammy to flee while at the same time opting to stay and help where he could.
But, if Sammy did decide to flee and begged Justin to come with her, she knew he would.
Or at least she hoped he would.
The prospect of all-out war and a repeat of what she saw at Gullivan and Nelain terrified her, and that’s what made the decision so difficult for her.
“We haven’t decided yet,” Sammy finally answered, much to Ceil’s annoyance.
“Perhaps a tour of the city and its defenses might help you,” Dharin suggested.
“I feel the knowledge of your existence has diffused through the city well enough now that you should be safe to walk outside the curtain wall.
You should still have a few guards with you at all times, which I can provide, and I can offer one of my commanders as a guide to take you wherever you wish to visit to help with your decision.”
“We can finally see the city?” Lemi asked in excitement.
“Yes.” Dharin smiled back like a grandfather admiring his adorable granddaughter.
“But do not become too depressed when you see that it is more stone than you thought.”
“But it is still very green.”
“Only on the upper tiers.
It depends on where you want to go.”
“I’ll be fine,” Lemi exclaimed with confidence.
“Where should we go first,” Sammy asked Justin.
“Go?” Justin looked quizzically down at Sammy, and she realized that the entire conversation had been in Elven.
With Dharin present, even Ceil chose Elven over English, and Sammy naturally followed, but this alienated Chloe and Justin.
Sammy felt a bit bad for them, so she quickly explained Dharin’s suggestion.
“I want to see the orphanage,” Chloe replied before Justin had time to think up an answer.
Apparently, the children had been on her mind for a while.
“I can arrange that,” Dharin said after Ceil quickly translated.
“Do not inform them we are coming,” Ceil ordered.
“I want to see the city as it is.
That goes for wherever else we visit as well.”
Dharin acquiesced, but Sammy noticed his countenance fall slightly.
It was not as if he had reason to hide anything.
This was a city overflowing with refugees and preparing for an inevitable siege.
There was no way everything would be pristine.
Would it not be better for their empress to see the truth?
Dharin promised to uphold Ceil’s conditions and left to prepare an escort and guide.
The remainder of the morning was free as it had been every day.
Tyree came inside with the help of one of the other Melians, Tae, due to her missing leg to check up on Justin.
She was worried about his stamina and whether he would be able to walk around the city, but she also felt that this would be a good opportunity to build his endurance so long as he did not overwork.
From what Sammy heard the day after Justin arrived, after he woke up he was far too weak to walk, so the Melians had carried him most of the way to Revlan, even while he slept through the night.
He had only just grown healthy enough to walk the day he arrived, which was why he could not stop Sammy when she collided into him.
He simply did not have the strength.
What surprised Sammy the most about the ordeal was that the Tolmyur commander had entrusted Tyree to take Justin to Revlan in his stead while he met up with the army.
Both she and Ceil had assumed that there would be an exchange just before the battle, but Tyree explained that Captain Byurk was trusting Ceil to uphold her side of their agreement.
Of course, by that time Ceil had already decided to stay, and that appeased Tyree.

Tyree was also of the opinion that Sammy should take Justin and Chloe and flee the city before the battle, and she reminded Sammy of this every time she checked up on Justin, adding more pressure on Sammy to make her decision.
Dharin returned just before noon.
With nothing else to do, everyone was already prepared to depart and followed Dharin outside without him needing to leave the entryway.
The nearly twenty Melians in the garden bowed to Ceil and waved to Justin as they passed.
One of the youngest who looked about fifteen or sixteen ran to the fence and knelt, presenting a pair of green woven sandals to Justin.
“For Sir Justin,” she said nervously.
“Those are for you,” Sammy explained, elbowing Justin in the arm.
Justin was already provided leather sandals, but he promptly removed them and retrieved the girl’s hand-crafted pair.
He slipped them on and tied the lace-like vines around his ankles to hold them in place.
“You don’t need to keep them on.
Once we are out of sight, you can change back,” Ceil suggested.
“No, I think I’ll wear them.
They are far more comfortable.
If they break, then I’ll change.
How do you say thank you in Melian?”
“Szeeta,” Sammy replied.
Justin knelt by the fence and smiled at the girl.
“Szeeta.”
Her elated giggle looked to Sammy like a young girl with a crush, but the concept of romantic attraction did not exist in dryad nature.
From what she heard, these Melians made a similar misunderstanding about Justin that the central Melian village had made about her.
Their empress was willing to go to battle to reclaim Justin from the Tolmyur army, so he had to be a high ranking official or royalty or perhaps Ceil’s lover, which Ceil vehemently rejected.
Once Ceil explained to them that Justin was Eydis’s lover, they made every effort to appeal to him.
After all, if what Ceil said was true, he could become emperor consort to the new Empress Eydis once Eydis claimed the throne.

This was a harsh reality check for Sammy, because even though she desperately wanted Justin to love her and to be hers, he already had Eydis, and who would turn down such a wonderful, strong, intelligent, kind, and beautiful woman who was also the future leader of an empire?

Eydis’s safety was unknown, but Sammy could never, even in the darkest reaches of her jealous heart, wish that ill fortune befell her best friend just so she could claim Justin as her own after she already had her chance with him and ruined it.

Although, Eydis had expressed shortly before she was hospitalized that sharing Justin with her was a matter of course, even going so far as to state that Sammy had far more right to Justin than she ever could.
Sammy laughed off the exchange back then, but perhaps that was Eydis’s way of telling Sammy to settle her and Justin’s past.
Eydis recognized how much Sammy still loved him.
Sammy hooked her arm around Justin’s and led him to the cobblestone street.
Four High Elf soldiers stood behind Dharin.
Sammy had seen male High Elves before, but none this close where she had time to admire them.
They had to be over seven feet tall.
Beside Dharin was a female elf in loose-fitting leather armor.
Sammy assumed she was an elf, but she was not like any she had seen before, at least that she could remember.
This elf was about six feet tall and had a curvaceous figure that her loose leather armor could not hide, completely different than the slender High Elves and fairies.
Her short brown hair stuck out straight in all directions, and her long pointed ears with fine brown fur lining the top edge drooped heavily downward.
Her face was lightly freckled, something Sammy had never seen in any race from this world, and her eyes were the most brilliant shade of orange.
“Your eyes are beautiful,” Sammy spoke without thinking.
The corner of the elf’s full lips curled upwards, but she did not speak.
Dharin extended his hand beside him to the new elf.
“This is Thanysa, a brier under my command.
She will act as your guide.”
Thanysa bowed to a perfect right angle.
“I am most honored to accompany you, Empress Ceil, Lady Sammy, Lady Chloe, and Sir Justin.”
“What’s a brier,” Sammy asked.
“A special operations unit that acts directly under the Thorn General,” Ceil explained.
“They handle counter-espionage and act as executioners for defectors and traitors, but they are mostly used to escort key political figures when not at war.
And she is a Mountain Elf, if you were not aware.
If you remember, they originate to the southwest, south of Fiorrae.”
Sammy was grateful for Ceil’s explanation.
There was one more question lingering on Sammy’s mind, so she posed it to Dharin.
“Isn’t this a fairy city?
Why didn’t you choose to use fairy guards?”
Sammy was worried the question might insult the High Elves, but their expressions did not change.
“Thanysa was raised in Revlan, so she is best suited for a guide.
High Elves have a wider range of magical affinities compared to fairies, so they have a wider range of methods to address any would-be threats.
Also, being twice the height of a Fairy, they have a better vantage point over crowds.
If there is nothing else, Thanysa, please escort them to the orphanage.
They will inform you of other locations they wish to visit along the way.”
“With pleasure.”
Thanysa gave a light bow to Dharin and took her position ahead of the group.
The High Elves stood like pillars in the four corners surrounding everyone.
Even though she asked why Dharin did not select fairy guards, Sammy felt far more secure with these towering figures than she would with guards who were as short as her or more often much shorter.
When Thanysa led them out the curtain wall gate, Sammy was surprised by how much the city changed in the days they had been confined to the central district.
The number of people had drastically increased, and most the streets were crowded enough that no one could walk without bumping shoulders with one another.
“Did they let refugees from the camp into the city,” Ceil asked.
Sammy was relieved she was not the only one surprised by the seemingly sudden change.

“Originally we only allowed those who had relatives from Revlan who could vouch for them enter the inner wall, or artisans and craftsman and any other trade that would be of use preparing for the war and aiding the masses, but the refugee camp filled to breaking.
We had to make more exceptions.
Parents with children were permitted.
Youth who were willing to work a trade regardless of skill were next.
Adults who were combat-able were sent to the soldier camp to the northeast of the city for weapons training.
Eventually, the only people remaining in the camp were elderly, injured, and those who were too psychologically damaged to be of any use, and there are a fair many of those.”
Thanysa’s voice trailed off.
No one could guess what was on her mind, but Sammy felt that if Thanysa was from Revlan, seeing her city in such dire circumstances must have weighed heavily on her.
“If you wanted to see the refugee camp, I would advise against it.
When you place so many mentally weak and unstable in such confines, madness spreads like disease.
It is now more of a death camp than a refuge.
The elderly are dying of fear and stress.
The manic sometimes attack indiscriminately.
Those with weak hearts are killing themselves.
Even the kindest of souls consider ending their own life to make room for others.
We lose about a hundred a day, and the fighting has not even begun.
At least the flow of refugees is ebbing, but that also means the enemy will be the next to approach our gates.”
“Thank you for your honesty,” Ceil said.
“At present, we have no plans to return to the refugee camp.
We have seen the gatehouse’s defenses already, and if I need to know more, I will ask.”
“I am grateful for your consideration.”
Thanysa turned and bowed before continuing onward.
The dense crowd started only one tier below the curtain wall.
The loud tapping of the High Elf guards’ spears signaled the people to part.
The guards did not announce Ceil’s presence per her orders.
She did not want any fanfare or to cause undue commotion, but most the city now knew who she was, so calming the crowd would have been impossible.
Cries rang out and heated conversation spread.
Some praised Ceil while others blamed her for the destruction.
Although word had spread that Sammy, Chloe, and Justin were allies to Vallen, the vilest of the comments Sammy heard were directed at them.
Death, rape, mutilation, torture--all forms of threats were thrown at her in languages and dialects that she was unsure even Ceil could understand.
Perhaps they were speaking in their own ancestral tongues solely to avoid the ire of Ceil and her guard, but Ceil’s steeled face showed that she probably understood a few of them.
Sammy was thankful that Justin and Chloe were not provided the same gift by the Arkhon, and by Lemi’s lack of reaction, she couldn’t understand any of it either.
Sammy understood the citizens’ ire, but that did not stop the anger bubbling up within her, and she struggled within herself to not snap back at the crowd.
If she retaliated in any way, their hatred would be vindicated.
Once Thanysa led them down to the second and then third tier, the crowds grew less angry.
Only the higher-class citizens felt justified in their accusations.
The craftsman and other labor force acknowledged the guarded escort, but they did not break from their toils.
This was Sammy’s first view of the lowest tier.
It was crowded and filthy, and there was no vegetation to be seen, much to Lemi’s dismay.
A stream wafting a sour odor ran through the middle of the widest street.
The air near it was frigid, and Sammy eyed it with suspicion.
“Be careful not to fall in,” Thanysa warned.
“There are a number of underground streams that feed into the city.
We collect fresh water where they spring, but once it enters the city, we use it to wash away refuse.
The water is far more potent due to the overcrowding.
The ice ven normally suppresses the stench.”
“Ice ven?
This is ven enriched water like in Fiorrae?” Sammy asked.
“Very perceptive, Lady Sammy.
Fiorrae is to the south and southwest, and the underground streams originate there.”
Chloe looked around to all the craft-shops, woodworkers, and butchers.
“Is the orphanage really down here?” Sammy translated her question to Thanysa.
“We originally held it between the outer and inner wall on the south side of the city, but the number of refugees grew too large.
We moved it to a warehouse to provide more room.
There are not as many orphaned children as you might think given the number of refugees.
It is over here.”
That only meant children were killed just as much as adults, Sammy realized.
Thanysa turned from the stream down an alley just wide enough to transport crates.
A sheer rock face rose at the end with a simple rectangular entrance.
The whimpers and cries of children could be heard from the dark.
She led them inside, and Sammy’s nose was immediately assaulted by a similar odor to that of the stream if not a little worse.
Her eyes adjusted, and she saw that the warehouse was not as dark as she assumed.
The back half of the large room was piled high with crates, barrels, and other wrapped and bound product.
Much of the hard stone floor in front of the storage was covered in coarse fabric to provide insulation to the two or three hundred children.
None of them looked older than eight years old, if Sammy ignored the difference in stature between the races.
Those who were older were likely put to use elsewhere.
The first Forest Elf to notice Ceil called out to the other women.
They immediately scrambled to tidy up soiled cloth, hush the crying children, and run the overflowing chamber pots out to the stream.
A fairy in the left corner quickly finished rinsing down three naked children with her water magic and wrapped them in a worn cloth.
She then ran to Ceil and bowed deeply.
Being the only one to approach, she was likely the matron.
“My sincerest apologies for the current state of the orphanage.
If we knew you were coming, we would have prepared.”
Ceil shook her head.
“No, this is what we wanted to see.”
There were only five women taking care of the numerous children, and each of them looked exhausted and prone to collapse, some struggling to even lift the smallest of the children.
“How long has it been since any of you have rested?”
“One of us rests at a time, and we trade off, but that often means going two days without sleep before our turn comes around again.”
“Why are you so short staffed?”
“Lord Olvor does not feel the orphanage is important to the war effort.
The six of us had to plead to him to organize it initially.
Before that, the children were neglected like all other refugees in the camp.
Once the children started dying, we had to do something.”
“I see…”
While Ceil and the matron conversed, Chloe located one of the children and ran to him.
He noticed her and a weak smile grew on his face.
It was the fairy boy they found outside the city.
She lifted the boy into her lap and talked with him and the other children around him.
None of them cared that they could not understand each other.
Their sorrowful expressions slowly changed as Chloe taught them the simple hand games she had learned from the children in Lemi’s village.
The scene warmed Sammy’s heart.
Even though Chloe was human, none of the children cared, their innocence freeing them of any hatred or bias.
They were starved for love and attention, and the moment Chloe offered it, they grasped for it with small, eager hands.
The Forest Elf watched in amazement as the first small cry of laughter was heard from a young fairy girl who could have been no older than three if she was human.
The women working in the orphanage were so busy taking care of the children that none had the time to play with them.
“How many children are there,” Sammy asked.
“As of this morning, 207.”
Ceil’s eyes narrowed.
“Thanysa, what is the largest estate in the inner city.”
“That would be Lord Olvar’s, your highness.
It has two manors and one servant house.”
“How many people are currently living there?”
“Lord Olvar, his two wives, and their five children.”
“How many could live comfortably in both manors.”
Thanysa grew a sly grin.
“Perhaps fifty if keeping to the standard of living the upper class are accustomed to.”
“And how many servants does he employ?”
Now the matron’s eyes grew wide.
“I am unsure,” Thanysa replied, “but the size of the servant house suggests that there may be at least twenty living there.”
Sammy couldn’t contain the excitement building in her chest, but she kept silent, not wanting to jump ahead of Ceil.
“In the name of Empress Ceil of the Amelian Empire, I declare that Lord Olvar’s estate be repurposed into an orphanage and that his servants help care for the children.
Should we win this war, the children will be the ones rebuilding the empire.
There is nowhere safer in a siege than the central district, and should the children not be protected?
If Lord Olvar protests or wrongs the children in any manner, I order him to live in this warehouse.
How soon can you make the arrangements?”
“By tonight.”
Thanysa snapped her finger and a tiny fairy no taller than a foot, or maybe a few inches less, warped in out of nowhere.
She recited Ceil’s decree to him verbatim, including her inflections, and then the tiny fairy vanished just as quickly as he appeared.
“What was that?” Sammy asked, slightly dumbfounded.
“A pixie,” Thanysa replied.
“They are a close relative to the fairies.
A small number of them can use spatial magic as an extension of their body, but they can only use teleportation and only on themselves and whatever is directly on their person.
We employ them as messengers and spies.”
“How can I ever repay you?”
The matron bowed herself before Ceil.
“You have done so much more than we ever could have hoped for.”
The other orphanage workers who heard the decree knelt where they were and sung praises to their empress.
Ceil bent down and lifted the matron.
“All I ask is that you continue caring for these children and protect them when the siege begins.”
“Of course. Of course, Your Highness.”
Content with what she saw, Ceil readied to leave the warehouse.
“Is it alright if I stay here?” Chloe asked with the small fairy boy in her arms and another fairy girl clinging to her skirt.
“All I wanted to see was the orphanage.
I don’t have anywhere else I want to go.”
“I see no issue.”
Ceil granted Chloe one of the High Elf guards with Thanysa’s permission and left her at the orphanage.
“Chloe is an odd one,” Ceil said as they walked back through the alleyway.
“Says the one who went out of her way to oust the local Lord for those same children,” Sammy chuckled.
“Any idea of what you want to see next?”
“I would like to see how they are preparing to arm the citizens.
They have far too few soldiers to fight against Tolmyur’s army.”
“I know the perfect location where they will not get annoyed by our presence,” Thanysa replied.
“Would anyone grow annoyed by their empress visiting them?” Sammy asked.
“Not that they would openly express, but this smith is different.
He is my father.”
“You were a smith?”
“Traditionally, Mountain Elf women are the warriors while the men are the workforce back in the village.
Mountain Elf women can birth as many as four to twelve children at once, so we are restricted by law to one litter conception per family in order to control our rapid population growth.
Extreme population and limited resources led to endless wars among Mountain Elves in the past, so the population control laws are rather strict.”
Sammy listened with confusion, not understanding how this answered her question.
“My mother only birthed my brother and I in her single allowed litter.
Even though we no longer live in Syvad, my father refused to let me inherit his forge, since allowing me would be a breach of tradition.
He ordered me to enlist and is raising my brother to be his successor.
My mother was employed in Amel to train the royal guard, so my father wanted me to follow her career.
Now, I am the instructor of the briers here in Vallen, but only after my superior died in the Gallanvale.”

Chapter 13
“The Difficult Decision”
Sammy

Thanysa led Ceil and Sammy back the way they came down the stream road of the lowest tier, and Sammy had to immediately look away from a High Elf craftsman who pulled his blackened apron aside to relieve himself directly into the stream.
“You’d think they would care more when their empress is right in front of them…” Sammy sighed.
“The workforce cares more for efficiency than appearance,” Thanysa explained.
“The quicker he can get back to work, the more productive he will be.
If you are bothered by nudity, then perhaps you should not enter the forge.”
“No, I am fine with it.
Chloe would be a mess, though.
Lucky for her she decided to stay behind.”
The moment Sammy spoke those words, she thought of another individual.
She looked behind her and noticed Lemi trailing behind.
Lemi’s expression was disconcerting, and she kept glancing up searching for any sign of the green on the tops of the buildings in the upper tiers.
“Are you alright?” Sammy stopped walking, and so everyone else was forced to halt with her.
Lemi did not answer, so Sammy put her arm around the girl.
She was shivering like a scared puppy.
Is the lack of greenery really that traumatizing for dryads?
Sammy hadn’t realized that Lemi was in such a state.
She hadn’t spoken or reacted to anything once they reached the bottom tier.
Sammy couldn’t even remember if Lemi had entered the warehouse orphanage.
“You can go back to the manor if you like.”
Lemi shook her head and drew closer to Sammy.
“If I hold onto you, will you be okay?
If it becomes too unbearable, tell me, and we can go back.”
Lemi nodded meekly.
Thanysa led them along the bottom tier to the south side of the city.
Before Sammy could see the smiths and forges, she felt the heat.

The temperature raised by no less than twenty degrees, and some of the craftsman wearing no more than their aprons sat next to the stream, which smelled slightly better now that it was closer to its fountain, to bask in its radiant chill.
“This way.”
Thanysa walked down another alleyway, and Sammy wondered if her family was a poorer smith in the city that could not afford a front-end shop.

This idea conflicted with her perception of the family considering Thanysa was an instructor for Vallen’s special operations force and her mother was an instructor for the Amelian palace guard, both incredibly prominent careers or so she assumed.
The alleyway opened to the widest, almost cavernous storefront carved deep into the tier above it.
The forge was completely open with thick stone pillars supporting the ceiling.
Even standing outside of it, the temperature increased yet again, feeling like a sweltering summer day.

The inside glowed with a deep orange, and the many men who worked within wore as little as was necessary to perform their labors, often no more than a small apron at their waist to cover their genitals from the sparks of the anvils and flames.
One of the largest individuals noticed the armed escort and walked out of the forge.
He was a broad-shouldered beast of an elf with thick, mane-like hair running down his back dripping with sweat.
His eyes were a darker orange, almost brown, and his ears were as long as Thanysa’s but hairless and pointed almost straight upwards.
His exuberant muscles were toned and heat-roasted from the flames, almost dark enough to hide the freckles on his chest, shoulders, and arms.
He approached Thanysa with a wide, fanged smile and embraced her, spinning her once in the air.
“Thanysa, you never visit, but I assume you are on official business?”
He set her back on the ground, her leather armor now darkened with his sweat.
“Escorting…” He looked down at Ceil and immediately knelt.
“Your Highness, it is a great honor to have you visit my humble forge.”
“You must be a smith of high renown to have the largest forge in the city,” Ceil said.
“You honor me.”
He bowed deeper, and his grin widened further to become almost haughty.
Either he was greatly proud of his standing or adored praise.
“Sarodyn is one of the few smiths in the Empire who can forge resfahil.
Such skill would warrant no less,” Thanysa explained.
Ceil’s eyes widened.
“Resfahil weaponry could give us an immense advantage in this battle.”
“Alas, Your Highness, the ore to smelt the alloy is in terribly short supply.
All we possess has been claimed by a single order requested by the Thorn General.”
Sarodyn stood and rested his hands on his hip.
“What brings the young empress to my forge?
Here to make a request of your own?”
Ceil shook her head.
“I wish to see how you are arming the civilians for the siege to make up for the lack of soldiers.”
Sarodyn nodded and promptly walked off.
“This way,” he called with a wave of his massive hand.
He led them to the far-left side of the forge-front where many large wooden crates sat in a row along the wall.
“While every fairy and elf in the city can use magic, most average citizens only learn what helps them in daily life, not combat.
We cannot expect them to learn offensive magic quickly, let alone safely, so instead we provide these.”
He dipped his hand in and raised it slowly, letting countless finger-sized pieces of metal sift through.
To Sammy, they almost looked like large silver bullets, but they were sharpened to a point.
“What are those?” Sammy asked.
“Spearheads, young lass.
Spears and pikes are the most versatile weapon for almost any form of mass warfare if you have room to wield it.
They can be used with minimal training, and the reach keeps you safe so long as your opponent lacks magic or a longer spear,” Sarodyn guffawed.
“Humans lack in magic compared to elfkind, no offense to you, which makes these weapons ever more vital.
If we can hold out against their magic until their ven depletes, we will have the advantage.”
Sarodyn reached behind the crate and lifted three different spears in a single grip.
He handed a short spear about two meters long to Ceil and the mid length spear about four meters long to Justin who struggled to hold it steady.
Sarodyn looked at him depressingly, and then took it from him to hand to Thanysa.
He held the longest and thinnest of the spears, an astonishing 8 meters.
They were each tipped with the same small spearhead.
“The spears are for the citizens who will not be defending the walls in the case of a breach.
The pikes are for our soldiers.
And this,” Sarodyn raised the spear by the base of the haft, almost making it reach halfway up to the next tier of the city, “is for the airborne fairies.
These spears are too flimsy for regular combat, but in the hands of a flyer, they can be quite lethal.
Word has it that we killed the Tolmyur captain in charge of the Vallen campaign with one.
Flyers are few among fairies, so we need to protect them.
Better to have their spear break after one or two uses and replace it than force them to approach their enemy and get killed.”
“Why not use bows,” Sammy asked.
Sarodyn walked over to another crate and dug out a handful of even smaller tips than the spearheads.
Like the spearheads, they were all perfectly identical.
Military mass production was on full display.
“I showed you the spearheads first because you asked how we armed the citizens.
Bows require far more skill, so we cannot let just anyone draw the string, especially in the city.
We have no shortage of wood, but we lack in iron, so we cannot make too much expendable ammunition.”
“Every soldier is given a shortbow and a small quiver of arrows,” Thanysa explained.
“Standard equipment.
This goes for winged fairies as well.
The carpenters are currently fletching a large number of wood-tipped arrows that will be kept in barrels along the wall walk.”
“In your opinion, what are our chances of surviving the siege?” Ceil asked.
“Oh, you ask difficult questions, Your Highness.”
Sarodyn retrieved the spears and returned them to their piles behind the crates.
“If I am to be completely honest, I would say we have a two in three chance of surviving so long as they do not choose the prolonged route and starve us.
With how many refugees we have taken in, once our supply of food is cut, we will not last.
In the worst case, we could turn some of the refugees into food provisions.
Mountain Elves have a history of eating their own, but I doubt the other races would be so willing even in the worst of situations.”
Sammy shuddered at the gruesome prospect.
She would rather starve.
“I see.
Thank you,” Ceil said.
“Do you wish to see anything else?
I could show you around the forge.”
Ceil looked into the glowing orange building and then over to Lemi who was already wilting from stress.
“That will not be necessary.
I am grateful we have such skilled craftsman here in Revlan.
Keep up the hard work.”
“Of course, Your Highness.”
Sarodyn bowed again, but he did appear slightly depressed that Ceil declined his invitation to show off his forge.
“Then we shall take our leave,” Thanysa announced, nodding to her father.
“I hope you would spare some time to visit when not on official business,” Sarodyn said as Thanysa led them down the alley.
“Do you not get along with your father?” Sammy asked.
“I harbor no ill will, but…” Thanysa shook her head.
“I was always fascinated by my father’s work.
My brother is incompetent and has been unable to grasp even the most basic concepts of resfahil alloys.
