Resfahil resists and disperses magic, so smelting, forging, and smithing the metal requires precise control of a natural flame, unlike all other metals that can be forged with the assistance of magic.
While I cannot vouch for my own skill having never apprenticed the trade, I feel I could have done better if my father only gave me the opportunity.
But there is nothing to be gained in dwelling on what could have been.
I take pride in my current position, and I am sure that pleases my father.
Where would you like to go next?”
Ceil looked back again at Lemi.
“I think we have spent long enough down here.
After what Sarodyn said, I wanted to ask about your food stores, but if they are also on the bottom tier, I will pass.”
“The majority of the warehouses are similar to what you saw at the orphanage, but there is somewhere I can take you that should help the young dryad feel better and hopefully answer your question.”
Thanysa brought them up to the first tier on the east side of the city and then to the wall walk of the inner wall.
Almost immediately Lemi had a full resurrection from the anxiety of the bottom tier after viewing the lush greenery of the city from high upon the wall and the expansive fields on the outer side.
Lemi released Sammy’s arm and pushed her to Justin who was struggling to walk after having climbed all those steps.
Justin refused to stop and rest, citing that he needed to push himself or he would not recover, so Sammy hung his arm over her shoulder and carried him forward with an exasperated grin.
Chloe could not handle heights or anywhere with male nudity.
Lemi could not handle locations without vegetation.
Justin could not endure anywhere that required even the lightest athleticism to access, at least for now.
Her friends had a strange set of weaknesses, all of which they had encountered on their tour of the city.
When they reached the west side of the city, Thanysa stopped so they could view the ongoing harvest.
Sammy watched the tiny workers, mostly older children, in amazement.
“Crops even grow during the winter here?”
“Winters in the Amelian Empire are often mild, so we can have multiple yields before summer arrives, but the yields are smaller, and the vegetables are not as healthy,” Ceil explained.
“Crops grown during winter are often kept for village stores whereas the summer crops are exported for profit.
Oh, this excludes seasonal crops that cannot be stored for long periods of time without spoiling.
Only preservables like grains, lentils, and root vegetables are handled this way, but those make up the bulk of most crops.
Fresh fruits are often only a seasonal luxury unless you are of high status.”
Ceil’s rigid expression melted when she talked about agriculture and pointed out the crops growing in each of the fields beyond the wall.
Seeing this warmed Sammy’s heart.
Ceil would almost smile at times during her explanations, but her lips never managed to curl upwards as if her cheeks had long lost the ability to do so.
“You are mostly growing barley from the appearance, but the ears do not look ripe.”
“We wanted to hold off on the harvest as long as possible, but with only one town and a village remaining, both mostly evacuated already, we cannot wait any longer.
We began the harvest two days ago, and the yield is far lower than what we were hoping.
We could speed the aging of some of the crop with life magic, but all our life mages are held up treating the refugees.”
“The Melians that arrived with Justin, if they are willing, we can send those not treating Justin to the fields to help increase the yield,” Ceil suggested and then paused to think.
“If Tolmyur plans to starve us, perhaps we could use the Melians to help grow crops within the city.
I do not know how large a field the Melians could tend with their ven capacity.
If they are willing, speak with them and allocate the appropriate size of garden space from the central district estates to be used for crops.
Dryads replenish their ven quickly, so even if it is not enough to sustain the city, we can at least continue growing during the siege until the soil loses its nutrients.”
Thanysa snapped her fingers, and again the pixie appeared from nowhere.
She recited Ceil’s suggestion to him, mentioning that it was not an order and that the dryads could refuse.
The messenger bowed to Ceil in the air and then vanished.
Ceil looked over the fields and then back into the city to see the numerous people moving about.
“Including this yield, do you have an estimate on how many days we can last with the city’s current population?”
“I apologize, Your Highness.
Such estimates are outside my expertise.”
“Your best guess then.”
“Fifty days?
If Tolmyur does choose to starve us, they will also need to consume their own food stores, and hopefully it is lower than ours.
Feeding an army requires more sustenance than feeding civilians, and unless they have an abundant food source, that may not be an option for them.”
“Are you employing other methods of gathering food, such as hunting or foraging?” Sammy asked.
“Of course, but we have already cleaned out the nearby forests.
And, your Habha has been very helpful in that regard.”
“I hope that wasn’t sarcasm,” Sammy groaned.
Coby flew off the day after Justin showed up, only showing himself periodically to check up on Sammy and sleep, and each time he looked exhausted.
“No, Lady Sammy.
I speak in all seriousness.
Habha are one of the fastest on wings.
He has been hunting far from the city and delivering his prey directly to the butchers in exchange for the fatty scraps that do not preserve well.”
“Coby’s been doing that?!”
Sammy could not believe what she heard.
Even Ceil was amazed.
She had to wonder if Coby was intelligent enough on his own to realize that the city needed more food or if he was just bartering premium fatty cuts for his kills.
“I would not doubt that he has doubled our meat stores in the few days he has been here.
Perhaps in the future we should train Habha.”
“I don’t know if that is possible,” Sammy grimaced.
“Coby is just an odd one.”
“I agree,” Ceil added.
“They are highly aggressive and territorial.
Coby is only with us because of Sammy’s absurdity.”
“Saving him may have been crazy, but he has helped us in turn many times,” Sammy retorted.
The tour finished with a visit to the soldier camp outside the northeast wall of the city where Ceil observed the training of the combat-able citizens and refugees.
Justin could barely walk by this point even with Lemi numbing the ache of his muscles and boosting his stamina, so they decided to retrieve Chloe and return to the manor.
On the way back up the tiers, Chloe was pensively silent despite the light conversation in English between Sammy, Justin, and Ceil, ignoring the angry shouts of the crowd.
Disregarding what was being discussed, Chloe spoke up just before they passed through the curtain wall gate.
“I’m staying for the siege.”
Everyone stopped and turned to look at Chloe.
“You and Justin can decide to leave if you want, but I’m staying.”
Ceil did not look please with Chloe’s decision.
“What led you to make that choice?”
“I already said I would fight for you.
But… more than that, I don’t want to abandon those children.
My fire magic is strong, and if the city falls, I couldn’t bear the idea that it might not have happened if I stayed.”
“And nothing I can say will make you change your mind?”
Chloe shook her head.
Ceil reached over and embraced Chloe.
She spoke something in a whisper that Sammy could barely hear, “Thank you… and sorry.”
Back inside the inner city, several guards stood on the street outside Dharin’s estate.
A lavishly robed fairy was in a heated argument with Dharin and Kiri.
When the fairy saw Ceil approach, he sent his guards to surround her.
The four High Elves brandished their spears and glared down at the far smaller fairies.
“Lord Olvor, what is the problem,” Ceil asked.
“This is what happens when a peasant is sat on a throne.
The briers removed me from my estate because of your decree.

First you falsely accuse the Rose General of treason after all he has done to save fairy lives, and now you remove me from my position as Lord after all I have done to prepare this city for the siege.”
Ceil’s eyebrows narrowed.
“I did no such thing.
You can keep your position as Lord.
If you were removed from your estate, then you must have openly opposed offering your spare rooms to children in need.”
“We already offered my city to those children when we gain nothing from doing so.
We could have turned them away.”
“Had you done so and I learned of it, I would have revoked your status as Lord.
I am grateful you are accepting refugees, and I am proud of what I have seen in your city in preparation for the battle.
I did not target you specifically.
I asked who in the inner city had the largest estate and then next confirmed that there were plentiful vacancies to house the children and servants to care for them.
If your estate lacked in any of these areas, I would not have made the decree and would have chosen another.
You are free to return to your estate if you are willing to accept those children.”
Ceil walked forward while Thanysa and the four guards shielded her.
Olvor’s guards parted nervously.
“Your empire is no more.
This is the Vallen Kingdom, and I refuse to acknowledge your authority,” Olvor said as Ceil passed.
“So be it.
Until Eydis FeAmel reclaims it, the Amel Dynasty has ended.
I, as the new empress, claim all territories of the former empire.
You can accept my rule or live in that dark warehouse alone.”
Ceil turned onto Dharin’s small estate and walked briskly for the manor without another word, her pace increasing to a run as she neared it.
She then flung open the door and slammed it behind her.
Thanysa and the guards stood before the property to block Lord Olvor and his guards.
Sammy wanted to chase after Ceil, but she was still supporting Justin.
Chloe and Lemi hurried to the manor in her stead.
“The rise of the Cielian Empire, the Empire of Life,” Dharin mused.
He turned to Lord Olvor and donned the authoritative presence of the Thorn General.
“The armies of Vallen are in full support of Her Highness, Empress Ceil.”
“The people of Vallen also pledge their loyalty to Her Highness, Empress Ceil,” Kiri followed.
“Lord Olvor, out of respect for your position as Lord of Revlan and the neighboring towns and villages, I ask that you submit yourself to Empress Ceil.
Should you refuse, by my authority as head of the royal council, I will revoke your title of lord and find another to replace you.
I am sure there will be many who are willing.”
Lord Olvor’s face grew red with anger, but when he saw the iron expressions of Dharin and Kiri, his countenance fell in defeat.
Even if he wanted to claim Vallen independent, either Dharin or Kiri would be crowned monarch, and they both expressed support for Ceil.
“Take me back to my estate,” he ordered his guards, walking off with his slender tail literally tucked between his legs.
Chloe spent the evening with Ceil to help her through the anxiety caused by her declaration and to thank her for what she did for the orphans.
Sammy was helping as well, but there was an important discussion she needed to have with Justin.
She helped Justin to their room and found Coby asleep by the window with his two jagged yellow plumes jutting forward once again like bizarre moth antennae.
“I still can’t get use to that,” Justin said while Sammy helped him sit down on their bed mats.
After the exhausting tour all over the city, Justin could not stand without his legs shaking uncontrollably and buckling.
“We pushed you too hard.
Tyree said today was more damaging than helpful, but it’s times like this that make me glad we have life magic freely available.
It’ll only set your rehabilitation back a few days.
It’d be quicker if gravity wasn’t so strong here.”
Sammy sat behind Justin and rested her head on the back of his shoulder.
She wrapped her arms around him and felt his ribs in her embrace.
With a deep breath, she spoke the words she had been holding in for the past few days.
“You are far too weak to take part in the siege.
I want you to leave the city as soon as you can walk on your own.
If that takes too long, I will beg the Melians to take you.”
Justin grabbed Sammy’s wrist, pulled it off his chest, and then intertwined their fingers.
“What about you?”
Sammy was glad that Justin did not outright reject her request.
Even he should realize how much of a liability he would be when the fighting begins.
But, when he directed the question back at her, her willfully suppressed emotions broke through, and she gripped his hand tighter.
“I’m scared.
I keep having nightmares about Gullivan.
What I saw in Nalain keeps flashing in my mind when I think about the siege.
It makes the nightmares worse.
Chloe is trying to help me with them, and Ceil says that I will get over them, but I’m not strong like they are.”
“You are plenty strong.
Someone weak would have never been able to carry me all over the world and take care of me long enough to find help.
I am alive because of you.”
“If it wasn’t for me, you wouldn’t have gotten hurt.
You would have received help sooner.”
Justin turned to face Sammy.
“This is unlike you.
What happened to the headstrong girl that never gave a damn what others thought and would power through any trial with sheer willpower and no shortage of stubbornness?”
“You happened.”
Sammy clung to Justin’s robe with a fallen gaze.
“Eydis happened.
The war happened.
I didn’t know if you would survive.
I don’t know if Eydis is alive.
If it was just me, I would be fine, but I have things I care about more than myself.
I want Ceil to run.
I want Chloe to run.
Lemi too.
I act stubborn in front of Ceil, but I’m scared.
Because Ceil decided to stay, I want to stay, especially now that Chloe is staying.
I don’t want to leave them.
I want to fight too, but I can’t.
I don’t know how, and I will be in their way.
I’m just as useless as you are.”
“That’s harsh,” Justin quipped.
“I’m being serious here!”
Sammy glared angrily at Justin, but he only looked back with a soft, understanding smile.
“Sounds to me like you already made your decision.”
“I have… I have but…”
“Then stay and don’t question it.
That’s what you would normally do.
No one will say you are useless, and it’s not like being in the city will make Ceil any less of a leader or Chloe any less powerful.
If anything, you being here will give them reason to fight harder.
They care for you as much as you care for them.
If they didn’t, they wouldn’t have wanted you to run.
So, are you going to stay?”
“If I can’t convince them to run, then yah, I want to stay.”
“Good.
Then I am staying too.”
“What?
No!
Justin!
Haven’t you been listening to anything I said?”
“I’ve said this before, but I kind of feel responsible for everything that’s happened.
I know I didn’t have much control over it, but it all started when I took Eydis in.
I haven’t told you this, but after you met Eydis and took us to the mall, when you learned the truth, that evening Eydis and I talked.
You made a good impression on her.
She liked you, but she told me to ask you to stay away, for your safety.
She practically begged me to, but I refused.
I told Eydis to try and become good friends with you because I thought that having another girl she could talk with would help her, although I did not tell her my reasoning.
“Because of me, you ended up getting involved just as much as I did.
I don’t regret it, but I would still feel terrible if something happened to you because of all this.
I’m not going to run.
I’ll help where I can.
I am probably useless in a fight.
You said it yourself.
But even so, I can at least make a good meat shield.”
“That’s not funny!”
Sammy pushed Justin in the shoulder, and he almost fell to his back, catching himself with his arm.
“God… Think about other’s feelings before you speak.”
Tears dripped from Sammy’s chin onto the bed mat, and she clutched her fists in her lap.

She wanted to punch him for that comment, but she felt she had caused him enough pain already, not only from prolonging his suffering by telling the Arkhon she would find him help, but also from all the times she abused him both physically and emotionally after she broke up with him.
And yet he never stopped caring for her.
“Sorry.
Bad joke,” Justin apologized.
Sammy grabbed Justin and pulled him down onto the mat so that she could hold him and cry silently into his chest.
“Promise me… promise me you will survive the battle.”
“I will.”
He rested one hand behind Sammy’s head and held her close.
“I am good a dodging, remember?”
A sound rose from Sammy’s throat that she did not know whether it was a hiccup, a laugh, or a cry.
She clung tighter to the warmth of Justin’s chest.
“Smart ass…”

Chapter 14
“A School of Combat”
Sammy
“So, you decided to stay.”
Ceil nervously rolled the torn piece of bread into a ball with her fingers.

Sammy did not receive the same gratitude and apology that Ceil had given Chloe, so Sammy had to assure herself that this was because Ceil truly wanted her to flee for her safety, not because Ceil thought she would be unable to contribute to the battle.
“Neither of us wanted to abandon you and Chloe.
We won’t be much use fighting up front like maybe Chloe would, but we’ll help where we can,” Sammy tried to explain.
“It was never about whether or not you could help,” Ceil said, much to Sammy’s relief.
“I am worried about your ability to protect yourself.
A lot can happen in a war.
There is no telling what you might encounter.”
“There is little time until the siege, but perhaps I can help,” Dharin spoke up.
“Thanysa is an instructor for the briers, and that includes the use of martial weaponry and hand-to-hand combat.
Learning the basics with a sword or spear could save your life.”
“Eydis taught us the basics of her family’s martial arts, but only the parts useful for self-defense,” Sammy explained.
“Did she truly?
There is little difference in skills used for defense and those use for offense.
If you know the basics, Thanysa may be able to help you more than I originally thought.
I will arrange a location for her to instruct you somewhere here in the central district so that Sir Justin will not need to travel far.”
“Will Justin even be able to participate?” Ceil asked.
“He couldn’t even hold a spear yesterday.”
“That was a pike.
You had the spear.
Maybe if it was something smaller, he would be fine.”
Sammy fought desperately for Justin’s inclusion.

Because the self-defense class back in Gullivan was only for women, he was unable to actively participate aside from demonstrations, and although he had some knowledge about what Eydis taught, he never practiced.
His inability to use any offensive magic also worried her.
“Justin needs a way to protect himself.”
Ceil shook her head.
“Sorry.
I did not mean to say that I was against him participating.”
“Then I will make the arrangements.”
“Thank you.”
Sammy bowed to Dharin over the table.
The morning proceeded like the previous day except it was Thanysa who came to the door instead of Dharin.
Everyone was present except for Chloe.
“Do you know where she went,” Sammy asked Ceil.
“She is helping set up the orphanage at Lord Olvor’s estate.
I doubt she requires combat training anyway.”
“She was one of the better students in Eydis’s class,” Sammy sighed, realizing once more just how absurd her friend was.
Then again, she almost died in Melia, so Sammy wanted her to participate anyway.
“It’s not like these lessons will go all day.
We should make her participate.
She can spend time at the orphanage after.”
As they passed Dharin’s gardens, now looking far lusher and more vibrant than when they first arrived, Sammy noticed something missing, the Melians.
Only Tyree and Tae remained.
“They left early this morning from what I hear,” Thanysa explained.
“They are helping with the harvest while space is being allocated here in the inner city for their crops.
They were quite ecstatic to be of use instead of acting as living ornaments of the Thorn General’s gardens.”
Sammy was amazed how quickly Ceil’s suggestions were being put into practice.
The people trusted Ceil as their empress.
Lord Olvor opposed at first, but none of the other nobles had come to protest the use of their lands.
Sammy felt that each of Ceil’s suggestions was brilliant, and anyone would be a fool to reject them.
If the empire comes out victorious in the war, Sammy knew Ceil would make a wonderful ruler.

Thanysa led them to the eastern sector of the central district to a large stone building almost as overgrown as Dharin’s except the vegetation on top was perfectly placed for aesthetics, and the entrance and garden was beautifully cultured.
Stone benches lined ponds decorated with skillfully crafted statues of nude fairies and elves.
Winter flowers of white and red bloomed all around.
Lemi ran through the gardens spinning and dancing with such abandon that some of her white petals fell loose from her hair.
Sammy smiled.
Lemi had to be happy that they went to a location that was lush and vibrant instead of the cold hard stone of the lower tiers.
“What is this building,” Sammy inquired.
“A dance hall for formal engagements.
It is large enough to hold combat practice, and the noble who owns it readily gave me permission to use it after I informed her it was for Her Highness.”
“The noble only wants to curry favor with me,” Ceil retorted.
Sammy nudged Ceil with her shoulder.
“Don’t be so pessimistic.”
As opposed to the beautifully artistic garden, the inside was more grandiose.
The original stone structure had been carved over by intricate patterns with accents overlaid by possibly silver.
Unlike the wood-shuttered windows of the manors, foggy glass panes were set into tall pointed arch windows with delicate green curtains pulled to the side.
Large, polished stone pots between each window held tall plants that reminded Sammy of bamboo but with long, runcinate leaves.
Lemi circled one of the large pots to admire the plant she had never seen before.
“Is it really okay to fight in here,” Sammy asked, worried about being unable to pay for any damages.
“Unless you have incredibly powerful magic, there should be no problem.
The owner knew full well our plans for her hall,” Thanysa said.
“There should be no problems in Chloe’s absence,” Ceil added.
“I think Chloe would be too afraid to use her magic even if she was here,” Sammy retorted.
Thanysa walked over to the small, elevated, oval stage at the front where a few bags were placed.
She removed simple leather training armor and passed it out to Sammy, Ceil, Lemi, and Justin.
One by one she helped them don the armor.
Trousers were also provided to replace everyone’s skirts so that they could don the leg armor.
Ceil made Sammy force Justin to look away while she changed despite Sammy’s assurance that Justin would not look.
Lemi appeared uncomfortable in the armor, which was understandable considering she usually only wore her dava.
Ceil likewise was uncomfortable but for another reason.
“I hate trousers.
My tails are so long I must run them down the pant legs, so they keep rubbing.” Ceil cringed with every bowlegged step.
“The trousers are unisex.
If you are that sensitive, you can use the tail hole in the back,” Thanysa said.
Ceil fingered the tail hole as if seriously considering its use but then looked over at Justin.
“I decline.
I will endure it.”
Thanysa removed a number of weapons including two types of swords, staves, spears, and a long, thin shield.
“Your Highness, having lived in the palace, I assume you were trained in combat?”
Ceil shook her head.
“They cared more about purging my commoner upbringing and teaching bed manners over any form of combat, but I was taught a little.”
“Any arts you are practiced in?”
“Staves, unarmed, and rapiers.”
Thanysa tossed a pair of gloves to Ceil.
“Show me.”
She took a peculiar, unarmed stance with one fist raised.
Sammy immediately recognized it from Eydis’s lessons.
Ceil matched the stance, and without a signal, the duel began.

Thanysa refrained from attacking at first, letting Ceil show the maneuvers ingrained in her, but Sammy could tell they were sloppy at best, like Ceil knew the form and what they should look like but had never put in the required practice time to perfect them.
Slowly, Thanysa added in strikes until Ceil was eventually overwhelmed.
And then it ended as abruptly as it began.
“Less than even a single season’s worth of practice,” Thanysa critiqued.
“As I said,” Ceil replied.
They changed to staves where Ceil showed far more proficiency.
Thanysa moved to offense rather quickly after only three strikes from Ceil, but like the first match, Ceil was eventually overpowered and was on her back after only a few minutes.
“They do not teach staves at the palace, at least not to the royal family.
This is self-taught.”
“Out of necessity in Fiorrae,” Ciel said.
“Your time there was short, but necessity breeds competence.
Your skill with the staff is far better.”
Rapiers followed, and Ceil’s performance was worse than unarmed.
In a real fight, Ceil would have died in the first few seconds.
Thanysa asked about magic, but Ceil could only use life magic, limiting her combat options.
In the end, Thanysa determined that improving Ceil’s competence with staves would best serve her abilities, especially when she could use her staff as a conduit for life magic.
Ceil was heavily flushed in the face after the assessment and sat down adjusting her tails inside her pant legs.
Lemi followed Ceil, but she could only use a bow.
According to her, Melians were not trained for war like the Kedros, Pefkos, or Elatos, the three warrior tribes of Dhuillir.
They only practiced archery by imperial mandate in preparation should they be called to battle, but even then, few actually practiced.
Melians were far more laid back than their other dryad counterparts.
Most other tribes had means of combat unique to them, but the Melians did not.
“You are really powerful with the bow, though,” Sammy said, expressing confidence in Lemi’s ability.
“You took off that cedar dryad’s arm with an arrow, and you blew up that one soldier’s chest.
I don’t think anyone else can do that with just an arrow.”
“It’s not the arrow,” Lemi replied.
“It’s life magic.
I put magic on the arrow, and it works when the arrow hits something living.”
“That is brilliant,” Ceil said with wide eyes.
“Do all Melians do this?”
Lemi nodded.
“Most of them, if they are good at life magic.”
“Can you give me a demonstration?” Thanysa requested.
Lemi nodded excitedly and placed her hand on one of the bamboo-like plants, ignoring the bow Thanysa removed from the bag for her.
The plant grew a new branch that curved into the recognizable shape of a bow and then sprouted a long root-like fiber from the top.
Lemi snapped the branch off at the base, and after bracing the base of the bow with her foot, she bent it to attach the root to the other tip.
After a practice draw, Lemi’s eyes widened.
“This is good wood!”
“The wood is thin and hollow, so we cannot use it for bows,” Thanysa said.
“If you grow it as a bow, it is really good!”
Lemi grew an arrow from the same stalk and snapped it off.
She knocked it into the string and drew the bow, releasing the arrow at one of the plants across the large hall without taking any time to aim.
Once the arrow struck the stalk, it ruptured with a loud crack, sending the tall plant careening onto the floor.
“Lemi!
Don’t destroy the place!”
Lemi looked back at Sammy confused.
“But she wanted a demonstration.”
She quickly ran over to the plant and hoisted it back onto the pot with some effort.
Ignoring Thanysa’s assurance that it was not a problem, Lemi used life magic to fuse the plant back to the base growing from the pot.
All that remained of Lemi’s damage was a small knot in the stalk and that the plant was shorter by about a foot.
Thanysa was confident in Lemi’s ability, so she turned to Sammy for the next assessment.
“Eydis taught me the same hand-to-hand that Ceil used, but I am worse than Ceil, and I only know self-defense.”
Thanysa tossed the pair of gloves to Sammy and took her fighting stance.
Sammy knew she expected an engagement, but she was embarrassed.
There was no way she could show anything of worth.
As if reading Sammy’s thoughts, Thanysa spoke up.
“Do not worry about your skill.
If I do not know what level you are at, I will not know what to teach.”
Sammy breathed deep and raised one fist with her other arm bent at her side.
She expected Thanysa to hold back and defend as she had with Ceil, but this time Thanysa started on offense.
Eydis’s instructions returned to Sammy one by one as she dodged and feinted for several minutes.
Sammy saw an opening, and with a swift strike to Thanysa’s side, Thanysa fell to one knee.
In this position, there was a takedown Sammy learned shortly before Eydis’s disappearance.
She grabbed Thanysa’s wrist and swept her foot at her anchor leg.
With a quick twist of Thanysa’s arm, Sammy was on her back looking up at the ceiling.
She had no idea what happened.
“You did well to find the opening I gave you, but the takedown just now was sloppy.
At least I knew what you were trying to do.
I know precisely where the First Princess left off on your training, and it appears she did skip most the offensive skills, or you would have caught the earlier openings and how to utilize them.
She followed the same training regimen my mother taught the palace guards.
Perhaps my mother was the First Princess’s instructor as well.”
Thanysa extended her hand to Sammy.
“Can you use any weaponry?”
Sammy shook her head.
“Combat magic?”
Again Sammy shook her head but then stopped.
“I do have one thing I can do, but it’s not really an attack.”
“Show me.”
Thanysa removed a small bluish-silver ring from her pocket and slipped it over her glove.
She then stood a few yards away from Sammy.
“You want me to attack you?”
“This ring is resfahil.
It will dispel whatever you attack me with.”
Sammy took a deep breath.
When she attacked Ceil out of anger, it only cracked her lip, so she doubted that it would hurt Thanysa.
A ball of water formed in Sammy’s hand, and she threw it at Thanysa.
The ball vaporized into mist when it impacted her glove instead of bursting.
Thanysa’s eyes narrowed.
She removed the ring and grabbed her staff.
“Again.”
Sammy created another ball of water and threw it.
Thanysa moved the top of the staff into the ball’s path, and the moment it burst against the staff, the staff swung back and nearly hit Thanysa in the face.
It was far more forceful than Thanysa expected, wrenching her wrist, but when she inspected the staff, there was no damage.
“I see.”
She returned the staff and folded her arms.
“I am not a magic instructor, especially not for the water element, so I cannot help you turn that non-lethal attack into something lethal.
As it is, it is well suited for defense.
For weapons, I will focus on teaching you the spear.
As my father explained it, spears can be used with minimal training and are safer with their longer reach.
I can also fill in the holes in your hand-to-hand instruction.”
Thanysa looked over at Justin who would be next for assessment.
Not only was there a language barrier, but he also still looked far too weak to even perform an assessment.
Her disparaging expression was disconcerting.
What could Justin do when he wasn’t even able to walk up steps or hold a slightly longer spear?
“It’s going to be the usual again, isn’t it,” Justin sighed with a self-depreciating grin.
Sammy felt terrible.

Justin always had to sit out of Eydis’s instructions, both with normal magic lessons and once she began the combat magic classes, left to meditate with the hope that he would somehow recognize and control his ven.
Sammy’s heart raced as she thought of something to say.
“Justin can use time magic,” she announced in a hurry.
Ceil shook her head exasperated, and Thanysa looked wide eyed at the atrophied man.
“Is this true?” Thanysa asked.
“Yes, but he can’t do anything but--” Sammy almost recited her usual belittling remark on Justin’s ability, and it cut at her heart with every word she spoke.
Old habits…, Sammy thought to herself.
Even after everything Justin had done and the love and care he had shown her, she still defaulted to insulting him as if nothing had changed from the weeks after she broke up with him.
A sinking feeling hung on her heart and threatened to choke out tears of self-reproach.
Justin was not useless.
Far from it.
“Justin saved my life multiple times using it.
His reaction time is incredible.
He probably can’t hold a weapon well enough to use it for now.
Maybe by the time the battle starts he could.
But…”
“May I ask what he can do with his magic?”
Sammy stood next to Justin.
“Do you have anything you can throw?”
Thanysa walked over to the bag and removed what looked like a few bean bags.
“Throw one of them as hard as you can at me.
Lemi can heal me if it hits.”
“Shouldn’t you tell Sir Justin?”
“No need.
Watch.”
Thanysa stood only about four yards away.
At this distance, Sammy knew that avoiding the small bean bag would be impossible for her.
Sammy trusted in Justin to protect her, and she knew that no one but Justin would be able to do it.
Without warning, Thanysa threw the bag with all her strength.
Sammy didn’t even have time to think before something appeared in front of her face.
She winced back, and then Justin stumbled into her.
She barely managed to catch him before he fell.
In his hand was the bean bag that nearly hit her face.
“I thought you were up to something when you stood next to me.”
Justin stabled himself on his knees and then stood with Sammy’s aid.
“A little warning would have been nice.”
“That would have ruined the demonstration.”
Sammy held Justin close at her side and smiled at Thanysa with confidence.
Thanysa’s mouth hung partially agape.
“I felt his magic, but there was no channeling time.
Is that even possible?”
“He’s awesome, right?!”
In direct contrast to the guilt Sammy felt for almost letting slip her earlier depreciating comment, her heart swelled with joy from being able to brag about how amazing Justin truly was.
Sammy looked over to Ceil.
“If there is a job I think he would be perfect for, it would be protecting Ceil.”
Ceil opened her mouth to speak in protest but fell silent in consternation.
“I certainly see the merit in your suggestion,” Thanysa answered readily.
“I will bring it personally to the Thorn General.”
Sammy hugged Justin with a wide smile.
“You aren’t useless at all.”

* * *
The combat lessons continued for a few hours every day at the hall.
Chloe joined beginning with the third lesson once the orphanage was established.
Ceil vouched for Chloe’s magic ability so she would not need to demonstrate its destructive power inside the pristine hall.
Chloe showed greater aptitude for hand-to-hand combat than even Ceil, and Sammy knew that once her flames were added, she would become even more lethal.
Thanysa even gave Chloe the rank of yeth, the second rank of the nameless martial art, after a brutal match that appeared as if Thanysa was trying to kill her.
Day by day, Sammy improved in the spear, Ceil with her staff, and Chloe with unarmed combat.
As Justin’s strength improved, he also picked up the spear, but his stamina never held for the full lesson.
Because of Justin’s new role as Ceil’s protector, Thanysa also trained him as a shield bearer using a long, tapered shield.
Most of his time was spent in strength training so that he could move it quickly.
Many of the estates were converted to farmland, and the Melians began growing their crops in preparation for the siege.
In time, word came that the last town had fallen quickly due to the level of evacuation.
Only one small village stood between the army of Tolmyur and Revlan, and that village had already been evacuated.
Tension rose in Revlan on a scale incomparable to their frantic preparations.
The enemy would be at their gates in a few short days.

Chapter 15
“The Kissiae”
“We have a thousand of our sisters ready to support you and our young empress.” An elderly yet still youthful-appearing dryad said with a bow.
A single large leaf grew from her forehead.
It extended over her head and down her back with slender yet full fronds sprouting along the spine to give the appearance of thick and verdant hair.
She was a Foinikade, a palm dryad.
The Hamadryad thanked the matriarch, and the Foinikade left the hollow.
She furrowed her brow in worry.
The Itians were proficient in combat, but the Melians, who made up the bulk of her army, were pacifists by nature.

Like the Melians, the Foinikades were also a pacifist tribe, which explained why they could only field so few and were the smallest reinforcements of the three tribes who had shown so far, even less than the Itians, who left many to delay the approach of the Tolmyur army, and the Fendamai, who were even further from Melia than the Itians.
The Hamadryad’s worry came from the lack of balance in her current forces.
The Melians could use bows, but due to their pacifist nature, only the most eager or eccentric of them practiced the art.

She could use their sheer numbers to overwhelm the army with arrows, but such a tactic could be fatal to her other forces who needed close proximity to deal damage, especially considering the life magic with which the Melians enhanced each arrow.
On top of this, Melian arrows were wood-tipped, so any metal armor and some hardened leather could prevent the arrow from penetrating to the flesh were their magic could take effect.

The Itians were more proficient with combat and well-practiced with their dances, but to make the most use of their abilities, they could not be in close proximity with any ally that could be hit by their incredibly long hair.
This was in direct conflict to the hot-headed Fendamai who used large numbers to overwhelm their opponents.
They lacked any martial skills, but they raised some of the best shamans in all of Dhuillir, kissiae aside, and instead use their numbers to get close enough to make use of their magic.

Luckily, being from Kedra, her incomplete pilgrimage took her through the three warrior tribes of Dhuillir, so they were under her influence; however, being at the beginning of her pilgrimage, they were the furthest from Melia and in the mountainous regions of eastern Dhuillir which was slow to travel, even for a dryad.
She was unsure if they would make it in time.
Tolmyur’s armies had entered Melia traveling at a quickened pace, so she needed to intercept them within the next day or two.
“What is on your mind,” Jenae asked standing in attention beside the entrance of the hollow.
“Can we even do this,” the hamadryad asked, not to Jenae, herself, or anyone in particular.
She realized this was the first time in many years that she had outwardly shown any sign of weakness.
“If you doubt yourself, your unease will spread to us all from our connection to you.
You mustn’t think of this battle as one which we could win or lose.
We are prepared to lay down our lives if only to provide Lady Ceil a moment of time and to weaken the army that would surely crush the remaining resistance in Vallen.”
“In a battle without victory as an option, we most certainly cannot lose,” spoke a male voice from the entrance of the hollow.
Debin arrived with his son, Benab, climbing over the roots behind him.
“Every minute we stall them and every life we take is a triumph.
You have no need to worry about victory or loss.”
The hamadryad smiled, not expecting to be comforted by one who was not a dryad.
“Debin, how progresses the training?”
“My time with the palace guard was short, so I could only teach what I know from hunting, but I must express my surprise in Melian archery.
They have such keen eyesight that they could spot a nut in the elbow of a tree at a hundred yards further than both my son and I and hit it with half as many attempts.
I can see now the wisdom of the past emperors and empresses who ordered the Melians to practice the bow.
If only they had more work ethic.
They could easily become the most lethal snipers on the continent.
Regrettably, we do not have a full season or two to train them.”
“How many would you say are proficient?”
“Only a couple hundred.
The rest can still use their bows, but I advised against applying their life magic to their arrows.
Their fellow dryads will not slow from being struck by a simple arrow, but the Tolmyur soldiers will.”
“Thank you for helping us in this battle.
I know that you wanted to avoid fighting if you could.”
Debin shook his head.
“I felt terrible leaving Lady Ceil to go to war on her own.
We fled south from Vallen to avoid it, and now war has risen from the south to meet us again.
Involvement was unavoidable it seems.
Fate can be cruel.”
“What of your wife?”
“She supports our involvement and will be in the care of the nymph couple in our absence.”
“The message,” Benab reminded his father.
“Of course.
The reason we came here was not to discuss the Melian’s archery training.
A messenger arrived where we were practicing and stated that a large group of dryads is approaching from the east.”
The Hamadryad searched her influence eastward out of fear that they were not her own.
What returned was the radiating warmth of support and eagerness that showed no fear of the coming battle.
It felt nostalgic.
“You could have informed me that you were close, Jekeet.
I was about to send our forces into position without you.”
“We wanted to make a dramatic entrance, but it seems a messenger slipped away from us.”
“This is no time for games.”
“What is war but a game with survival as the prize?”
“Enduring your Kedran war games is bad enough.
I would hope that you are more professional on a true battlefield.
Hamadryad, I am Takitan.
We Pefkos and the Elatos are also here, numbering one hundred and thirty thousand, including your sister Kedros.”
The hamadryad was stunned silent.
She never expected such a showing.
Being a Kedros, she expected a large number from Kedra, but she never expected all three war tribes to send their full armies.
Including the Melians, they now far outnumbered the estimated Tolmyur forces.
“I am Namasee, the War Chieftain of the Elatos.
We were excited when we learned that our Grandmatriarch was from a warrior tribe.

Our soldiers agreed unanimously to aid in the battle to see what terror could be wrought upon Tolmyur with a Kedros hamadryad in command, the first war Hamadryad since the unification of Dhuillir under the Amelian banner, but Jekeet informed us that you have no military or tactical education.
Is this true?”
“It is.
Having mothered many children, my body aged quickly and so I was exempt from combat practice and training.”
“Then on behalf of the Elatos I must express my concern in your leadership.
As the senior War Chieftain, I request all command be given to me.
That is the requirement for our aid.”
Neither Jakeet nor Takitan spoke up after Namasee’s announcement.
They had agreed upon the arrangement beforehand.
The Hamadryad did not have so much pride that she would rather risk making foolish decisions on the battlefield than give up her command.
“I assume these conditions are agreeable?”
“They are better than I could have wished for.
Your support could mean the difference between stalling the Tolmyur army and defeating it.
Time is short.
I will explain the tribes we have and their numbers and can communicate your orders to our forces.
If possible, we must strike within two days.”

* * *
The longer Bregon’s army traveled through Melia without encountering resistance, the more suspicious he became.
The three villages that his army passed were emptied.

Given that there were never any structures and that dryads never worked the land, he only knew they were villages because the pairs of dryads he sent out as scouts to look out for any signs of hostility had informed him as such.
He would simply laugh off his caution if nothing happened, and that was preferable compared to delays and further losses, but he knew the Melians were plotting something.

The Symidian who always acted as the mouthpiece for the dryads when speaking to Bregon or relaying other messages, who he could now recognize after seeing her so often, suggested that the Melians fled.
According to her, they were a pacifist tribe.
Bregon did not trust this explanation.
After all, the Hamadryad was in Melia, and they would not leave her unguarded.
“Halt the march!”
The silencing of boots cascaded down the long train of soldiers and carts.
The dryads shielding his army on all sides also stopped, but he could barely hear their footsteps despite their numbers and especially over the thundering of his own troops.
“Thees!”
The Symidian from the forward dryad barrier weaved her way through the throng to approach Bregon.
“What do you need, General Bregon?”
The woman saluted in the manner she had seen his soldiers.
It was a bit sloppy, but Bregon recognized that she was making an attempt to be formal given her unofficial position as spokesperson.
“A handful of scouts are too small a net.
I want the dryad barriers to spread out further.
Keep the highest density near my soldiers, but send out half… no, a quarter of the dryads in all directions.
Make certain that they stay within sight of no less than ten other dryads at all times, and disperse as far as that permits.
Something is not right in Melia, and I want to know about it long before it happens.
I want any threat, no matter how small, signaled back to me through the net.”
“I will relay your orders immediately.”
Thees ran back to her fellow dryads.
After a few minutes of explanation, multiple dryads hurried to spread the message.
Dryad networks were intriguing, and Bregon watched with an intellectual eye the messengers he could see from the road.
They spread like roots or perhaps the branches of a tree.
One dryad would relay her message to another group and then return.
The new group would then send out any number of dryads to propagate the information in the same manner.
Instead of the Tolmyur method of sending a single messenger to relay the orders to all relevant parties, dryad messages spread at a staggering pace.

The more the message spread, the faster and wider it spread until after only a brief span of time all the dryads were informed, and those on the outer perimeter of the protective dryad barrier began dispersing as per his instruction.

Bregon could find issue with displacing large numbers of his soldiers when using this method of information transfer, and there was a risk of the message changing as it alternated messengers, but perhaps it could be used within the Tolmyur army after a few modifications.
Using simple messages like military hand signals might prevent alterations in the message as it spread.
Bregon expected his larger net to extend an extra mile on all sides.

There were risks to thinning the defense if the Melians came after him in force using a single spear formation to penetrate through to reach the road, but the dryads did not appear to use traditional military formations, especially after witnessing the bizarre machinations of the Itians, and with the wide net, he hoped he would have enough forewarning to gather the dryads at the tip of the spear to blunt its edge should such a tactic be used.
Any other formation would force his dryads back to their position as a barrier for his men on the road.
His only worry was another unforeseeable tactic like that employed by the Itians.
He could not rule out the possibility that they could somehow still reach the road.
The remainder of the afternoon and evening passed without event, and Bregon spent a restless night thinking about the following day.
He pushed his army to keep a double pace, taking advantage of the dryad’s tireless stamina to pull the carts.
He would be rid of Melia and enter Vallen in two days.
The Mailan Hills of northern Melia were visible in the distance when setting up camp.
If something was to happen, it would be then when his army reached the hills or after they were deep within.
The road followed the path of easiest travel, forcing it to meander through the ravines and valleys around the numerous tors and other rocky outcroppings.
Even his net would be inhibited by such terrain.
He ordered his men to march with weapons drawn at normal pace to give time for any message of attack to reach him.
Fire mages readied hailfire, each with three shieldmen for protection.
His wind mages were spread evenly along the road to deflect incoming arrows.
He took every precaution, but nothing happened that day.

If his army reached Vallen safely, he would laugh off his caution, but until then, his alert was as high as when he could hear the siren songs before the battle that destroyed his home village of Jurmorr during the Coastal Wars.
“I want dryads scouting the tops of every hill from here till the flatlands of Vallen.
Spread the net further, half of the dryads keeping within sight of no less than five others.
We reach Vallen by sunset.
The Melians will attack before then.”
“They may not.
They are pacifists,” Thees replied.
“They will,” Bregon answered with a calm bluntness that forced the Symidian’s silence.
She saluted and left to relay the message.
Bregon’s orders spread through the network, but it collided half-way with another message that overwhelmed his.
“Arrows from the south.
Melian archers,” one of his men called from further down the train.
The first sign of aggression, and from the rear.
Did he pass their offense due to his increased pace?
They may have thought he would continue at the rate he passed through Itia.
Bregon was not alarmed.
On the contrary, he was overcome with relief as all his anxiety over the threat of attack left him all at once.
His wide net trailing his army would prevent the initial arrows from reaching his soldiers.
There would be no losses among his men, but surely this would not be their only attempt.
“Dryads along the borders, keep position.
Those near the end, gather at the tail to prevent the Melian archers from approaching.
Wind mages ready updrafts to deflect arrows from the road.
We continue the march!”
There was no word on numbers, only that there were arrows.
He expected more from another direction.
“From the east,” a dryad called out.
“Numerous Fendamai.
The fringes are being overwhelmed.”
“Draw back to the defensive perimeter and hold them back in force.
No matter their numbers, we should have more.”
Bregon finally understood the reason for stalling.
The hamadryad was gathering forces.
The Melians attacking the south were attempting to pull away his forces and enable the Fendamai access to his soldiers.
He looked up through the dense trees to the rocky hills bordering the road on the east.
His dryads were pulling back to the downward slopes.
Once he saw the first red-leafed Fendamai stand atop a tor, he realized the error in his orders.
“Dryads!
Take the hilltops!
Do not abandon them!”
While the Fendamai appeared unarmed, a second form of dryad appeared behind them, Melians.
The Fendamai jumped down the slope, and immediately the trees twisted and knotted together.
New and thick brush grew so rapidly that it immediately died from lack of nutrients as did the ground around it.

A thick wall of foliage that prevented his dryads from retaking the nearby tor formed, and due to the loss of life in the plants and soil, his dryads could not make use of their own life magic to remove it.
“Fire mages!
Hailfire at will!
Wind mages!
Updra--” Bregon quickly turned his head as the first arrow bounced off the side of his barbute.
Had he been a moment later in noticing, it would have perfectly entered the slit in the front.
It was an incredibly lucky arrow for the distance from the top of the hill, or so he thought before a second, third, and fourth arrow hit his barbute, pauldron, and chestplate.
“Updraft!
Updraft!” Bregon hollered while he raised his shield with haste.
The two wind mages near him billowed wind upward, sending approaching arrows over their mark to land on the far side of the road, but the protection was imperfect.
Arrows that would hit the east side would not catch the draft, so those on the vulnerable side, including the wind mages creating the draft, could be hit.
“Shields to the east!”
Fire mages launched their volleys of hailfire, but the tors atop the hills held little vegetation that could catch and provided ample cover for the archers.
Occasionally, an arrow would slip through the draft.
When Bregon saw the first soldier take an arrow in the hand, he realized the lethality of these wood-tipped projectiles.
The man’s hand ruptured like a giant festering blister, removing it at the wrist.
A second arrow hit a soldier in the neck, and gore shot up through his helmet.
None of the dryads on either side of the road were being harmed.
Each and every arrow was aimed perfectly for the road.
“Take back the hill!”
Bregon chanced a glance at the hill from under his shield and found it quickly being covered by a smokescreen.
The dead tree wall caught from the hailfire and was burning rapidly.
His dryads could no longer take the hill, but as the black smoke grew, his soldiers also received cover from the keen eyes of the archers.
Arrows still fell, but the number aimed directly at him lessened.
“Move under the smoke cover!
Fire mages, keep up hailfire!”

If his soldiers could follow the road around the next bend, the hill he lost in his folly would no longer be a threat, but there was still about four miles worth of his soldiers that needed to pass that bend.
“Triple march!
Dryads, take the hills down the road and hold them!”
The dryads at the forward barrier rushed ahead.
There were few of them compared to the number that traveled beside the road.
With the offense on the east side, he could spare some of the west.
He made the order and watched the left flank thin as more dryads rushed ahead.
He still had his net cast to the west, and no warnings had come.
No sooner had Bregon reached the bend than a message from the forward dryads returned warning of more Fendamai to the east swarming to take the hilltops on the other side of the bend.
If he lost those hills, his army would be under fire the entire road.
“West barrier, half of who remain rush ahead and assist!
We must keep the hills!”
The scene atop the rocky hills that met Bregon around the bend was unlike any form of civilized warfare.
A swarm-like flood of red leaves fought like animals grasping at the bodies and wooden weapons of his dryads.
Any one of his dryads who was grappled by a Fendamai fell dead while two or three of his dryads were needed to overpower a single enemy.
Those approaching the slaughter were being felled by the inhuman precision of arrows cast from an even further location, the bodies of his dryads bursting with each hit.
Even without trees and brush to serve as a wall, the Fendamai alone were powerful enough a force at close combat to prevent anyone from reaching the archers.
The only saving grace was that the dryads were taking the brunt of those impossibly lethal arrows instead of his men.
Bregon looked back over his soldiers circling the bend and saw that several of them had been picked off by the arrows of the hill he lost.
His mistake may cost him hundreds of his men by the time the four-mile train finished rounding the bend.
“General Bregon!” Thees approached from ahead of his army with a terrified expression.
“Emergency!
Pefkos from the west!”
This was the first time any of the warnings had come as an emergency.
The Melian archers with their incredible precision were not labeled as an emergency by his dryads.
The Fendamai who appeared to overpower any of his dryads with life magic were not such a threat.
Who then were the Pefkos?
“What emergency?
What are the Pefkos?
Speak!”
“One of the three warrior tribes,” Thees answered promptly.
“Do you know of their skills or tactics?”
“They are the only tribe that uses bladed weaponry provided by the empire.
They are physically weaker than most other dryads but are incredibly flexible and agile and train in combat as a profession.
Of all the dryads in Dhuillir, they are the most proficient in weapons combat.”
“Bladed weaponry, as in swords?” Thees nodded.
“Yes, sir.”
“If you can create shields from the trees, do so quickly.
Front line shields followed by three rows of spears, each subsequent row of spears longer than the one before.
Use your life magic through your spear’s reach to stop them from breaking through.
If they are weak, then your life magic should be effective.”
Thees immediately ran ahead down the road, now facing west, to relay Bregon’s formation orders.
A benefit of the dryads was their ability to fashion new weaponry at whim from nearby trees.
Such a rapid change in tactics would be impossible for his men.

Spears were often superior to swords in open conflict, so he held confidence in the order, but unlike the ongoing struggle between his dryads and the Fendamai, he could not see the advance of the Pefkos or the progress of his dryads’ defense against them over the shallow hill.
The Pefkos attacked the moment he sent reinforcements from the west flank to support the struggle atop the hills against the Fendamai.
This was precisely planned, drawing his forces to the east to thin his defense on the west.
The hamadryad waited until his most vulnerable moment to send their trump card, the warrior tribe.
The hills and snaking road were disadvantageous to his troops.
If they kept the triple pace, they would reach the flatlands of Vallen by midafternoon so long as his ever-thinning dryad barrier held.
Once there, he would be able to make full use of his men and formations.
He was confident that there in the open he could hold out against any number of dryads, especially with fire magic at his disposal.
He only needed to avoid direct confrontation on the road that would slow his advance.
The road curved once more and returned facing north.
Bregon glanced back at the visible two miles of his train and noticed in the distance that the red-leafed Fendamai topped the hill.
His dryads lost, but unlike the first hill, there were no archers raining arrows down on his men.
After eliminating a countless number of his dryads, they stood like sentinels and watched him flee.
What was their purpose in taking the hill if they were not going to use it like the first?
Unless, it was to draw away and thin his dryads.
That thought was a revelation.
If they wanted to pick off his army on the road, they could have employed far more archers, including the Fendamai who were content solely occupying his dryads.
The Pefkos were a cause for fear in his dryads, and yet they had not overpowered his west flank and come to the road to attack.
If his suspicions were correct, they were culling his west flank.
When word came of a fourth type of dryad, the Foinikades, joining in the attack on the south and drawing even more of his dryad barrier into conflict, Bregon knew he fell into a trap.
His soldiers were never their target.
His dryads were.
Each attack was designed to draw them away, either on their own or by his order, and whittle them down while simultaneously pushing his soldiers into a quicker march.
But to what end?
Where would the trap spring?
Only a few thousand dryads now led his march and fewer there were on the flanks.
There was no more net due to the bend.
His warning system was gone.
“Fire mages, set the forest ablaze as we pass!
We are nearing Vallen!
We must keep the enemy from the road!”
Hailfire rained on the forest, but was slow to catch, sending up no more than a large smoke screen until the length of his train passed.
Only then did flames stretch to the canopies.
He could not waste too much of his fire mage’s ven in the event that a controlled dryad attack on the road did happen, but hailfire used very little ven.
Once the fires began to burn to cover their trail, they would fuel themselves.
He was close.
Down the road in the distance, the hills stopped growing.
In the coming hour, he would reach Vallen and the open fields.
He counted the remaining hills as he passed while word arrived of more of his dryad barrier at the rear being eliminated.
If he did not hurry, the enemy would reach his soldiers before they reached less vulnerable terrain.
One more hill and one more bend.
“General Bregon, we must stop!” Thees ran directly to Bregon, but he ignored her.
He could not halt the march.
She continued pleading to him.
“Our forward scouts have not returned to say the way is clear.
I sent out more, but they have not returned either.”
The Nuanae Range of the southern wilderlands was now visible past the ravine far on the horizon.
“We must clear the hills.
We will confront whatever awaits us on the fields of Vallen.”
All at once the forested ravine cleared into an open field.
A forest bordered it on the far side, and the road bent around it to the east, but from here, he would travel west to catch up with the Vallen conquest.
No enemies were visible.
He moved his soldiers onto the open field with his dryad barrier surrounding them.
Only once out in the open did he notice just how few of his dryads remained.
By sight, they numbered only a quarter of his army.
So many had been lost.
“Sir, they are pushing harder from the rear!
The dryads cannot hold them!”
One of Bregon’s own soldiers ran to him with ill news of the dryad resistance’s desperate attempts to catch up and prevent as many of his soldiers as possible from reaching open terrain.
“Form ranks facing the ravine!
Shields and spears in front.
Fire mages at the rear to ready hailfire.
Dryads cover the flanks and move the carts to the back.
Those holding the rear, slow the enemy as much as possible!
We burn them to the ground here!”
The ranks formed quickly as his soldiers continued pouring out of the valley.
Once the final group of soldiers and handcarts entered the field followed by a couple thousand dryads, Bregon swelled with confidence.
Now he could fight them as equals.
The beating of hollow wood thundered over the flatlands.
Bregon turned behind him to see tens of thousands of needle-haired dryads walking in ranks from the forest on the far side of the field.
They carried shields as tall as they with thick and stone-tipped spears in hand.
From where the road curved east, a second army of familiar, long-haired dryads approached dragging trees behind them, Itians.
From the forest to the west approached a third and final army of dryads with dark green fans of scale-like needle hair.

Once the trickle of his own dryads finished fleeing out of the ravine, far fewer than Bregon had hoped, a slow procession of singed and blackened dryads with longer needle-like hair exited the valley and formed their own ranks with tarnished swords in hand.
“Bregon,” Thees spoke in fear, disregarding the formality of titles.
“The Pefkos, Elatos, and Kedros are the strongest warrior tribes of Dhuillir.”
“Perimeter formation!” Bregon called.
His army reacted immediately.
The flanks bent around in a circle with shields and spears on the outside.
Swords stood behind to eliminate those who broke through in the tight confines of close combat.
Mages and rangers held their positions in the center.
The earth mages quickly erected walls ten yards outside the perimeter with choke point openings for the mages and rangers to focus.
He ordered the dryads to hold the walls and prevent entry if possible, but their numbers were far too few.
They would be quickly overwhelmed, and every dryad positioned there knew it.
“Tolmyur General,” called a voice from the forest side of the field.
An elderly woman stood alone, one of the Elatos.
“You may be a commander of humans, but you know nothing of the dryads.
You treat your conscripts as expendable foot soldiers instead of utilizing the individual strengths unique to each tribe.
Now you are on your own.
Show me now how humans do battle!”
Once again the hollow wood drums sounded over the field.
Silent steps charged, impossible to know their number.
“Hailfire in all directions!” Bregon called.
Fire rained out from the center of the defensive circle.
In return, a rain of arrows fell on his mages from the hills.
Bregon looked from beneath his shield to see the hilled forests moving with so many dryads that they nearly outnumbered the armies present on the field.
Every Melian, Fendamai, and Foinikade had a bow almost as long as they were tall.
With such a high volume of archers, not even his wind mages could stop the arrows.
“Hailfire to the hills!
Burn the archers!”
His army was a still target, and even with the widespread destruction that hailfire could cause dryads, he knew the number of fire mages under his command could not stop such numbers quickly.
The moment the first cudgel-bearing Kedros broke through the earthen wall, Bregon knew this was a losing battle.

* * *
“Utilizing the Fendamai and Melians to eliminate most of his dryads worked brilliantly,” Namasee informed the hamadryad.
“Without their numbers, this battle will be easy.
In truth, I am a tad disappointed.”
“Will you be victorious?”
“Eventually, but his perimeter is strong, and his fire mages are continuing to pose a problem.
Any single fire mage counts for a thousand of us.”
The hamadryad continued watching the battle through the senses of the numerous matriarchs included in the armies.
She could not see the events unfold, but through thought and emotion, she knew the progress.
At the beginning of the attack, there was close to a hundred thousand on Tolmyur’s side and twice that on hers.
Victory was assured.
“Urgent message!”
Seiva stumbled over the roots as she entered the hollow.
“The kissiae are nearing the village and demand audience.”
“The kissiae?
How many?”
“All of them.”
Seiva looked up at the hamadryad unable to hide the disbelief in her own words.
“What purpose would draw all kissiae out of Elos?
Send them here.”
The arrival of the Kissiae could either be the miracle they needed to end the war against Tolmyur, or it could be a terrible omen.
A procession of four hundred Eleionomai entered the village.
About forty kissiae were interspersed among them riding on their backs and shoulders.
A single kissiae unaided by one of the naiads crawled over the roots and entered the hollow.
By appearance and an unmistakable aura of superiority emanating from her, the hamadryad knew this was the kissiae matriarch and a dryad ages older than her.
“I am most humbled that you would see fit to seek audience with me, matriarch of the kissiae, but I must express my worry over what tidings caused you to depart from the safety of Elos.”
The hamadryad nodded her head, the sole motion of humility she could express with her body fused to the great cedar.
“That cause could see the end of the Amelian Empire and all those in it,” the Kissiae warned.
“I speak of the Tolmyur Commanding General Jethro and the companions of young Empress Ceil.”
The Kissiae matriarch placed her hand on the base of the hamadryad’s leg.
The hamadryad immediately felt a drain on her mind.
“You have gathered a large army to oppose Tolmyur in support of the empress and her companions.” The kissiae’s eyes narrowed.
“You are aware that her companions are not of this world.”
The hamadryad knew she could hide nothing from a kissiae matriarch, so she answered in the affirmative.
“They have the support of the Sprite Arkhon.”
“Did you not know that interference between worlds is banned by the Gods?
You should have expended every effort to eliminate those trespassers the moment they entered this village.”
“The Sprite Arkhon is elder to us all.
I am obligated to obey,” the hamadryad replied.
“The Sprite Arkhon was there at the fall of the ancient civilization at the hands of the Gods.
That same threat now hangs over us all once again.
I do not know what the Arkhon is scheming, but we must put an end to it before we all suffer.
I understand that betraying the trust the empress has in you is difficult, but it must be done.

In return for your cooperation in eliminating the empress and her companions, the kissiae are prepared to transplant you in the hamadryads’ grove and spread your influence throughout all of Dhuillir to unify us against this threat.”
“Is transplanting a hamadryad possible?”
“It is trivial for us.”
The promise of becoming a legitimate hamadryad was indeed tempting, but the motives of the Sprite Arkhon were a worry that the Hamadryad could not ignore.
The sprites were tasked with the maintenance of this world and had been since the beginning of time.
The Arkhon had given warnings in the past to protect the peoples of the Amelian Empire.
She doubted he would purposely take action that would lead to its destruction.
This should be known to the kissiae as well.
“While I am most grateful for your generous offer, I must decline.
I trust the Sprite Arkhon.”
“Then my hand is forced.”
The kissiae matriarch sprung up and clung to the hamadryad.
Janae and Seiva immediately rushed to the hamadryad’s aid but were beheaded by the Eleionomai guard before they could reach her.
The kissiae placed her hand on the hamadryad’s forehead.

Before the kissiae could take any action, the hamadryad broke her connection with the ongoing battle to focus all her life magic on offence against the kissiae, but her resistance was like a single tree attempting to hold back a landslide.
Her mind was plucked from its roots and enveloped in immense anguish.

* * *
Bregon swung his heavy, broad-leafed spear to crush through an Elatos shield and then thrust it through her neck, nearly severing her head.
He changed quickly to his next target, a Pefkos who brandished her sword against a nearby fire mage.
He impaled her exposed back and flung her over the melee into the Kedros pouring through the gap in the wall.
His dryads had only held for a moment.
His shield perimeter was broken in two locations allowing access to his few vital fire mages within.
The rain of arrows continued all the while with the wind mages making every effort to direct them into the oncoming dryads.
Unlike the first arrows that were lethal on contact, these were unenhanced.
The dryads who were hit ignored them and continued their assault.
He and his fellow giants in their full plate were the only soldiers who could ignore the arrows and come to the aid of the more overwhelmed parties.
The dwarves in their half plate kept up the magic offense being too immobile to change location quickly through the melee.

Over half his minums were injured by the arrows that made it through their shield cover, and his humans holding the perimeter were falling quickly to the three warrior tribes who were equal to them in combat but far superior in both stamina and vitality, being able to ignore blows that would be lethal to his men.
There was one more set of dryads who were not present in the melee, the Itians.
Bregon cast his gaze toward the eastward road and saw that the trees they dragged had been transplanted in a line.
They bent back unnaturally, and with a snap, dozens of Itians flew over the wall and past the perimeter into the mages in the center.
This was a repeat of Itia, and now Bregon knew the absurd methods the Itians employed.
The suicidal Itians landed on the minums and dwarves, knocking back the shields and making them vulnerable to the rain of arrows.
Those Itians still able to move began to claw their way to skin and flesh or made use of their long whip-like hair to strike with their caustic life magic.
Bregon switched from eliminating the dryads who broke through the perimeter to protecting his mages from the Itians.
The dryad commander criticized that he did not utilize the strengths of his conscripted dryads to his advantage.
Seeing the methods of the Itians, he wondered what he could have done or what unique tactics his dryads could make use of, but now it was too late.
His only thought was how long he could hold.
If he could protect his fire mages long enough, the enemy dryads would continue taking incurable damage.
That was his only hope to survive.
Passing through Fiorrae may have been the better option.
All at once the rain of arrows ceased.
No more Itians fell on his soldiers.
The enemy dryads cried out and writhed on the ground, unable to attack.
They held their heads, clawing at their scalps in anguish.
“Quickly!
Behead them all!”
Every soldier even if injured did not miss this miraculous opportunity.
Even the mages drew their swords and hurried through the chaos to sever the necks of the downed dryads.
Within minutes, all enemy dryads inside the walls were disposed.
His earth mages lowered the walls, and the army spread out.
Tens of thousands of dryads were eliminated in an instant until the fields were clear.
Not wanting to waste the opportunity, Bregon turned his army towards the hills.
His worn and injured soldiers pressed forward and climbed the smoldering slopes, disposing of the numerous archers they passed.
The army that outnumbered his by double or more was eliminated in an hour’s time.
“What happened?” Bregon looked back at his soldiers gathered in the field.
Those of his dryads who had avoided the slaughter of the war tribes, numbering no more than a few thousand, were unaffected by this strange disease that had infested the opposition so suddenly.
“General Bregon!
Come quick!”
One of the dryads approached and called him to an enemy dryad who had been cut down but was still alive.
She spoke through the gargles of the life sap filling her mouth.
“The kissiae… request Bregon’s… in… central… village.”
“Here as well!”
One of his soldiers called him over to another living dryad.
“The Ki… Bregon’s presence… central… Melian…”
Bregon called over the nearest dryad.
“Where is the central Melian village?”
“Would it not be in central Melia?”
“Is there any dryad who can act as a guide?!”
The few dryads who heard stared at him, but none spoke up.
Melia was far too large to search for a single village.
“Guide…” The injured dryad pointed to the road entering the valley between the hills.
There alone stood a Melian with her head cocked to the side walking with an unnatural gait.
Bregon called for some giants and uninjured minum fire mages to accompany him.
“Dryads, heal my men to the best of your abilities and then tend to your own injuries.”
“Sir, what of the fallen dryads?
Do we use them for food?” one of his lieutenants asked.
Bregon looked over the devastation, and his eyes caught sight of one dryad.
He walked over to her and saw the familiar face of a Symidian with her eyes open, frozen in a death stare.
“Separate the enemy from those who sided with us.
The enemy will become food stores for the battles ahead.
As for the conscripted dryads, let their kin here decide how best you should treat their dead.
We would have never survived if not for their sacrifice.
My summon to the central village may take a few days.
Make camp and prepare funeral pyres for our fallen.
Rest until I return but keep vigilance in case more dryads arrive.”
He led his small band of soldiers to the awaiting Melian.
She did not attack or flee, only repeating the words “guide” and “follow.”
The moment he ordered her to move, she turned her back to him and walked onward through the smoking road.

* * *
Reaching the central Melian village took four days at the slow pace the guide walked.
Unlike the other dryad villages devoid of structures, numerous huts surrounded a towering cedar in the center.
Most the residents of the village were gone save a few Melians who avoided Bregon and his men.
Apparently the disease affecting the Melians had passed, being replaced by fear of him and those now occupying the village.
The majority of the populous were humanoids with white silken gowns and turquoise hair.
At their hips, radiant silver blades were sheathed.
Bregon immediately recognized the resfahil blade and naiad bearers.
He was on alert, but none of them drew their swords on his approach.
The moment one of the naiads met him, his Melian guide fell to the earth, dead.
“I am General Bregon of Tolmyur.
The kissiae have called me here,” Bregon announced.
The naiad bowed.
“This way.
Follow me,” she spoke in an archaic human tongue.
She led him through the village to the cedar growing out of a stout tree in the center.
The closer he neared the cedar the clearer he could see that it was sickly.
The boughs of fan-like needles wilted, and many broke from their branches as he watched.
He stepped up over the large roots exiting the hollow and was met by the hamadryad, or what remained of her.
Her body was shriveled and lifeless, her hollow eyes staring blankly at his feet.
Clinging to her upstretched arms was a much smaller dryad with long ivy hair that hung down to the floor of the hollow.
She was elderly, but the fury in her eyes gave an overwhelming presence that made her feel immortal.
“Are you the kissiae who summoned me?” Bregon asked.
His men readied their weapons to prepare against any hostility that might follow the kissiae’s antagonizing gaze.
The kissiae glared back at his men, and even the most seasoned of his giants shrunk back on instinct.
This was not a being to threaten.
“I have come to give a warning to ensure the survival of both my kind and your nation.
Your Commanding General has committed an egregious sin by invading another world.
Likewise, the young empress whom you seek has committed that same sin by accepting the aid of the trespassers from the world you invaded.
The kissiae will aid in your capture and execution of the empress and her companions.
We will do so without need of repayment for our aid.
However, should your Commanding General ever return to Whinhlem, you must execute him for breaking the laws of this world.
If you do not, we will be your next enemies and rid you from Amel so that the retribution of the gods only befalls Tolmyur.”

Chapter 16
“The Arrival of Tolmyur”
Byurk looked upon the walls of Revlan rising just above the forest canopy far in the distance.
The city knew his army was there, yet they never left their fortifications to meet them in battle.
Like the previous cities, this would be a siege.
His army camped far enough from the city that magic and arrows would never reach them, but Byurk knew from personal experience the lethality of the silently flying fairies.
At night, camp pyres were lit to give plentiful visibility, and the watch was tripled with both archers and mages at the ready.
At least fairy wings emitted a subdued glow, making them easier to spot at night.
For now, he was stalling.
Due to the hastened evacuation of the previous three villages and cities, plenty of food remained abandoned, but it could only buy his army about twenty days at most.

Including his current food stores, he would need to assault the city after about thirty days to give ample time for them to take the city before his food supply ran too low to last the return trip to Amel.
Thirty days was too short for a prolonged siege against a city.
He sent a message to Amel for reinforcements, but a messenger had yet to arrive informing him whether a contingent force would be sent.
He estimated the city’s forces at about fifty thousand, but if he wanted to include all civilians, the number could increase as far as two hundred thousand.

If their numbers were that large, his army was too small to take the city without careful planning and strategy, but the benefit of stalling longer would increase, and perhaps their food stores would run out before his.
He could starve them first and then attack the weakened city, using the extra time to wait for word of reinforcements from Amel.
“We have done nothing but sit here for three days,” Lieutenant Soppet protested.
“We should act before they have further time to prepare.”
Byurk ignored his lieutenant’s complaints for a moment and continued staring at the walls.
