From his distance, he could just barely see the shadow of a gathering of soldiers atop it eyeing his camp in return.
“This will not be like the previous cities.
It is far more defended.
We cannot risk another attack like Nalain.
With their numbers, we would lose.
You have grown too accustomed to quick massacres.
This siege will be different.”
“Then are we to sit here?”
The method of leadership and warfare between Lieutenant Soppet and Byurk could not have been more different.
Byurk made every effort to minimize the losses of his own army throughout the campaign in Vallen due to how prolonged he knew it would be.
After his injury that sent him back to Amel, Lieutenant Soppet took command and spread through Vallen like the flash flood of the first heavy rain following a prolonged drought.
His losses were greater for each city taken, but in return, the fairies never had the time to prepare a solid defense.
This also saved on provisions, lessening the time taken to finish the campaign.

However, if they kept moving at Byurk’s pace and with his planning, they would have had more soldiers, and the enemy never would have chosen to abandon cities and gather in a single fortress, using the added manpower to further fortify it.
It would have been a city like all the rest.
Revlan was the result of Lieutenant Soppet’s haste.

One could argue which method was more productive, but now that they reached the final city in Vallen, and such a fortified city of Lieutenant Soppet’s creation, Lieutenant Soppet’s methods were ill-matched to conquer it.
“No.
We will send out patrols starting tomorrow.
At our distance, the siege cannot begin.
They still have freedom to gather supplies, and there is always the chance that the widow of the emperor might flee the city if she is there and we delay further.
Fleeing north to the wilderlands might still be beneficial for us with the large bounty Jethro placed on her head, but if she flees south to Fiorrae, we will have trouble.
Once we make our presence known, I will call for a meeting with the city’s commander.”
“You still wish to end this by negotiation?
You are wasting your time.
You offered mercy to every village, town, and city you encountered, and they still fought us to the last life.
You can’t possibly think Revlan will be any different.”
Byurk shook his head.
“I never wanted this to be genocide.
The fairies are stubborn and prideful.
They would rather die than be taken captive, but we should give them the option to surrender, nonetheless.
There are few of their kind left.
It would be to their benefit to comply.
And we must make certain the widow is in the city.”

* * *
Ceil stood atop the wall walk on the east side of the city.
The military camp just north of her had been evacuated into the city the day before, now looking more akin to a ghost town.
The reason was the new camp that rose in the distance the day before the evacuation, one belonging to the enemy who pursued her.
The city was already filled to bursting, so most of the soldiers slept atop the walls.
Those on the eastern walls slept little due to the ever-present feeling of the enemy breathing down their necks.
At least with the continued deaths of the unstable refugees, the spaces between the walls emptied as the refugees were moved to the large courtyard, making room for the soldiers.
“Do you think they will attack,” Ceil asked Dharin.
“Not yet.
I sent some wings to scout their numbers, and they do not have enough soldiers to assault the city safely.
As we feared, this will be a prolonged confrontation.”
“Would it be possible to meet them on the battlefield and use our numbers to overwhelm them?”
Dharin shook his head.
“With our lack of trained soldiers, we would lose in open confrontation.
Our best tactic is to hold the city against them.”
“They cannot assault us, and we cannot meet them in combat.” Ceil ground her teeth.
“A deadlock.”
“We can assume for now that the city is safe.
They will act in the coming days when their own investigation of our defenses finishes.
Their commander should have also noticed the deadlock and will scheme to circumvent it.
There is little we can do until we surmise their intentions or they make them clear to us.”
Ceil turned away from the enemy camp and weaved through the hunkered and resting soldiers.
There was barely room to set each foot, but the soldiers made effort to shift as much as was possible out of her way.
Her guard followed close behind and matched her steps as her steps were truly the only places to set their feet.
The crowded streets of the city were no better, and Ceil could barely walk without brushing shoulders with someone.
At least the citizens were too occupied to yell accusations at her for bringing this destruction upon them.
The enemy was here, and each family and refugee had their own preparations to make.
Unlike the rest of the city, the inside of the curtain wall was uncrowded, so Ceil could breathe easier.
She felt it a bit unfair that the nobles refused to let anyone inside, but at the same time she enjoyed the far calmer atmosphere, so she could not judge them harshly.
If she was forced to stay on the crowded streets amid sweat, body heat, and filth, she knew her emotions would break.
After all, she caused this solely by existing, and that thought plagued her every time she stepped outside the tranquil central district.
Ceil bid farewell to her guards and walked immediately to the garden where Justin and Sammy sat with Lemi.
“How are you feeling?”
“I keep saying I’m fine,” Lemi pouted.
A few days ago, Lemi was wracked with an unbearable pain that had her clawing at her hair and face.
Ceil, Sammy, and Justin were forced to restrain her while Tyree tried desperately to investigate the cause and heal her if possible.
It continued late into the evening but eventually subsided, leaving Lemi exhausted and bedridden for two days.
Lemi requested to be moved to the garden so she could soak in the sun to speed her recovery and remained there even after she felt better.
“Do you have any idea what the cause could have been?
Something you ate, maybe?
Did you drink too much wine?”
“We already asked that,” Sammy replied.
“And we’ve been preventing her from drinking the wine unless it was watered down.”
“And if Tyree is correct and there are no Melian diseases that matched the symptoms, what could have caused it?
Are you sure you do not feel anything different?” Ceil asked.
Lemi shook her head.
“And none of the other Dryads have caught it or experienced the same symptoms…”
“Must have been some freak thing,” Sammy mused.
“Sudden pain like that doesn’t happen without reason.
Could the Sprite Arkhon have done something?”
“I tested that too, but she can’t understand other languages, so we can at least rule out that it’s the same as what happened to me.”
“That does not mean he could not have done something else.”
Sammy looked up at the sky in thought.
“Arkhon are you here?”
“You cannot seriously expect the Sprite Arkhon to appear when you call him.”
Sammy ignored Ceil’s rebuke and waited.
She could not explain her reason, but she had a hunch.
Slowly, a warm wind enveloped the area, and a wind sprite appeared in the center of the group, stunning Ceil silent.
Sammy was likewise amazed, but the one who appeared was not the sprite Arkhon but a female wind sprite.
“Sorry, but the Arkhon is preoccupied at the moment, so he sent me in his place.
I am Ephora.”
“Can you seriously summon a sprite on whim?!”
Ceil looked at Sammy rather exasperated.
“Oh, no.
We are not some elemental you can summon.
We are simply observing Sammy here, so of course we could hear her.”
The sprite flitted around the group, and Sammy’s eyes followed her.
She was finally able to see them if only just a little.
“Observing me?
Why?”
“Sorry, but I am not permitted to explain further.
Did you have a question?”
Sammy looked over at Lemi and noticed Justin turning his head away from the Sprite.
This was the same reaction he had to Lemi and the other Melians when they were uncovered, out of respect to them as women.
A small suspicion rose in Sammy’s mind.
“Are the sprites naked?”
“Is that your question,” Ephora asked with a laugh.
“Our forms are remnants from when we had physical bodies, and we appear no different than you, so you could say that we are.
You may consider us souls who have chosen the elements as our covering instead of flesh.
As the elements, we have no need for clothing.”
“Justin, can you see her?!”
Justin looked back at Sammy surprised.
“Of course.
I mean, are you unable to?”
“Can you see her clearly?
Not as a blur or transparent silhouette or anything else?”
“Yah. She’s not transparent at all.”
Now Ceil was surprised.
She could see the sprites clearly, but they were always transparent, lacking any physical appearance.
“That must be because his ven signature is very similar to ours.” Ephora explained.
“Those who are sensitive to ven or meditate enough to increase their sensitivity can see us in a way, but because their signature is different, they cannot truly see us.”
“So Justin has absolutely zero recognition of his ven but he can see you because his ven is the same?” Sammy shook her head in disbelief.
All her effort to increase her own sensitivity, and Justin could see the sprites naturally.
“If that is all the questions you have, I will be on my way.”
“Wait,” Ceil called.
“Can the sprites help us in this battle?”
“No.
We have a strong non-interference restriction instated by Gyea.
We are permitted to interact with the races as one of them, but we cannot interfere.”
“Gyea?
One of the two titan guardians of Whinhlem?” Ceil asked, amazed.
“Is there anything else?” Ephora asked.
Sammy breathed a sigh.
“Sorry for all the odd questions, but the true reason I called you was to ask if you knew why Lemi was in such pain a few days ago.
The sprites are skilled with life magic, so I was hoping you might be able to discover something that the dryad’s missed.”
“Oh, I know the reason.
A powerful kissiae caused it.
It affected many dryads throughout most of northern Dhuillir, but you have no need to worry.
It cannot happen again.
However, in the Arkhon’s place I will give you a warning.
Beware the kissiae.
They are acting on their own to your demise, visitors from Earth, and they have sided with the Tolmyur armies.
They will join the battle against you, but do not anger them.
Farewell.”
Ephora disappeared without another word.
“Who are the kissiae?” Sammy asked.
Instead of answering, Ceil had a question of her own.
“Did she just use the name of your world?
Did the sprites know all along you were not from Whinhlem?”
“I kind of suspected the Arkhon knew, so it’s no surprise that she did as well.
What about the kissiae?”
Ceil sighed.
The Arkhon must have known everything about Sammy and her friends from the beginning, leaving her to discover it on her own.
“They are ivy dryads that live in Elos,” Lemi replied.
“They are one of the oldest species of dryad and also the strongest.
She said that they sided with Tolmyur.
Isn’t that bad?”
“I will inform Dharin,” Ceil said as she ran for the manor.

* * *
“Ten parties of five hundred are a bit excessive for mere scouts,” Lieutenant Soppet said as he watched the second-to-last party leave camp.
“Such large parties will not be very mobile.
If your purpose is a preemptive attack, you should send more to show our strength.”
“Hardly the point,” Byurk replied as he finished lacing his leather armor to join the final scouting party.
“They already know our numbers.
The purpose is to create unease while we observe the fortifications and surrounding terrain as well as prevent them from leaving the city to gather provisions.
I expect many in the city to be troubled while our morale is high.
Further breaking the enemy’s spirits will improve our chances of victory.
The size of the parties is meant to deter them from any attempted retaliation.
The parties were instructed to stay outside arrow and magic range.
If they send out a sizable force to defeat the scouts safely, the scouts will be more mobile and should have no problem escaping.”
Byurk walked to the head of the final party composed solely of humans for increased mobility.
Despite being a minum, no one doubted his ability to keep pace.
“Scouting rotations are four-hour shifts.
When the first group returns, make certain the next is prepared.
I want no gaps in our pressure.”
“Understood.”
Byurk dug his heel into the soil, and with a swift step propelled lightly by earth magic, he led his party in a jog out of the camp.
The flat terrain marbled with dense forests and open plains created a unique battlefield.
While mobility decreased in the forests, his soldiers could advance while the thick cover of the canopy hid both their numbers and direction.
The perfectly flat fields then provided quick movement for attack and retreat as well as giving ample room for use of magic and archery.
Much of the south side of the city was forested including a small section on the north side.
The northeast was open field with an abandoned military camp that his men could not enter without drawing within attack range.
The west side was the largest field expanding far into the distance.
Crops were growing in various stages of harvest, having been abandoned when his soldiers arrived.
Byurk met up with one of the nearby scouting groups and instructed them to scavenge the farmlands for abandoned provisions, gather wood for war ladders, and burn everything else.
The black smoke would be a perfect show for those cowering in the sunken city.

If he wanted a proper assault, his best choice would be to attack from the west, but the gatehouse there was small, and from the appearance of the inner wall behind it, there was no immediate entrance to the city.
There, he had three options.
His soldiers could move through the vulnerable gap between the two walls to reach the gate into the city.
They could carry in taller war ladders to climb the inner wall or bridge the gap between the walks of the two walls.
Lastly, they could buy time for earth mages to tear down the walls.
For such large fortifications, that would be a time-consuming task while under constant fire, and his supply of earth mages was low.
This made the gatehouse on the southeast side the best location for entering the city, but the dense forests provided poor visibility of the walls from under the canopy.
The trees could provide some shelter, but his soldiers would be unable to see the attacks raining down from the walls.
While contemplating how to assault the main gatehouse, Byurk noticed a large blue bird flying into the city.
He recognized it immediately as the Habha trained by the widow of the emperor.
It carried some animal half its size in its talons.
He halted his party and waited while the soldiers on the wall stared him down in the distance.
After a few minutes, the Habha rose once more and flew southwest at incredible speed.
It was gathering provisions for the city.
The beast it carried could provide a day’s meal for a hundred if rationed.
Even if it could hunt twenty times in one day, that was hardly enough to feed an overcrowded city, but it would decrease the consumption of their stored provisions.
Byurk had no way of knowing yet how much food was stored in the city, but just seeing the Habha made him feel that starving the city may be more difficult than originally expected.
Back at the camp, Byurk listened to the reports of each initial scouting group and those who returned after each subsequent shift.

“The city is heavily defended, more so than expected,” Lieutenant Mackrum, second lieutenant under Lieutenant Soppet, said after hearing the most recent report from a party that risked sending a pair of scouts under the forest canopy to gain a closer view of the wall and southeast gatehouse.
“The portcullis is reinforced with iron, and the tunnel is far too long.
If it has murder holes, our bodies could fill the tunnel before we manage to make it through,” Lieutenant Soppet added.
“We cannot ignore the possibility of Oreads hiding in the stone.
There were three in Nalain, and we lost many soldiers to them alone.”
Byurk remained silent while his Lieutenants discussed how best to assault the city.
His hand moved in quick motions as he fashioned a letter to Revlan’s commander in clean Elven.

On the morrow, he would send out two messengers carrying Tolmyur’s banner to deliver it to the main gatehouse, earth mages specialized in reinforcement magic in case the enemy decided to shoot them down after the message was delivered.

* * *
The front door of the manor swung open with a loud bang against the wall, interrupting breakfast.
“Dharin!
A letter from Captain Byurk of the Tolmyur army!”
Kiri appeared in the lounge carrying a rolled sheet of parchment tied with a crude strip of leather.
“Byurk?
I thought we assassinated him.
He survived?”
The tactics of the invading army changed drastically after the assassination, a sure sign that a new commander was leading the campaign.
The tactics never reverted, so they had assumed that the commander died.
Dharin stood and quickly retrieved the message.
“Is it…”
“A call for a meeting of commanders on the eastward field,” Dharin interrupted Kiri.
“He details the troops he will bring for protection and asks that we match the numbers.
Both he and his Lieutenant will be present.”
“There is nothing to discuss,” Ceil said, leaning back on her cushion.
“They did not stop their campaign once they learned I was not in Vallen.
They will not stop now that I am here.”
“He specifically mentions his agreement with you to meet him before the battle and demands your presence,” Dharin explained after reading further.
“So the commander you met in Dhuillir was Captain Byurk.”
“Let me see.”
Ceil grabbed the parchment and scanned it while Sammy looked over her shoulder.
“I can understand languages but can’t read them?” Sammy groaned.
“I can teach you later.”
Ceil continued reading.
“That makes no sense.
He already returned Justin.
We have no reason to meet.”
“Probably to make sure you are here to uphold your end of the agreement,” Sammy surmised.
“That is most probable,” Dharin agreed.
“The time is set for noon today.
That gives us little time to prepare.”
“Are you going with,” Sammy asked Ceil.
“I have nothing to discuss with him, but I will show him I have not run.”
“Then we should retrieve your armor.
It should be finished by now,” Dharin said.
“I will have Thanysa take you while I prepare our escort and discuss the meeting with the council.”
Dharin drained his goblet and grabbed one more strip of cured meat before following Kiri out the front door.
Less than an hour later, Thanysa arrived with the usual four High Elf guards to escort Ceil to the forge.
Despite Ceil’s assurance that no one else needed to follow, everyone but Lemi decided to join.
Unlike their first visit to the forge, the open storefront was frantic with craftsman and soldiers moving out the completed weaponry.
The large crates of spear tips and arrowheads were replaced by even larger racks piled so full of spears that they rolled onto the ground whenever more were added.
“Thanysa!
I’m glad you have decided to visit again, but as you can see, we are quite busy.”
Sarodyn carried a large barrel full of arrows on his shoulder, the fletching just visible above the rim.
He placed it with two similar barrels on a handcart for two fairy soldiers to haul off.
“We are here for Her Highness’s order.”
“The young empress?”
Sarodyn looked down at Ceil.
“Oh, the Thorn General’s order.
Understood.
Wait to the side to stay out of the way.
I will be but a moment.”
Ceil’s company moved closer to one of the pillars by the entrance to the forge.
Although Sarodyn stated he would be brief, he left them waiting long enough for beads of sweat to pour down everyone’s flushed faces, everyone but Chloe, but her face was flushed for other reasons.

The craftsmen inside the forge worked at twice the pace of those outside moving the finished product to the walls to arm the soldiers, and Ceil had to wonder if the haste of the smiths was due to them currently lacking enough arms should the enemy launch an immediate attack.
Traveling through the city, she could see very few of the citizens armed, and the locations where weapons were to be distributed had yet to be set up.
This meant they had not fully armed the soldiers.
The city was not yet ready for war, and this worried her.
“Sorry for the delay.
I finished a few days back, so somebody had moved it to make room.
I had to beat a few skulls to find out where.”
Sarodyn set down a case and removed a set of armor.
“Here you are, lass.
A set of plated jack leather armor.

There was not enough resfahil for the full chainmail the Thorn General requested even if we diluted the alloy to its limit, so we went for a jack with small resfahil plates interspersed through the fabric.
With his permission, of course.
I feel full mail may have been too heavy for you anyway.”
“I thought royalty was not supposed to wear resfahil in case of an emergency,” Ceil asked.
“There is not a single spatial mage in the entire city,” Thanysa admitted reluctantly.
“We have a single spatial pixy, but we cannot use him for your protection or escape.
Without barriers, resfahil is our best hope to protect you from magic.”
“Try it on so we can adjust the fit.
I padded the inside of both the jack and skirt to keep it comfortable, but you should still wear a fabric skirt underneath.”
Sarodyn handed a leather skirt to Thanysa who wrapped it around Ceil’s waist and tied it down the back.
The vertical plats of leather were connected between by purple linen to provide for mobility and prevent the skirt from being too stiff.
The jack was also overlaid with the same purple linen sewn with diamond patterns to attach the small resfahil plates on the inside.
“There was a small note from Kiri in the order to color it purple if possible, but dies and stains can weaken leather, so I used purple fabric where fabric was needed.
The leather collar, bracers, and cuffs are also imprinted with the Amelian insignia.
A bit of regal flair for our young empress.”

“I…” Ceil was about to say she would rather not stand out in such gaudy colors, but she found the bright shade of purple beautiful, and like the dress provided her by her maid--her cousin--in the Gallanvale, she knew this armor was crafted out of consideration for her.
“Thank you.”
“I regret that I could not have done more.
How’s the fit?”
Thanysa finished lacing the back of the jack, so Ceil raised her arms, twisted at the waist, and lifted her knees.
“Fit looks good,” Thanysa said after inspecting each motion.
“We may not have time today, but you should wear it during our training sessions to get a feel for the added weight and decreased mobility.”
Ceil turned to Sammy and spread her arms lightly.
“It looks great,” she exclaimed with a smile.
“I like the color,” Chloe said, catching on to the flow of conversation despite being unable to understand it.
“Seems practical,” Justin finished, and Sammy batted him lightly on the arm.
“What kind of complement is that?” Sammy chastised.
“It is fine.
Armor is meant to be practical,” Ceil said.
“Sammy, can you throw one of your water orbs at me, the forceful kind?”
“You serious?”
Ceil nodded.
Sammy took a few steps back, taking care not to get in anyone’s way.
She conjured a sphere of water and tossed it at the center of Ceil’s chest.
Instead of bursting, the water simply hit her chest, serving no greater purpose than cooling Ceil off from the heat of the forge.
“The water did not dissipate but the effect of the attack was mitigated,” Ceil said after wiping her face.
“Any magic attack strong enough to pierce the armor and touch the resfahil should be nullified.
Others that don’t pierce it should be mitigated like that water orb, so it should protect against magically created fire, but remember that resfahil is nothing but metal against the natural elements.
Otherwise we couldn’t refine it,” Sarodyn guffawed.
“Thank you again,” Ceil said after turning to face Sarodyn.
“It was my pleasure to craft our new empress’s first set of regal armor.”
“I will let you return to your work.”
Thanysa waved to her father as she walked off, once again ignoring his plea for her to visit for reasons other than work.
“May I make a request,” Thanysa asked Ceil.
“Of course.”
“I will bring this to the Thorn General, but I should ask you and your companions first.
When you go with the Thorn General to meet the Tolmyur commander, I would like you to take Sir Justin and Lady Chloe with you.”
“What about me?” Sammy asked.
“Lady Chloe is the most powerful mage in the city, and without a spatial mage, Sir Justin may be the best protection we can provide Her Highness with only a twenty-soldier escort.
I mean no offense, but there is nothing you can offer in the discussions.”
“Yes there is,” Sammy protested.
“I understand every language on Whinhlem.
Every single one.
They don’t know that.
If they try to speak among themselves in a different language, I can tell you what they say.”
“No, Sammy.
I agree with Chloe and Justin’s involvement, but should the discussions result in conflict, you would be a liability.
You have improved, but you are still nothing compared to a trained soldier, especially those whom the commander will bring for these discussions.”
“Her Highness is correct.
Just as we will be bringing our best, he will as well.
Lady Sammy, you can join me atop the walk to watch the discussions.”
Perhaps speaking to them in their own language could help the discussions progress smoothly.
Perhaps she could convince them not to assault the city and find a different way to resolve the conflict without further bloodshed.
Sammy tried desperately to think of a reason for her to take part, but each thought she stumbled upon fell short to her own reasoning.
The commander spoke fluent Elven in her memory of the central Melian village, and what could she even say to convince them that the genocide that was nearly complete should end?
Sammy fell silent in dejection after once again failing to be useful to the conflict, but her deeply rooted desire to leave her mark on the conflict burned stronger within her because of it.
Once Ceil explained Thanysa’s suggestion to Chloe and Justin, they agreed readily.
Thanysa brought them to the inner sanctum of the temple to be part of the continued discussions about the meeting of commanders.

When Chloe and Justin’s involvement was presented, there were some on the council who still found issue with their human origins and questioned their loyalty, claiming that this would be the perfect opportunity to betray Ceil and hand her over to the enemy, but when Ceil pounded her staff into the ground, the dissenting voices silenced in fear, remembering the brutal execution of the Rose General.

These humans were Ceil’s chosen companions, and while the thought that their empress would choose to associate with humans over her fellow elfkind raised doubts of Ceil’s loyalty to the fairy conflict, they assented unanimously.

The remaining time before the meeting of commanders was spent organizing the guard and a small army of one thousand who would stay back in the abandoned camp to come to the aid of Ceil and her guard should conflict arise.
The soldiers of the guard were hand-selected by Dharin, but Ceil was asked to speak with each of them to ratify the selection or reject any individual with whom she found fault.
Once finished, Ceil, her two companions, the Thorn General, and their guard left the safety of the walls of Revlan for the eastern fields.

* * *
Byurk led the march out of his camp.
His guard consisted of two of his veteran giants, two dwarven combat mages, five human shieldsmen, six swordsmen, and seven archers.
Aside from his giants, the other soldiers were of average or lower skill selected by Lieutenant Soppet to minimize losses should the worst happen.
Byurk was the best mage of his army, so the numbers were solely a deterrent against hostility.
He was confident that he could protect himself so long as there was no enemy far more powerful present.
A cold breeze cut across the field from the north.
The long stalks of grass waved in ripples down the field, nearly obscuring the party approaching on the far end.
He recognized one of them immediately and realized that no small number of men he brought could stop the enemy should they decide to attack.
Standing far across the field with the enemy procession was an orange-haired woman, the otherworld fire mage of extraordinary power.
Her presence alone meant that peaceful negotiations were his responsibility, because he and his men would be in the greatest danger should violence break out.
“Remember that this is a conversation, not an attack,” Byurk reminded his lieutenant.
“They overpower us by a grave margin.”
“We should have brought our elite,” Lieutenant Soppet complained.
“If their general is seasoned, he would recognize that the men we brought are not our finest.
Are these discussions not to intimidate them?”
“No, we are here for information, whatever we can glean.”
“For one as ruthless as you are in combat, your strategy in war is awfully precautious.”
“With our current strength, caution is most important,” Byurk reminded.
At about a hundred yards distant from the opposing party, Byurk halted his march.
He eyed the widow’s guard, consisting of mostly High Elves with four winged fairies hovering in the air slightly above.

Four bodies stood before the guard: the otherworld fire mage on the left, a short, elderly fairy to her right, the emperor’s widow, and then her shield bearer, possibly half fairy, half elf by his stature.
A line of soldiers stood in rank in front of the camp at the end of the field behind them, an extra precaution Byurk felt was not needed with that fire mage present.
To match numbers of the meeting parties, he called one of his elite giants and one of the dwarven battle mages, an earth mage specialized in area defense.
He did not doubt his giant’s ability to take down the shield bearer, but he knew the dwarf was unlikely to be able to fully protect them against the firepower of that mage.
He stepped out with his four across the field, and their four approached to meet him midway.
Having called the meeting, Byurk spoke first.
“I am Captain Byurk of Tolmyur, commander in charge of the Vallen campaign.
As you can see, your assassination has failed, and I am in good health.
Such tactics will not work a second time.
With me is Lieutenant Soppet who led the campaign during my absence.”
Lieutenant Soppet straightened his back, standing tall for a minum, and grinned at the fairy general who could do nothing to stop his rapid advance across Vallen.
“Dharin, Thorn General of the fairies of Vallen,” the elderly fairy said.
“With me are those who I assume need no introduction, Her Highness, Empress Ceil and her companions whom you met in Melia of Dhuillir.”
“I desire to know the name of the otherworld fire mage beside you, Thorn General.
I have lost many valiant men to her power.”
“Chloe Hearn,” the widow answered with pride.
“You would do well to remember it.”
“If I may,” Lieutenant Soppet cut in, surprising Byurk although he refrained from showing it.
“I have encountered many in my destruction of Vallen who have claimed to be the widow of the Amelian emperor as you do now.
They have all proven to be imposters and have received adequate punishment for their deception.”
The widow visibly tensed, and her ire leaked into her expression.
If she visited any of the fallen cities or villages on her way to Revlan, Byurk was certain she would have seen Lieutenant Soppet’s abhorrent displays.
“From what I have learned of your previous encounters with Captain Byurk, you have provided no evidence of the truth of your claim as widow of Emperor Yuro.
We demand that you prove it here, or the destruction that follows the widow may not end with Revlan.”
“And how would I prove my identity to you?” the widow asked.
“Your tails,” Lieutenant Soppet replied.
Byurk focused to control his anger.

They were not in a position to antagonize the enemy, but stopping his Lieutenant now would undermine his standing in these discussions, revealing that his side was either not unified or that he lacked the command to control his men.
However, if his lieutenant’s intimidation bore success, it set him as dominant at the start of the discussions whereas their refusal would not harm either side’s position.
“The empress is under no obligation to expose herself for your gratification,” the Thorn General replied, but the widow extended her hand to stop him.
“No, it is fine.
Dharin, untie me.”
The Thorn General hesitated, but the widow asserted her decision.
“Do it.”
He moved behind her and unlaced the back of her hardened leather skirt letting it slide down her legs to the ground.
A brown, silken underskirt extended just past the calves of her legs.
She turned her back to Byurk, raised the back of her skirt, and lifted her two long and elegant tails of perfectly even length from the fabric cradle, letting them slowly slide over her hand.
“Is that what you wanted to see, commander?”
The widow, now unquestionable in her claim, returned her tails to their cradle and ordered the Thorn General to lace up the back of her leather skirt once more.
Though she stood confident, her face was flushed red from the embarrassment of the act.
“Let it be known that win or lose, I fought you in battle, and the destruction of my people in your pursuit of my life ends here in Vallen.”
“Having born witness, we accept your claim as widow of the late emperor,” Lieutenant Soppet replied with a sneer.
“And I commend you for upholding your end of our agreement in Melia and not returning into hiding,” Byurk added, playing off his lieutenant’s script.
“Even without the return of Justin, I would have come.
I can run no longer.”
“Admirable, but as you can see, your companion is not with me.”
The widow held out her left hand to her shield bearer, presenting him to Byurk.
“He arrived safely in Revlan.
This ends our agreement.”
Byurk suppressed the utter shock rising from within his chest.
He looked up into the shaded face under the leather cowl of the shield bearer.
He was not as sickly as before, but the features were unmistakable.
How could an unconscious human survive buried under a mountain of rubble submerged in water?
Even with the aid of that dryad, he should not have survived.
Byurk was surer now more than ever that this otherworlder was more of a threat than even the fire mage.
In order to survive such an ordeal, he had to be as powerful as Jethro.
Byurk was somewhat accustomed to the capabilities of spatial magic due to his long association with Jethro, but he knew little about time magic.
That otherworlder’s presence alone made this siege far to grave a risk with his current forces.
Instead of information, Byurk needed to resolve this conflict through negotiation if at all possible.
“Our agreement may be finished, but I must once again impress upon you the direness of your situation.

Among all of the nations that once allied themselves under the Amelian banner, only the fairies remain in opposition to Tolmyur, and their numbers are few, the main body of survivors huddling in fear within the walled city behind you.
When we parted in Melia, I sent an urgent request to Amel for reinforcements, and they are on their way as we speak.
If you hope to defeat us, your sole chance of survival lies in surrender or open combat on these fields.
We have ample provisions to starve your city until our reinforcements arrive, upon which we will have numbers sufficient to overwhelm you.”
“If you want to defeat us, you will have no choice but to throw your corpses at our walls,” the Thorn General retorted.

Given the Thorn General’s confidence, Byurk was certain that their store of provisions was indeed sufficient, and his refusal to fight in open combat hinted that his armies lacked the manpower or training to be victorious no matter his skill in command and tactics.
If they had sufficient otherworlders at their command, a victory on the field would be trivial for them, so their numbers may yet be small.
“Then you have chosen your inevitable demise and an endangerment to the race of fairies.

There is certainly a small number of your kind interspersed throughout the continent, but without a homeland where you may gather, in not so many generations the few of your people who remain will be absorbed into the other races and cease to be.
While this would be fitting irony for the elves, I am not so petty that I would also wish it upon their next of kin.
I offer you the chance to save your people and end this conflict so that you might rebuild and reclaim your homeland.
We will not go so far as ordering you to swear allegiance to Tolmyur.
All we ask is that you surrender the widow of the emperor, and we will see to your survival and expend all efforts to aid in your recovery.”
The widow gripped the staff in her right hand with white knuckles but did not speak.
If the Thorn General demanded it, she would have no other choice but to surrender herself.
Her eyes bore the anger seething within, but she did not turn to look at the Thorn General to plead her safety.
“If fate has chosen our race to end, we will see that our end be glorious, fallen in epic battle sung for all of history so that we may never be forgotten!”
Byurk’s eyes narrowed, focusing on the weak flame of doubt flickering in the eyes of the widow.
“Having heard the Thorn General’s declaration, do you wish that fate upon them?
Do you also desire the genocide of the fairies, Empress Ceil?
You were willing to sacrifice the Melians for your benefit.
Are you just as willing to sacrifice the fairies?
I make you the same offer I did in Melia.
Surrender yourself and show that you do care for your subjects.”
The widow’s lips quivered.
She looked back at her guard, the line of soldiers before the camp, and the city walls topped with so many soldiers there was not a single gap for light between them.
She could spare them all.
One to two hundred thousand lives and the continuation of a now endangered race for the life of one.
Her life bore an immense weight, and Byurk wanted her to be crushed beneath it.
“Instead of history remembering that you fought me in battle at the cost of the noble race of fairies, would your legacy not be grander if you gave your life to ensure their survival instead?”
“Enough!” Dharin called, but the widow did not turn from gazing at the walled city.
“The future rests on her survival, a future of which you know nothing.
If our sacrifice is a means to that end, we will gladly accept it, but know here and now that we will not yield.
If you want her, every man, woman, and child of Revlan will stand in your path.”
Byurk did not care about the Thorn General’s reply.
The Thorn General would never yield.
He wanted the widow’s.
“Empress Ceil, your decision,” Byurk demanded.
The widow remained silent, but Byurk could see she would soon break the longer her gaze lingered on the overcrowded city behind her.
“You will not have her.”
The Thorn General Drew his sword and extended it out in front of the wife, blocking her should she decide to surrender.
“So be it.”
Byurk turned his back and walked away.
He wanted to push harder, but even if he convinced the widow, nothing could be done.
The fairies were prepared to hold her in the city against her will if needed.
Any attempt to aid the widow in her surrender by fighting against the Thorn General here in the field would result in his certain destruction at the hands of Chloe Hearn.
At least he was able to obtain some vital information, so he considered the discussion a success.
One of the shieldsmen among their waiting guard gave the hand signal requesting orders.
Lieutenant Soppet returned a brief signal in front of his chest that Byurk did not catch.
Two wind longbowman peaked out between the shields.
Byurk panicked.
He turned towards the enemy just as two wind-imbued arrows flew close enough overhead for him to feel the trail of wind.
“You fool!”

With impossible timing, the otherworld shieldbearer swung his long and slender shield to catch the first arrow while simultaneously grabbing the widow and pulling her to the ground to avoid the second that passed just between their heads.
A surprise attack may have worked against a normal time mage but not one who could ignore channeling time.
Now that his side made the first move, they were committed.
Byurk stamped his foot into the ground to raise a spike beneath the fallen widow and otherworlder.
The time mage pushed the wife aside in time for her to avoid the spike while he caught it on his shield, flipping him back several feet into the air and into a crumpled heap on the ground.
The Thorn General grabbed the widow with his feathered wings spread and lunged back to meet the four rapidly approaching winged fairies.
Unable to bear her weight alone, he passed her off to them, and they carried her as they weaved to and fro close to the ground to better avoid the arrows his archers rapidly fired.
“Not her!
Shoot th--”
Byurk’s words caught in his throat.
Chloe Hearn stepped forward with her arms engulfed in flames like wings of destruction unfurled before him.
His giant elite caught his collar and threw him back with incredible strength as the mage’s hand swung together into a deafening clap.
The explosion robbed him of his breath and propelled him further.

He spun through the air, unable to know sky from earth, and the moment he caught his bearings, he reinforced his body with earth magic and struck his foot out to obliterate the rapidly approaching soil into fine sand.

* * *
“Justin!”
“Lady Sammy!
Wait!” Thanysa called out to Sammy but could not avail her reason.
The woman who had just watched the man she loved take a direct attack from the enemy commander pushed her way through the riled soldiers and out of Thanysa’s reach.
Thanysa jumped from the wall and slid down its steep slope, aided by her earth magic.
The moment she touched ground, she lunged forward with pillars of earth propelling each step.
The four fairies carrying Empress Ceil passed above her into the safety of the walled city.
She quickly passed the soldiers now in full charge to support the Thorn General and his guard.
A second grand explosion erupted that nearly robbed Thanysa of her breath, even from her distance.
A monstrous plume of flame billowed into the sky, many times larger than the first.
She trusted Empress Ceil’s word about Lady Chloe’s power, but she never could have imagined it would be of such a magnitude.
If Lady Chloe was an enemy, Revlan would fall in a single night.
Their walls could never hold against such power.
The guard kept a wide breadth from the explosion and rushed forward to try and cut off the fleeing enemy.
The Thorn General was with Justin, but he was unable to move the unconscious man.
Thanysa rushed to his aid.
His shield bent inward from the impact of the spike, but thankfully Sir Justin lived.
“He is far too heavy for me.
Take him,” Dharin ordered.
“What of Lady Chloe?”
“She is within the flames.
We must trust that she can withstand her own fire.
I will call the soldiers back.
If they extend too far, they could get caught by Tolmyur’s armies and overwhelmed.”
The Thorn General flew off to intercept his forward guard.
Thanysa wrapped Justin’s arm over her shoulder and lifted him.
He weighed as much or more than a fully armored High Elf, far more than anyone his size in studded leather should weigh.
She crouched down and swung his other arm over her other shoulder, pulling him close to her back.
There she waited, hoping that Lady Chloe would return from within the inferno.
When she felt she could wait no longer, when she could see the Thorn General appear with his guard from around the flames, a burning figure walked out from within.
Chloe stumbled over the grass, lighting it with every step until she collapsed to her knees, hunched over.
“Water,” the flaming body called in desperation.
“Chloe is immensely powerful, no doubt the strongest fire mage on the continent, but she has a tendency to overheat.
If we are to use her in the war, we need to keep an ice mage on hand to cool her off.”
Thanysa thought Ceil’s praise and warning about her companion was exaggeration, but it was all true.
She called to the approaching army.
“Douse Lady Chloe in water!
Use ice!
Quickly!”
Several mages rapidly surrounded the burning body, unable to approach too near for the intensity of the heat.
Together they released fountains of water and mists of frost.
Steam erupted, enshrouding the field in a dense fog.
Lady Chloe hunched over on her elbows, naked and shaking.
Unable to bear her agony any longer, she collapsed to the ground.
“What kind of self-destructive power is this?”
Both of Empress Ceil’s companions successfully saved her life, but in doing so they incapacitated themselves.
If this happened in the midst of battle, their lives would be forfeit.
There could be none now who would ever question these humans’ loyalty to the empress and this war.
Thanysa passed Justin off to two High Elves while two others lifted Chloe.
“Return to the city,” the Thorn General called, and immediately the army was in full retreat.

* * *
Byurk awoke to the sight of his tent ceiling in dim torchlight.
Remembering the events caused by his foolish Lieutenant, he shot up from his bed and called for a soldier.
To his surprise, his body did not ache.
He had no injuries that he could feel.
Even when turning the ground to sand on impact, he expected to have a few broken bones.
“Sir.”
Lieutenant Mackrum stood in the entryway relieved to see his captain awake.
A pale-skinned dryad sat in the corner beside the entrance on a stool.
“Tell me what happened, and explain this dryad.”
“Lieutenant Soppet set up the assassination as you ordered but we were unable to eliminate the widow before she escaped.”
Byurk swallowed his shout that he never gave such an order.
Had he died in that fire, Lieutenant Soppet’s aggression and lack of foresight could have lost them this war.
Lieutenant Mackrum would have been the only remaining officer, and he was still unskilled.
“And the casualties?”
“Lieutenant Soppet died in the initial blast.
Your guard rushed to your aid but most of them died in the second.
Despite grave injuries, the few who survived were able to retrieve you and carry you back to camp.
Only one of them lived long enough to receive treatment.”
“The dryad?”
“She healed you as well as the sole surviving shieldsman.
She arrived four hours ago bearing a message from General Bregon.
He will arrive in eight days with an army from Amel.
Accompanying him is an even larger army of dryads from Dhuillir led by the kissiae.
They have joined the war on our side to eliminate the otherworlders, and General Bregon has relinquished command of our armies to their matriarch.”

Chapter 17
“Second Chances”
Sammy
The army retrieved Chloe and Justin safely, and they were carried immediately to Tyree.
Chloe suffered first- and second-degree burns covering most of her body.
The two massive explosions had used up all her ven, and she passed out from mental trauma and pain cause by a combination of the burns and ven exhaustion.
Her burns were trivial to heal, so all she needed was to rest for the night.
Justin received heavy bruising on his right forearm and chest, a mild fracture on that same arm, and three cracked ribs.
He also received a slight concussion from landing on the ground after being thrown.
The benign damage of his cracked ribs and fracture was mended quickly.
Bruises, like burns, were trivial to heal, but concussions were a far more delicate matter that took Tyree’s time and patience.
Like Chloe, Justin was left to rest overnight with the promise that he would return to perfect health in the morning aside from the appearance of the bruising that would fade naturally.
From the moment Justin woke the next morning, Sammy clung to him and would not let go.
Visions of him being shot and the following months of his pain and anguish--the numerous days she feared that she would wake to him dead the next morning--returned in force.

She was the one who requested that Justin should be charged with Ceil’s protection, but she never expected that would send him directly into danger’s path where he would need to sacrifice himself for Ceil as he had for her.
She seethed inside, hating herself for making that suggestion, but when she saw Ceil bow to the floor in front of Chloe and Justin before breakfast, she knew she had made the correct decision.
Ceil was alive because of Justin.
“Thank you for saving me.
If not for you both, I never could have survived that attack.”
Chloe grew flustered and coaxed Ceil to lift her head.
“You don’t need to thank us.
We volunteered specifically for that reason.
They were sure to try something.”
“I was a bit worried, but I’m glad it worked out,” Justin said with a smile.
“Come back to the table and eat.”
Ceil lifted her head and looked at the splotches of fresh pink skin on Chloe’s face and the large bruise on Justin’s outstretched arm.
She ignored Justin’s hand and crawled forward to sit on her cushion next to the table.
“I must say that I am quite astounded at the power of Lady Chloe and Sir Justin,” Dharin said once breakfast began.
“Is this the strength of those from their world?”
“No,” Sammy replied quickly.
“I am normal when it comes to magic.
Justin and Chloe were recognized by the Arkhon, so it’s understandable that they would be different.”
“That does not mean anything,” Ceil said.
“I am supposedly special according to him, but my skill in life magic is laughable.”
“You are the empress.
That makes you plenty special,” Sammy retorted.
“You are blessed to have such companions,” Dharin said.
“You should treasure them.”
Sammy drew closer to Justin and squeezed the arm she clung to.
Justin turned to her and smiled, confused by the sudden affection being unable to understand the conversation.
Sammy smiled back and rested her head on his shoulder.
Ceil watched the exchange quizzically.
“Sammy, have you spoken with him about your misunderstandings in the past,” she asked in the fairy language so Justin could not understand the conversation even with his limited knowledge of elven.
“No…” Sammy nervously rolled a hard, winter berry under her forefinger on the table.
“Not yet.”
“You never know what could happen in war.
Should the worst come to pass, you do not want anything left unsaid, for both your sakes.
Take what happened yesterday as a sign that you cannot wait any longer.”
Sammy had countless moments when she could have asked, but she was scared.
She knew Justin for nearly a year in what she felt was a trusting and loving relationship.
If after all that time he could not tell her no matter how often she pleaded, why would he suddenly open up to her now?
And there were some things that people wanted to keep secret even from those they love most.
Especially from those they love most.
Whatever Justin could be hiding might be something he feared would change how Sammy felt about him, and the more he cared for her, the more he would want that secret to remain hidden.
She did not know if this was the case, but she could at least make the commitment now that no matter what she heard, she would accept it and not judge Justin because of it.
“I’ll speak with him tonight,” Sammy said.
“Before that, in the evening, can I talk with you and Tyree in the garden?”
“Of course, if the city is not attacked by then,” Ceil replied.

* * *
Sammy sat next to Ceil on a stone bench in a corner of Dharin’s garden.
The only others present were Tyree and Lemi, who now spent all her time in the garden instead of going inside.
She asked if she could be a part of whatever they were discussing, and Sammy saw no reason to deny her.
The other Melians were absent, each one caring for a field in one of the other manors.
Tae remained due to her job as Tyree’s caretaker, but she excused herself, not wanting to intrude on the private conversation.

Sammy felt a bit embarrassed, but those present were the only people she could ask, at least comfortably, Ceil because she was Sammy’s friend, and Tyree because she was essentially Justin’s doctor and a specialist in life magic.
“Ceil and Lemi kind of know the situation between Justin and me,” Sammy began, speaking to Tyree to quickly fill her in.
“We were a couple in the past, but that ended when I tried to have sex with him.
He rejected me, and our relationship fell apart after that.
I never found out why, but I’m going to ask him tonight.”
Sammy took a deep breath to both calm down and mentally prepare.
“I plan on going all out, and if things work out, I was wondering… Does your world have any contraceptives or contraceptive magic?”
Lemi grew confused by the question, and Tyree gave no reaction.
Ceil sighed and shook her head.
Sammy almost thought that was her answer, that there were none.
“Is that what you called us together to ask?
You could have asked me this morning during breakfast,” Ceil said.
“This is not a topic that should be brought up while eating together with everyone.
What would Dharin have thought?”
“No one would have found issue with it.
I do not doubt Dharin would have been delighted to answer any questions you had.”

“Such desires become even more commonplace before any major battle,” Tyree explained, “and I do not doubt that should the city survive, many children will be born before the change of the season, even between those without any prior relationship.”
“To answer your question, yes, there is contraceptive magic,” Ceil replied.
“I can perform it for you whenever you need.”
Sammy sighed in relief, making Ceil mildly annoyed in return.
“Was that really such a big worry?
You love Justin.
It is not like you are being forced into such acts with someone you dislike.”
“That’s not the point.
We are going to be involved in a lot of fighting and whatever is going to happen in the future, right?
Getting pregnant during a war would be bad.”
“You don’t need to be involved in any of it, Sammy.
If you want to start a family, you can.
Since you are not important to what is coming, that may be the better option for you.”
“No way.
I’m staying involved as long as Justin and Chloe are.”
Ceil shook her head once more.
“Fine, fine.
Just come to me afterwards if you want it done.”
She stood and walked back to the manor without another word.
Sammy knew that Ceil wanted to end Sammy’s involvement because she cared about her, but she could not deny that she felt slightly annoyed by Ceil’s attitude.
There was one more question Sammy wanted to ask, and this was the main reason she wanted Tyree present.
“Is Justin healthy enough for sex now?”
“What do you mean?
Even in the condition he arrived, he could have done his part.
When producing offspring, the male body is able to allocate sufficient resources for the task even if a moment from death.”
That’s not what I mean, Sammy wanted to say, but she knew Tyree understood.
Justin was still thin and lacked stamina, and he was recently injured.
She wanted to know if anything she did could hurt him.
“You have no need to worry,” Tyree said to put Sammy’s worries to rest.
“I’ll send Justin out here for his evening checkup.
When you are done, can you tell him to see me in our room?”
“I will.”
“Thank you.”
Sammy stood and stretched to loosen up from sitting hunched.
When she passed through the gate, Lemi ran after her and pulled her by the arm to the garden on the other side of the walkway out of earshot of Tyree.
“Sammy,” Lemi began sheepishly.
There was guilt in her countenance, and Sammy knew that a confession would soon follow.
“Is being pregnant during a war really that bad?”
Sammy looked Lemi in the eyes.
“Lemi… are you?”
Lemi grabbed Sammy’s hand and used it to brush the side of her hair.
Countless tiny petals fell like drifting snow knocked loose from a heavy-laden branch.
Lemi watched them fall in surprise herself.
“Since when?
When did you find out?”
Lemi hesitated, and her lips quickly dried from nerves.
“I found out when I checked in Melia.
I lied.
I wanted to go with you no matter what.
I’m sorry…”
Sammy pulled Lemi in and hugged her.
She wanted to tell her how angry she was that she lied about something so important, but she couldn’t.
It felt wrong.
She separated from Lemi and placed her hand gently on the girl’s stomach.
“Congratulations,” she said with a warm and loving smile.
Tears welled in Lemi’s eyes, and a wide toothy smile grew across her face.
This was a joyous time for any anthousai, and Lemi had to stifle her joy in secret because no one was supposed to know.
She wrapped her arms around Sammy’s neck and spun in circles with giggling laughter.
“What are you going to do,” Sammy said once the spinning ended.
“I’m staying with you.
I’ll figure something out.
I’ll make it work.
I promise!”
“You are going to have to tell Ceil and everyone else.”
“Can I wait until after the battle is over?”
“Yah.
I’ll keep it a secret too.”
“Our secret!”
Lemi pranced in a circle around Sammy.
She then grabbed Sammy’s shoulders from behind and pushed her towards the walkway.
“Go see Justin.
We can be mothers together!”
“Say it so loud and everyone will hear.
No more wine, okay?”
“Okay!”
Sammy turned and gave Lemi one more hug before leaving the garden.

Sammy sent Justin to meet Tyree in the garden for his checkup, something that he felt he no longer needed but Sammy continued insisting upon, especially now that he had to wear armor and carry a heavy shield to protect Ceil.
His muscles were still in a state of atrophy compared to how he was before they found themselves in Whinhlem.
She rushed up the spiral staircase to her room.
Coby was perched sleeping by the window, so she woke him and asked that he rest in Lemi’s room instead, just for tonight.
He cried in protest but hopped to the room across the hall.
Now alone, Sammy grew nervous.

She could not think how to bridge the topic of their past or even ask that he be with her for the night, not as they had every night but in the most intimate of meanings, something she had yearned for desperately for such a long time.
All she knew was that she should not repeat how she acted the night Justin walked out on her in anger.
No assertion.
No aggression.
She laid out the bed mats as she did every evening and wrapped the blanket around her, her clothes stashed in the corner of the room out of sight.
There she sat in the center of her mat and waited.
Each minute her anxiety built until she could no longer stop her shoulders from shaking.
Am I making a mistake?
This could ruin the relationship I managed to rebuild with Justin.
The moment Sammy’s anxiety grew unbearable and she was about to abandon her plan in order to preserve what affection Justin now showed her, Justin entered the room.
He took one look at Sammy’s hunkered, almost crying frame with their blanket pulled close over her shoulders and closed the door.
“Are you okay,” Justin asked as he sat down in front of her.
“Tyree said you have something important you want to talk with me about.”
Sammy’s mind fell in a state of panic.
In all her anxious waiting she had not thought of how to initiate the conversation.
She could easily pass it off as nothing, and say that it was not that important anyway, but then again, Justin would never accept that after seeing her so troubled.
Her mind spun in a tumult to think of anything to say, but nothing felt right.
All the while Justin sat patiently waiting for Sammy to speak first.
In the end, she fell upon one question, unsure if it was the right one, but it was all she had.
“When… when I broke up with you, I saw how much it hurt you.
Why didn’t you try to stop me?
You never tried to convince me to stay.
Not a single word.
You accepted it too quickly.
Why?”
Justin’s gaze lowered to the space between them.
“So, this is it,” Justin’s expression was saying.
Sammy was opening old wounds that she was sure Justin wanted to forget.
“It was because I loved you,” he answered.
Sammy’s breath caught.
Her jaw quivered, but she managed to speak.
“If you loved me, you should have stopped me.
I didn’t want to do it!
I thought there was something wrong with me that you didn’t like.
I thought you hated me after what I did that one night…
When you didn’t try to stop me, I thought you really did hate me.”
Justin took a slow and deep breath.
“I had given up on relationships before I met you, but you were so adamant about it that I decided to give myself one last chance, and I was ready to do everything I could to make it work.
The more time I spent with you, the more I grew to love you.
You are amazing, you know that?
You are strong-willed, intelligent, incredibly caring.”
Sammy listened intently, not wanting to miss a single syllable.
This was the first time Justin had ever opened up to her.
Over their entire year of dating, he never talked about his feelings, and he rarely talked about himself.
He showed how he felt through his actions and how he treated her, but that was all.
“The more I realized my feelings, the more scared I became,” Justin continued.
“Scared?”
“That night you mentioned, when you tried to urge me into sex, I was not mad at you.
I was angry at myself for not telling you the truth about me.
I was too terrified to tell you, but I knew that if I didn’t, I would eventually give in to my feelings for you and hurt you.”
Now Sammy was scared.
“What do you mean?”
“At the diner back in Gullivan you once asked about my past relationships.
My first time was when I was twelve.
She was fourteen.
We were just some stupid kids experimenting with love, but immediately afterwards she got terribly sick.
The truth came out, and a feud grew between our two families.
My parents ended up having to help pay for her doctor’s visits, but as far as I know, she never recovered and remained bedridden most of her life.
“My second girlfriend was in high school.
I was stupid then too, and just like before, she immediately grew ill.
Worse, she also got pregnant.
My parents berated me because we went through the same ordeal all over again.
She miscarried near the end of her first trimester, and two days later she passed away.
Her family found out that something similar happened with me before and they sued because they thought I slept with their daughter knowing this could happen.
Medical professionals and researchers got involved to try to figure out why this was happening, but no one ever could.
I don’t have any known STDs.
I am sure there’s a medical journal or two written about me floating around somewhere.
I never brought you to meet my parents because I have been estranged from them after everything that has happened.”
Sammy now understood Justin’s aversion to sex.
He had some unknown disease that was potentially lethal.

Sammy wanted to ask him why he never told her, that she could have been in danger, but she had to remind herself that she would not judge him no matter the truth she heard, although she never expected the truth to be something so severe.
“When I got into college, I met another girl, and we started dating.
I told her immediately that I wouldn’t have sex, and she was fine with that, but eventually she wanted to know why.
When I told her, she broke up with me immediately and never spoke to me again.
When I got to know another girl and we started talking about dating, I was up front about my condition.
She not only broke all connection to me, she accused me of trying to kill her.”
“That’s terrible!”
“That happened the day before I met you.
Can you tell me honestly that you would not have done the same if I told you from the beginning?”
Sammy could not answer.
Justin refrained from looking at her, but she could see the guilt eating away at him.
“I never meant to lead you on.
You positively glowed.
I could see that you loved me more than anyone ever had.
I hoped that maybe, just maybe, you would be the one.
When I walked out angry at myself for not telling you, for nearly putting you in that same danger, I decided then that I had to tell you the truth, and if you still loved me afterwards…
I took extra jobs because I was saving for a ring.”
Tears flowed from Sammy’s eyes, and guilt twisted her stomach in knots.
You were… propose…
Sammy mouthed the words her heart ached too much to ask.
She loved Justin terribly, which was what made his reservation and silence near the end of their relationship so unbearable.
While she was spiraling into depression from the unknown, he was agonizing over revealing what he feared was a relationship-ending secret.
“I was going to tell you once I bought it, but when you broke up with me, I felt that choice was safer for you, so I let you go.”
Sammy reached out a bare arm from under the blanket and grabbed Justin’s robe.
She pulled herself, blanket and all, on top of him and knocked him back onto the mat.
“You dumbass,” she screamed through tears with her arms wrapped around him.
“I’m sorry, so sorry.”
She could not judge him.
She knew she could never understand what pain he had gone through after experiencing what he did, after accidently killing someone and then fearing that he might do the same to her.
Ceil was wrong.
Justin was not at fault.
No one was.
Justin embraced Sammy and rubbed her back while she cried.
“That’s why I can’t do this tonight or ever.
I don’t want to hurt you.”
Sammy stifled her cries.
Justin had realized her goal.
He possibly knew the moment he saw her bundled in a blanket.
She knew he was not so dense.
She looked into his warm and understanding gaze so full of love for her that it made her chest burn.
“We could ask Tyree.
We might at least be able to find out why it happens.”
Justin’s expression darkened with guilt and some unspoken, hidden pain.
“I know why.
After it happened to… to Eydis… I realized it’s because of my toxic ven.
Ven transfers between partners through sex.
I somehow have a resistance to it until it builds up and causes my migraines, but my ven overwhelms others and hurts them.
She couldn’t even use magic afterwards.”
Sammy sat back on Justin’s legs and covered her mouth in shock.
Eydis’s sickly appearance in the hospital was not from battle with a life mage as Justin had told her.
It was because of him.
If she was unable to use magic, then she was unable to heal herself.
No wonder Justin felt so guilty over what happened and would never leave her bedside.
He might have thought that it would be safe with someone who could use life magic, that Eydis was his last and only chance for a loving, intimate relationship.
“Wasn’t she removing your toxic ven,” Sammy asked, still partially in denial over Justin’s explanation.
“After she disappeared, we stopped, so it built up again.”
Sammy’s eyes widened, and her chest warmed.
There was a way.
“If there was someone else who could use life magic…”
She got off of Justin and pulled him to sit up.
She took a deep breath and spoke with all seriousness.
“You have spent so long fearing you will hurt someone you love.
You can’t continue living like that.
I couldn’t bear seeing you suffer.
I love you, more than anything in the world.
I did when we were together, and I still do now…
I love you even more than I did back then…”
“Sammy, we can’t,” Justin pleaded.
“I don’t want you to be controlled by fear anymore.
I can fix this.
I want you to trust me.
Can you?”
Fear spread across Justin’s face, so Sammy slowly crawled over and brought her face close, placing her hand gently on his cheek as if consoling a child.
“Trust me,” she said before kissing him.
When their lips separated, she looked deeply and lovingly into the terror of his eyes.
Their silent and still exchange continued, giving Justin all the time he needed to sort through his worries and fears.
Sammy waited.
No force.
No aggression.
Not a single word to urge his decision.
The choice was his to make, and if he refused, she would continue loving him, even more than she ever had in the past, because more than anything, Justin was deserving of love.
Justin consented.
He was shaking, so Sammy promised that she would envelope him in so much love that it would drown out his fears.
She wanted him to enjoy this moment, and more importantly, she wanted him to feel free to enjoy many similar moments in the future, no longer imprisoned by his fears or past.
“Let me take care of everything.”

* * *
Sammy awoke in the middle of the night in full body pain worse than the height of a terrible flu.
She had never felt so ill in her entire life, and for a moment, a terrifying worry entered her mind.
What if this was permanent?
One girl never recovered.
Another died.
Eydis was unconscious and bedridden in the hospital unable to use life magic.
Sammy turned to look at Justin beside her.
He was sleeping peacefully.
She was doing this for him.
She told him to trust her.
She absolutely could not let him see her in this state.
Little by little she slid out from under the blanket and crawled out of the room, lacking the strength to stand.
Her muscles screamed with every motion, and she fought to suppress her cries.
Once in front of Ceil’s door, she wondered if she even had the strength to reach up for the latch.
Coby hopped over the cold floor and pulled down the latch with his beak.
He clamped his beak in worry, so Sammy thanked him and assured him that she would be fine.
“Ceil, wake up. Please.”
Sammy shook Ceil’s shoulders until her friend awoke with a start.
“Sammy?” Ceil pulled Sammy closer.
“You have a high fever.
What happened?”
“Tyree, quickly.”
Ceil rushed out of the room leaving Sammy sprawled out exhausted on her bed mat.
She returned in haste with Tyree leaning on her shoulder.
“What happened,” Ceil asked again.
“Ven poisoning,” Sammy replied.
“I hope.”
Tyree’s eyes narrowed.
“I should have known this would happen.
Sorry for not realizing it sooner.”
“Someone please explain,” Ceil pleaded.
“Justin produces toxic ven,” Tyree elaborated.
“Ven levels equalize between partners during intercourse, and Justin has such abundance that Sammy, whose capacity is miniscule in comparison, would end up taking most of it.
The surplus of healthy ven would disperse, but the toxic ven would remain, unable to escape.”
She placed her hand on Sammy’s forehead.
“She has no healthy ven in her.
It is all toxic.”
Hearing this, Sammy laughed.
“What are you laughing for,” Ceil scolded, trying not to yell.
“This is a deadly condition.”
“This is exactly what I was hoping would happen,” Sammy said.
“You wanted this?”
Ceil could not have looked more dumbfounded.
“I wanted to show Justin that this is something that could be fixed.
Tyree, can you remove it?”
“I can, but it will hurt,” Tyree warned.
“Can you numb me or knock me out first?
Eydis used to do that for Justin when she removed it daily.”
Tyree shook her head.
“No, with how much stress your body is under, if I did that, your body could succumb and die.
It is far safer for you to stay conscious through the pain.
I can go slowly to make it less painful.
Your capacity is low, so it should only take a moment.”
Ceil grabbed her bind and wadded it up.
“Bite on this.”
Sammy did as instructed and mentally prepared.
Tyree placed her hand on Sammy’s forehead, and all at once Sammy’s body was wracked with excruciating pain starting from her head and spreading throughout her extremities.
She writhed, but Ceil held her fast.
This is for Justin, she reminded herself.
Sammy spat out the wad of fabric.
“Wait,” she cried silently with an agonized, high pitched squeal.
“Leave a little behind.”
“You cannot be serious,” Ceil complained.
The pain slowly subsided followed by the onset of a deathly chill and then warmth.
Sammy was sweating profusely, but the feeling of relaxation after such a traumatizing ordeal was heavenly and almost made Sammy laugh.
“I left a little as requested and replaced your missing ven with mine,” Tyree explained
“Why keep some?” Ceil demanded an answer.
“I’m going to investigate it during my meditation.
Maybe I will learn something that can help Justin.”
“I agree with letting a little remain,” Tyree said.
“When she learns to expel it on her own, she will not need a life mage to aid her should she choose to continue her relationship with Justin.”
“That is absurd.”
Ceil sat back, bewildered by her friend’s commitment to such a troublesome man.
“Justin should be expelling his own first before you even consider doing this again.”
“He can’t,” Sammy replied outright.
“He is unable to control his ven.
He can’t even feel it.
Eydis was trying to teach him how to do it, but he’s never been successful.
She was always at a loss over what to do.
She always removed the toxic ven for him.”
Ceil shook her head slowly, giving up.
“For now, I will expel Justin’s toxic ven during his daily examinations.
That should make sex safer for you for the time being,” Tyree said.
“Speaking of safety,” Sammy said with a smile, finally feeling the satisfaction that should have immediately followed her evening with Justin, “can you use the contraceptive magic?”
“I did promise.”
Ceil paced her hand over Sammy’s lower abdomen, and after a light prick internally that felt no different than being poked by a few needles, she finished.
Sammy hugged both Ceil and Tyree, thanking them for their help and apologizing for waking them.
She left Ceil’s room with Coby hopping close behind and entered her own room, pure elation bubbling within her.
Unable to contain her excitement, she dove back onto the bed and crawled on top of Justin.
He awoke with a weary gaze, and met Sammy’s smiling eyes.
“Sammy?”
Sammy kissed him passionately and then rested her cheek on his chest.
“See?
I told you everything would be okay.”

Chapter 18
“Walking Forests”
Salim walked away from the funeral pyre with weary steps.
As captain of the guard, somehow the management of the refugee camp just beyond his gatehouse fell under his jurisdiction.
That also meant the disposal of the deceased from the camp was his duty.
It was a miserable and thankless job, and he feared that the smell of burning flesh would never leave his nostrils.
As the camp became less crowded, the deaths became less frequent, but there were still about ten a day.
His only solace was that he had others who stripped the corpses and prepared them for cremation.
He only needed to light the fires and observe them for ceremonial purposes until the corpses were consumed.
He dreaded the day when he would be required to pull a body mistaken for dead from the flames.
A life mage was among those he assigned to prepare the dead, so it shouldn’t happen, but given the number of dead he burned each day, it was bound to happen at least once.
His eyes followed the billowing smoke barely visible in the dark, cloudy night as he climbed the long stairway to the wall walk.
He wanted to sleep, but his shift was not over and would not be over until midnight when his second in command would arrive to relieve him.
He could then hide away in the cramped guard house insulated by thick stone from the haunting noises of the refugee camp and hopefully sleep until sunrise.
The soldiers on the wall walk gazed at Salim with eyes just as weary as his.
All but a few were conscripted refugees with no more than a few days of combat training.

At first, they were glad not to be stationed on the east wall staring down the enemy camp in the distance, but after the disastrous meeting of commanders, the south wall became the most dangerous station.
Enemies hid among the trees, snipers employing wind magic to imbue their arrows with lethal power.
The arrows of wind archers ignored the breeze and were carried at many times the speed of normal arrows until the stored wind energy dissipated.
A skilled sniper could hit their target so long as there was a direct path.
The more skilled among them could even control the path of the arrow to hit targets around obstacles at the cost of some of the arrow’s penetrating power.

Salim had two wind archers of his own on the south wall, but they could never see the enemy snipers through the forest canopy at night when the attacks usually occurred, whereas his soldiers were practically stationary targets atop the fire-lit walls.

At least the fairies were able to hide behind the merlons built with small fairy stature in mind; however, this meant that the elves were often unable to fully conceal themselves, making them the common casualty of the enemy harassment.
Lord Olvor should have considered the other races when he ordered that the wall be elevated.
“It’s going to happen again.”
“It’s about the time.”
“Please not me…”
The whispers of the soldiers Salim could hear as he passed showed the low state of the morale of the south wall.
He heard that the enemy currently lacked the forces to assault the walls, but their psychological tactics were certainly effective.
“Commander!
Movement from the forest!” One of the Forest Elves under Salim’s command waved him over.
Their improved night vision made them indispensable spotters.
“Just off the road before the bend,” the Forest Elf elaborated when Salim neared.
The other soldiers hunkered down with a few daring to peek from the embrasures.
“Too far for arrow fire… but a wind archer could still manage.
Can you hit them?”
“Perhaps.”
The Forest Elf drew his bow, and near invisible wind energy enveloped the arrow.
“Hold your fire,” Salim ordered.
Something fell out of the forest onto the roadside, or perhaps it was thrown out of the forest.
The Forest Elf lowered his bow when a figure walked out and grabbed the limp body.
“That’s a Forest Elf,” he replied.
A second figure appeared on the road dragging another body.
The two Forest Elves were not armored.
They wore simple fur vests and knee-length trousers.
They were hunters, but what purpose would hunters have to come to a city under siege?
How did they sneak past the tight patrols of the scouting parties circling the city?
The eldest Forest Elf tossed the corpse of the human archer before the wall.
“My name is Debin.
We come from Melia with urgent news for your Thorn General.”
“Lower the ropes,” Salim ordered. “Quickly!”

* * *
Dharin was awoken by the loud rapping of his bedroom door.
“Thorn General!”
He threw off his blanket and ran to the soldier.
“Is it an attack?”
One by one his guests peaked out of their rooms with worry spread across their faces.
“No, sir.
An emergency council has been called to session by the Captain of the Guard.
A messenger from Melia has arrived with grave news.”
“Inform Salim I will be there immediately.”
“Yes sir.”
The soldier saluted and ran down the spiral staircase.
“Ceil, will you join us,” Dharin asked.
“Certainly.” Ceil disappeared back into her room to prepare.
Dharin threw on his robe and looped his long ponytail behind his head.
Kiri was ready just after him with Ceil following close behind.
“Should we come too,” Sammy asked.
“We alone are fine,” Ceil answered for Dharin.
“I will inform you afterwards.”
Dharin rushed out of the manor and to the temple a tier higher in the middle of the central district.
Several council members and nobles were slowly filtering in through the corridor to the inner sanctum.
Behind the table stood Salim and two Forest Elves, one elderly and the second much younger and with heavy burn scars covering his chest and arms.
“I know them,” Ceil said to Dharin as they neared the inner sanctum.
“They live in the central Melian village where the hamadryad resides.
They saved Chloe from Captain Byurk’s soldiers.
Their message should be trusted.”
“Understood,” Dharin replied.
The two Forest Elves noticed Ceil and bowed deeply.
She took her seat and raised her hand to signal that they could relax.
Once the remaining council members wandered in, some with far less urgency than Dharin would have expected for a city under siege, the emergency meeting began, and Salim stood to address the council.
