“I called this meeting to discuss the message brought to us by Debin and Benab.
They originally fled Vallen ahead of the campaign but returned to us from Melia bearing ominous news.
The hamadryad who supported Empress Ceil and controlled northern Dhuillir is dead, and a large army from Amel is approaching.”
Dharin heard a small gasp from Ceil’s seat beside him.
Indeed, this was terrible news.
Frantic whispers grew from around the table, and Dharin raised his hand to silence them.
“Debin, your full report, please,” he said.
Salim stepped back to let Debin take his place.
“We received word that an army from Amel was marching through Dhuillir conscripting dryads not loyal to the hamadryad.
The hamadryad ordered all who were able to gather in Melia to stop the rapidly growing army from passing into Vallen.
This included the three warrior tribes.
About eleven days ago, the hamadryad’s army did battle against the forces of Tolmyur, and victory was assured, but we learned the kissiae had left the protection of Elos to meet with the hamadryad.

When the kissiae matriarch could not convince the hamadryad to change sides against our Empress and her companions, she used the connection of the hamadryad to incapacitate all dryads under her influence, slowly killing the hamadryad in the process.
The forces of Tolmyur eliminated our army.
The kissiae have joined Tolmyur, bringing along every able-bodied dryad they passed on their way from Elos to Melia.”
“This is absurd,” one council member spoke, and even Dharin felt that such a chain of events was hard to believe.
The kissiae never left Elos because they had spent the past thousands of years in isolation trying to regrow their population from the brink of extinction.

Dharin already informed the council of the kissiae’s involvement that Ceil had learned from a sprite, but without any other evidence than the sprite’s word, there were few on the council who believed.
Also, the thought that a regular dryad, even a kissiae, could overpower a hamadryad was just as absurd.
“I can add validity to Debin’s story,” Ceil said, silencing the whispers of the counsel.
“Eleven days matches the time one of my companions, a Melian under the hamadryad’s influence, was caught with a terrible disease that left her bedridden for two days.”
“What of the Melians working our grounds?” one of the council asked.
“They came from a new village that had not learned of the hamadryad’s existence and so were not under her influence.
Lemi was the only one affected.”
“Our Empress informed me that she knew these two Forrest Elves from Melia and that we should trust any news they carry,” Dharin explained in an attempt to satisfy the doubting eyes of the council.
“How large is the approaching army?”
“Of Tolmyur, possibly 40 or 50 thousand.
Of the dryads, too many to estimate, many times more than the population of your city, refugees included,” Benab announced.
“They are making use of their dryads to move Tolmyur’s army quickly.
It was all we could do to stay ahead of them.
They will arrive on the morrow, by morning if not sooner.”
The entire room fell silent.
The minimum ratio of soldiers required to assault a fortified city was about two to one, but that was expecting heavy casualties on the attacking side.
If this army was as large as he said, they would far surpass those numbers.
The enemy had more than enough power to overtake the city.
The question then became what the kissiae, the strongest of all the dryads, would add to the battle.
“If I may be so bold,” Benab spoke up, catching the attention of the council.
“This is not a fight you can win.
There is little that can be done for your city, so I beg that you send Empress Ceil and her companions out of the city.
We can take them safely past the enemy patrols.”
“I refuse!” Ceil stood from her chair.
Her sudden refusal silenced the angry shouts that were about to erupt from the council.
“You witnessed the power of Chloe in Melia.
If you were here eight days ago, you would have witnessed an even grander display.
She alone could eliminate a hundred thousand dryads.
We can still survive this battle.”
Dharin’s heart sank when hearing his granddaughter speak of the destruction of her own former subjects, but this was war, and with the loss of the hamadryad, the dryads were now their enemy.
The fairies were truly alone in their struggle, and should they survive this battle, Ceil would have to rebuild her empire anew.
“You will not flee?” Debin asked with mournful eyes.
“No.
I will weather this storm with the fairies,” Ceil asserted.
The council exchanged expressions of awe.
Those who once berated Ceil and doubted her commitment to the war now glowed with praise for their empress.
“Long live Empress Ceil!”
“Praised be our Empress!”
Ceil watched the admiration in shock.
Dharin knew of her commitment and the pain that Ceil felt choosing against all ridicule to support a city whose leaders did not trust her.
This was the first great milestone in the creation of her new empire.
“Have you all gone mad,” Benab protested, but Debin placed his hand on his shoulder to silence him.
Benab brushed it off and spoke after a deep breath.
“I have stood with Lady Chloe on the shores of Ithsa.
If you are to send her to fight an army on her own, I will protect her with my life.”
Ithsa, the river of death in ancient Forest Elf religion--Dharin understood his meaning.
Those who stood on its shores together, who have tasted death together and survived, are soul-bound.
Benab will not leave Chloe’s side after such a declaration.
“She will not be alone, and thank you for your help.”
Ceil looked to Debin, and there was an unspoken conversation between their gazes, one of remorse and apology.
“We must hasten our preparations,” Dharin said.
“We are already far behind schedule.
The great battle may be upon us sooner than we think.”

* * *
Byurk stood in attention at the border of his camp as the support army from Amel arrived.
Those behind General Bregon were not humans, although at first appearance one might mistake them as such.
They were naiads, and upon the shoulders of some rode dryads no larger than he with long ivy hair that fell to the ground.

Byurk worried about General Bregon’s order to give full command to the kissiae, that the order might have been made through a kissiae’s infamous domination, but no kissiae clung to General Bregon that he could see.
A massive army of dryads appeared from the forests behind the naiads, outnumbering his army many to one.

Convincing such a large concourse of dryads who despised Tolmyur to join them in battle against former citizens of their empire and their empress should have been impossible, but the words of the hamadryad echoed in Byurk’s mind.
Age was authority in dryad tradition, and legends told of a kissiae older than the Amelian Empire.
If she preached their traditional customs now that the empire had fallen, the dryads would obey.
As the army neared, Byurk found the eldest of the kissiae sitting atop the naiad closest to General Bregon.
The longer he looked upon her, the more pressure he felt by her presence.
There was no doubt in his mind.
She was a kissiae that predated the Amelian Empire’s fifty-thousand-year reign.
Byurk almost knelt out of reflex but managed a salute as General Bregon approached.
“General Bregon, thank you for heeding my request for aid.
You could not have come at a better time.”

“Captain Byurk, by your wisdom and planning in effort to preserve our hold in Amel and eliminate the widow of the emperor and her otherworld companions, you are hereby promoted to general, ratified by six of the eight generals stationed in Amel under our Commanding General Jethro.”
Byurk bowed, surprised by the sudden promotion.
He felt that ever since he encountered the widow, he had made one mistake after another.
“I am humbled and graciously accept.”
“General Byurk,” the kissiae matriarch spoke, causing the hairs on the back of Byurk’s neck to rise, “You and your soldiers will obey my orders in this battle.
I promise that most of your men will survive, but first, I must know all you know.”
The naiad approached and set the kissiae matriarch on the ground before Byurk.
His nerves told him to flee, but he was unable to move away from her overpowering presence.
She placed her hand on his forehead, and all his memories from the beginning of the Vallen campaign flooded his mind at impossible speeds.
He was left mentally exhausted and barely able to stand when she stepped back from him.
“I rescind my promise, General Byurk.
We may indeed have an arduous battle ahead of us.”
“Is the city that powerful,” General Bregon asked.
“Not the city or the elf-kin but those we are after, the trespassers you have led to this world.”
“My plan was to weaken the city through starvation and harassment,” Byurk explained.
“Even if they are powerful, their minds and bodies are still human.
Our chance of success will be far greater.”
“No.
The sprites have sided with the trespassers.
Should the situation grow dire, they may come to their aid.
No number of soldiers we bring could ever defeat them, and the only kissiae who could stand against them is not present.
Even if the sprites do not aid them, the longer we wait, the higher the possibility they may escape.
I will make preparations immediately.
Our attack will begin when finished.”

* * *
Salim trudged through the refugee camp with heavy steps.
The meeting he called dragged on into the early morning, and because he had called it to session, he was not allowed to leave until it finished.
They spent much of the time trying to plan countermeasures against the kissiae and the large army of dryads following them.

This led to an even longer discussion on how to best supply Lady Chloe with enough ven, prevent her from overheating, replenish the nutrients required for fire ven conversion, and protect her against an inevitable enemy counterattack because she would surely draw aggression immediately.
She was their most powerful weapon, and it was no stretch to say that if she fell quickly, so would the city.
The sun would rise in a few hours, so Salim hoped that his replacement would agree to cover for him longer so that he could sleep through the morning.
Night or day made no difference in the windowless guardhouse.
He only needed some quiet, but that did not appear to be possible.
The soldiers atop the wall were all awake and in a panic, immediately removing any hope Salim had of sleep.
He dashed up the steps to see the source of the commotion.
A low rumble vibrated through the stone and slowly grew louder.
An attack was the first thought on Salim’s mind, but what he saw from atop the wall was bewildering.
If it was an attack, it was not one of soldiers but of trees.
The forests in the distance gathered and approached, walking on their roots and collecting the trees in their path.
The mass of foliage grew larger and larger until it met the walls and bent around the city as if trying to absorb it.
The enemy had numerous dryads at their command.
They had the kissiae.
None of the soldiers on the wall had been informed about this yet.
This was an attack.
“To arms!
Sound the alarm!”
Horns blared across Revlan waking the city from its troubled sleep.
Red flares rose into the sky.
Soldiers gathered beyond capacity atop the outer and inner walls, and the refugees in the camp were evacuated to the inner city by weapon-point.
“Fire mages, burn the trees at first sign of enemy movement!”
As the fires atop the walls grew larger for better visibility in the dark, Salim saw the northern forest engulfing the city to meet the south.
Revlan was surrounded, and the thickness of the forests continued to grow around the city until no one could see where the forests ended in the dark.
Only the pyres of the enemy camp to the east remained visible, unchanging, as if it had no part in the amassing forests.
All at once the world grew still.
Every soldier watched the dark with bated breath fearing when the attack would begin.
The canopy of the trees was so full that when looking down from the wall they stood upon they could not see the ground.
The night was far too silent, and no one dared make any noise for fear of drowning out the sound of approaching boots or clanking weapons and armor.
“Something’s there,” a Forest Elf said as she stared into the dense canopy.
A winged fairy flew overhead and circled the forest.
A long spear many times his height was in hand, and he swiped at the canopy as he passed to catch glimpse of what hid underneath.
He immediately flew back to the walls.
“Dryads!”
The silent killers.
“Burn the trees!” Salim called, but those who heard him hesitated.
“The dryads have sided with Tolmyur!
Burn the trees!”
Before the first fireball could be thrown, the trees nearest the walls bent and contorted with the sound of snapping wood.
Their branches grew rapidly toward the wall and clung to the stone until they climbed high enough to reach the walk.
The trees behind clung to those before until the thickening branches weaved into a ramp from below the canopy across every stretch of the wall walk.
These were war ladders, and there were far too many to remove.
“Burn them!” Salim screamed as the first silent killers ran up the branches from below the canopy.

Chapter 19
“The Kissiae’s Targets”
“Lady Ceil, hurry.
We must take you to the inner sanctum,” Kiri called from the doorway of the manor.
“They will not reach the curtain wall so quickly.”
Ceil raised her arms to adjust the slack of her armor while Justin laced up the back so that the jack would not be too tight.
Thanysa relinquished the duty of Ceil’s armor to him because it was far easier to fasten.
Meanwhile Thanysa was busy attaching the many pieces of Justin’s leather armor to his arms and legs.
When finished, Kiri passed Justin his shield and led them down the manor walkway in a slow jog so Justin could keep pace.
They met Sammy and Chloe on the road surrounded by several soldiers and the two familiar Forest Elves.
“Please help protect the orphanage while I’m gone,” Chloe asked.
“I will,” Sammy replied.
“I hope you are not sending her to the outer wall,” Ceil said to Dharin.

Chloe’s position discussed in the meeting was on the east wall facing the enemy camp where she could preemptively attack any approaching enemies, but now that the attack had already begun, placing her on the outer wall was too dangerous.
“She will be atop a tower on the inner wall on the southeast side,” Dharin explained.
“The dryads are already attacking the outer wall in force all around the city.
We are holding them back for now.
Chloe should be able to attack over the outer wall from there, and any who make it past into the refugee camp will become open targets for her.”
Ceil eyed the large guard assigned to Chloe.
There were four winged fairies tasked with areal cover and evacuation should the wall be overrun.
Two High Elves were provided both for life magic and to transfer ven to her from her other guards, a number of fairies and elves whose ven capacities were quite high.
Each of them was also a water mage tasked with preventing Chloe from overheating.
Debin was a wind archer, so he and his son were tasked with taking out any enemies who could potentially attack Chloe from a distance.
Lastly, a single Mountain Elf even larger than Sarodyn and nearly as tall as the High Elves was selected for his skill in reinforcement magic.
He was adorned in plate armor to be Chloe’s shield.
The guard, far more powerful than what Ceil was ever provided, may have looked excessive, but Ceil knew that the city’s survival very much depended on Chloe’s magic.
“Remember Chloe, no massive attacks like before.
You will deal more damage with multiple smaller attacks.
Even your smaller attacks should be far more powerful than anything we or they could manage.”
Ceil reminded Chloe of Dharin’s advice after the meeting of commanders.
In large scale war, reserving one’s ven was vital for survival.
The moment one’s ven depleted, they would weaken and become easily killed.
Most magic used in large battles was weaker and used very little ven for this reason.
Chloe nodded, and Ceil reached over to hug her friend.
“Be safe.
Come back alive,” Ceil said.
“I will,” Chloe replied, rubbing Ceil’s back.
Despite Chloe’s assurance, Ceil was still worried.
Both times Chloe fought against enemy soldiers she had been injured.
Sammy hugged Ceil next.
“If something happens to me, take care of Justin for me.
Please?”
Ceil sighed.
“If Tolmyur succeeds in breaching all the way to the central district with enough forces to place you in danger, we are all dead anyway, including him.”
“We must hurry,” Kiri said again, urging everyone to move to their assigned tasks.
Dharin flew off to command his soldiers, and Sammy and Lemi ran for Lord Olvor’s manor.
Ceil followed Kiri up the steps to the temple grounds, pausing momentarily to watch Chloe and her guard run out the gate in the distance.
The entrances to the temple grounds were defended by royal guards as if advertising Ceil’s presence.
It was the center of the city behind another wall and portcullis that was now closing.
There were three steep stairways to the grounds that could be easily defended.
The temple itself was a sturdy stone structure that had survived from the ancient civilization and would not likely be destroyed from an attack.
The doors to the inner sanctum were crafted from thick and heavy wood and could be barred by four large beams on the inside.
The corridor past the door was long and would be difficult to assault if the soldiers holed themselves in.
In the fortress city of Revlan, the temple was a fortress all its own.
Ceil sat in the back of the sanctum next to Justin who stood with shield at the ready.
Kiri was also present sending and receiving messages through the single overworked spatial pixie.
The large council table was divided into its sections to be used as a barricade in the corridor, and no less than thirty elite soldiers stood with weapons drawn behind it.
The thick stone walls insulated the sanctuary from any noise outside.
Even the small sun holes were crafted with such acoustics that sound was muffled and could not reach the sanctum.
This was a room for prayer, meditation, and silence, but that also meant that Ceil had no way to know how the battle was progressing.
The messages being passed to Kiri were often written, and anything spoken was brief or in military code that Ceil did not understand.
“I hate not knowing what is happening,” she mumbled in English.
Justin turned to her with an assuring face shaded under the lip of his cowl.
She had not spoken in English to be comforted by him or to strike a conversation.
In all honesty, she was still uncomfortable being next to him.
Her resentment for him had not fully abated even though she knew it was unwarranted, especially after Justin saved her, but the silence was choking her nerves and drawing out her anxiety.
The soldiers would make terrible conversation partners, and Kiri was busy, so Justin was all she had, but what could she talk about?
Thinking topics over in the suffocating silence, there was something that she wanted to vent now that the fighting had begun.
“I want you to know that I am very angry at you and Sammy.”
“Angry?” Justin was taken aback by the sudden statement.
“Was it because of, well…”
“No. What you two choose to do together in private is none of my concern, and I am more than happy to help Sammy.
My anger lies elsewhere.
You and Sammy should have fled when I told you to.
You have no reason to be caught up in this battle.”
Justin smiled and shook his head.
“We do have a reason.
Sammy sees you as a friend, and though you don’t seem to like me much, I do as well.
You were very dear to Eydis, so of course we would stay and help.
I was already able to help you once, so I’m glad I stayed.”
Ceil glanced around at Kiri and the other soldiers.
She was speaking in English, so none of them could understand, but she was still worried one of them might, no matter how unlikely it would be.
“I am grateful to you for saving me, but I want you to promise me something.”
She turned to look into Justin’s eyes.
This was the first time she had ever done so, so Justin immediately caught on to the seriousness of her request.
“If it is something I can do.”
“Good.
If the temple is breached and you must make the choice to save me or save yourself, I want you to save yourself.”
Justin sighed.
“You know I can’t make that promise.”
His light dismissal of her earnest request twisted a knot in Ceil’s chest.
Anger welled within her that she could not keep from overflowing.
She pushed aside his shield and grabbed the front of his hardened leather armor.
“Do you have any idea why Sammy chose you to protect me?”
Justin grew nervous from the startled glances of the soldiers who watched their empress grow angry at the man charged with her protection.
He tried to motion Ceil to calm down, but she wouldn’t have it.
“Answer me.”
“Because I can’t do much else with my time magic.”
Ceil released Justin, completely flabbergasted by his lack of understanding.
“Look at where you are standing.
Look at the walls, the barricade, the soldiers, and the door.
Anywhere they would put me during the attack would be the safest place in the entire city.
Sammy charged you with my protection so that you would be safe!
I have no one waiting for me to return to them.
My death will be no major loss for anyone.
You have both Eydis and Sammy, two women with whom you can build a future together.
I do not know the full extent of your relationship with Eydis, but I do know how much Sammy loves you.
You never saw what anguish she endured fearing your death every day.
She would be devastated if anything happened to you.
She may mourn my death for a time, but she would never recover from yours.
If you must choose between saving my life and saving yours, I order you to abandon me.”
Justin frowned.
“No. Sammy and Eydis would never forgive me if I left you to die.
If you want to give an order, you can.
You are the empress.
The soldiers here will listen to anything you say.
If you want me to abandon you, order them to remove me from the temple.
If you can’t, I will stay and protect you.”
Justin’s refusal after all that Ceil said to help him understand how much he had to lose infuriated her.
She wanted to order the soldiers to remove him, but she couldn’t.
The doors were barred and would not be opened.

If she expressed any distrust in Justin or his ability to protect her, her order would only serve to have him moved to the forward barricade or bound, and in the event of an attack, his life would be in even greater danger.
Ceil swallowed her anger and relinquished herself to his protection, promising in silence that she would never stop hating him.

* * *
The broad-shouldered Mountain Elf led Chloe up the spiral stairway inside one of the inner wall’s towers.
In the circular room at the top of the steps, the exit to the wall walk was so crowded with frantic soldiers they were nearly falling into the stairwell.

A cacophony of shouts and cries echoed across the stone, and Chloe thought that the enemy had made it to the inner wall, but the armored Mountain Elf pushing the much smaller fairies aside did not appear to be preparing for combat.
The walls were simply that crowded.
Chloe followed close to his back so that she would not get separated from the important gap in the crowd he created with each assertive step.
The rest of her guard followed close behind, preventing the gap from closing.
“Where… um…Where stop,” Chloe asked loudly in broken Elven to be heard over the noise of the soldiers and combat that was not yet visible.
The Mountain Elf pointed upwards.
In the back of the small room of the tower, a lone ladder rose through an opening in the ceiling.
The legs of soldiers were visible in the flickering glow of the firelight atop the tower belvedere.
Chloe’s heart raced as the grip of fear repeatedly squeezed it in rapid succession.
She was sure she could manage standing atop the walls.
They were tall but not too tall, only about fifty feet, and there was a lip that would prevent her from falling.
Standing atop the tower was different.
It was smaller, and there was a drop on every side.
The only exit was a hole down a twenty-foot drop.
The Mountain Elf swiftly climbed the creaking wooden ladder in his heavy plate armor and waived his hand to urge Chloe to follow.
Chloe grabbed the rungs of the ladder and quickly scaled it with her eyes shut tight.
She did not know how close she was to the top, but she feared to open them until she could feel the stone floor beneath her feet.
Near to the top, large hands grabbed both her arms and lifted her through the opening to set her on solid ground.
A swift pat on her back forced her eyes open.
The belvedere looked like a stone gazebo with tall, pointed archways facing each of the eight cardinal directions.
A conical wood-lined roof sat atop the archways with even smaller arched windows.
A thin walkway circled the base of the ceiling where fairy archers knelt, firing arrows out the windows into the night.
Debin and Benab jumped up to grab hold of the walkway and swung up and out of the belvedere to stand above the windows on the roof for a less obstructed view.
Chloe feared for a moment that she would be placed up there in an even taller, far more precarious location, but the Mountain Elf nudged her forward to the east-facing archway.
The belvedere was far less crowded than the walls, and only archers and mages stood atop it.
Packing them in would benefit little if they could not be near the edge to fire upon the enemy.
The fairies quickly made room for Chloe after seeing who had approached behind them, but Chloe desperately wished they were still in front of her.
There was no low wall, no railing, nothing to prevent her from falling nearly eighty feet to her death.
In a moment of panic, she lunged to the side and clung to the nearest stone pillar supporting the roof.
“I can’t do this.
I can’t do it,” Chloe cried.
She felt terribly ashamed.
The thought of being personally involved in the battle and taking many lives did not scare her as much as this.
The battle should be far more harrowing, but what broke her spirit was her fear of heights.
She hated it.
She knew that this fear was unfounded.
There was no reason to be so terrified.
She knew it and tried to convince herself of it, but her mind and body reacted on its own by pure fearful instinct.
“I’m sorry,” Chloe said in Elven, unable to open her eyes.
A large hand rested gently on her shoulder.
“We are all scared,” the Mountain Elf replied in a soft tone, “but there is something we fear more, the loss of our loved ones in the city.”
“Look,” spoke a female voice from the direction Chloe knew was the open air.
Her eyes resisted, but she managed to peel them open long enough to see a woman floating in the air on translucent feathered wings that almost glowed in the night.
The fairy looked like an angel.
“We will protect you.”

The words of encouragement Chloe knew were being spoken for her benefit fell upon ears that could not understand them, but what Chloe realized after seeing the angelic fairy was that these guards would not let her fall.
She quite literally had guardian angels looking out for her, and that thought lit a faint spark of courage in her.
The fairy noticed the small spark in Chloe’s eyes and flew upwards.
Chloe’s world that had been restricted to the top of the tower because she so desperately wanted to ignore the heights outside the gazebo-like room now extended into the open air.
She saw the ongoing struggle atop the outer wall no more than twenty yards away and the immense forest beyond that had not existed before in her memory.
Each soldier raised a spear over the head of the one before them.
Fairies stood in the front near the crenellations, and the taller elves stood behind nearly leaning over the fairies.
Dryads climbed up every foot of wall in great numbers--most were weaponless or carried spears of their own--and impaled themselves on the fairies’ spears.
Chloe watched as each dryad was slowly torn apart by numerous and repeated punctures, and yet they still reached forward to kill with their touch.
Some of the dryads grew branches and roots from their spears to ensnare and kill the fairies blocking their entrance into the wall.
Those became immediate targets for fire magic, but they often could not be killed in time to spare the victims of the dryad’s deadly touch.
If not for the reach of the spears preventing most the dryads from coming close, the entire wall would have been overrun.
For every two or three mutilated or burning dryads that were flung overhead by the tips of the elves’ spears into the space between the walls, a fairy or elf fell to a dryad’s magic, spear, or arrow.
Like the dead dryads, the deceased among the soldiers were shifted back to be pushed unceremoniously down into the space between the walls to make room for more soldiers at the front.
In all the frantic carnage, Chloe could not see where she would be able to use her fire magic to help them.
The forest canopy glowed faintly from the fires lit atop the walls, but she could not see from what direction the dryads came.
A few of the trees were already burning, but that did not stop the dryads from climbing up the sloping branches to the wall.
Dharin and Ceil ordered her to use small fireballs strategically, but a little fire would never stop them.
With one arm wrapped around the stone, she conjured a fireball that dripped with viscous heat.
Her body trembled from the fear that throwing it would make her lose her balance and fall.
Her breaths grew short as her arm reached back, and with a scream, she flung her hand forward and loosed the ball.
It spat flames to propel it through the air safely over the soldiers’ desperate struggle on the outer wall and landed in the canopy another fifty yards past.
The explosion sent a glowing plume of fire into the air, almost blinding in the dark.
The heat washed over everyone atop the wall and even reached Chloe on her tower, feeling like a strong breeze.
Amid the cries of battle, Chloe heard shouts of praise and excitement.
Their ultimate weapon had arrived to repel the seemingly endless wave of dryads.
Chloe lit a second fireball and threw it near the first.
The third she threw just beside the second.
Each fireball and resulting explosion created a line of fire that began to ebb the wave of dryads approaching from that direction.
The few who made it through were either on fire or heavily burnt and too weak to assault those defending the wall.
After the fourth, Chloe felt the cold shivers of exhaustion.

She could only manage two of her largest before depleting her ven, and although she decreased the size, she could only create four of these fireballs, each one similar in destructive power to the one she used in the central Melian village.
A cold breeze enveloped Chloe’s radiating body from a fairy releasing frost from his hands.
She had not even realized that she was growing too hot to touch.
When her body temperature dropped, a High Elf placed his hand on her arm wrapped around the stone.
Clasped in his other hand was the arm of a different fairy.
Chloe felt warmth enter her arm and spread throughout her body, ending her shivers as her body filled with ven.
A confident smile grew on Chloe’s face.
She could do this.
She lit another fireball and continued lengthening her wall of fire.

* * *
“That is Chloe Hearn, third tower from the south.” Byurk’s words to the kissiae matriarch were relayed directly to one of the five kissiae hiding deep in the forest on the south side of the city.
“We located a trespasser,” she informed the awaiting naiads and Tolmyur soldiers.
The 44 kissiae were divided into ten groups and placed at the edge of the forest around the city.
The naiads who guarded them were likewise distributed as were the Tolmyur soldiers.
The goal of the dryad assault was not to overtake the outer wall, although if they could the battle would progress much quicker.
Using dryads as the sole initial attackers drew out the city’s most powerful fire mage, one of the kissiae’s targets.
The naiads led the march through the dense forest, parting the dryads fearfully awaiting their turn to throw themselves at the enemies atop the walls.
The nearest entrance was the main gatehouse blocked by a thick, metal-reinforced portcullis.

Trees were initially moved in front of the portcullis close enough for their trunks to touch to prevent those who may be in the tunnel from seeing the approaching dryads, but now the tree barrier served no purpose.
The kissiae placed her small hand on one of the trunks.
Branches grew out from the tightly packed barrier of trees and wrapped around the beams of the portcullis.
With one swift motion, the entire portcullis was ripped from the walls as if pulling a weed up from its roots, sending a shower of rock and stone from the broken wall.
The branches raised the portcullis above the entrance to the tunnel, and the trunks of the trees parted.
The terrified soldiers guarding the gatehouse tunnel watched naiads enter from between the trees with glimmering silver swords brandished in front of them.
Magic of fire, ice, wind, and stone flew at them, but the practiced arms of the naiads dispersed the magic before it could harm the archers following behind.
A barrage of arrows flooded the cramped tunnel without giving the soldiers anywhere to flee but back toward the city.
A fairy earth mage erected a wall to block passage.
Two dwarves charged through, pressing against the wall and forcing it back with their own earth magic.
Several earth mages joined them quickly, and the barrier that the enemy foolishly erected in fear became a protection for safe passage through the tunnel.
A thin string appeared from the wall of the tunnel and snagged the neck of one of the human earth mages.
Strong and woven from hair, it was sharp and slowly cut through the flesh of his neck.
“Oreads!”
The soldiers focused their attention on the sides of the tunnel and stopped moving the wall.
One of the dwarves placed his hand on the stone near the ensnared soldier, and after scanning it with earth magic, he struck it with his fist.
A horizontal fissure grew, and the soldier was released immediately.
Although nymphs could meld with their elements, their bodies were still present.
Oreads could be killed if the stone that held their bodies was severed so that one vital section of their body was completely separated from the other.
“She moved in time,” the dwarf announced.
“The split wasn’t perfect.”
“Keep moving,” the kissiae ordered.
The earth mages continued pushing the wall through the tunnel while the other soldiers and naiads watched the stone.
Another cord appeared, but a swift-handed giant grabbed it before it could snag a minum.
He tugged with his superior strength, and the hands that held the cord were severed immediately by a naiad’s blade the moment they appeared from the wall.
The oread cried in pain and retracted into the stone.
She could no longer harm them.
None attacked after the first oread was neutralized, but the soldiers kept watch.
Perhaps there was only one oread present at this entrance.
“Ready,” one of the dwarves called once the wall reached the end of the tunnel.
With a signal from the kissiae, the earth mages struck the wall, blowing it out as shrapnel into the courtyard.
Magic and arrows rained on the exit, but the dwarves and giants were ready with their shields and the naiads with their resfahil blades.
They flooded out into the courtyard trampling the Revlan soldiers caught in the rubble.
The soldiers in the courtyard were in disarray.
There was no rank or order to them.
“Conscripts!
Take them out!”
“The naiads will handle the courtyard,” the kissiae called.
“You soldiers take the walls.”
Most of the enemy on the wall walk was preoccupied trying to hold back the never-ending dryad onslaught, but there were a few who turned back to fire magic and arrows into the courtyard.
The giants led the assault up the steps, kicking aside and trampling the fairies who only stood as high as their thighs.
Their shields and plate armor repelled most spears and arrows, but even then, there was too little resistance.
The soldiers in the courtyard were not the only amateurs.
Many of those atop the wall were untrained as well.
One of the giants took an arrow through the helmet from a wind archer and fell back atop his fellow soldiers.
All they needed was to clear one section of wall, but a second well-placed arrow killed another giant.
“Target the wind bowman,” a minum screamed, and their archers fired a volley of arrows in the direction of the attack, not knowing from where the arrows came.
The cover fire stalled long enough for one last giant and three dwarves to reach the top of the steps.
One of the dwarves, a fire mage, imbued his hammer with flame, spreading glowing cracks through the metal.
Each strike exploded with sparks and metal shrapnel.
The giant threw every fairy and elf he could off the back of the wall onto his soldiers waiting below.
The remaining two dwarves impaled the enemy with stone spikes raised from the wall walk below their feet.
The resistance was breached.
Dryads now flooded over the wall and into the courtyard.
“Hurry and get us to the inner wall before the trespasser notices the dryads got in,” the kissiae ordered.

She and the other four kissiae jumped off their naiads’ shoulders and sprinted on all fours weaving through the enemy soldiers while the naiads killed those who tried to attack them to act as a distraction away from the small green bodies.
The reach of the spears were nothing against the parries of the trained naiads, and soon, the amateur soldiers forgot about the kissiae who did not attack.
All touched by the kissiae’s long ivy hair were injected with the toxin that made their minds more susceptible to influence.
A single command to attack the naiads was all they needed to divert attention.
The kissiae reached the tower and climbed as if their hands and feet adhered to the stone.
Their movement was swift and quiet, ignored by the pandemonium on the outer wall despite being in direct sight if any soldier so much as turned around.
Two of the kissiae split out to the sides towards the wall walk and hid under the machicolations near the tower.
Their ivy hair grew and spread across the wall, silently winding their rootlets into the boots and pant legs of all the soldiers near the tower.
The soldiers under the influence of the kissiae would not notice the remaining three who climbed past to the tower’s belvedere.
A massive fireball flew out over the topmost kissiae’s head towards the courtyard.
She turned her head and saw that all the city’s soldiers had been eliminated, and the courtyard was filling with dryads.
The few naiads were interspersed among the dryads to thwart any fire magic launched at them from the walls, but every face watched the approaching fireball in terror.
One naiad near the epicenter of impact threw her sword in desperation.
The resfahil blade spun through the air and collided with the flame, melting instantly and causing a premature detonation.
The fireball burst like a massive shower of sparks, only partially dispelled.
Each spark that fell detonated on contact with the ground, coating its surroundings in an oil-like flame that clung to the dryads, naiads, and few Tolmyur soldiers.
Their wailing death rows as they burned sounded over the roar of combat, followed shortly by the cheers of the city’s soldiers watching from the inner wall.
The kissiae climbed with renewed urgency.
They needed to reach the trespasser before she attacked again.
The first kissiae stopped just below the belvedere and sent her hair slithering up to seek out the trespasser.
The first boot she touched near the edge was a fairy, and after reading her mind, she found their target.
The trespasser clung to the easternmost pillar.
She relayed the message to her sister kissiae closer to the target.
That kissiae’s ivy hair crawled up and clung to the trespasser’s ankle and burnt off almost immediately, but that brief moment was enough.
I found the location of all the trespassers.
Three in total.
There is one with the widow in the temple and another at the city lord’s manor.
“Were you able to kill the fire mage?”
No.
She’s a flame-skin.
I could not hold on long enough.
“Dominate the soldiers atop the tower and use them to kill her before she escapes!”
The Mountain Elf pulled Chloe away from the edge the moment he noticed the strand of ivy grab her ankle.
The kissiae had arrived, and in such a brief moment, their damage had been done.
Chloe was unable to stand.
Her eyes, ears, and nose bled from some unknown internal trauma caused by the powerful dryad’s brief touch.
“Evacuate her quickly!
Take her to the Melian shaman!”
When ivy quickly filled the floor of the tower, the Mountain Elf realized the one weakness in their guard.
None of the guard assigned to Chloe were fire mages.
Fire mages were present on the tower, but none specifically tasked with Chloe’s watch and protection.
The few fire mages posted at the tower were dominated first and threw themselves off.
The Mountain Elf grabbed Chloe’s arm to lift her away from the rapidly spreading ivy and barely managed to pass her to two of the winged fairies before he felt an acute pain in his ankle.
He fought and resisted with all his might but was unable to stop the swing of his spear that struck down one of the winged fairies who shielded Chloe against the blow.
The single fairy was unable to carry the unnaturally heavy woman, but the two remaining winged fairies grabbed Chloe’s legs and pulled her swiftly from the tower.
The dominated mages and archers fired desperately at Chloe as the winged fairies dove down into the upper tiers of the city to make use of the buildings to avoid attack.
One of the fairies carrying Chloe shouted a desperate order into her ear as they dived and weaved to narrowly avoid the attacks from their allies that struck the innocent civilians below.
A single glowing orb formed in Chloe’s free hand, and it flew upwards towards the tower.

Well done, the Mountain Elf praised in his mind before the fireball detonated, covering the entire belvedere in liquid flame that ran down the sides of the tower, incinerating the three kissiae who clung to the stone.

Chapter 20
“The One Who Should Not Be Angered.”
“One… three?”
“Is something the matter,” Emer asked Keeya.
His mind was connected directly to her, so when she felt powerful emotion, those emotions often leaked into him.
Right now, he felt terror and confusion, the most powerful he had ever experienced from her.
“Bad.
This bad!” Keeya screamed.
“Three kissiae die.
Three sisters just die!”

Keeya activated her connection to all the kissiae that she had suppressed while in subjugation to Jethro as part of their agreement, but while she could feel their fear and anxiety, she could not find them.
They were too far away.
“We go Elos!”
Keeya took control of Emer and instantly activated a transmission spell to the Dhuillir wetlands, surprising him.

She had access to all his knowledge, so he expected her to be able to make use of spatial magic through him, but the speed at which she crafted the formula to take them to a destination Emer had never visited, meaning that she would have had to work out the destination coordinates on her own with little of his prior knowledge, was fascinating.
Emer appeared on the dark humid island, but Keeya moved him with haste as if she could see as clear as day.
Every tree she made Emer touch she scanned for signs of life on their branches.
Each tree found barren increased the worry Keeya felt until atop the grandest tree in the center of the island she found a single life, a kissiae child.
Keeya forced Emer to climb the tree using strength he did not know he had, but his muscles ached terribly once he reached the top.
“What happen?
Where everyone,” Keeya asked the young child who was possibly no more than a year old if she was elven.
The child cowered at the sight of Emer, so Keeya hunched him over to align her face with the child’s.
“What happen?”
“Keeya…?
I missed you.”
The small girl wrapped her arms around Keeya’s neck and cried.
There was no one here, and that isolation had to be terrifying for someone so young.
Keeya nuzzled the child’s cheek, unable to do anything else with her arms attached to Emer.
“Where everyone go,” Keeya asked once the child calmed down.
“Humans came, and everyone left.
I don’t know why.
They told me to stay.
I was too young.”
Emer recalled the dismembered dryads they discovered in one of the palace’s kitchens, or perhaps he remembered it because Keeya remembered.
The chefs were forced to discover methods of cooking dryad.
About that time a large army left Amel for Vallen, traveling through Dhuillir.
“This is bad,” Emer said, fearing the worst.
He felt anger well up in Keeya.
She made the same connection.
“We should speak with General Lamek.
He would know.”
Emer felt Keeya search his mind for the most probable location he would find General Lamek, but Emer did not know.
Aside from his interactions with Jethro, he knew nothing of the military affairs of the palace or where the officers resided.
It was very early morning, and the sun had yet to rise.
General Lamek would be sleeping, and Emer did not know which of the many rooms of the palace he was using.
“We ask soldiers!”
Another immediate transmission brought them to the central courtyard where soldiers were always posted, especially after Jethro’s emergency contact.
Keeya located the closest lieutenant and ensnared him in her ivy hair.
The soldiers gathered quickly with angry shouts and weapon’s drawn, but a barrier appeared around them.
Emer did not erect it.
Keeya did.
She was in full control of him now, all but his conscious mind.
He witnessed the event unfold like an out of body experience, like watching a skilled puppeteer in action through the puppet’s eyes.
Keeya’s hair dug under the soldier’s armor, and rootlets pierced his skin wherever they made contact.
Just as quickly as Keeya ensnared the terrified soldier, she released him.
A third immediate transmission brought Emer to a dark room.
From the appearance, it once belonged to one of the wives of Emperor Yuro.
“LAMEK!” Keeya screamed, but her voice was more than sound.
It permeated Emer’s mind and echoed what his ears heard.
The sensation made his head throb, and the agony was also felt by the dwarf writhing beneath the bedsheets.
General Lamek threw off his covers and eyed Emer with suspicion.
“What are you doing in my quarters,” he demanded to know, reaching for a blade at his bedside.
“What happened to kissiae?
Tell me!”
Once again Keeya’s voice caused General Lamek to reel, preventing him from grabbing his weapon.
After a wince and shake of his head, General Lamek glared at Keeya.
“I have no reason to speak to one of Jethro’s slaves, especially concerning military action.
Leave.”
“Tell me,” Keeya screamed.
Emer’s hand reached out, and not even he knew what magic Keeya threaten.
She had all natural elements at her disposal through him.
“You are under Commanding General Jethro’s orders not to harm any of the Generals.
Your rebellion will not go unpunished, dryad.
Jethro already bested you once.
Leave, and I will not inform him of your actions tonight.”
Keeya hesitated, but her anger burned stronger.
Kissiae have died.
Whatever bargain you made with Jethro is now void, Emer told Keeya through his thoughts.
Do what you must.
He cannot be angry with you if one of his subordinates broke the terms of your agreement.
That was all the persuasion Keeya required.
Emer dove at General Lamek, but Lamek was prepared with a powerful torrent of wind blasted out his hand.
The wind split harmlessly to the sides as if Emer was a wedge, and with a flick of Emer’s wrist, the extended arm severed at the shoulder.
Emer landed atop Lamek, and Keeya’s hair bound him.
She pumped him so full of her toxin that his skin ruptured and Keeya’s long ivy hair wilted.
His eyes rolled back, his mind broken from overdose.
Emer expected Keeya to find answers, but the longer Keeya bound him, the greater her unbridled rage grew.
The ivy vines tightened as the cracking of bones grew louder until Keeya shredded the body apart in a spray of gore.
What did you find, Emer asked, afraid of the answer after witnessing the brutal execution.
“He not know,” Keeya replied, seething.
“General Bregon going to Vallen, capture or kill and eat dryads on way.
Maybe capture and kill kissiae…”
But the kissiae are powerful.
Wouldn’t they be able to stop them?
“No, they join soldiers.
Kissiae afraid of Jethro.
Jethro defeat me.
Fire dryad weakness, but spatial magic greater weakness.
Jethro trap me in barrier before I attack.
If I cannot touch, I cannot attack.
He threaten to kill all kissiae if I not help him.
If I help, he promise to protect kissiae, like past Emper…”
Keeya fell silent.
Keeya?
“No!
Two more dead!
Three!
Why?
Why this happen?!”
We must go to Vallen.
The campaign should be in northwestern Vallen by now.
Emer thought of a location, one of the smaller villages on the flatlands, and Keeya teleported them there.
The village square was barren, and decomposing corpses littered the ground around buildings that lay in blackened heaps.
Keeya paid no mind to the destruction.
Now that she was closer, she sent out a mental communication.
“Kanazee!”
“Keeya?
Are you in Vallen?
We have an emergency.
Trespassers from another world are in Revlan.
I have taken control of Tolmyur’s armies to eliminate them.
We need your help.”
“You…?”
Emer could feel shock and betrayal seep from Keeya’s emotions.
“You do this?
Kissiae die…”
“Only a few of us.
We have broken through the southeast gatehouse as well as the western and norther walls.
The dangerous part is past for most of us, but they still have a powerful fire mage and a time mage.
We will need your assistance eliminating them.”
“No! Kissiae die!
You let kissiae die!”
Emer felt physical pain through Keeya’s sorrow.
“Just now… another kissiae die.
Why you do this?!
Very few of us left!”
“If our recovery is set back a few thousand years, it is better than inciting Gyea’s wrath for letting trespassers walk among us.
Such would doom us all.”
“I not afraid of Gyea!”
Emer’s consciousness slipped for a moment due to the force of Keeya’s emotions.
His mind and body burned, and he feared that if she did not calm, she would kill him without realizing.
Keeya, please calm yourself.
“No!
I will not calm!
Kanazee betray kissiae.
Humans betray kissiae.
Elves betray kissiae.
Every race betray kissiae!
They use us, kill us until none left.
But not Keeya!
Keeya protect kissiae even if I must kill all who betray us!”
We have not betrayed you.
“Elves of past no different.
They capture and use us.
Many kissiae die.”
But, that was long ago.
“Quiet!”
Emer’s consciousness faded.
Keeya searched for Kanazee’s location fearing that she may still be too far away to locate but found her not far to the west.
She appeared before Kanazee in an explosion of gore from the unfortunate naiad who had been present at the destination of the transmission.
“Emer,” the giant next to Kanazee said in surprise, not bothered by the blood soaking Emer’s robes and Keeya’s hair thinking that it may have come from the unfortunate naiad.
“So the one you were in conversation with was Jethro’s kissiae.
Perfect.
Several kissiae have infiltrated the city and are on their way to the central district.
You can take us there directly.”
Byurk saw the fury in Keeya’s eyes and cowered.
The kissiae matriarch who he feared the moment he saw her was no more than a child to the wrathful being before him.
That overpowering aura must have been suppressed when he first saw Emer after his duel with Fect.
He looked up at General Bregon and wondered how he could not feel that same commanding presence.
“This is not an ally,” Byurk warned ready to fight or flee for his life.
He had never felt such fear, not even when face to face with a flock of dragons.
“No,” Keeya said in direct defiance to General Bregon’s order.
Emer’s hand extended, and Kanazee vanished.
“What is the meaning of this,” General Bregon roared, but Keeya only viewed him as an insignificant insect unworthy of her time.
She vanished and appeared in the dense forest on the eastern side of the city.
The many dryads who had yet to storm the walls screamed and bowed before Keeya.
Keeya reached out her mind across the city to locate all the Kissiae, sensing each and every one’s position and direction of motion.
Emer’s hands dug into the soil, and all life died in the vicinity, spreading outward like a plague.
The trees wilted.
The dryads collapsed and withered.
After a moment of deathly silence, the ground rumbled.

* * *
Debin and Benab covered their faces from the choking smoke rising from the belvedere.

Something happened below that required Chloe’s immediate evacuation, but while sitting atop the tower they were unable to know what, and the heat of the fire prevented them from descending to the belvedere.
Benab patted his father’s shoulder.
“The forest,” he called through painful coughs.
The entire eastern forest that had glowed faintly from behind Chloe’s firewall grew dark, and the trees shriveled into nothing.
Shortly thereafter, the seemingly endless wave of dryads ceased.
Cheers erupted on the outer wall from those who thought they had outlasted the dryad onslaught, but at the height atop the wall they could not see the dark omen beyond Chloe’s flames.
The tower began to shake, and the rumbling grew audible like an approaching stampede of beasts.
The rumbling grew to a quake until the earth in the distance burst, revealing massive vines as thick as Revlan’s walls.
They wove in and out of the ground like a sea serpent through water in their rapid approach towards the city.
What magic was this?
What sorcery?
How many dryads would have been needed to conjure such a massive plant?
Was the initial onslaught only to stall for time until such a force was conjured?
Was this the work of all the kissiae?
The only truth Debin knew was that the city was now doomed.
“Evacuate the walls,” he screamed, but no amount of haste could save them.
The vines tore through the stone, sending soldiers and large sections of wall hurling through the air and over the inner wall into the sunken city.
A pandemonium of screams erupted from the citizens as debris rained upon them and large sections of the inner wall blew inward.
The vines divided and dug into the ground, creating massive fissures that collapsed walls, buildings, and towers.
One of the vines writhed and collided with the base of Debin and Benab’s tower.
Benab slipped and slid down the smooth tiling.
Debin dove and caught his son before he fell, but his desperation could only delay the inevitable.
The tower tilted as the vine dug through its base, and soon it careened forward.
There was no time to think.
Debin swung the arm clasping his son’s wrist.
He prayed to the gods and released his grip.
Benab collided with the soldiers atop the outer wall and watched his father fall with the burning tower into the space between the walls.

* * *
“What are those vines?!
Are they your kind’s doing?!”
A minum screamed at the kissiae atop her naiad’s shoulder.
“No!”

The kissiae was just as terrified of the massive plant that was rapidly pursuing them between and through the walls, destroying everything and everyone in their path, Revlan, dryad, and Tolmyur combatant alike.
She and her sisters were about to scale the inner wall on the south side to infiltrate the city before the unprejudiced destruction sent both enemy and ally into disarray.
Fairies fled beside minums and elves beside humans without hostility, caring only for their own lives, but the vines were too quick.
They struck the ground, sending the Tolmyur soldiers and naiads tumbling forward and battering them with debris.
It slithered over them, and the moment it touched a kissiae, she vanished with a light pop.
The naiads and soldiers with them were ground into the earth under the plant’s massive weight.
The vine immediately divided and changed course, one outside the city and one through the inner wall into the city.
The wall collapsed inward, and the writhing of the vine sent massive chunks of stone and buildings cascading down the tiers.
It weaved north where two Kissiae fled in terror, not from the vines but from the elves in the forge district.
While most citizens never learned magic for combat, fire was different, being destructive by nature.
Most of the smiths and forgery workers held fire affinities, something these two younger kissiae were unaware of having been sheltered in Elos all their lives.
A fireball flew overhead and collided with the top of the building they scaled to flee.
The younger of the two cried from the fire that fell and burned their arms and shoulders.
“Go around, I’ll hold them off,” the elder sister ordered, but the youngest was too afraid now to move.
Fire was beneath them and now fire was above them.
They were surrounded by people they could control, but their ivy hair would never reach them through the flames.
“Go,” she screamed before descending to buy what little time she could for her sister to escape.
The naiads who protected them could not scale the steep walls, so when their acting matriarch gave the order for the kissiae to infiltrate the city on their own, she was hesitant.
Neither she nor her sister had any experience in combat or stealth.
They cleared the wall easily due to the simple manipulation of the unaware soldiers at the top, but the city was far too crowded.
There was nowhere they could go without being in sight of someone.
The moment they were forced to manipulate and kill a single citizen, a target was painted on their backs.
Every fire mage closed in on them, and in their flight, they found themselves in the lowest tier of the city where almost solely fire mages resided.
Two well aimed fireballs approached, and the elder sister was forced to use her hair to block them.
The explosion burned her body, and her elegant ivy hair fell in cinders to the ground.
She survived the impact, but the flames clung to her body in burning agony that dryad pain tolerance could not ignore.
She looked up with hope that her sister fled, but she remained motionless on the corner of the structure, her eyes glued to something behind them.
Both the kissiae and the elves that pursued them had been unaware of the approaching destruction.
The cries of fear and death reached their ears, and the shaking ground threatened to rip her fingers from the stone.
Massive vines as thick as buildings cascaded down the city tiers in their direction.
“Run,” she screamed to her sister before her burning body gave out and fell to the ground where the fleeing trampled her under foot.
The massive vine rolled over the district destroying everything in its path, and the younger sister who could not move for the fear vanished the moment the vine collided with the burning building.

* * *
Keeya counted every kissiae touched by the massive vines that were an extension of her, teleporting them instantly via transmission out of harm’s way.
Her urgency grew by the second.
A kissiae died and then another.

Some of the naiads were carrying their charges away from the vines that were there to save them while other kissiae were captured inside the city being executed or tortured, further infuriating Keeya.
“Release the kissiae or die,” Keeya screamed into the minds of every soul inside the city.
The naiads stopped fleeing allowing the kissiae to be recovered at the cost of being crushed to death by the massive vines.

The citizens of the city who had cornered the kissiae that failed to infiltrate to the city center fled in panic as the writhing vines tore up buildings to reach the helpless kissiae, but for some, the vines were too late.
The last three kissiae were already in the city center.
Keeya could feel them, but the emotions of the three were of terror.
There was a monster of fire there from whom they fled.
All vines converged on the central district, tearing through the upper tiers of the city and then the walls in their haste.
An enormous orange light glowed in the distance from the center of the city, visible above the demolished outer walls.
Keeya watched the plume of flame rise into the dark night.
In that same moment, she felt the lives of the last three kissiae vanish.
Fury and sorrow enveloped Keeya so intense that Emer’s glazed eyes shed a fountain of tears and the veins of his body bulged.
She sent her vines deep into the stone beneath the central district to destroy the foundation, fracturing the elevated city and sending large sections sliding into the sunken tiers below.
The massive shift of land sent tremors out into the forests and fields beyond.
And then, the vines grew still.
The fountain of tears spread to Keeya’s eyes as her emotions pulled inward, relieving Emer of his torment.
Fifteen dead and twenty-nine rescued.
A third of the Kissiae remaining on Whinhlem were lost in a single night.
Keeya cried as she removed Emer’s hands from the soil, snapping the roots wound about his fingers.
The forest and city were silent.
The sounds of battle no longer echoed through the night.
Keeya vanished, leaving the destruction of Revlan behind her.

Chapter 21
“Tolmyur’s Target”
The soldiers stationed to protect the officers back at the camp stared in awe at the ruins of Revlan glowing against the yellow flames the distance.
They felt the quake, witnessed the massive vines tear down the walls, and watched the city crumble.
Many still shook from the agonizing message that rang in their heads demanding the release of the kissiae.
The weak-minded huddled against the ground, hands on their helmets, crying for the words to silence in their minds.
Only the hardened soldiers who had witnessed the harsh battles of the past were mostly unaffected, but even among the unaffected, some still worried over what evil they may have ignorantly awakened.
“We have made enemies with someone dangerous,” Byurk said to General Bregon.
“I disagree.
The kissiae joined of their own will and led us in the attack.
If the kissiae enslaved by Commanding General Jethro truly believed that we forced them, she may have killed us where we stood.
We would not have had the power to stop her.
From the message, we can assume she arrived solely to retrieve her kind, and once finished, she left.”
“Jethro’s agreement with her was to continue their protection.
This does not bode well.”

“General Byurk, I understand that you have personal history with our Commanding General, but as a general, you should use proper titles when before your fellow soldiers.” “Yes, sir.” “And to address your concern, this may be fortuitous for us.
“Yes, sir.”
“And to address your concern, this may be fortuitous for us.
Commanding General Jethro bested that kissiae to subjugate her kind, a testament to his power after what we just witnessed.
I do not believe she will rebel out of fear of him, and now we know we have one with greater power than the otherworlders on our side.
In truth, she has given us a golden opportunity.
Most of our army is still without the walls at the edges of the forests.
Only a few groups followed the naiads and kissiae inside.
Among all the casualties, we should have sustained the least.
Our time to strike is now when the city is open and recovering.”
General Bregon called Lieutenant Mackrum.
“Send messengers to all the awaiting forces surrounding Revlan.
Each contacted force is to send out five more messengers to search for scattered parties.
Those they find should send out two messengers of their own.
Continue that propagation until every survivor has been reached.
Order them to gather all those who are still combat-able to the northeast.
Beat them if you must recover their senses.
We need to make haste and pierce deep to the inner city before the enemy has time to recuperate and rally its people.”

* * *
A faint orange glow permeated the gaps and cracks in the rubble.
Cinders from the braziers were scattered and smoldering, but it was impossible to tell from where.
At least they provided enough light to barely see the outlines of the rubble.
Ceil’s vision was blurry, and she realized that she had been unconscious, but for how long?
“Are you okay,” Justin moaned, his voice strained and breath heavy.
Ceil rubbed her eyes to help them find focus.
Her body ached, and she could feel blood from her forehead running down and dripping from her cheek.
“I am unharmed,” she replied after scanning her body with life magic for injury.
Aside from a few cuts and bruises, she was uninjured.
She looked up at the large slabs of stone.
Somehow Justin was able to find a location where the collapsing stone would not crush her.
Surely his time magic was to thank for this miracle.
The events all happened too fast for Ceil to process.
The floor beneath them suddenly dropped ten feet, and the impact and subsequent tremors collapsed the walls and ceiling of the temple.
Justin grabbed her and dodged the falling stone, diving into the column framing the end of the corridor.
He covered her with his shield until all went dark.
His arm and shield pressed heavily and painfully into her back, but she was alive and mostly unharmed--a miracle indeed.
A sudden fear crossed Ceil’s mind.
She shifted her arm out from under her, tearing the vibrant purple fabric of her jack against the coarse stone, and placed her hand on Justin’s cheek.
A sigh of relief passed her lips.
Justin was slightly more battered, but he was not severely injured, and none of his limbs were pinned under the heavy rubble.
The last thing Ceil wanted was for Justin to be fatally injured or un-savable because he chose to shield her instead of himself.
She could not stand watching Sammy suffer from his loss.
“I’m fine,” Justin said, pulling Ceil’s hand from his face, “but the shield is stuck.
I can’t move my arm.”
Ceil reached to her hip to retrieve the small dagger provided to her for emergency protection.
She felt around her back for the location of the leather enarmes and carefully slid the dagger between them and Justin’s arm.
The leverage available to her in the cramped space was little, especially with her arm twisted around her back, but it was just enough to jiggle the blade and cut into the leather.
The first strap snapped, but the second was further across her back.
She could only reach it with the tip of the knife and had to flick the tip against the leather, slowly and carefully chewing through it.
“Try and slide your arm out when I exhale… Now.”
Ceil breathed out, and Justin tried to pull his arm up her back.
He applied a bit too much force causing it to slip out and knock her in the back of the head, but he was free.
“Sorry,” Justin said.
Ceil blinked off the sudden impact.
Without his arm, she had a little more movement.
She tried shimmying forward, but there was too little room.
Instead, she pushed against the rubble beside her to slide closer to Justin.
The shield shifted with the large slab of stone.
Justin grabbed Ceil and pulled her into his chest as the slab buckled, pinning the shield beneath it.
The movement sent a cascade of rubble crumbling and shifting in the collapsed temple out of sight from their cramped space.
Justin covered Ceil’s head until the shifting ceased.
Much above them may be unstable, and at any moment they knew the ancient stone could give way and crush them as it did the shield where Ceil had just been.
“Can we even get out of here,” Justin whispered, his breath caressing Ceil’s ear.
“I do not want to hear that from the one man who was able to find the only place that could save us from the collapse.
There were earth mages among those with us in the temple… but without your reflexes, they may not have been able to react in time.”
Ceil careened her neck to look above them.
There was a gap in the stone possibly large enough to squeeze through.
“How much movement do you have?”
“I can move my legs just fine,” Justin said, testing his range of movement.
“Can you slide backwards?”
Justin curled his legs and shifted down Ceil until his head was on her thighs.
This gave Ceil enough room to twist her torso and sit up in the thin space.
She reached her arm into the gap and found the other side open, at least as far as she could reach.
“I will try to go up.
I trust you to pull me back if something shifts,” Ceil said.
“Do not try to move anything that is not already loose,” Justin warned.
Ceil reached her other arm through, and with Justin pushing her legs, she squeezed her shoulders past the gap.
The rest of her body followed with relative ease.
The stone slab beneath her felt solid, now settled after the recent shift and collapse.
Above her was one of the many decorative stone arches from the ceiling.
It was not a window but a shallow concave ornamentation, and the cavity provided enough room for her to crouch.
The glow of the few cinders was a bit brighter here, just enough for her to see where loose rubble collected.
She cleared away whatever loose stones she could find to look for a second gap.
One caused a cascade of sand and gravel onto her face and into her eyes.
Ceil reeled back and held in her cry to not worry Justin.
After wiping her face and blinking away what sand she could, she investigated from where the loose gravel poured.
The gap was slightly smaller than the first.
She and Justin could pass through but not with their armor.
“Justin, I might have found a way further up.”
Justin’s arms appeared from the gap below, and he barely managed to shimmy through.
“We need to remove our armor or we will not fit.”
Justin immediately got to work unlacing Ceil’s Jack and skirt.
They then worked together to remove the many sections of Justin’s armor.
Ceil in her bind and underskirt slid her lithe frame through the new opening.
“There is space here.
We will have to climb,” she said.
Justin reached his arm through, and ceil tried to pull him up, but his shoulders caught.
He was too broad.
Justin dropped back down and tried a different angle with only one arm through.
He tilted his shoulders and squeezed them together as close as he could with his other arm pressed against his side.
The second shoulder passed, but his tunic tore, and as Ceil pulled, the sharp stone cut down his arm.
He was through.
Justin breathed heavy through his teeth to fight the pain.
Ceil wanted to stem the bleeding, but she could not risk the harm her magic might cause him.
She felt safe using life magic on Sammy because of how much she cared for her, but she feared that her hatred of Justin might trigger that dark magic, causing far greater harm.
Instead, she removed her bind and wrapped the long cut tightly.
Ceil looked at the injury with a new worry.
“Can you climb with that arm?”
“I will manage.
We don’t have a choice.”
The cavity was slender but tall.
The section of wall to their right caved inwards catching on another that collapsed to meet it.
Rubble filled most the gap, but near the top there was a crack where the wall broke from the ceiling.
It was large enough to crawl through and hopefully would lead somewhere they could scale the rubble or at least give more options to climb higher out of the temple.
Justin stared at Ceil from her head to her skirt, his eyes lingering on the latter.
“I will climb first.”
“No. You already saw my tails at the meeting of commanders, so it is no matter.”
“That’s not what I mean,” Justin protested, causing Ceil to blush angrily for thinking his usual consideration was the reason.
“I can react faster if something is unsafe.”
“Again, no.
Your arm is injured, and your body is heavy.
I am the better climber.
You will need my help to climb through the crack.”
Ceil began scaling the broken wall before Justin had time to argue further.
The cracks along its length gave plentiful grip but were difficult to locate in the dark.
The higher she climbed, the closer the far wall came until she could prop one leg against it.
With one hand clinging to the edge of the large crack they would need to climb through and her legs spread to reach strong holds on both walls, she reached down with her free hand to beckon Justin.
He began his ascent, but after looking up, he turned his head, choosing instead to feel for the next grip.
His consideration was the issue, much to her annoyance, and it showed when it was most dangerous.
“Fool!
I said it was no matter.
Look where you are gripping before you fall!”
Justin was infuriating.
All his so-called good characteristics that Sammy praised were a cause for nothing but trouble and annoyance to Ceil.

She watched with nervous anticipation as his arms trembled with each new grip, and when he was close enough, she grabbed his outstretched arm so that he would not have to climb the steep angle at the top as she did.
She strained under his weight as she helped him reach the crack, and once he had an elbow through, she let go of her grip, praying that her legs held.
She used both hands below his feet to hoist him up.
“Ceil, you need to see this.” Justin reached down and pulled Ceil up.
From atop the wall, they could see the pile of rubble at the bottom of the inner sanctum.
There were no bodies or movement, and the location they had been buried was the only place where most the rubble kept its shape to allow for gaps.
Justin’s time magic was not the only force at play.
They were lucky, simply lucky.
The far wall had collapsed outward revealing the dark night sky and the upper tiers of the city’s edge through the corridors and rooms that surrounded the inner sanctum, but something felt off.
The city lay at a slant.
The most troubling revelation was the gargantuan vines that had ripped through the walls and buildings and now stood motionless as terrible monuments to the destruction they wrought.
This was not damage that Tolmyur could have caused.
“Did the kissiae do this,” Ceil asked, remembering the painful message that had entered her mind before the disaster.
“I don’t know…”
They needed to leave the temple, and the opening on the other side was their best option.
Ceil took the lead and climbed down the other side of the sloping wall to the pile of rubble.
Justin followed carefully behind her, but his injured arm nearly slipped multiple times, making Ceil tense.
She wanted to look for survivors, but she knew there would be no hope for them.
The corridor had collapsed with only the pillars framing the end standing, and the rubble beneath their feet was too fine to allow for gaps someone could have survived in.
Only an earth mage or a competent life mage could detect any bodies below the rubble, and Ceil was neither.
Something caught Ceil’s eye in the corner of the room.
She hopped over the rubble to a slender piece of wood protruding from the rubble, her staff.
She pulled at it, not wanting to lose another, but it would not budge.
Justin was about to help, but she stopped him.
There was plentiful life in it unlike her last staff when the hamadryad rooted in Melia.
She used some of that life to sever it where the stone held and retrieved the piece no longer than half her forearm.
“This is enough,” she assured Justin.
“It will take a few days, but I can regrow it.”
“Your Highness!”
Ceil and Justin looked up to see Kiri flying above the collapsed roof.
Ceil did not even know Kiri could fly, but she was relieved that she was able to survive the collapse, possibly because of her wings.
Kiri quickly flew away and returned with two others.
They descended to the rubble, their expressions exuding relief.
“We will take you to safety.”
“No, take Justin first,” Ceil ordered.
Justin protested, but the fairies were quick to obey.
They grabbed his arms and lifted him slowly into the air.
Ceil did not have to wait long.
A second pair followed shortly after along with Kiri.
“What of your armor?” Kiri asked.
“Under the rubble.” Ceil pointed to the large slabs of stone near the pillars of the corridor where she and Justin had abandoned it.
“You will need it.
I will search.
Go,” she ordered the fairies, and they lifted Ceil out of the temple.
The sight of the destruction around the city stole Ceil’s breath.
The city was not at a slant.
The entire central district was.
Large and deep fissures broke it apart, and much of the eastern side had slid into the lower tiers.
The vines she saw from within the temple were all around the city, coiled within the immense destruction and converging at the center.
She could see people moving through the destruction trying to help themselves and rescue others.
Never in her wildest nightmares could she have imagined such a disaster, but the nightmare was not finished.
Ceil’s heart raced with panic.
“To the north!
Tolmyur!”
Tolmyur soldiers were pouring through an opening in the north wall.
They followed the smooth trail of rubble left behind by the vines down the tiers and then across the vines to the north side of the central district.
Ceil was now positive that the destruction of the city was caused by the kissiae so that the soldiers could reach her.
All the vines converged on the central district, creating easy paths to walk upon and avoid the maze of buildings and stairways.
The fairies flew her down to where many soldiers gathered.
A few of the Melians were present as was Chloe and Dharin.
“Tolmyur soldiers are arriving at the north end of the central district,” Ceil screamed.
“Our fliers already spotted them moments before,” Dharin replied.
“We are trying to gather as many soldiers as we can on the other side of the fissure to delay them, but the devastation is too widespread, and with the fissure and wall, it’s mostly isolated.
They organized much quicker than we could.”
“Can you not see this was planned from the start?!
Of course they would be organized!
We need to take Chloe over there quickly!”
“You rely too heavily on Lady Chloe,” Dharin chastised.
“She nearly died to the kissiae before the disaster.”
“I know I do, but she’s the most powerful mage we have.
We need to save Sammy, save everyone.”
“We already tried retrieving Sammy and Lemi, but they refused.
Sammy said she did not want another repeat of Gullivan, and I assume you understand better than I what she means by that.”
“The destruction of her city…” Ceil whispered to herself.
“Take me there.
Bring Chloe, the Melians, everyone you can.”
“I will not place you in further danger,” Dharin replied.
“This is an order as your Empress!”
Stunned gazes bore down on Ceil.
Even after surviving such a harrowing disaster, she demanded to be at the front to protect her friends and her people.
Dharin frowned.
He was proud of his great-granddaughter, but heroism was often detrimental in war.
It only led to death.
Gritting his teeth, he gave the order.
“You heard her!
Organize as many wings as you can to take those fit for battle across the fissure.
Locate enough earth mages to build a bridge in the meantime.
Those who arrive first, hold off the enemy until our main force can arrive.”
Ceil grabbed Dharin’s armor, turning him to face her.
Her hand shook with anger.
She could not believe the order she just heard.
“You were not already preparing to send soldiers to the north?
Were you planning to abandon them?!”
“With our forces scattered and how isolated that section of the central district now is, we are at a severe disadvantage with the enemy approaching in mass.

Abandoning it so that we can better situate ourselves drastically increases our chance of survival, but yes, all the nobles, their guards, servants, the orphanage, and everyone who chose to stay would be lost, including your friends.
This is our last chance to turn away the Tolmyur filth.
