If we lose here, we lose Revlan, and your order has made victory far more difficult for us.”
“I will not change my mind,” Ceil said flatly.
“I know.
You are too much like a fairy in that regard.
We will take you to the north so you can fight with us, but you will join the main force and wait until we bridge the fissure.
I will not yield on this matter.”
“Fine.”
Ceil walked away from Dharin.
She understood that in war, sacrifices were sometimes needed to better ensure victory, but she could not accept it.
If there was a chance that they could save Sammy, Lemi, and the orphanage, she wanted to take that chance.
Right now, all those who were important according to the sprites were here: Chloe, Justin, and herself.

If the calamity was still to come, and if they were important to the events that would soon take place, perhaps having the three of them there on the north side of the central district would increase their chance of victory.
Ceil placed her hope on Chloe’s words, that they would not die so easily, and the only way they would die is if the district was lost.
Ceil located Chloe and Justin with the Melians who were stationed at manors on this side of the fissure.
She noticed just how badly Chloe was injured from the dried blood on her face that ran from her ears, nose, and eyes.
Tyree was treating Justin’s arm and his other injuries, but once she saw Ceil, she quickly stopped and beckoned her over.
“No, finish him first,” Ceil ordered.
“Chloe, Justin, you are going over to the orphanage ahead of me.”
“What about you,” Justin asked.
“I’m supposed to protect you.”
Ceil gritted her teeth but took a breath so she would not shout.
“You fulfilled your role at the temple splendidly.
Consider yourself dismissed.
Tolmyur’s army is entering the north side of the central district, which is why you are needed there.
Instead of worrying about me, you should worry about your woman.
Sammy needs you far more than I. I must wait until we can organize our soldiers, but then I will be joining you.
You will have to hold out until then…”
Ceil gripped her skirt and tried to prevent her jaw from quivering.
“Please hold out until then.”

Chapter 22
“For the Protection of Those Held Dear”
Sammy ran down the stairs of the central hall of Lord Olvor’s manor, nearly tripping on rubble scattered over the steps.
A sack of clean rags she retrieved from a storage closet on the third floor was tucked tightly under her arm, and a roll of bandages was in her other hand.
“Has anyone located Yasef yet?” she called.
“No.”
“Not yet!”
A few fairy maids called back answers as they ran to and from the many rooms lining both the first and second floor of the hall.
All 308 children except one had been accounted for after the tremors that rocked the central district.
The destruction on the north side of the district was fortunately less than others.
From what Sammy could see from the third floor, the temple grounds in the middle of the district were at a slant, and an entire section of the district to the east had disappeared.
Now that they were informed that enemy soldiers were also on their way and could very well be entering the district at this very moment, everyone was scrambling to locate and secure the children.
No help would be coming for them.
The north was isolated, and Sammy wondered if they would survive an encounter with the Tolmyur army.
She passed the rags and bandages off to a pair of Melians treating the injured children and located Lord Olvor by the entrance.
“Olvor!
What of the other nobles?!”
Lord Olvor sneered at Sammy as she approached.
She knew he disliked her, mostly because she was human, but he was not one to let personal feelings get in the way during an emergency.
“Hurn and Dollen both died in the quakes, but their families agreed to lend their guards and servants.
They should be arriving shortly.
As for the lesser nobles, they have no choice but to listen to me.
Their households and guards will aid us in defense.
That gives us about fifty more.”
“That few?”
“Most of our soldiers were at the temple grounds.
You see what good that does us now.”
“Do you know how many of them will need bows?
Lemi has started creating them from those bamboo plants in your garden.
I can tell her to increase the number.”
“Bamboo?
I have no idea.
The families’ guards should have their own weapons but only Dollen’s family regularly trained.
Have her make twenty more just in case.”
“On it.”
Sammy ran past Lord Olvor out the door.
The dark morning was lit by an ominous orange glow from the fires around the city, and the giant vines that had caused the destruction sent painful shivers down Sammy’s back.
She shook her head to try and not dwell on what was beyond her control and ran to the garden on the west side of the manor.
Lemi had spotted a small bamboo forest there when they arrived, and the second they learned of the approaching enemy, she ran there to make weapons.
Sammy quickly located Lemi, amazed at how much of the small forest had disappeared.

Two piles of bows lay behind her, one with many short bows that fairies could use, and the other pile contained nine bows that were even larger and thicker than what Sammy expected a longbow would be.
Sammy picked up one of the longbows and tried to pull the string.
It wouldn’t budge.
“No one is going to be able to use these,” Sammy protested.
Lemi finished growing what looked like a hundred arrows from a branch of bamboo, making it appear like a massive pine bough.
“Maybe only a Mountain Elf would be strong enough to pull the string,” she said while shaking them loose like dead needles.
“But all these nobles only employ fairies!”
Lemi picked up one of the bows that was as tall as her and pulled the string.
The wood bent back with a creak.
The form looked terribly menacing.
She then slowly relaxed the string to not dry-fire the bow.
“You need to use life magic to draw it.
The wood is strong but flexible and has very good recoil.
These are for me and the other eight Melians.
Their matriarch, Preelen, is really good with the bow, so maybe those in her village might be able to use them well, too.”
“Olvor says we might need twenty more fairy bows, but…” Sammy looked at the large pile, “you might have enough here already.
I’ll take them to the front of the manor so we can distribute them.”
Sammy swung eight of the longbows over her back and packed her arms full of as many of the shortbows as she could carry.
She ran to the front walkway near a fountain where the walkway split between the different houses of the manor and the servant’s quarters.
The guards and families of the other nobles were beginning to gather.
“Those of you who need bows, here!”
She slid the bows off her arms at their feet.
“Remember that even though you are nobles, you are fighting for your lives, so if you cannot use any other weapons, grab one.
I will be back with more bows and some arrows in a bit.”
Sammy ran back to the main house and into the central hall.
“Preelen!”
A Melian poked her head out one of the rooms on the second floor.
After seeing Sammy, she jumped down from the mezzanine.
“Here, these are for you and the other Melians.
You’ll need to use life magic to draw them.”
Preelen inspected one of the bows.
“Lemi made these?
That child has a talent!”
“About the arrows…”
“Just give each one of us a single stalk of that plant, and we should be able to make them as we need them.”
“No.
That might be too slow.
I’ve seen Lemi grow arrows.
It would be faster if you already have them on hand and can fire them quickly.
I was wondering if you could send one or two of you to help Lemi finish all the arrows for everyone else as well.”
“I’ll send someone over immediately.”
“Thanks,” Sammy said before running back to the door.
“Take a moment to breathe!
You look like you’re about to faint!”
“I’ll be fine!” Sammy assured her before heading outside back to Lemi.
Her lungs burned and her legs ached, but she could not stop.
She did not have time to stop.
Sammy doubted she would be able to do much once the fighting started, so she wanted to be as much use as possible while they prepared.
“Preelen is sending someone to help with arrows,” Sammy informed Lemi before grabbing as many shortbows as she could carry and returning to the fountain.
“More shortbows,” Sammy said as she set down the bow at the nobles’ feet.
She nearly fell forward on top of the pile.
“You need to slow down a little,” one of the noble women said with mild worry on her face.
“We don’t have time to slow down!
You should all be getting ready instead of standing here!”
“The soldiers have passed the curtain wall,” a fairy scout cried before flying back to monitor the enemy’s progress.
“See!
Damn it!”
Sammy ran back toward the main house.
The central district was large, but it was not that large.
If the enemy army was at the walls, they were only about a mile away.
She stumbled through the doorway and fell to her knees.
“Enemy has passed the walls,” she called.
“They will be here soon!
Move the children to the cellars and… and…”
She ran out of breath.
“… damn it…”
“You heard her!
Move the children to the cellars, prep kitchens, and storage rooms,” the head butler echoed, and all the maids and manservants went into frenzy.
Children were brought out of rooms on the upper floors and led down the steps to be escorted to the basement of the manor.
Preelen jumped down from the mezzanine and lifted Sammy, helping her outside where the guards were gathered.
“You have done enough,” she said.
“Like hell I have,” Sammy retorted, confusing Preelen with her odd phrasing.
“The walls around the manor grounds will give us some defense,” Sammy heard one of the guards say when she approached.
“A single earth mage will make short work of them,” a second countered.
“We cannot hope to fight them on the open road with our numbers against theirs,” Lord Olvor replied, silencing the argument.
“We will use my manor as best we can for cover.”
“What of the children,” one of the women asked.
“We have sent them to the basement and cellars,” Sammy replied, winded.
“I will take my sisters to the rooftops and pick them off before they reach your grounds,” Preelen announced.
“We will focus on mages first, but we probably will not be able to take down dwarves or giants with their armor.”
“The dwarves are the most dangerous.
They are armored and use magic.
If any of the enemy can take down the walls, it’s them.”
“They are avoiding the manors,” another scout announced.
“They might be heading directly for the temple grounds, but they will not be able to reach them.
And they will see us first.
You have your positions.
Go!” Lord Olvor ordered.
The guards, servants, and noble families scattered at Lord Olvor’s call.
Sammy was about to run back to Lemi when she noticed a pair of High Elf soldiers running through the entrance gate to the manor grounds.
Lord Olvor also noticed and ran with Sammy and Preelen to meet them.
“By command of Empress Ceil, the orphanage will not be abandoned,” the soldier announced.
That was the best news Sammy could have hoped to hear.
After seeing the temple in ruins, she feared that Justin and Ceil might be hurt or worse.
Running up behind the soldier were another three, and behind them were Chloe and Justin.
“What are you doing here,” Sammy screamed at them.
“We’re here to help,” Justin replied.
“The Tolmyur soldiers are already here,” she cried.
“We know.
We saw from the air.
Ceil is having the flying fairies carry reinforcements over the ravine, so they should be arriving slowly.
Once bridges are built, a lot more will be coming.”
“I’ll guard the road,” Chloe said, flagging several High Elves to follow her.
“Chloe,” Sammy called, but Chloe ignored her.
She punched Justin in the arm.
“You were supposed to stay where it was safe!”
“I’m here to help keep you safe.
After all, you can’t do much with your magic,” Justin replied.
Sammy wanted to punch Justin again for turning her past depreciating remarks against her, but she could not argue.
She looked around and found that Preelen had already left.
If they were to climb to the fenced roof before the Tolmyur soldiers got within range of arrow distance, they needed to hurry.
“We’re going to the roof.”
Sammy pulled Justin back to the manor and found Lemi climbing the side.
“Doesn’t she know there is a roof entrance?”
They paid her no mind and ran inside and up the steps to the third floor and then to a spiral staircase to the rooftop garden.
Lemi met them with two other Melians.
From there they could see the approaching army, and Sammy’s heart sank.
There were thousands of them.
At most, Lord Olvor’s manor had maybe a hundred combatants, and Dharin’s reinforcements were trickling in as fast as whatever number of flying fairies he had remaining could carry them over.
By their speed of arrival, Sammy could not think there were any more than ten winged fairies.
That was far too slow to make any dent in the enemy army or bolster their forces fast enough to put up a solid resistance.
“I got one!” Lemi cheered.
Unknown to Sammy, the Melians had already begun firing.
Her fears had drowned out the twang of the bows.
The army was not yet at the wall surrounding the manor grounds, but apparently it was close enough for the Melians to make use of their archery.
The other Melian’s frustration showed that she was not having the same luck, but a second cheer from Lemi hinted that every arrow she loosed hit its mark.
Sammy looked out to the rooftops of the second house and the servant’s house and saw that a few of the other Melians were having similar success.
Preelen was particularly astonishing.
She was firing at twice the rate of Lemi, her posture emanating the confidence that each arrow loosed would hit her target.
“Lemi, stop talking and focus,” Sammy rebuked.
Even with their archers picking off a few soldiers every couple of seconds, it wasn’t enough.
Not nearly enough.
Not even close.
They would need a hundred Melians, not eight, and even then it would only slow the enemy a little.
An explosion rose from the road just past the manor grounds.
Chloe encountered the army, but the size of the explosion was much smaller than what Sammy knew Chloe was capable.
Either she was trying to conserve her ven or she already had little at her disposal, possibly both.
It’s not enough!
Anxiety ate at Sammy’s stomach, causing it to sting.
She felt like vomiting.
“This doesn’t look good,” Justin said from beside her.
“I know that!
Damn it!
Oh, god…”
“Sammy.”
Sammy screamed and fell to her back.
A transparent feminine figure hovered above the railing where her face had just been.
“Ephora?
Are you here to help?” Justin pulled Sammy to her feet.
“We just finished our predictions, and I am here to tell you that you lose.
I specifically warned you not to anger the kissiae, and this is the result.”
“We didn’t do anything to anger the kissiae!
They did this on their own!
They are the ones who chose to attack us!”
Sammy’s voice squealed in her desperation.
“I gave ample warning so you could take preventative measures, but you did nothing.
Now Chloe, Justin, and Ceil are going to die.
We can manage without one of them, perhaps two, but not all three, and if Ceil is lost here, so is your future.”

Ceil had questioned her own importance in what is to come, citing her lack of ability, but if Sammy heard Ephora correctly, Ceil was more important than both Chloe and Justin to the approaching calamity.
“They broke through the wall,” someone yelled from below.
Sammy returned to the railing and saw that the manor guards were in combat with soldiers, falling quickly.
Arrows rained on them from the windows of the buildings, fired by the noble families and servants, but their lack of skill was apparent, and they did little to stop the flood.
“What are we supposed to do,” Sammy screamed at the sprite.
“Take Justin and flee the city quickly.
Take Ceil with you.
You won’t reach Chloe in time to save her.”
“But the orphanage…” Tears welled in Sammy’s eyes.
She couldn’t abandon the children to slaughter, and even if she could reach Chloe, Chloe wouldn’t leave them either.
“The children will die either way.
By pulling everyone to defend the largest manor, Tolmyur’s commanders believe that Ceil is being protected here.
They will search and eliminate everyone.”
“I can’t…” Sammy dropped to her knees.
She looked up at Justin, and he shook his head.
“There is no way we could leave,” he affirmed.
Ephora sighed.
“Archon said the same thing.
He told me you wouldn’t leave.

I was prepared to teleport Justin, Chloe, and Ceil away from the city, but he warned that your sudden disappearance from a battle where you play a pivotal role would create too large an interference in our foresight, even if your role is only holding out until your imminent demise.”
“Can you take the children away?”
Sammy jumped to her feet, nearly slamming her face into the small transparent body.
“Can you?”
“Perhaps…” Ephora vanished without giving an affirmation.
“Where’d she go?
Ephora!
Come back!
Are you going to do it or not?!”
Sammy raced down the spiral staircase and ran through the manor to the bottom floor and cellar entrance.
She hammered on the thick wooden door, making the children inside cry.
They were still there.
“What is she doing?
We aren’t going to last that long…”
“Sammy?” Justin called out for her, but she did not answer.
She rested her forehead on the barricaded door and listened to the faint cries of the children on the other side.
“Please…”
“I checked with the Arkhon.”
Sammy spun around and tried to grasp Ephora, but the warm air only flowed through her fingers.
“He warned that you might try to grab me…
The sprites gave permission.”
“Really?!”

“The orphans are supposed to die without taking any action of their own, so if we take them away, not only from the city but from civilization, interference should be mitigated, and Gyea should not notice that we are meddling with events.
The sprites of Fiorrae have offered to raise them.
They were awfully excited about the prospect, actually.”
“Great!
Hurry!” Sammy shouted.
“It’s already done.”
“What?” Sammy pressed her ear against the door and could no longer hear the cries.
All she heard were the panicked voices of the servants and orphanage workers.
“All of them?
Even those in the other house?”
“Even the winged fairy boy hiding in the rafters of the fourth room to the left of the stairwell on the third floor.
Now listen.
Every future we see still ends in all your friends’ deaths, but for an unknown reason your existence does not factor into our foresight.
To explain simply, we cannot predict what you do, so if any of them are to survive, it would be from some action you take.
You are no longer bound to this location.
Flee quickly.
Try to save at least Ceil and Justin, but it may still be too late for Chloe.”
The sprite vanished, leaving a sinking terror gripping Sammy’s chest.
The children were safe now, but there was no relief.
She rapped on the door.
“It’s me!”
“Lady Sammy?
The children are gone!
We don’t--”
“I took care of them.
They’re safe.
Spread the word that we need to evacuate to the other side of the ravine quickly before we’re overwhelmed.”
Sammy ran out of the kitchen and bumped into Justin.
“What’s going on?” he asked.
“The children have been taken to Fiorrae.
We are evacuating the manor.”
Justin followed Sammy out the front door while the servants who were in the cellar spread out to inform everyone holed up with bows in the rooms facing the army.
“Lemi!
We’re retreating,” Sammy called up to the roof.
Lemi climbed down without question, and her fellow Melians followed.
Sammy turned right at the fountain and headed for the second house.
The door was closed and likely barricaded, so she picked up a rock and threw it at one of the side windows.
“We’re evacuating,” She called through the broken, clouded glass.
The head butler showed up almost immediately in a panic.
“Lady Sammy, the children--”
“I know.
I took care of them.
They’re safe.
We need to evacuate before the grounds are overwhelmed.
We’ll take the west gate and head south for the fissure.”
“Understood.
I will tell Lord Olvor.”
“Hurry!”
Sammy rushed diagonally through the garden towards the south gate, pushing her legs onward through her overwhelming exhaustion.
Only one person was on her mind, Chloe, but before she could reach the gate, she saw that the Tolmyur soldiers were already there, had torn down the metal bars, and were engaging the guards.
They already passed the road Chloe defended.
All the time she was outside relaying the evacuation order, she had not seen a single explosion.
“It may still be too late for Chloe.”
“Damn it!” Sammy reeled internally, but turned back.
“Lemi, tell the servant house we are escaping, but if the soldiers are already there, turn back.”
Lemi ran off without a word.
The only comfort Sammy found in sending the young girl to a location much closer to the soldiers was the confident grin on Lemi’s face.
“Let’s go.” Sammy pulled Justin who had only just now caught up, wheezing heavily.
“What about… Chloe?”
She shook her head, unable to voice an answer.
They could not reach her now.
The evacuation of the main and second houses was in full force.
The noble families ran with their servants taking the rear in case the soldiers caught up.
No one had time to be scared except the children.
Children?
A few of the noblewomen pulled young children along almost too fast for their small legs to carry them.
Sammy realized then that Ephora had only taken the orphans, not the noble children who were hiding with their parents in the rooms.
“Those half-assed pricks!”
Sammy screamed despite knowing that it was only because of the sprites that they were able to evacuate at all and that in her request she only asked that the orphans be saved.
“I couldn’t reach the house,” Lemi called from behind.
“Preelen told me to run while she and the servants slow them down.”
That meant that the army had already eliminated all the guards at the east wall.
“The soldiers noticed the evacuation too.
They’re coming.”
Lemi caught up to Justin and slung his arm over her shoulder so that she could help him run.
“Sammy… Can I ask you something?” Lemi spoke up.
“What?” Sammy prayed that it would not be something like requesting to stay behind to help everyone else escape.
“If we survive this, can I name my daughter after you?”
Sammy’s heart skipped a beat.
Her hand reached for her mouth to hold back the sobs that tried to break out, but the tears in her eyes flowed unabated.
There was another child she had forgotten about, Lemi’s.
I’m so stupid!
So fucking stupid!
“Sammy?” Lemi’s earnest voice almost sounded as if she was scared that she had somehow insulted Sammy with the request.
“Yes,” Sammy cried.
“Thank you… And I’ll name my first daughter after you.”
“Really!?”
Lemi pranced a few steps, jostling Justin who hung on her shoulder, oblivious to their conversation.
Only a few guards stood at the west gate.
They quickly ushered the first arrivals through.
The servants took point leading them south along the wall.
Sammy waited with Justin and Lemi by the gate until most the nobles and servants passed.
A well-aimed arrow struck the back of one of the noblewomen, signaling that their time was up.
The soldiers were there.
Lemi removed her bow from her back and grew three arrows.
She fired them in quick succession.
“Hurry,” she yelled, pushing Justin into Sammy before growing another three arrows.
“No! You need to come too!”
Sammy grabbed Lemi’s arm, causing her to shoot the next arrow high into the air.
She pulled her and Justin through the gate right before numerous magic attacks and arrows pelted the walls and those who had yet to evacuate the grounds.
Far to the south, a group of soldiers gathered and led the evacuees onward.
The bridge was finished, raising a small glimmer of hope in Sammy’s heart.
When she passed the south corner of the wall, she saw them in open combat with the Tolmyur army.
They were immensely outnumbered, but the elite soldiers who had been posted on the temple grounds were mostly High Elves who held magical superiority over any human, dwarf, and most minums.

They were being pushed back slowly, showing that they would have not been able to break through and save everyone if they had remained in the manor, but their unrestrained barrage of magic without care for their ven levels was buying enough time for everyone to pass.
A stray arrow or magical projectile hit an evacuee every few seconds, sending out sprays of blood and propagating the cries of fear.
Justin pulled Sammy’s shoulder back before an arrow grazed past her nose, the fletching nicking the tip with a sting like a paper cut.
All the while, Lemi grew more arrows and fired them while running.
Sammy wondered how good the girl’s aim could be in such a hurried flight, but with the density of the enemy army, she did not need to be accurate.
She only needed to avoid hitting the High Elves who were struggling so desperately to save them.
“Look,” Justin called.
The road seemed to disappear about two hundred yards ahead.
The entire section of the district was at a slant beyond the fissure, so the continuing road was far lower in elevation.
The evacuees were not stopping, seemingly running off the cliff, so the bridge had to be there.
“Pull back!
Retreat!” Sammy heard Dharin yell from somewhere above her.
She looked back and saw soldiers gaining on the last stragglers at the back of the line, and having seen the number that still had to pass through the west gate, she knew that many did not make it.
The elite soldiers moved quickly to cut off the pursuers.
Lemi reached the fissure first and extended her hand to Justin.
The bridge was a shallow ramp that declined about thirty feet over the fissure which was far larger and deeper than Sammy expected.
In the dark, she couldn’t see the bottom.
It extended west until it reached the severed curtain wall and east past the north side of the temple grounds.
The massive vines coiled up and jutted out at a few locations along its course as if they were holding the fissure open.
She had seen some of the damage around the city from the main house’s third floor and rooftop, but being this close, it felt impossible that this could have been caused by some magic.
At the end of the ramp bridge, Soldiers moved Sammy through the thick defensive line until a slender arm reached out and grabbed her.
“Sammy!” Ceil pulled Sammy into a hug, her tattered jack scraping against Sammy’s bare stomach and arms.
She was happy to see Lemi and thanked Justin for bringing her back safely.
She waited for a moment, but there was one person she couldn’t find.
“Where’s Chloe?”
“We couldn’t get to her…” Sammy said, her expression dolorous.
Ceil’s lips quivered.
“And the children?”
A number of children had made it to safety with their parents, but Ceil knew how many orphans were at Lord Olvor’s manor.
She feared for the worst.
“The sprites took the orphans to Fiorrae so we could escape.”
“I am… I put you through all this.
And even Chloe…” Ceil gripped Sammy’s arms and fought to hold back from crying.
“It’s not your fault.”
“Yes it is!”
“It’s not,” Justin affirmed.
“We knew what we were getting into when we chose to stay.”
“But none of this would have happened if it wasn’t for…”
A fireball hit the bank atop the other side of the ravine.
A few soldiers rushed down the bridge, but many others were forced to the edge only to be pushed off by the mass of Tolmyur’s army.
A few wind mages propelled themselves over the fissure to be caught by their fellow soldiers on the other side.
Some tried to jump, but none could clear the gap, falling into the dark.
Magic and arrows fired from both sides, and Ceil was pulled with Sammy, Justin, and Lemi to the back of the defensive line.
Thanysa was among the last of Revlan’s soldiers to reach the bridge, and when the army began running down it, she struck it with her fist.

It cracked, and despite one human mage’s attempt to fortify it with his own earth magic, the bridge broke under its weight and crumbled into the fissure, taking Thanysa and no fewer than twenty of both Tolmyur and Revlan soldiers with it.
The other side of the ravine quickly filled with enemies along its breadth.
There were hundreds upon hundreds of them, and everyone knew that there were thousands more behind.
Revlan’s soldiers were eclipsed, and everyone felt as if a dangerous predator was staring down at them from its perch.
Both sides attacked with whatever ranged abilities were available to them.
The power was on Revlan’s side, but the sheer numbers were on Tolmyur’s.
Ven would run dry before a fraction of the enemy army was defeated, and while Revlan could only attack the enemy soldiers at the edge, every Revlan soldier was in sight.
Everyone dies…
Sammy cowered under the shields that covered her and her friends.
Ephora said that only she could lead them to victory, but that was impossible.
It had to be.
Sammy had no military training.
She knew nothing of tactics.
She even hated playing strategy games like chess.
There was no way out.
The barrage would continue until all of them were dead.
“CEASE FIRE!”
A terrifyingly deep voice enhanced through wind magic echoed over the battle, and slowly the barrage grew to a halt.
The shields covering Sammy were lifted.
At the edge of the fissure, a giant taller than most stood with grandeur before the Revlan resistance.
A familiar minum appeared from between the legs of the soldiers beside him, Byurk.
“Empress Ceil,” Byurk called, “I offer you again my mercy.
Turn yourself over to us and we will spare this city!”
Revlan’s soldiers hollered curses and rebuke at the minum’s offer.
Sammy looked beside her and saw Ceil shaking.
“No,” Sammy said, holding onto Ceil’s arm.
“You go to them, and you’re dead.”
“But if I stay, we are all dead…” Ceil whispered.
“Still being stubborn?” Byurk called.
“How about a trade?”
The soldiers parted and two dwarves stepped forward.
Their arms were alight with flame, and in their grasp was an orange-haired woman.
Her face was bruised and battered with heavy, viscous blood dripping from her nose and mouth down the fissure they hung her over.
Two spears were pointed at her neck from behind.
“Chloe!” Ceil pushed her way through the soldiers to the edge of the fissure.
“Not again,” she cried.

This was a repeat of Melia, but instead of Justin, Chloe was being held ransom for Byurk’s deal; only this time, the opposing sides were not equal, and the decision could not be postponed to a later date and place.
This was the last battle, the final offer.
“Ceil, you can’t,” Sammy pleaded in English.
“But Chloe’s only in that position because of me.
Dharin was right.
I relied too heavily on her strength.
I kept sacrificing her so I could survive longer.”
“We are not willing to bargain,” Dharin replied, hovering in the air above his soldiers.
“You are not the one with whom I am bargaining, fairy,” Byurk rebuked.
Ceil took a step forward.
“This deal isn’t going to work,” Sammy pleaded, blocking Ceil with her arm.
“The sprites said that we all die, so of course this is not going to work.”
“Then what does it matter?
Even if there is a chance, is it not better I die and save the city than refuse and die anyway with the rest of Revlan?”
Sammy bit her lip so hard she felt it split between her teeth, the faint taste of iron spreading over her tongue.
She looked around for a way out or any inspiration.
She was the one who had to save the situation, but she just couldn’t see it.
The city was in ruins.
The walls were destroyed.
The citizens were too busy recovering themselves and saving each other after the vines’ destruction.
With the east side of the central district gone, even if there were reinforcements, the steps leading to the curtain wall gate and the gate itself were gone with it.
No one could come to their aid without taking the same path the Tolmyur army had.
Sammy was about to give up hope until she saw the faint silhouette of a large bird perched in the darkness atop the ruins of the temple.
Coby?
Where the hell have you been all this time?!
“My life for Chloe and the remaining people of Revlan.
No, all of Vallen.
Do we have a deal?” Ceil called.
Angry shouts from Revlan battled cheers from Tolmyur.
“Agreeable terms,” Byurk replied.
The soldiers behind Ceil called for her to reconsider.
“I have made my decision, and as your Empress, I order you not to stop me….
I am doing this for all of you…”
Byurk kicked his heel into the ground.
A thin platform jutted out from the cliff level with Ceil’s side of the ravine.
The loss of earth used to create the platform destabilized some of the soil, causing a small cascade that startled the soldiers nearest the edge, but none of them fell.
“I assume you can climb?” he asked.
“Easily.” Ceil stepped one foot on the dark brown stone to assess its strength.
“I assure you it is secure.
We do not want you falling.
We need your body to show Commanding General Jethro.”
Sammy grabbed Ceil’s hand, but Ceil shook it off.
“Please… let me do this.”
“No!” Sammy protested.
“I order you to let me do this!” Ceil’s shoulders quivered.
Sammy’s hand extended, but although Ceil was only a step beyond reach, now two steps, Sammy could not grasp her.
Her hand grew to a fist.
She looked over toward the temple.
Coby’s head was turned towards them, watching.
“Coby!”
The large bird flapped its wings upon hearing his name.
“Grab Ceil and take her away from here!”
Her trusted pet responded.
Ceil turned toward Sammy in wide-eyed anger.
“No!”
“I am not your subject!
I am your friend!
You cannot order me!”
Among everyone Sammy held dear, there were only two who were light enough for Coby to carry, Lemi and Ceil.
Lemi was pregnant with a girl who would bear Sammy’s name.
By every instinct, Sammy knew Lemi should be saved, but she couldn’t.
At least one must survive between Justin, Chloe, and Ceil, and the only one of those three that Coby could carry was Ceil.
And if she understood Ephora correctly, Ceil at least must be saved.
Sammy’s order in English to Coby was not understood by the Tolmyur army, but Byurk noticed the large hawk diving.
“Kill the Habha!
Quickly!”

Before the first arrow could fire, Chloe heard Sammy’s order, and with the last of her waning strength, she erupted in fire, killing the soldiers behind her and creating a cascade of soldiers that sent many falling into the fissure.
The heat of the blast was too much even for the dwarven fire mages, so they thrust her forward.
Coby’s talons reached Ceil’s arms amid the chaos, and with a strong flap of his massive wings, he shot into the air with a cry.
The arrows that fired after him were too slow to catch his rapid ascent.
“Go!
Go!” Sammy screamed with waving arms.
Bregon, protected from most of Chloe’s blast by his thick plate armor and the soldiers between them, grabbed the nearest spear and hurled it.
Justin broke from between the soldiers beside Sammy.
He tried to reach her, but the spear thrown by the giant was faster.
Sammy felt it tear through her left breast and out her back the moment Justin grabbed her.
A simple thought crossed Sammy’s mind in the sudden, immense pain.
Maybe the reason the sprites could not see me in the future was because I was not there.
She apologized to Justin and Lemi in her heart and prayed that she would be able to see them together with Chloe when they shortly followed her to the afterlife, if such a place even existed at all.
Ceil watched Chloe fall into the fissure in a blaze and the giant impale Sammy with a single powerfully thrown spear.
“No!
No!
Not again…”
The tears that Ceil constantly fought every day to hold back flowed from her eyes and blew away in the overpowering wind.
First it was the night of the assassinations in the Amelian palace.
Next it was the attack on the Gallanvale.
Now during the fall of Revlan, it happened again.
“I do not want to be the only one who survives,” she cried as the rapid ascent lightened her head until she passed out.

Chapter 23
“The Survivors”
Flowers of purple and blue, red and orange, and a myriad of other colors floated through the air on a soft breeze carried by gentle songs of loving comfort.
The petals drew pictures of animals and scenery in the sky like a stage play orchestrated by Mother Nature.

The terrified cries of the children slowly ceased, but the confusion and fear in a child’s mind was often difficult to abate, especially when their cries were propagated by many other children who were too scared not to follow along with the chorus.

The worst of the children were cradled atop warm wind that rocked them like a loving mother, and the few of them with keen senses beyond their years recovered quickly after discovering that they were not alone in this idyllic forest garden.
There were tiny people at play moving the flowers and singing the songs.
They wiped the tears from the children’s faces and kissed their cheeks and foreheads.
They brought sweet fruit and mild nectar for the children to eat and drink.
None of the children knew how they got here, but they were protected.
“Thank you,” one boy said to the tiny silhouette of a man who handed him a small cup of warm nectar.
“My, how polite.
You are welcome, young one,” the Arkhon replied.
“You should put your wings away before they tire you.
You will not need to flee from here.
You are safe.”
“Thank you,” the boy said again, dispersing his translucent feathered wings.
The Arkhon tousled the fairy boy’s bangs and drifted off towards what had once been Ceil’s hut.
Now a small village spread before him with plentiful rooms and beds for the 308 children rescued from Revlan.
It rose almost instantly after all the sprites of Fiorrae learned of Sammy’s proposal, that they would receive the orphans.
To them it was a festival, one that would continue for years as they watched the children grow, become lovers, and then start families with children of their own.

“What if Gyea gets wind of this,” Ephora asked, a sprite the Arkhon had tasked with monitoring Sammy in his place, one that he had been with on Whinhlem from the beginning while many others came and went.
“She cannot be angry at us for it.”
“Did she not summon you because she suspected that we are taking action without her knowledge?”
“That was certainly part of it,” the Arkhon laughed.
“That is why I requested the speaker on Earth to send those three here instead of us bringing them.
Interference from other worlds is much harder to detect, and Kalya is far more lenient despite her temper.
In any case, Gyea is the one who gave us permission to use her world as a sanctuary.
We can live as one of the races but cannot interfere with the progress of her world.
I say taking care of children is well within our freedoms.”
“Elf and fairy biology is not accustomed to Fiorrae.
Have you considered what effect raising children in such a ven-rich environment might have on them?
You exiled Ceil for that very reason, did you not?”
“I exiled her because it was her time, but I do not deny the harm our land might have caused her if she stayed too long.
Young children are different.
They are growing, and their bodies are adaptable.
They should be fine so long as we monitor them.
Looking at everyone else, you might be the only one worried on that point.
Now that the village is finished, I think we should begin the discussion.”
“Discussion?”
“Of what title to bestow upon Sammy,” the Arkhon exclaimed with an aerial cartwheel.
The nearby Sprites who heard the Arkhon’s announcement gathered in anticipation, and word quickly spread to those who were not comforting the children.
Soon a commotion was rising in the new village just as loud as the children in the nearby flowered grove.
“What good would giving her a title do now?” Ephora asked.
“To show respect?
I did promise to give her a reward if she shook things up a bit.”
“You did what?!”
Ephora grew wide-eyed with disbelief.
“Sammy’s quick thinking did set the events mostly back on course.
Ceil will supplicate Bydrofe as originally foreseen,” the Arkhon continued, ignoring his partner’s outburst.
“Being the speaker on Whinhlem does not give you the authority to act without consulting the rest of us.
Your invisible girl has already caused enough trouble.
The kissiae, and especially Keeya, were not supposed to be part of this, and we are still scrambling to see how much her involvement will change the course of events.”
“Sammy being unseen in our foresight is the most important reason that she deserves a title.
There is no telling how far her ripple of distortion will continue to spread.
Keeya may only be the beginning.”
The face glaring at the Arkhon froze in shock, and Ephora immediately vanished, returning to Revlan.
“Now, any ideas for Sammy’s title,” the Arkhon asked, turning to the excited gathering.

* * *
“Evacuate Her Highness’s companions quickly!
Take them to the Melians!”
Swift hands pushed Justin through the crowd of soldiers fast enough to nearly lift his heavy feet off the fractured streets.
Arrows and bolts of magic flew overhead as the battle that had halted for one final attempt to negotiate surrender continued with even greater ferocity.
“Careful with her,” Justin screamed not caring that no one could understand him.
The soldiers passed Sammy beside him with her blood draining quickly along the wood protruding from her back.
He knew it but could not accept it.
The spear had been instantly fatal, and life magic could not raise the dead.
He cursed himself, wishing it had been him.
He controlled time.
His time magic had saved Sammy once before.
He caught a bullet for her.
Why now could he not catch a spear?
The answer was simple: he had noticed too late.
Justin could willfully slow time now.
He had when Jethro tried to shoot Sammy and again when Byurk tried to impale Ceil during the meeting of commanders.
But this time, his eyes were on Ceil flying into the sky in Coby’s talons, not on the enemy or Sammy.
Protecting Sammy was his duty, and he failed.
A Mountain Elf retrieved Sammy and ran with her to the southern wall of the inner district near Dharin’s estate.
Justin fought to keep pace with Lemi’s help.
Kiri flew in from overhead and called the two Melians from the garden.
Tae aided Tyree as she hopped as fast as she could on her single leg to meet them at the gate.
The Mountain Elf held Sammy before Tyree, not letting the spear touch the ground.
Justin arrived just as Tyree placed her hand on Sammy’s forehead.
Her head shook slowly, and Justin collapsed to his knees barely able to voice his sorrow due to the shortness of his breath.
“Do something,” he wheezed.
“Do anything.”
His lip quivered as he looked up at Tyree with tears streaming from his eyes.
“Please,” he begged in Elven.
“Help, please.”
Tyree knelt in front of Justin.
“Her heart is destroyed, carved away by the spear.
I can heal, but I cannot regrow a lost organ.
Not even a kissiae can perform such a miracle.”
Justin did not need to understand Elven to know that Tyree could not help Sammy.
A warm wind enveloped the walkway, and Ephora appeared above Sammy.
Justin’s heart skipped at the slight feeling of hope the new appearance brought.
“Can you save her?” he nearly screamed.
Ephora looked down at Justin with calm eyes.
The spear flew out of Sammy’s chest as if yanked by an invisible hand and dropped to the ground.
No blood poured from the wound, having been stemmed by Tyree just moments before.
She flitted down and placed her tiny hand on Sammy’s forehead.
A small complacent sigh escaped her lips.
Justin’s chest warmed, his hope growing stronger.
“After what the Arkhon said, I had almost thought she survived.”
Justin’s hope shattered, and his heart broke with it.
Her words sounded as if she was glad Sammy died.
“Can you save her,” he asked again.
“I will not.
Her death is beneficial.”
Justin sprung to his feet and shouted at Ephora, his face no more than a few inches from her.
“What do you mean beneficial?!”
Immediately Justin was forced back to the ground by an immense weight that made his joints pop.
His head grew faint.
Tyree and the other Melians quickly bowed down before the sprite in fear.
The Mountain Elf knelt on one knee, still taking care not to jostle the body in his arms.
The power of the sprites was feared by all races of elfkind.
Only Kiri remained standing.
“Sammy’s actions have already endangered all our preparations.
Because of her, the necessary events preceding the calamity would have fallen into chaos leading to destruction far worse than you can imagine.
Her actions in saving Ceil have just barely set events back on course.
Because of Sammy, you all would have died and may yet die here in Revlan, so be grateful that you still breathe, Master of Time.
Instead of mourning her loss, escape the city quickly.
You and the Aspect of Destruction are still vital in what is to come.”
The weight bearing down on Justin lifted.
He looked up at Ephora with remorseful eyes, begging for any hope this powerful being could give him.
“Is there anything I can do with my time magic?
If… if I get better at it, can I go back and save her?”
Ephora met his gaze, and for a moment her eyes grew apologetic.
She shook her head and flew over to Sammy, sitting on her forehead and caressing her gently.
“Time is a constant stream.
You can speed it up to incredible lengths or slow it down enough to be imperceptible, but you cannot stop it, and you cannot reverse its course.
Such is unnatural.
To try is taboo, and you will be punished by natural consequence.
Sammy is gone,” she said, this time in a comforting tone.
“Her heart is damaged beyond repair.”
“What about a heart transplant,” Justin asked in desperation.
He would not, could not give up on Sammy.
“Life magic can do that, right?
Earth can do it without life magic.
I have seen someone’s side carved out heal like new.
It should be easy for you.”
“Whose heart would you use,” Ephora replied promptly.
“You are the only human from Earth here, and you are incompatible.
Even if you were, you are needed alive.
Sammy saved Ceil at the cost of her life.
Ceil has fled north.
Join her and protect her in Sammy’s stead.
That is what Sammy would want.”
Ephora turned to Kiri.
“Take Justin from Revlan by force if necessary and pursue Ceil.
She is headed for the wilderlands.
Quickly, before the battle reaches you or Ceil is lost.”
Kiri bowed her head.
“As you wish.”
Justin watched Sammy’s body vanish from the Mountain Elf’s arms.
If her body remained in Revlan, Ephora knew Justin would stay.
She apologized to his dead eyes one final time before leaving, not wanting to hear his wailing cries that would soon follow.

* * *
“Get away from me!” A terrified fairy drove his knife into the abdomen of a dark-skinned dryad as she knelt over him to treat his arm crushed by the rubble of the crumbling wall.
Her life sap slowly leaked from the wound onto the blade and hand that gripped it with fear and ire, but she did not grow angry.
“Sorry,” she said with remorseful eyes.
Her apology was not for the dryads’ betrayal of their former ally but for the severity of the damage to the fairy’s arm.
It could not be healed.
It would need to be amputated.
She cut the circulation to the arm to prevent the rot of his dead flesh from spreading and stood to find a sword, letting the blade slide out of her smooth skin.
Not a moment later, her wound sealed shut.
“Ignore him,” a faint voice spoke.
“I need help.”
The dryad looked to her side down the pile of stone that had once been part of Revlan’s eastern wall and saw a Forest Elf with a spear protruding from his side.
She rushed down the rubble, nearly tripping over a loose stone, and knelt beside him.
The spear belonged to Revlan, not Tolmyur or the dryads.
He was not attacked from behind.
He must have fallen from the wall that even now leaned over the rubble, only held back from full collapse by the trees gripping it with their branches on the far side.
“It’s stuck in the rubble.
I cannot move.”
She placed her hand on the haft.
The spears were crafted fresh from the nearby forests for the battle.
A little life remained in the wood.
Trivial life magic made the wood brittle just above where it entered his side, and she snapped it off with a swift tug, removing it.
The man hissed out a groan but thanked her and sat up.
“Do not move.
I can only perform emergency treatment.
Most the dryads fled.
There are not enough of us to help all the injured.”
“No, heal me the best you can.
I must return to Lady Chloe.”
The dryad placed her hands over both the entry and exit wound.
“That would deprive many others of treatment that could save their life.”
Benab grabbed the dryad’s arm.
“I am not being selfish.
I am the sole surviving guard of Her Highness Empress Ceil’s companion, Lady Chloe Hearn.
She was evacuated to the inner city when the kissiae attacked our tower shortly before the vines appeared.
I can hear the battle raging in the city.
The other soldiers would agree.
I must go to her!”
“Do it,” ordered a stout fairy slouched in the rubble only a few feet away.
His hands dug in and pulled out a thin Tolmyurin sword nearly his height in length.
He needed both hands to stable it in his grip.
“I will join you.
We will gather all who are able on our way to the inner city.
We must drive out the Tolmyur filth and protect her Highness and her companions.”
The dryad obeyed with reluctance.
“Your wound should not hinder you now, but know that it is not fully healed.”
“That is enough.
You have my thanks.”
Benab jumped down the rubble and ran beside the fairy, signaling all who were able to follow.
Entering the city was simple.
The massive vines had broken through the large wall with ease sending large sections cascading into the sunken city.
Benab did not want to think about how many were crushed under the rubble.
The city was packed to bursting with almost no room to walk.
There would have been little room to flee.
He ignored the injured and pleading, only calling to those who were healthy to join him.

* * *
The roar of battle between the soldiers of Tolmyur and the final fairy resistance of Revlan echoed down the deep fissure becoming no more than unrecognizable noise buzzing in Thanysa’s ears.
The flashes of light from the fire magic cast over the fissure between opposing forces were brief and insufficient to fully break the darkness.
There had been light for a moment when a flaming body fell into the earthen cavity at the beginning of the battle, but that fire had been extinguished.
Thanysa could not let it burn.
By chance she had recognized the form of a familiar woman falling in flames and pulverized the cliff-side into fine powder with interspersed pockets of air underneath to cushion the body.
The body rolled down the powder as the pockets collapsed until it slid into the muddy and frigid water that slowly filled the bottom of the fissure from the underground streams.
Hot steam filled the crevice and soaked Thanysa’s leather armor with both water and sweat.
Most of the other soldiers who fell with Thanysa when she destroyed the bridge across the fissure died from the fall.
The only other survivor was an earth mage, a human soldier that cursed her before she beheaded him.
“You will rot in this grave with us, troll.”
Thanysa pulled the steaming body from the mud and laid her beside the beheaded soldier.
The young woman, Lady Chloe, had the luck of the gods.

Thanysa and that soldier had survived the fall due to their reinforcement magic, but Chloe would have surely died like the others if Thanysa had not tripped back to avoid the stone spike the soldier conjured below her feet as she beheaded him.
She never would have remained on her back exhausted from the fall and the earth ven conversion required to save her from its impact.
She never would have stared at the approaching flame and noticed who it was that burned.
Twice now Thanysa had seen Chloe fall victim to the power of her own flame.
Fire mages are skilled a manipulating heat, their body heat being the source of their power and the fuel for ven conversion.
Thanysa was not a fire mage, but about a fourth of all Mountain Elves were, the rest being earth mages.
Before any child is taught to conjure their first flame, they are first taught to regulate their body heat.
Converting fire ven naturally heats the body, and if that heat is not controlled, it could harm the user.
The rare few known as flame-skins were highly resistant to the increase of their body heat, enabling them to endure temperatures high enough to burn others on contact without conjuring a flame.
Chloe was certainly one of these rare few among fire mages, but even she was unable to fully resist the strength of her own flame.
She was powerful, but that power came at a price.
Thanysa shielded her face from another body splashing into the ever-rising mud.
She needed to rescue Chloe from the fissure.
The mud eroded the loose soil, filling the floor of the fissure and slowly burying the dead bodies that continued to fall from the conflict above.
Chloe was half submerged in the frigid mud again, but there was no more steam.
Her body was cold enough to carry now.
The issue was her unnatural weight.
Thanysa could never hope to climb the deep fissure carrying one who weighed twice her.
She did not have enough ven remaining to lift them to the surface with earth magic.
She could only follow the fissure wherever it led, praying to her ancestors that the eroding earthen walls would not collapse around her.
The fissure carved through the central district of the city, barely missing the Temple of the Gods as it meandered eastward.
The thick mud rose slowly, at first up to Thanysa’s ankles but now to her knees.

Any attempt to harden the earth beneath her to improve her footing or raise her above the mud momentarily gained her no more than a few inches of height until the heavy earth sank down just as deep as or deeper than before.
The combined weight of Chloe and her was too heavy for the soft mud.
Thanysa could only harden the walls of earth beside her to prevent them from eroding away and thickening the rising mud.
At the same time, she could not carve away at the walls to help fill the crevice with earth allowing her to walk on dry soil without fear of the loosening soil cascading down and burying them alive.
“Ancestors help us,” Thanysa groaned.
The fissure bent to the right where one of the massive vines that dug deep into the fissure wedged overhead as if holding the fissure open.
It was far too high to reach, and its shadow blocked what little light filtered from the surface.
Mountain Elves could see well in the dark, but only if there was at least some faint light.
Here there was none, only a dark muddy passageway underneath the massive vine.
Thanysa continued with Chloe on her back, the frigid mud now up to her thighs.
Deep into the dark, Thanysa bumped her head.
The vine dipped low, and she feared that it would lower further giving her no passage out.
She conjured a blade and struck the vine.
It was hard and wooden.
She would be unable to carve through it, and she certainly could not climb it.
The mud now rose past her waist.
She knelt down, chest-deep into the mud and continued onward with one hand grasping Chloe’s arms across her chest and the other raised to touch the vine to guide her.
The mud deepened and the vine lowered still.
Now only their heads remained above the thick mud, each movement agonizing under the pressure.
She could feel Chloe growing hot on her back.
When in danger, the body of those with a strong connection to their ven converts its ven to its dominant element to aid survival.
If Chloe grew too hot, Thanysa would be unable to carry her.
At least the mud was regulating much of the heat, but her back stung.
Should I turn back?
Thanysa realized that if she continued any further, they would be in danger.
Perhaps the vine reached the bottom of the fissure and there was no passage.
The mud was still rising.
If she turned back, it would rise far above her head before she could travel to the far side of the central district to exit on the lower levels of the city, if it even reached that far.
A vine might even impede her passage there as well.
She dug her hand into the earthen wall to sense the structure further east down the fissure.
If there was no exit, if the vine dug down into the soil, they would not be able to escape, at least not together.
If Thanysa wanted to live and be of help to those still fighting above, she would have to leave Chloe here, condemning her to death.
Thanysa could not sense too far through the soil.
Her proficiency in earth magic was the same as her mother--conjuration, not manipulation, although she could employ both--so her ability to feel the structure of the earth was limited.
The soil and rock hugged the massive vine on the sides.
She could not pass beside it.
The mud was thick and deep beneath, but not solid.
Passage under was possible.
But how far?
She was not a life mage.
She could not sense if the vine rose at any point or how long she would need to remain submerged in the mud.
The only hope she felt was that the walls of the fissure did not hold strong the shape of the vine further down.
Perhaps the fissure grew wider or the vine rose.
Or perhaps the mud was deeper there, making sensing the shape of the earth difficult.
Risk diving into the mud, or abandon Chloe and climb to safety on her own.
Those were her choices.

* * *
Benab led his rallied soldiers down to the second tier of the city.
The civilians desperately trying to unbury their friends, family, and anyone they could find quickly moved out of their way.

The bottom tier of the city was flooding with mud, but those below the bridges and walkways continued their desperate rescues until the mud grew too high for fairies, forcing many to flee to the second tier.
“Do you see a way up,” Benab called to a fairy flying above.
Its wings were dim, showing the exhaustion of the small figure.
“We could possibly climb the section of the central district that broke off,” a High Elf suggested.
“Impossible,” the flying fairy called back from above.
“The fissure at the top is too wide.”
Benab looked behind him at the forty or so soldiers.
There were only six High Elves, but that might be enough.
“Can we use the vines?
Who of you can use dryadic magic?”
One of the High Elves looked up the collapsed and crumbling section of the central district.
A vine slithered from the outer wall down the tiers to the bottom tier of the city before entering where the fissure extended through the collapsed district.
Further in the distance it protruded from the top near the Temple of the Gods.
They could enter atop the vine from the fissure and continue along it until the vine rose.
A life mage would not need to manipulate the vine, only grow holds for everyone to climb.
“I can,” the High Elf called.
“As can I,” spoke another.
“And I,” the stout fairy carrying the Tolmyurin blade added.
Benab was not expecting a fairy to be proficient in dryadic magic.
“Shey, fly back and recruit one of the dryads if possible,” ordered the fairy commander, and their sole flying fairy took off for the outer walls.
“We have no time to waste.
We will climb the vines.”
Benab ran ahead of the group along the outer walk of the second tier.
The bottom tier of the city was another thirty yards below and filling with water.
The collapsed central district that spilled into the bottom tier muddied it, making it difficult to gauge the depth.
The vine entered the fissure from the bottom tier, and it appeared safer to climb atop it using the rubble there than descend onto it from the second tier.
“Smoke?
No, steam?” Benab spoke, quizzically.
Below the vine, mud bubbled up releasing steam.
“Are there geothermal veins below this city,” he asked to those close behind him.
“None.
You would need to go far west of Fiorrae or far north into the wilderlands to encounter any hot springs or geysers.”
Benab hastened down the long steps to the first tier and the base of the vine, ready to climb.
The bubbling mud about his waist was hot.
He stopped with his hand rested on the vine.
Those behind him rushed past, climbing the rubble and crumbled stone.
A body surfaced from the boiling mud.
The heat radiating from it stung Benab’s legs.
The woman was caked with so much mud that her form was nearly unrecognizable.
A suspicion crept into his mind that he could not ignore.
He pulled the heavy body to himself and out of the mud, ignoring the sting.
He once felt heat far worse than now, causing the burn scars all over his body.
When he wiped the woman’s face he found his suspicions were true.
“By the gods!
Lady Chloe!
Life mages, water mages, wind mages!
Hurry!”
Benab was about to carry Chloe to the broken steps up to the second tier when a thought came to him.
Chloe was unconscious, but something pushed her from beneath the vine.
She would not have been able to do so herself.
“Hold her.”
He passed Chloe off to one of the High Elves and dove into the now still mud beneath the vine.
He dug down wondering if his intuition had been wrong.
The mud was thick, and his hands could feel little, until there was a hand, then an arm.
He pulled but he could not loosen it.
He rose for air.
“I need help!”
Two fairies submerged with him.
The mud cleared from the water magic of one while the other helped him grip the arm.
The flow of water helped loosen the body, and Benab pulled her to the surface.
It was a Mountain Elf.
The skin of her face and arms was scalded, and like Chloe, she was not breathing.
“Thanysa,” the fairy commander remarked.
“What chaos led these two to be buried under the vines?
Life mages unable to use dryadic magic, remain here.
The rest of you, follow me up the vine!”
A wind mage, water mage, and four life mages remained behind with Benab.
They carried Chloe and Thanysa to the steps and laid them on the stone, quickly stripping off their chest armor.
“Their lungs are filled with mud,” the High Elf explained.
“Lady Chloe first,” Benab ordered.
The fairy water mage flushed Chloe’s mouth out and forced more water into her lungs.
He then expelled it to purge the mud.
After repeating three more times, he swapped with the wind mage who forced air into her lungs while the High Elf placed his hand atop her left breast to work her heart.
Once Thanysa’s lungs were purged, the same wind mage placed his hand over her mouth.
A second High Elf worked to beat life into her heart.
The remaining two life mages aided blood circulation and repaired the lung damage to improve breathing.
“Please…” Benab begged the gods with his eyes gripped shut.
He did not want to lose Chloe.
She was his charge, and he was unable to save her when she was attacked by the kissiae or join her in the fight in the central district.
He promised to protect her, and here she was again drinking the waters of Ithsa, the putrid river of death.
She had been on its shores once before in Melia, beside him, tasting of the bitter water.
He was bound to her.
Now he feared she drank her fill, ready to collapse into Ithsa to be carried away in its current.
A cough.
Benab opened his eyes to see Thanysa spit out browned water and reel, but her eyes did not open, too weak to fully wake, but she was alive.
His heart beat in anticipation.
Surely Chloe would wake next.
“I brought a dryad,” the flying fairy called from above.
The same dark-skinned dryad who had helped Benab clung to the arms of the fairy who was just barely managing to keep flight.
“Here, quickly,” Benab waved.
The dryad let go of the fairy and fell five yards to land gracefully on the steps.
She immediately turned her attention to Thanysa.
Benab grabbed her arm and wrenched it towards Chloe.
“Her first,” he ordered.
The dryad shook her head.
“She is lost.
Surely the High Elves here have realized this already.”
“Yet still they try.
Help her.”
“I cannot raise the dead,” the dryad spoke, showing no emotion.
“Cannot or will not?
She has not been dead for long.
I know some of your tribes do not aid what has died, but Forest Elves have been resuscitating the recent dead for millennia.
It is possible.
Help her!”
“To try would be a waste.
There are others in need of my assistance who are dying as we speak.”
Benab drew the blade of the High Elf tending to Thanysa beside him.
“Lady Chloe is a companion of Her Highness, Empress Ceil, and a hero to us all.
I will behead you where you stand if you refuse again, traitor of the empire!”
The dryad looked up at Benab with only pity in her eyes.

* * *
“I cannot clear this gap,” the Mountain Elf, Hethyro, said to Kiri.
He had a fire affinity, not earth.
He had no way to create a bridge or even launch himself over the fifty-yard crevice between the crumbling road where they stood and the collapsed section of the central district.
“Your wings are the only way.”
He set Justin down on the cobblestone road.
Justin had not moved or spoken since Ephora informed him that Sammy was dead and would not be saved.
Tears slowly built and ran down his cheeks, but he did not cry out his grief.
His heart was broken and his voice broken with it.
Kiri hooked her arms under his shoulders and grew large feathered wings that shone with a translucent glow.
Her feet kicked off with a light flap, and she struggled to hold him.
Her elevation decreased despite her efforts to stay airborne, but it was enough.
The steeply sloped road of the far side was much lower in elevation.
She reached it with a few feet to spare.
She set him down against a metal fence fastened into the ground so that he would not slide and returned for Lemi, Tyree, and Tae, the three Melians.
“You next,” she said to Hethyro.
“Can you carry me?”
“Perhaps without your armor.”
Hethyro removed his plate armor and the leather beneath.
Wearing no more than his trousers, he appeared to shrink by a third his original size.
He gripped Kiri’s arms and kicked off as far as he could.
He was heavier than Justin by about twice.
Her approach was slow, and he barely had enough reach to grab the ledge above him on the other side.
Together they descended the crumbling city.
Buildings had collapsed and slid down the side.
The curtain wall was nonexistent.
The entire southeastern section of the top tier of the city was buried beneath, and the rubble ran into the second tier, leveling buildings and nearly running off the edge into the bottom tier.
Their descent ended atop a single-story structure beside a broken stairway to the flooding bottom tier of the city.
There atop the structure they saw the moment a Forest Elf beheaded a dryad.
Kiri knew him.
“Benab!”
Benab looked up and saw Kiri, Hethyro carrying Justin, and three more Dryads.
“Kiri,” he screamed, “Chloe needs dryad life magic! Quick!”
Lemi jumped off the building and hopped down the steps.
She froze before Chloe.
Like the dryad before, Lemi’s life magic told her that Chloe was dead.
“Tyree, you are the only one who can help her,” Lemi shouted as she ran to the base of the building.
Tae slowly positioned Tyree to fall into Lemi’s arms.
Lemi collapsed back from the impact, but quickly recovered and led Tyree to Chloe with the help of one of the High Elves.
“Impossible.
I saw her fall into the fissure,” Kiri gasped.
She landed nearby and dispersed her wings.
“Thanysa fell too.
Did she…”
“Yes.
I am certain Thanysa saved Chloe,” Benab explained.
“She is well and will live, but Chloe--”
“Dead,” Tyree said flatly.
“I will do what I can, but I make no promise.”
Justin arrived, hanging over Hethyro’s shoulder.
He saw Chloe motionless and caked in mud on the steps, not breathing.
He struggled and slid off Hethyro, nearly tripping down the steps.
He did not dare draw too near.
He could do nothing while he watched Tyree work as the seconds passed with no success.
He wanted to call out to Ephora for help but hesitated.
What if she took Chloe away as she had Sammy?
In his mind he remembered Sammy’s warning to Ceil before Ceil offered herself to the Tolmyur soldiers in exchange for their lives.
She said that they all would die.
Sammy died in front of him.
Chloe was dead in front of him now.
Justin was exhausted, physically, mentally, and emotionally.
His body ached from his anguish.
Justin rose to his feet and walked away down the road to a bridge across the bottom tier before the sight of the death of another of his friends broke his will to move forward.
He failed Eydis and did not know if she was dead or alive.
He failed Sammy.
He failed Chloe.
But, there was another he could still help, another who still lived.
Ephora was correct.
Justin had a mission, and focusing on that could help him ignore the pain that threatened to tear him apart.
He was not seeking redemption for his failures.
He only loathed the thought of losing another.
Lemi called his name from far across the other side of the bridge, but he ignored her.
Next Kiri called his name, but again it fell on deaf ears.
She flew to him as he pushed his way through the frantic crowds of fairies and elves struggling to help the injured.
His feet reached the first step up to the top tier of the city, but a small hand grabbed his shoulder.
“Justin,” she called.
“I am going after Ceil,” he said, knowing well Kiri would not understand him.
Kiri jumped in front of him, her face level with his on the steps above.
“Chloe lives.”
The short phrase was in Elven, but Justin understood.
He turned back to see Lemi waving and jumping excitedly.
“Chloe’s alive,” he repeated as fresh tears fell down his cheeks.
He ran back over the rubble, through the crowd, and across the bridge.
Lemi latched onto his arm and pulled him to the steps.
There Chloe lay, her chest rising and falling with weak breaths.
“We escape the city immediately,” Kiri ordered.
“We can treat Chloe and Thanysa as we travel.
We must pursue Her Highness in the wilderlands.”
Intermission
Screams erupted in the city as people fled in terror.
Husbands were forced to abandon their wives and mothers their children as those of slower pace were consumed before their very eyes.
Vines of variegated ivy crawled over every road, wall, and rooftop as fast as the swiftest feet could fly.
Those ensnared shriveled as their life was sucked from their bodies, but they did not die.
The lifeless thralls attacked those who fled, even former loved ones, as if chasing them out of the walls of the city where the growth stopped.
It began from the palace that was once conquered by the Tolmyur army and spread in all directions as a verdant flood that not even fire could abate, the vines seemingly immune.
Where fire was used, the ivy vines retaliated with water magic or amassed to crush the threat.
Any who used magic became targets, forcing all to flee.
There was no hope, no salvation for the captive city of Amel.
Deep in the palace gardens, now unrecognizable from the immense growth of the foliage and the thick ivy that coated every surface, was a coven of thirty-one kissiae, the last of their kind.
All of them but one trembled at the sight of the greatest among them, Keeya, despite her outwardly calm demeanor.

Keeya sat Emer, who was unaffected by the drain of her ivy hair deeply rooted in the ground around them, in the center of the garden and used his arm to hold and caress the sole kissiae child who was left alone and afraid in Elos.
The child snuggled up to the warm body as if it was Keeya’s and basked in the attention.
“I am not angry at you,” Keeya said to those who cowered around her.
Her voice that had sounded as a child’s now spoke clearly.
The long, long ages of pain and mental anguish that caused her mind to regress had reverted, and her mind regained its vibrancy.
Although her ever-youthful appearance had not changed, the drastic increase in the pressure of her very presence bore down on her fellow kissiae.
She was different now than before.
Keeya was no longer just a dryad and no longer just a kissiae.
“I am not angry at you,” Keeya repeated.
“I am angry at myself.”
The young child turned in Emer’s lap to look up into Keeya’s eyes as if asking why.
“I was one of the first of the kissiae at a time in ages past where dryads were far longer lived than they are now.
In all my many years I never bore a single child, not one daughter to call my own.
Hamadryads cannot bear children, so when my time came, I resisted.
I fought it through torment until I learned how to stop my roots from growing, but the pain never left.
Life became my obsession.
I longed for the day I would mother a child that I could hold in my arms as I hold you now.”
Keeya embraced the young girl, making her giggle.
“I avoided war.
I avoided conflict.
When the races grew fearful of the kissiae, I basked in the safety that fear provided.
When they began to hunt us, I hid, abandoning my kind as our numbers dwindled and the races poached us for our toxins.
I hate conflict.
I hate fighting.
I want to create life, not end it!”
Keeya gritted her teeth as a tear fell down her cheek.
The kissiae surrounding her cowered once more, but the young child stood in Emer’s lap and wiped away the tear.
“Don’t cry…”
Keeya embraced the child and lifted her to nuzzle their cheeks together.
“While I hid, the hunting continued until there were only eight of us left.
Kanazee was one of them, only an infant at the time.”
Kanazee hung her head in shame.
As one of the few survivors, she understood that she, more than anyone in Keeya’s absence, should have prioritized the survival of her kind and not sent them into battle.

But the threat of Gyea’s retribution was too dangerous to ignore, its scars forever marking the continent, so even now, she did not regret her decision, only that she failed to kill the trespassers before Keeya intervened.
“The Amelian Empire offered us sanctuary, and I sided with Tolmyur to preserve it without conflict when the empire fell, but now I know that I cannot even trust you to save each other.”
The kissiae bowed to the ground in apology and supplication for mercy, but Keeya only smiled lovingly.
“All my life I have yearned for a daughter, but as of today, that is no longer possible.
You are now my daughters, and your daughters will be my daughters.
I will hide no longer.
I will avoid conflict no longer.
To protect my children, I will make the entire world that has wronged us my enemy.
Even if it means angering the gods, I will protect my children.”
